description:
One of my friends was desperate to try cassoulet for the first time and, after asking around a bit, decided to make the short trip to Glen Park to try Le P'tit Laurent. There were three people in our group, and we got to the restaurant at just the right time and only waited around 5-10 minutes to be seated. 

We ordered several plates to share: escargots, tartine de brie, cassoulet, scallops, and one of the fixed price neighborhood menus (the starter was a melon-prosciutto salad; the entree was a delicious French take on shepherd's pie; dessert was profiteroles). Everything was absolutely amazing! I would absolutely return and re-order any of the items we tried, but there were a ton of other things on the menu I'd love to taste as well. 

Service was friendly and we never felt rushed. This restaurant is definitely worth the short drive we took.
author: Sarah B.

description:
I went with my date to celebrate my birthday.  On a Saturday night, I was glad we had reservations for 6:30 PM, it is a very popular place.  It is cozy, the staff is excellent and friendly.

We started with the cheese plate and wine.  It was delicious!

I had the rack of lamb with green beans and mash, my date had the night's special filet mignon.  While mine was lovely and I enjoyed everything about it, my date's filet had too many parts that were chewy, too much gristle.  For the price, just not okay, thus 4 stars not 5.  It wasn't until I was done that I noticed the pile of steak bits on his plate when he was done.  We had been engaged in eating and conversation.  I would have sent it back when 2 bits were unedible but he was hungry and just wanted his dinner.

I had lemon sorbet with vodka for dessert.  Light and WOW!
author: Robin P.

description:
This restaurant is a hidden gem in Glen Park! The staff were incredibly helpful with suggestions on what to order and had great taste that helped us discover my new favorite drink that paired well with our food! As someone who only occasionally eats french cuisine, having the wait staff there made our experience.

The food was excellent! We ordered a Lillet Blanc to drink (Waiter's suggestion), the baked brie, escargot, steak & fries & the yogurt fruit dessert that resembled a nougat. 

The food was delicious except for the steak & fries. It was too tough and the flavor wasn't there.. Will definitely go again and try a different item like the sea bass!

I still think of the baked brie and that nougat dessert!!! *Drools*
author: Brittani C.

description:
We came here on a Sunday evening around 6pm and there were plenty of room.  We even found parking just outside.  This is a bistro like ambience with a long counter at the bar. The walls are decorated with old French signs and pictures.
Our food was really delicious and it did not disappoint.  Only one dish was not what I expected.  The Hachis Parment $22, was kinda dry for me.  With minced meat topped with mash and cheese rather like a gratin. I would have preferred to have gravy in the meat for a juicier and hearty meal.  However, the rest of the dishes were really delicious.  My favorites are the onion soup $10, chicken coq au vin $29 and the fois gras $16.  Great service and attention.  They also have a 3 course set $31 available Mon - Thurs.  Well worth try if you are in the neighborhood.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
This family owned french restaurant is a gem hidden in a lesser-known but adorable neighborhood of Glen Park, San francisco. The servers here are very friendly and comical. I had a wonderful dinner here with 2 friends. I have my dairy allergy so it was a bit difficult to enjoy french cuisine, but they gave me a couple of light options with very minimal butter. 

If you don't have an allergy to butter (and other milk products) like me, definitely make an effort to stop by here. You won't be disappointed :)
author: Annie Z.

description: Great food and dining vibe, the waitress and waiters are very very friendly that they come check with us whenever we need anything, wine paring was great every time. Definitely my favorite French restaurant with decent price!
author: Hannah T.

description: What a cool find. I just walked out of the BART station and stumbled into this wonderful French bistro. Greeted instantly with a quick hello "in French"and a invitation to sit at the bar. I had a delicious glass of red wine and Bree melted over a baguette and a delicious salad with sliced pears in it A fantastic find and memorable experience.I can't wait to visit again!
author: Tim J.

description:
I love this place. So cozy and romantic
 Our go to for any special occasion for the last 3 years. I love the escargot and the absinthe.  Also the host and service are lovely friendly people.
author: Sasha K.

description:
Staff was super nice and attentive. Our waiter was Irish and very polite. The bread was good. The butter was from the fridge clearly. It was a nice cold chunk in a light metal dish. The lamb chops was quite rare for medium well done. I had to switch my dish to give it to my husband. The mashed potatoes was nice but nothing special. The sauce was very dark brown, as if it came canned already. The duck dish was a complete fail. It was a ducks leg and spam like meat chunks in a bowl of white bean soup. That costs you $37. I could buy 2 whole roasted ducks for that price! They cooked it like chicken...with carrots. Smh. If this restaurant was in LA, it would not survive. Food critics are very critical there. Not sure why NorCal loves this place. 

Oh they also did not disclose the "CC ask" which a credit card adjustment otherwise known as a credit card fee of $3.99 after we paid $124 plus tip. We had wine and dessert. Créeme brûlée was good and wine was pretty average. You'd think they would not charge you for using a credit card because you are dining there and charging over $10-$15 as an incentive. Nope! It wasn't a party of 15 either. First try here but definitely not memorable to go back just for bread or dessert to be charged $3.99 to use credit.

I enjoyed the ambiance more then the food. The neighborhood was okay. SF has small space and small restaurants. Ambiance and bread doesn't give a client incentive to come back if the price isn't the same quality as the food. Cmon guys $37
author: Tom W.

description: Annual visit and i still think their escargot is my favorite, but i can add in additional their baguette and their chicolate fondant are also my favorite.  The short rib was good except that one was a bit chewy and the other piece is nice and tender.  Service was wonderful as usual.
author: Helen L.

description: I was there last Thursday, was supposed to be a date. But, my date decided to stand me up. I figured, what the hell, went ahead and treated myself to dinner. As usual, the food was excellent as well as the service. Since I was on a roll, I had three glasses of Lillet as well... un verre de rouge suivi de deux verres de blanc. Great place, highly recommend going there.
author: John H.

description: Wonderful neighborhood French restaurant. Excellent food with an old world charm. A truly memorable experience.
author: Rich H.

description: Great neighborhood cozy French place. Romantic lighting at night & great for dates! Also cool for enjoying a good meal at the bar. On a cold and foggy Glen Park night, there's nothing like their classic French Onion Soup. Superb! Their chocolate fondant is to die for...excellent Montpelier red too! On weekdays I go for the neighborhood Prix fix! Today a most delicious vegetable cream soup, steak with frites and tarte tartin for $31. Pleasant friendly staff and a hard-working redhead bartendress, who doubled up on many other duties! Digest it all with a warm fragrant Calvados and you'll be living la vie en rose!
author: Michael H.

description:
We had a lovely dinner here on a Saturday night!  The food was great, the service was friendly and efficient, and the ambiance was elegant and "very French"!

I started with the French Onion soup and enjoyed it.  My entree, the rack of lamb with ratatouille, was excellent!  It was very flavorful and prepared wonderfully.  My husband had the steak frites, and liked it, though it wasn't outstanding in the way my lamb was.  We shared the pain perdu (French toast with ice cream) for dessert, and it was fantastic!

The service was attentive and polite - we generally felt well taken care of.  The only exception was that they didn't check on us for a while after our entrees arrived, so we actually had to flag them down so my husband could order another glass of wine to accompany his main.

The setting is classy, cozy, warm, and inviting - we quite liked it.

Overall, our meal here was lovely, and we look forward to returning!
author: Barnali D.

description:
Very nice to step off BART and into France. This spot was cozy and quiet when I arrived at 515 and packed soon after. Great French vibe, fabulous waitstaff, and the food was very good. 
App to die for: The baked Brie on toast drizzled with honey / salad. Desert- the chocolate fondant with coconut sorbet. Whoa wow!
author: Jake G.

description: This is my second visit to Le P'tit Laurent. The first was for my birthday dinner a few years ago and my most vivid memorable dish was the Rabbit Normandy. I returned tonight and ordered the Rabbit Normandy and it was as memorable as it tasted years ago. Everything about this place is amazing from the service to the food.
author: Ellen T.

description:
Le P'tit Laurent is an authentic French restaurant, if French-speaking staff and lots of French-speaking customers are any indication. The food and the venue are reminiscent of typical neighborhood bistros in residential parts of Paris. While it might not be haute cuisine, it's all dependable, well-executed stuff, and the best part is the very reasonable pricing.

The "neighborhood menu" offered Sunday through Thursday, for example, is a deal by pricey West Bay standards: three courses for just $28. You start with a soup or salad, move on to a meatier entree like ribs or fish, and end with a dessert like pain perdu. All solid, satisfying stuff. Service is efficient and courteous, with the only drawback being the somewhat small space where folks are packed in rather tightly. Nevertheless, you'll be sure to get your money's worth here.

Yet another great find, thanks to Yelp!
author: Vincent L.

description:
3.5 stars

Made reservations for three at 630pm on a Monday evening for a birthday. We were seated immediately and the restaurant wasn't too busy. The ambiance of the place is lovely - has a nice homey feeling with interesting decor. They offer a rotating 3-course neighborhood menu for $29 that consists of a starter (soup or salad), a main, and a dessert. It's a great deal if you like the items that week!

Escargot - seasoning was garlic parsley butter, which was good. I order escargot whenever I see it offered on any menu, so I've had my fair share. This was slightly better than average. 
Tuna tartare - tuna was so stringy! It's not nice to be eating a tartare and have to keep on chewing and chewing. So while the seasoning of the fish was good, the quality wasn't. Also didn't enjoy all the ginger pieces in this.
French onion soup (if substituting into the neighborhood menu, add $5) - way too salty, would have been good if not for that 
Smoked salmon with salad - generous portion of smoked salmon, dill cream was nice
Fish bouillabaisse - the stew had a very rich seafood flavor, which was awesome. Came with several big pieces of fish, two big pieces of shrimp, and four mussels. It looked a little small, but it was enough because I had already had several appetizers and bread.
Lamb shank - presentation was good and lamb itself was cooked well. The green beans that came with it, however, had no flavor and were overcooked. I really dislike it when green beans are that soft. 
Fresh pear tart - looked nice coming out, but taste was mediocre
Vanilla ice cream profiteroles - delicious. Light and airy profiteroles were great with the ice cream. The chocolate sauce on top was slightly bitter and the whole thing just worked well together.

Because the owner knew we were celebrating a birthday, they brought out some ice cream with a candle on top, which was nice. Service was great and the owner and waiter were friendly. Complimentary bread comes out nice and warm. We had a good time, but for the price of the meal (~$130), we expected better food taste and quality. I'd still come again if I see something I like on their neighborhood menu (posted online), but probably not otherwise.
author: Nicole M.

description:
This review is for dinner last night. 
Service was outstanding from the host to our waiter who was discreetly attentive and personable. 
The cocktails and wine pours were really small... The port was much better but it was warm... ;(
The foie gras I ordered came without its fruit compote but spinach instead. That was a major let down. Bread was delightful.
Escargots were good. 
The cassoulet was good, except for the cubes in there which felt like what I imagine spam tastes like
My husband was happy with the rabbit. 
The profiterolles were really lacking some whip cream or almonds something...
The ambiance was great, parking was easy, kid friendly with a menu for them.
author: Carpe D.

description: I absolutely adore this incredible secret gem in quaint Glen Park! The owners whip up incredible French cuisine that rivals some of he best bistros in Paris! They pair delicious French wines that go beautifully with their delicious meals. I loved the tomato soup and the fois gras, albeit very rich as expected. C'est un restaurant français magnifique! I'm excited to explore more of the menu, which promises to be incroyable!
author: William H.

description:
Located in one of my favorite villages in San Francisco, this place transported me back to my Summers in the southern French countryside. Set up like a quirky cafe, serving solid staples, I could not believe how authentic the baguettes were crackling as we bit into them greedily after smearing thawed butter onto the slices. They even got stiff and bland when cold--perfect for swabbing up sauce!

The foie in the foie gras terrine were whole lobes and pinkish textured decadence served with balsamic reduction to offset the mind numbing richness.

The hangar steak with fries was dressed in a port (?) reduction that was heady and complex. Fries were perfectly crispy and fluffy and so well seasoned I did not need to add anything to it.

The cassoulet was heavy in the white beans. But... succulent pork cubes, alluring sausage morsels and rich duck confit leg quarter made this dish the headliner of the evening. It was served in a cast iron receptacle that kept the dish a tad too warm for my liking. At the end when the entree cooled, I could taste more of the Herbs de Provence which I adore. Given that there are at least several valid interpretations of cassoulet, this being one, we prefer the example containing chevre and lamb. 

The pain perdu was intriguing. It was like a really dense french toast until you take a swipe at the ice cream and caramel sauce then some kind of wizardry happens in your mouth.

The creme brulee had thick crackle. And the creme was good. But not exceptional. 

The service was old school fabulous. The maitre'd offered to check our coats when he seated us and offered sparkling or regular water. Our table setting was reset each time dishes were cleared and a new basket of bread brought out without request. When the entree was cleared, the table was swept and dessert menus brought out. When I inadvertently ordered a white wine with the meal, the server graciously and gently pointed it out, then proceeded to recommend a wine for our meal.

The Prix Fixe at $28 for 3 courses is a bargain if you want the items featured. Other wise,  the 3 courses would me more like $40-$45 a person.

If I had the items I ordered at the Prix Fixe price, this place would be a no brainer 5 star, and the reservation list even longer certainly. But even though the ala carte menu is a bit pricey, I am thrilled to have an authentic representation of solid French Cafe food this side of the city where I had
author: Lu-Shien T.

description: The best french food in the area! We live right up the hill and it was our 4 year anniversary so we decided to give it a go.  We heard great things about it, but that said I wasn't expecting much. Unlike other restaurants on Chenery St, the place was packed, (definitely make a reservation). We ordered the 3 course pre-fixed meal. To my surprise each course got better and better, and the portions were surprisingly big for French standards. The waitress was authentic from France, and very knowledgeable about the food. We can't wait to go back and try there Escargot and steamed mussels next. Turns out this chef has a following in the bay area and people come from all over to try this little neighborhood find.
author: Kimberly C.

description:
All the wonderful things that have been said about food and service are true. I am giving the 2 stars because of a diconcerting policy the restaurant has inacted.  We have been coming for years but not for a while due to travels.  We went last night celebrate my husband's birthday and after a lovely meal and great service our poor waitress had to embarassingly tell us that, "due to the new $l5.00 minimum wage if we pay by cash our bill would remain as presented but if we used a credit card they would ad the 3.2 percent cc charge."  After we recovered from shock at this announcement we looked to see if we had enough cash, as we do not carry very much.  The bill was hefty and we did not have the cash.  My next thought was to reduced the waitresses tip by 5% to recoup the 3.2%, but she was so wonderful we still gave her the full 20%.  I think many people would consider this and due it. As we left we did speak to owner and told him we thought the request was poor marketing and why not just increase some of the prices. We also said that every 1 person who might bring this to his attention 10 will leave, never come back and tell friends.  He stated that he appreciated our imput but this was an experiment and they were going to see how it played out. We have been to many upscale restaurants since the wage increase and none have inacted such a policy, I have noted some price increase.

It was not the best way to end a lovely meal in a place we have loved. The waitress did give my husband a bottle of wine (Spanish not French)  for his birthday, which was a nice touch.  I hope this experiment ends soon as I am not going to go to ATMs everytime I want to eat there.
author: Sally Z.

description: Missed the brunch menu and realized it was dinner time. Working night shift will do that to you. Haha AMAZING french toast though! Recommended by the server. We'll be back for sure.
author: Keet K.

description: We had a sweet 16th birthday celebration there last Saturday party of 15.  We went with party menus.  Foods were delicious.  Service was fast and excellent.  Highly recommended.
author: Holly K.

description:
Le P'tit Lament is what this restaurant should be called as it was a abysmal from start to finish. The only positive side was the staff whom were kind, attentive and apologetic. 
We ordered the Foie Gras which was a bed of extremely greasy and cold spinach and onions topped with the smallest portion of liver which was bloody, had veins in it and was barely seared. 
The mussels were well cooked, but the sauce was watery and had almost no flavor and was served with the smallest bowl of shoestring french fries. 
So we can say that this was one of the worst meals in a "french bistro" we have ever experienced. We are both knowledgeable cooks and have traveled the world, including France, and never have we seen Foie so abused. 
The only saving grace was the staff...
author: Lisa-Marie S.

description:
I'm torn. Part of me wants to  go 4. so per usual, it's 3.5

It's a really cute place - small and homey feeling, but probably a good idea to make a reservation.  

The staff was friendly, and actually spoke french.

The food, was, well, good? I don't know.  Maybe it's just french food that I have yet to be wowed by in general? You know, it just seemed a lot like meat and vegetables and butter - which are all great things, but not life changing? Isn't french food supposed to be life changing?

The lobster bisque was creamy and definitely tasted like lobster.
The Boeuf Bourguignon was also good - the meat and gravy were both super flavorful
The Le Cassoulet toulousain Maison was underwhelming - mostly tasted like lentils with sausage and then some duck - again, not bad, but no wow!
The lamb in the arret d'agneau braise et harricots vert, sauce au romarin itself was really quite tender and nice, but the whole plate didn't impress that much.  

We got the wine of the month which tasted a lot like wine that someone cares about, but again didn't change my life.  

Not huge portions, but also not tiny. I'd say a little small for the price.  I'd say it's pushing $$$.

Maybe I'm being too harsh - because I did enjoy my dinner - but I'm just not feeling impressed.
author: Sarah C.

description: Delicious food, wonderful atmosphere and great service!  This place is solid all around.  And the bread was phenomenal.  Worth the visit.
author: Sharon M.

description:
It was a getaway on a Monday afternoon evening. I felt like french food for din din, so i found here. 
.
Its noisy and hot so be warned. The bar was cool because the door is open for the breeze. 
.
Dinner is the neighborhood menu, you don't know you ask. Basically 3 course meal, starter either salad or soup, entree, and dessert. Sorry wifey vegan be a challenge. 
.
To start off i got the soup carrot bisque. Super creamy and flavorful! Goes well with bread! Basically use the bread to wipe the bowl clean. 
.
My order of escargot came next. Basically pesto, garlic, onion, and oily goodness to dip bread in! So nummy! 
.
Fish with mussels and shrimp Bouillabaisse with Rouille.
The sauce was amazing! Generous portion of fish! Just amazing by this course i was filled with bread. 
.
Dessert is French toast with Carmel and butterscotch ice cream! Soft gooey caramel sticking to the soft fluff bread with light syrup and then shock it with a cold bite of rich butter scotch ice cream! Pure amazingness! Paired with black strong coffee! Dessert is bon a petit! 
.
Overall sitting at the bar with a cool breeze every so often was a smart idea. Definitely busy and prepare to wait. Dining for one or two people max you be fine. Bathroom was clean and spacious. As well service was great. I left fancy and happy and i will be back and a place to recommend! Thanks for reading and stay classy.
author: Alex T.

description:
Crème Brulee to die for. Seriously; don't skip this or you'll end up regretting it. 

I have a special love for this restaurant since it's not jaw dropping expensive for delicious French cuisine. 

The prix fixe menu is a great deal and they do not skimp on the portions like I've noticed with some other places. I have yet to eat a dish here 

Plus points for consistent top notch service. I've been here a few times now and every single time they manage to impress me. 

For example this last trip they intentionally didn't remove my soup before I was finished sopping up every last drop of umami with their house bread. 

When my fiancé asked them to pack her leftovers she said that they put in extra mashed potatoes since she only had a small amount remaining when we left and noticed that there was a lot more when we got home.  

re-bookmarked this place to come by for brunch. They had me at Bottomless Mimosas 

Highly recommended to get a dessert as I've tried all of them and it's well worth the extra full feeling after the meal.
author: Norris T.

description: Came here on Friday night last week. The place was packed and thankfully we had reservations. It's commonly known as one of the best restaurants in glen park eorthtraveling to the neighborhood to try. We were instantly greeted as we walked in by the staff. The inside was warmly decorated with rustic kitchy French stuff like hats and maps of Paris. We sat down and were instantly greeted by a waiter. We started with the escargot. It was nice and garlicky but a little too oily and over cooked to the point it was quite chewy. I then had the coq au vin. That was fantastic. The chicken was so moist. The sauce was super flavorful and the veggies and chicken had been marinating for hours. My boyfriend got the lamb which was cooked medium rare and again fantastic. If you are looking for good French food in sf, come here.
author: Anne S.

description: This was my favorite Sunday brunch spot!!! So sad they stopped serving brunch on Sunday's! BRING IT BACK.... please
author: Sabrina M.

description:
i really like the bread here, so i ask the nice people if they make it or they get it from somewhere, and they're like we get it from bakers of paris.  then i'm like oh yes, awesome, pretending like i know what that is.  

long story short, i email bakers of paris and be like, hey where can i get your bread because i like it, and they don't respond.  i understand though, they got stuff going on probably.
author: Andy W.

description:
Made a reservation a week in advance for Mother's Day. They do not overbook, however the restaurant is very tiny and packed to the brim with tables. It is very hard to get to the table, and to leave the table. Also, conversations aren't private at all due to the proximity. I can see the restaurant having a quaint, homey feel when it isn't crowded. 

My mom's order of lamb chops was perfect after having it sent back 3 times. Their chef does not understand the normal meaning of well-done. If you enjoy your meat fully cooked, do explicitly state that you would like your dish fully cooked. Our server was great, making sure we were fully satisfied with our dishes. Service is definitely top-notch! My steak and frites was alright. I couldn't taste the flavor of the steak as it was drowned in sauce. The fries were very delicious despite how they looked. 

Parking is terrible. Take Bart or Muni here if possible. Price is quite decent for French cuisine. 3 solid stars as they didn't wow me as other French restaurants have, but not bad either!
author: Kristi T.

description:
Small, quaint restaurant with friendly service and good food. Service was excellent.
We had 
1- Terrine de Foie gras cuit au torchon et toast, which was good, presented well, just needed more than 3 toasts, they did serve us bread so that sufficed. 
2- Lapin facon Normande- Rabbit was over cooked for my taste and bit dry, but the gravy covering it was well done and tasty.
3- Crème Brûlée à la Vanille- I feel this was hastily done, it could have been more flavorful, I could smell vanilla but really couldn't taste in the dessert.

Personally, I think this is a great neighborhood restaurant if you have tasted the food before you can ask the chef to make the modifications to suit your palate, now that I know, next time I will ask for the Rabbit slightly undercooked. 

I would go back and try this place again.
Great wine menu--
author: Sean T.

description: Love everything about this place other than the noise level. At dinner with 2/3 restaurant full it was 75 db. Three of us at a table and we had to shout.
author: Jane M.

description: Adorable location. Tough parking. Tight seating. Great ambiance. I truly enjoyed the food. My cassoulet was lovely and my creme brûlée one of the best that I have eaten. Plan to spend some money and sit and enjoy your food! Attentive service, with many regular customers... great place.
author: Monica T.

description: I've been here twice and both times have been a 5 star experience. The staff is friendly and knowledgeable about  what they have to offer, with both food and drink. The food is amazingly delicious and well prepared. Save room for dessert and get the French toast....it will ruin all desserts for you after you try it. It's the most amazing I've ever eaten. Warning, the restaurant is small so it isn't great for groups bigger than 4 maybr and the wait can be a bit long (so make sure to get a reservation), but it is worth it.
author: Princess D.

description:
Great neighborhood French restaurant.  We had the cassoulet and mussels, both which were cooked well.  However, I felt the mussels had a little too much garlic.

This restaurant gets unbelievably crowded and surprisingly isn't that loud.  

I'd definitely come back.
author: Angelica C.

description: We had a 7:45 reservation through yelp on a Friday night and arrived on time.  There were three other parties waiting for tables.  After fifteen minutes packed in like sardines and minimal acknowledgement from the host, we left.  What a joke!  I can't speak French but I know what a reservation is.  The food might be good.  I'll never know.  The service is a proven stinker however.  My advice if you want to try this place is to bring a tent and pitch it on the sidewalk so you can wait for your "reservation".
author: Hh Y.

description: What an awesome place! The creme brule is fantastic, but so far the other deserts have been so so at best. Every evening except Fridays and Saturdays they have a discounted "neighborhood menu," and during tax season an even more discounted one, both of which are excellent deals.
author: Zaire R.

description: My family and I celebrated my dad's birthday at Le P'tit today, it was the most amazing experience we have never had! They made my dad feel so special! My heart melted when they gave my dad a bottle of wine as a birthday gift. Thank you so much for your good service and wondering good!
author: Emi W.

description: Desperately wanted to like it, but the food just wasn't that good. Very price for very "blah" food.
author: Gus C.

description:
First time here (and definitely not my last!) and was  amazed with the great service and delicious food. Loving the neighborhood prie fixed meal for $29 for 3 awesome home-cooked style meals. 
Asked waiter for suggestions on wine to go with the osso bucco and waiter was nice enough to let us try the Cabernet and Pinot before suggesting the Bordeaux and it worked perfectly. Service was fast and meal started with fresh Parisian baguette with soft butter in side (nice touch). The creamy vegetarian soup and calamari salad were on hit and great start to a great meal. The ossu buco came with mashed potatoes and greens were tender with the rjght amount of sauce. The Cassoulet Toulousain Maison with duck confit, pork and Toulouse sausage were amazing. Finished off with pain Perdue which is a French toast with ice cream was perfectly sized to share with a caramelized toast and coffee ice cream. Omg heaven! We didn't have reservations but came at the right time by 6ish before the crowds came in about 30 minutes later. Reservations are recommended. Very small and romantic type place. Can't wait to come back!
author: Cera-Lyn S.

description:
I'm afraid that this restaurant is resting on its laurels and really isn't performing as well as they have in the past.  I've been here several times previously and it was much better.

The service is really outstanding, and the waitress was very helpful with her recommendations.  That said, there were several things that were disappointing.  First of all, the menu on their web site is not the menu they gave us at the restaurant.  Always a bad sign when you are handed a laminated menu.  That's the restaurant equivalent of chiseling something in stone:  it never changes.  I was disappointed that they did not serve the Boeuf Bourgouignon or the Veal Shank they mentioned online.  (A French restaurant without Boeuf B?  That's like a steak house with no steak!).  The pate I ordered was okay but nothing special,  something you can buy at any gourmet food store.  Most of my guests thought their dinners were good, but nothing particularly remarkable.  I had the cassoulet, which was also good, but... not the best I've had.  And I've had better... at THIS restaurant!

I am not a wine snob and don't order fine, vintage wines.   But their wine "list" is actually a book.  Now, this is a fairly small neighborhood restaurant and they could not possibly store all of the wines they listed.  With the help of one of my friends, we selected a Pinot Grigio.  Not available.  Viognier?  Non.  White Burgundy?  Helas!  Then tried some red:  Pinot Noir?  Not tonight.  I was finally sort of exasperated and just ordered a white similar to the Pinot G and a bottle of burgundy.  The waitress came up with some recommendations for wine they actually had available, which was a relief.

The owner was at the restaurant and very attentive to everything going on.  I just hope they can bring this back to the outstanding level they had before.
author: Larry B.

description: So so lovely. The ambiance is that of a very chill neighborhood bistro in the Marais. I was warmly greeted, and although I dined alone, I was never forgotten about, and treated so warmly and kindly. I could tell the owner was my server, he had an heir of pride in the most humble and heartwarming way; Laurent clearly takes pride in having a place for regulars to get together and enjoy wonderful food. He recommended a wonderful Syrah that I really enjoyed, and I enjoyed a perfect (not too salty or too big!) onion soup, and a delicious tuna tartare. Unfortunately I was too full for dessert- but he brought me a lovely glass of champagne. I can't wait to visit his sister restaurant in Noe, & definitely return with friends. What a hidden treasure !
author: Juliana O.

description:
This is one of the rare dining experiences I've had that I consider a 5-star experience, based on the food alone. Service was fantastic too, of course.

ESCARGOT.
While I still fail to see the enjoyment that lies behind eating snails, the escargot was extremely well done here, each one dripping in a wonderful buttery-garlicky sauce (make sure you mop the remains up with the baguette at your table!).

FOIE GRAS TERRINE w/CARAMELIZED APPLE JAM.
This one was a real winner at my table (for me). My non-adventurous brother didn't seem to be a fan, but my dad and I feasted on this (and again, use your baguette to devour this dish).

RACK OF LAMB w/SAUTEED POTATOES LANDAISES.
This dish completely blew me away, seriously. If it's on the menu, order it. Every part of the dish comes together perfectly, and it's just such a classic, hearty dish.

PAIN PERDU.
This dessert should be ordered with the intent of sharing, as it is a very heavy one at that - three custard-y slices of French toast, drizzled with caramel by a heavy hand, and a scoop of ice cream to boot. I could barely get through a full piece of the French toast, and it was incredibly filling.

For extremely unpretentious, delicious French food, I highly recommend this hole-in-the-wall.
author: Claire S.

description:
Did not make any reservation so when we arrived, it was packed but no waiting list.
The place is small but cute French bistro atmosphere and it's dimmed. Actually not dimmed, but dark.
The French employee in the front was nice enough to call us when there's a table available. 
Within few minutes, we got our table. It's a bit compact and all our orders somewhat did not fit on the table. 
We got the ribeye with fries, lamb shank w/ sautéed potatoes landaises, and half a dozen oysters.
The ribeye was cooked perfectly and it was flavorful. 
My boyfriend likes the lamb shank, and of course, we killed the oysters within few seconds.
Overall, the service was great and food was delicious!
author: Laramae E.

description: One of my top 5 places to go in the city. Food is amazing yet reasonable. Service great. Only downside is the small space.
author: Brian P.

description:
It's a cozy nice neighborhood restaurant. Staffs are warm and courteous though they are very busy. We ordered the crab salad, foies gras salad, and duck breast salad, the crab and foies gras salads are very small. We also have the beef, rabbit, and salmon. Salmon is our favorite while the beef has rough texture and not as soft and smooth as we hoped. Rabbit is just ok. I would rate the food somewhere from 3 to 3.5 stars. Not bad but not impressive either

Nevertheless, its a lovely cozy restaurant that I may want to come back for the vibe and environment.
author: S N.

description:
What a wonderful time we had celebrating my daughters birthday!
The food was delicious. We all ordered something different and we all loved our meals.  The service was excellent. We brought our own cake and they were so nice to add candles, drizzle with chocolate and sing happy birthday!
I have been here a few times and I highly recommend this neighborhood gem. 
Lovely!
author: jeanne j.

description: We came here because of the high rating. They had some amazing soup and salad but the main dishes were not up to par. We were disappointed with the fish snapper that was not fresh and tasted fishy. The rabbit was overlooked and dry. However, the dessert was amazing.
author: Linda H.

description:
What a rip-off!  

First the good.  The place is cute and cozy- feels very french and the service is friendly.  

My wife loved the onion soup and the cheese plate was a reasonable portion and decent variety. The wine was nice, although the prices for the wines were pretty high.   

$35 for 4 scrawny lamb chops with too much demi-glace
$11 for sweet breads that was basically a small dish of stew that was almost entirely green beans and carrots. there was many 1/2 ounce of sweetbread chopped up among the veggies. 
$34 for cassoulet that was not very good and especially that they advertised it is with duck leg confit and they give what is obvious to be a chicken leg.   
$16 for the butter lettuce salad with a little blue cheese and 1/4 of a pear
author: Mike P.

description:
Updated review. Many of our preferred restaurants went downhill. Le P'tit Laurent is one of them. We can't recommend to others with so many better and more reasonable places in San Francisco. 

Thoughts about last nights' dinner:

- 20% gratuity after tax...really!?!?!? Ridiculous!!! 
- mashed potatoes tasted like it came from instant powder. Waiter said it must be truffle oil. Trust me, I have eaten enough fresh potatoes (and foods in general) with truffles AND truffle oil to know that the mashed potatoes they served was not fresh. It wasn't because of truffle oil. 
- service was friendly, but still slow. Food came out faster this time (compared to the past several times) though, maybe because it was a set menu, all ready for vday.
- overall, the rest of the meal was pretty good.

Unfortunately, the 20% gratuity on top of taxes is highway robbery! On top of the subpar potatoes is unacceptable. I won't be coming back, and this used to be one of my favored French bistros!!!
author: Carrie-C N.

description: Food was amazing! Service was incredible!! Our waiter was Daniel and he did a phenomenal job with us!! If you are up for an adventure,Ask him to "surprise you"'with a meal. All of it was so good. Definitely coming back!!
author: Jaime N.

description: This evening my friends and I enjoyed a wonderful meal that was made more memorable because of the attentive service and warm hospitality of our waiter (and owner) Laurent.  The vegetarian entree was well executed and comparable to meat & fish specials.  I look forward to the next opportunity to enjoy dinner & laughter at this gem of a restaurant.
author: Joan R.

description:
This is hands-down the best French restaurant in SF.
It's a tiny neighborhood place that feels just like a Parisian bistro. The food is excellent and so is the service.
I've brought my parents here, I've been on date nights with my husband and even brought a supplier for a business meeting - everyone raved throughout the meal about what a SF gem this is.
The cherry on top of the cake is that they also have great wines including small French labels, l like to call them hidden treasures.
Simply delightful!
author: Paula L.

description: Wow!  A wonderful birthday dinner for my husband!  The foie gras was excellent along with the escargot in the garlic sauce!  Rack of lamb for my husband (which was cooked to perfection) and sea bass for me!   The ambiance is relaxing and the staff are attentive and so warm!   We are already planning are next visit!
author: Barb L.

description:
Not the place we used to go and enjoy!!!
Le petit Laurent has been a place where we enjoyed to go for many years. I am French, and it was our to go place, to get some authentic French Bistro experience, with good food not overly expensive. I had not been to Le petit Laurent for maybe 3 years, and I heard mixed reviews from friends who had been there more recently. Our last experience last week was disappointing, for both food and service. The French bistro feeling is still there, but that's it for the positive. Unless you get the formule Menu, average main dish is $30 or more. Nothing extravagant for SF, but at least I would like to get a good homemade cassoulet for $34. The cassoulet was ok, but nothing memorable. I clearly do better at home. We had salad de crottin de chavignol as a starter. This was not "crottin de chavignol", but just "spread" goat cheese. Goat cheese was plain, with little flavor. Once again, it was not bad, but we do better goat cheese toast with Costco "spread" goat cheese. Finally, the service. We had a "pushy" waiter who made fun of our guest who did not order wine. Yes because not everybody drink wine, and our guest cannot drink wine at this time. Waiter did not know that, but he did not have to come back multiple time, being a bully with our guest. Really disappointing from a place where we loved to go.
author: Erwan L.

description: This is the worst meal I've had in the Bay Area in recent memory. And I eat out in SF and Oakland 3-4x/week. You'd do better at any other place in Glenn Park.
author: Elguero s.

description:
Such a cute neighborhood restaurant!  The seating was wonderful but a bit tight.  Nothing losing a few plus could help with.  My friend and I were seated at the window which faves the bus stop so people were constantly looking in,  which I didn't mind at all.  

I ordered the foie gras for appetizer because I'm a rebel like that.  I finished that whole damn thing and I could hardly keep my eyes open.  It was super rich and buttery,  just beautiful,  but damn,  oh so sinful and probably put me over my caloric intake for the week. 

My main was a rack of lamb over veggies.  Damn delish if you ask me.  The lamb was tasty and tender,  just as it should be.  

The service was wonderful except towards the end when they switched our server and it was this chick who said nothing to us except to put menus and our bill on the table.

Would I come back? MAIS OUI!!
author: Sharon B.

description: Meh the French onion soup was good but the mussels were skimpy. We found four shells with no mussel inside. They also charged $6 for sparkling water which seemed really expensive to me. I would suggest Gialina pizzeria across the street instead it's a better value.
author: Jay Y.

description: Very cute little French resto. Ambiance is great. Was wanting to have just a light dinner since I had a late lunch so I only had the onion soup and escargot. They served delicious warm bread that I couldn't resist! Soup came out and it was cheesy goodness. The escargot though... YUM. After I ate all, I took the bread and soaked up all the "snail butter". Waiter recommended a Bordeaux which was perfect. So much for a light dinner. It was worth it.
author: Di G.

description:
Ahhh the beginnings of things. Remember that first date with your special someone? How the butterflies fluttered in your stomach... how you almost went out of your head trying to find the perfect outfit... how you scrambled at the last minute, trying not to make him wait *too* long as you jammed your feets into shoes and threw lipstick and mints in your bag. Wow, that all sounds stressful as eff. But all worth it.

Thankfully my date and I had been out a few times with friends prior to our "first date", but called this romantic evening our official first date for reasons I can't actually remember. Something to do with no chaperone and it being on a Friday night. Anyhow, I still had first date jitters and was very excited that he had chosen Le P'tit Laurent for the occasion.

The restaurant is intimate and kitschy-chic: lots of French art and random items on the walls, dim lighting, burgundy booth seating. I felt it was perfect for a first date because it's not super quiet and it's a bit lively. We went at 8PM and the bar was full but our table was ready right away. There were lots of tables of people speaking French, which, to me was a good sign, because if the Frenchies of the city eat here, it must have something authentically Frenchie about it.

We both ordered a glass of Bordeaux to go along with our meals, and started off with the Escargot. It was amazing! I had never tried Escargot and my Frenchie friend Holly P insisted I get it. The sauce it was served in was still simmering when it came out in it's ramekin. Garlicky, buttery goodness right there. We dipped the warm, soft, crusty bread in it after we ate our Escargot. Yum, a definite must for when you go.

I had the rabbit for my main, as I've heard that rabbit is legit and I saw an episode of "The F Word" where Gordon Ramsey makes rabbit ragu, so I've been wanting to try it. To be honest, I wish I had gotten the lamb or the pork. The rabbit was not bad, it was just gamey and served with a sweet potato puree which I wasn't crazy about. His rack of lamb was really good but slightly overcooked. The bed of green beans it was served on were good, kind of gingery, warm and crisp.

We didn't have dessert because we were super full, and they didn't have bread pudding, which is my dessert weakness. Overall, I would definitely go back, even if just for drinks and Escargot or other appetizers. It's an adorable place that should be tried by all, not only the first daters of the city.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Our party of three arrived at around 6 pm on a Friday night and it was already bustling inside. We took three seats at the bar, but while we were still perusing the menu, a manager(?) came over and asked if we wanted to move to the table that had just opened up. We gladly agreed, and he led us over with an "Allez!" (This is when I knew I'd love the restaurant)

It's small and cozy and I would say quintessentially French, but I am not well acquainted with French culture to say so. I love the decor and the feel of the restaurant anyway! The low lights coupled with the relaxed ambiance of the restaurant made it a very comfortable dinner. There was some sort of art/poster covering all the walls. 

Also, the bathroom is CLEAN and does not smell! It actually smells quite nice. Even the bathroom decor maintains the restaurant's homey but hip vibe. 

But what about the food?? Excellent! Once you order, you get a basket of sliced bread. WARM sliced bread. Oh, it was wonderful. 

I ordered the special for the night, red striped bass sautéed with white wine clam sauce paired with a vegetable risotto. The first bite of the bass- oh my goodness, I did NOT expect it to taste so...delectable. The bass was tender and buttery and flavorful with the sauce. The risotto was also a great, lighter complement to the bass. 

Great find, and so close to the Glen Park Bart station. Worth it just to Bart and take the short walk over to fill your stomach with goodness.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Le P'tit Laurent in Glen Park area of SF is very good. I very much recommend it. I ate the lamb shank, which  was juicy and tasted excellent. The green beans were tasty but some of them were too chewy. 

The waitress was attentive and very helpful. They have a bar for drinks and for eating. 

It opens at 5:30 and gets crowded on weekend by about 6:00. I recommend making reservation.

On street meter parking only, which accepts coins and credit cards.
author: Robert H.

description:
On Sunday morning I blew out of Sacramento like the hell on wheels that I am and rushed full throttle back to San Francisco to complete an assignment for work so I could make it to an anniversary dinner at LPL.  This was not my best planning, however, because by the time it was time for our dinner reservation, I had fallen asleep sitting upright watching GoT, in full make up, with shoes on.  Yeah, not the best.  I was actually tempted to cancel the dinner. 

I am SO GLAD I didn't.  

We walked in for our reservation at 7:30 p.m. PST and LPL was packed and hopping.  The owner advised that they weren't quite ready for us, and sent us to the bar.  The bartender/server seemed slammed--it took a long time to get a drink menu and an even longer time to get the drinks.  It was understandable and also very French, so we tried to relax.  

Within 10 minutes we were then sat at a VERY good table - in the corner and out of harm's way--very private.  I know that most establishments in San Francisco are small and therefore seating is tight, but sometimes it's not so great having to sit ass to ankles when you are trying to have a private conversation or quiet dinner (for more on this topic, please see my review of Hecho).  I also get annoyed when there are empty tables but I am nevertheless sat on the laps of the couple next to me (see my forthcoming review of Kama Sushi for more on this topic).  

We started with the Ceviche and French Onion Soup.  We were on the fence about the French Onion Soup, but I had to order it because I could tell we were at a place where they knew what they were doing.  I think French Onion Soup is a hard dish to get right - but LPL knows what they are doing--the cheese was delicious and thick, the crouton was perfect and not a soggy wreck, and the flavors were on point - it was all working.  We were surprised at how good the Ceviche was -- it was perfect!  The citrus was not too overpowering, and the seafood was tender and flavorful.  

For the main course, I ordered the stuffed pork tenderloin and my boyfriend ordered the mussels and frites.  I thought my dinner was phenomenal - the pork tenderloin was, well, tender as hell.  The side dish, which consisted of a cabbage and bacon mixture, was nice and smoky --complementing the pork quite nicely.  My boyfriend's mussels were equally yummy - I could have been quite pleased with just a bowl of that white wine and garlic sauce and a side of French bread.  The frites were served piping hot with a side of aioli (upon request).  

I had two (one and a half, actually) Camp-tini cocktails.  I was too tired to have drinks and was afraid of falling asleep at the table.  They were great though - pretty mild.  

I'm tempted to launch into a diatribe about the odd bathroom situation I encountered whilst at LPL, but I fear it would detract from the most important part of this or any review: the food.  I will note that the girl in line ahead of me turned around to stare at me the entire time she was waiting.  It was extremely odd.  

Dessert looked delicious but we were full and anxious to get back home to go to sleep.  I note that there's a prix fixe menu on the back of the regular menu which includes dessert - a lot of folks appeared to be taking advantage of that option.  

Overall - a great dining experience worth having.  Great location in Glen Park.  Easily accessible via parking and BART.
author: Sunny S.

description:
A very friendly neighborhood place a we've been coming here for years.
However, have to say that the much higher prices - aren't warranted .

Food was god bistro fare and staff were attentive .

Great cassoulet - and nice wine list.
But  ( sadly) it's not worth $36 entrees.

Pear tartine was disappointing - the only disappointing dish we had.
author: Thomas T.

description:
I really, really wanted to like this place, as I'd love to find a French place where I can take my family to enjoy the food from the old country without breaking the bank or having to sit down for 3 hours, and this place seemed like it could fit the bill.

To summarize, it will do in a pinch, but it could be better. Hard to put my finger on it exactly, but it seemed like execution was a bit lacking. Cassoulet had the wrong kind of sausage, and some white meat, which is unusual. Osso bucco looked pretty sad in its plate with those two strands of broccolini and that small serving of not-so-great mashed potatoes. And, last but not least, the slices of French bread were dry, like the bread had been sliced the day before or in the morning. I'm sorry, but in a French restaurant that should just not happen.

All in all, it seemed like a lot of corners had been cut, which is exactly what you don't want to do with French bistro food.

On the plus side, service was friendly and efficient. Owners (they're French) are nice. I seem to recall a review explaining they're opening another place, which may explain the off night. I may or may not give them another chance.
author: Laurent C.

description:
Good food; good atmosphere (small living room setting); not pretentious. Mediocre wine selection and slightly pricey but worth the experience and good cuisine! 

Good for intimate date setting.
author: Wei W.

description:
Wonderful restaurant!!  The owner is very congenial, the food is delicious and the decor is charming.  Makes me feel like I am in a cute neighborhood bistro in St Germain des Pres!  Bonus points for asking me how I like my salmon grilled.  
I like it seared and raw in the middle.  Mais bien sur Madame!  
It gets a little crowded but then again the food is good...  I can not wait to go back!!  I'd like to try the prix fix menu.  Every time I check the site, the choices are appetizing and the price is so reasonable.  
Merci pour une soiree superbe et un repas inoubliable.  A bientot!
author: Keeping It Real K.

description:
Le P'tit Laurent is a cozy French bistro offering a warm French dining experience. However, the dishes of the night left a little more to be desired. 

I visited Le P'tit Laurent with 2 friends on a Saturday night. It passed our minds, but we should have made a reservation as we had to wait an hour and a half for a table. It didn't bother me, as none of us were in a rush, but I do recommend making a reservation especially for Friday or Saturday. 

As for the food, I ordered the duck cassoulet along with 2 appetizers to share - the escargot and the fried frog legs. The escargot had a delicious garlic butter to accompany the dish; it seemed to mask the flavor of the snail though. The fried frog legs were crunchy and fresh, however, the breading seemed to be a bit thick for the amount of meat. Lastly, the duck cassoulet had a delicious, rich, but overpowering stew. The duck was very tender, practically falling off the bone, but all I could taste was the stew. It's my first time trying a cassoulet, but I was very disappointed to find that all these great ingredients - white beans, sausage, pork, and duck - were nothing more than a texture in the stew. After finishing half of the stew, the singular flavor profile became too salty for my preference. 

The service was quick and attentive and the overall dining experience was decent. Although I appreciate the strong flavors and generous servings, would love to see some main components shine through the rice sauces in the dishes.

Additionally, the price rating seems to be a bit outdated. Yelp reviews Le P'tit Laurent as $$ (Under $30). It's appropriate for brunch, but in terms of dinner, most entrees start around $31, and more often than not, parties order appetizers and/or dessert and drink. Also, the neighborhood menu offered Sunday through Thursday is now $28. The menu on yelp should be amended to reflect these changes.
author: Jonathan C.

description: This is one of the cutest, most romantic, most fun restaurants in San Francisco.  I just love the food, the service, the atmosphere, etc..  They have a full bar, lots of starters, delicious main dishes, desserts to die for, and much more. They also have the cleanest bathroom in town.  I suggest getting a reservation if possible since this cosy restaurant is very small.  The bar has limited seating too if you are feeling spontaneous and didn't get a reservation in advance.  This is what makes San Francisco great!
author: Lancelot C.

description: Super super super. Great negroni, great wine and yummy food. Nice service, very nice ambience. We will be back
author: Eduardo M.

description: My girlfriend and I discovered this tiny little gem through a friend of ours and we love it. Their specials are always tasty and very reasonably priced and getting a reservation has never been a problem. We especially like their soups of the day and always make sure to get the French toast dessert, which I can easily say would be right up there for best desserts I've ever had - it's delicious. If you like simple, flavorful food with a hole-in-wall atmosphere I really recommend this place.
author: Marty E.

description: Pricey and I've definitely had way better. I would not bother trying if you're on the fence due to the price. The food is edible and not horrendous so I gave one extra star. One star is reserved for the worse. You can just get better elsewhere for your money. House pate came with 2 pieces of hard as rock bread. Pate not the spreadable kind. Tomato and cheese appetizer was ok. I had the rack of lamb and it was ok. For some reason I liked the rataouille that came with it better but I didn't come for that. New York steak and french fries, steak again was just ok and so were the fries. Tilapia was also just ok. Beef stew with mash. The mash was cold. Not sure what this dish was called that was on the set menu but the beef was chewy. Creme brulee is again just ok. Ok is just mediocre and not that memorable. But the price was very memorable that I have to write this to warn people. You do not get dessert if you don't pick from the set menu. The creme brulee is nothing special so you're not missing anything but again for the price, I have high expectations of the food that this just didn't meet.
author: lia m.

description:
I dont know why I have not reviewed Lauret's restaurant before, as I have been dinning there since 2007.  I had just come back from my vineyard in the Languedoc and had made a pit stop in Paris and stopped at Laurents. To my surprise when I came back to the states as I was walking on San Francisco's Chenery st. I see this quaint space that used to be a neighborhood bar and what do I see, but a bit of Paris at that corner. I walked in and Benedict greeted me in full Parisian french and suddenly I said voila I am in Paris. My first experiences at Laurents were great both the service and the food. Did Laurent adapt the recipes to be more American? sure a tad. But over all the food was always good. If you want Le Foolie then go there. That said the reason I gave it 3 stars is because of the service. Laurent works very hard to make your experience is memorable to say the least but even an old customer like me does not get treated well when Laurent is not there and that is an issue. All I can suggest is that if you are coming in for the first time or want to give it another shot make sure that Laurent will be working that night and you can be certain to have a phenomenal experience. Laurents experience and desire to serve his customers shows when he is there. After all the joint bears hi name. Best to my friend Laurent and lots of love. 
-AP
author: A.M. E.

description:
My partner and I went to this restaurant for our anniversary. Everyone was very welcoming and made us feel special. The food was like home made French food. 
The crab salad was amazing! However, everything we ordered was delicious. 
We are definitely coming back.
author: Francisco S.

description:
Classic Authentic and Earthy French Food, Excellent Service.  We come to this neighborhood restaurant even though it is not really in our neighborhood, because it does feel like home and the food is delicious and comforting.  Most recently wife and I came on a Saturday night for a 6 PM OpenTable reservation and the small restaurant was already almost full.  We were seated promptly and provided with menus including a good wine and a full bar menu.  The food is traditional French comfort food including cassoulets, boef bourginon, escargot, rabbit Normandie style, lamb rack, etc.  We ordered French Onion soups, sweetbreads and vegetable stew, and a mixed green salad for appetitzers and were very happy with each item.  For the main course, wife ordered the mussels and fries and I ordered the flat iron steak with wine sauce, a special.  They were both excellent, the mussels with a flavorful garlic and wine sauce, and the steak was deliciously flavorful and tender, cooked just right.  By the time we finished the main course, there was no room for dessert.  The ambience of the restaurant is friendly and lively if a bit noisy.  The service was wonderful-  in spite of the restaurant being quite full, we were served very promptly by the very friendly waiter.  We will come more often!


Attachments area
author: Hoyle L.

description: Sooo good. Everything I tried was delicious and cooked to perfection. The ambiance is intimate and perfect for conversation with friends or for a date. $28 for the prix fixe menu (choose your own starter, main, and desert), which considering the price of their mains, is a stellar deal. A little pricey but well worth it. Already making plans to go back. The place is on the small side so you'll want to make reservations because it fills fast.
author: Kelli C.

description: I recently moved nearby and had to dine at this place for the first time. We came here last week with no reservation and ended up sitting at the bar. The waitress was really nice and attentive. We started with a crab salad that was really fresh and yummy. It was seasoned just right. Next was foie gras with toast that was tasty but a tad chill. Lastly was the swordfish special that was an alternate to the Mahi that I wanted. This was prepared perfectly with a nice balance of flavor and seasoning. I'll be back for that mahi!! Thank you very much!!
author: Yip J.

description: I studied in Paris and go back to France quite frequently. In between visits I come here to get my French food fix. It's a wonderfully authentic French bistro serving simple yet elegant French fare. My go to is the cassoulet. On cold nights I like to sit at the bar with a glass of vin blanc and a bowl of soul-warming onion soup. It's a total neighborhood gem!!!!
author: Jay E.

description: I am so happy my friend convinced me to have dinner here. They have a weekday "neighborhood dinner" fixed price menu that is $28 for 3 courses. I had the Osso Bucco (sp), and it was tender and delicious.
author: L A.

description: The onion soup tasted like vinegar and both drumsticks in the braised chicken dish were bland and also burnt on a side.   French fries had no seasoning at all and not crunchy.  The chocolate sauce for the profiteroles had no flavor.  I don't generally give 1 star reviews, but for ~$30-40 per person, it's a big waste of $$$ :(
author: P T.

description: Launent is a fantastic host at his namesake restaurant.   My bride and I dine here often and the service and food is always fantastic.  Although tonight I appreciated that Laurent recognized me while waiting for the bus, came out to say hello and gave me a glass of wine while I waited.   I'm sure this is the exception since we dine here often like, but it is appreciated nonetheless.   If you live in the area or are just visiting I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Daniel W.

description:
My family and I had a lovely 4th of July dinner here (because no one does independence like the French amirite).  My favorite part of the restaurant is the décor - the room feels warm, friendly, local. It's covered with French posters and road signs; the walls are fitted with mirrors, which makes the room seem much larger than it actually is.  Though rather loud, the restaurant is still comfortable enough to have a conversation in. 

I would recommend trying the escargot, for those of us who are adventurous!  Their onion soup and salads are quite good as well. 

I had the bass filet entree, which was cooked perfectly and drizzled with a lemon cream sauce and capers.  Set on a bed of spinach, leeks and mushrooms, the fish was topped with a handful of delicately grilled onions.  The entrée was fabulous, I would highly recommend it. 

Lastly, we had the pain Perdue with espressos for dessert.  It tastes like bread-equivalent of crème brûlée; crispy on the outside and gooey with cream on the inside.

Many people were celebrating as well - anniversaries, birthdays, etc.  It seems like it would be a lovely place for a date!
author: Sydney K.

description:
Don't really understand the five star reviews. Food was fine but unimpressive, and waaaay too expensive for what it was. There are other French restaurants in SF where you can get much better food for the same price.

I got the beef bourguignon. Flavors were good but the potatoes were not cooked. They tasted "green". Like biting into a raw potato.

Girlfriend got the lamb shank. The meat was good, and it came with very basic green beans on the side. She was disappointed there were no potatoes or other starch, especially given that the plate was over $30. It would've completed the plate and I would expect it at any other French restaurant.
author: Steve P.

description:
This place has exceptionally rude, snobby and passive aggressive service. 
I don't believe it has good reviews. I also can't believe it's a restaurant of San Francisco, California.
author: Anastasiy S.

description:
I went in with my mother and sister for a nice evening out. we wanted some good french food (we are french, from a french country).. 
 The service was pretty awful -- no one checked in on us at all throughout our meal... my mom had the cassoulet which is nothing at all of what you expect from a cassoulet. And their fries are definitely frozen.. c'mon.. even in-n-out has fresh fries..... it was pretty lame for a french restaurant in san francisco. theres much MUCH better out there.. not worth the money we spent there.
author: Danielle G.

description:
My boyfriend and I went on a date here on Saturday night and it was just awesome. I grew up in London and frequently went to Paris and the bistro decor made me feel right at home. So authentic. 

The food was amazing, and the limited menu gave me confidence that they know what they're doing. We started with the crab + tuna tartare salad which was phenomenal and for my main I had the fish with clams and courgette - and my boyfriend had the scallops. So so good. The petit sirah we had was delicious as well, and reasonably priced. 

Also, I have a 'thing' about American bread - too sweet etc. The table bread (baguette) provided was excellent.

I think it was Laurent himself who seated us, and our waitress was lovely. 

We'll be back. Too full for dessert this time, but I would love to try the crème brûlée Thank you!
author: Julia O.

description:
I'm starting to think that I purely go to French bistrots just to relish in sexlicious French accents because in the past year, I haven't had much luck finding a remarkable bistrot(s) worth returning to yet I keep wanting to try a new one.

Coq Au Vin with a side of oh la la?

Oh yes, seafoodplay! Yup, that's how I pronounce "s'il vous plaît". Thankfully, I took Spanish and not French in high school.

Le P'tit Laurent is a very rustic and charming bistrot in Glen Park. It's a tiny and pretty cramped place (good for 2-4 people only) but the intimacy really adds to the charm. Beware, this place is LOUD though. Saturday night bar LOUD so it's not good for a first date. Reservations are highly recommended as it was packed on the weeknight we went.

If you have trouble finding parking, there's a hidden dirt lot in the back of Gialina.

What I love about Le P'tit Laurent was the very warm staff. Service was slow but our waitress, Kris was the ultimate sweetheart so it more than made up for it.

I wish I could say the same about the food. Maybe we went on an off night...maybe the chef that night got too salty happy but our party of four thought almost everything we ordered was ridiculously salty. Salty to the point of being nearly inedible. 

Btw, sorry in advance for the fugly food pics; it was very dark in the restaurant. 

We started with a dozen of oysters ($2.20 each) which was a bad suggestion on my part because these oysters had a funky bitterness to them; not a clean oceany taste that a really fresh oyster would have: http://bit.ly/156d07E.

Craving a salad, I ordered a the Frisée Salad w/ bacon & poached egg ($11) which had a perfectly cooked egg that oozed yolk porn upon cutting: http://bit.ly/169GaZu. The greens however were completely drenched in the vinaigrette like wet laundry. I lifted up a forkful of them to find a pool of vinaigrette underneath. Ugh, so much for quenching that salad craving.

Others in the group, ordered the French Soup which they couldn't finish because they said, it was too salty.

To play it safe, I ordered the most raved about dish on Yelp for my entree: Cassoulet w/ duck confit, pork, toulouse sausage & beans ($29): http://bit.ly/1aL2rLr. Oh dear, this classic French comfort dish was crazy salty. I had to take a bite of bread with each spoonful to neutralize the salt. My friend ordered the same thing and she too had trouble eating the cassoulet. The only edible portion was the duck confit meat underneath the skin because it wasn't exposed to the pungently salty bean stew. I brought the leftovers to work the next day thinking my palate was probably just screwed up that night but had to chuck it after one bite and go to the vending machine to buy a granola bar for lunch. :X

Disappointed with the apps, salads/soups and entrees, we each ordered our own dessert. A highlight of the night, the Pain Perdu ($7.50) was incredibly delicious: http://bit.ly/16mjOOL. The rich french toast had this sensational caramelized edges and was served with a scoop of creamy sweet caramel ice cream. This is a MUST order! Fyi, we had a birthday in our group and the staff went out of their way to wish her a happy birthday but they didn't comp her birthday dessert. Not a big deal but I thought that most restaurants do? 

Le P'tit Laurent is not a place I would return to for the regular menu. I much rather spend a little more and eat at the bougie La Folie considering dinner here was about $75 pp after tax and tip (no alkie for me). However, they have an awesome deal from Sunday - Thursday. For just $20.13, you get to choose an app and an entrée from their neighborhood menu. Just $20 and some change to relish in oh la la sexlicious French accents? YES, SEAFOODPLAY!
author: Cherylynn N.

description: I love steak frites. It's quite possibly my favorite thing to get when I go to french restaurants. I've also had a good experience with this item at other restaurants in the Bay Area (ex: Garçon). However, the steak frites at Le P'tit was underwhelming. It was chewy, lathered with excessive and flavorless sauce (making the outline of the steak impossible to detect in the dark ambiance). The perfect storm of flavorless and poor texture. The fries were also disappointing. I filled up on the bread and wine and we all left feeling a bit sick altogether. It was the first time I took a restaurant's business card on the way out just to make sure I remember never to return. [Note: this review reflects my visit to the restaurant on 3/18/17]
author: Behnam S.

description: On our mission to try a new place every week, we went to Laurent...which was new to us. What a fabulous neighborhood gem! The ambience is lovely...Lots of French kitsch without being tacky at all. Our host was warm, funny, and charming. The food was amazing. We each had a cocktail: the cucumber martini for him and the vodka pineapple martini for me (delicioisly dangerous!)We shared the arugula beet salad...very fresh and tangy with lots of thyme. I had the steak frites and my bf had the rabbit. Everything cooked perfectly and the sauces were divine. Even though we were stuffed, we couldn't resist dessert...the pear tart. Heaven in caramel and vanilla ice cream. It was easy to see why the place was packed on a Wednesday night. We'll definitely be back!
author: Teri K.

description:
Cute little neighborhood bistro that transported me back to Paris. We started with Lillet and moved on to a glass of French wine. 

The French onion soup was amazing - some of the best I've ever had!  We were mopping up the remaining morsels with the delicious baguette they brought to the table. 

The scallop main dish was delicious. There were enough scallops to feed two of us. Granted, we had just stuffed ourselves with French onion soup and baguette... True to French cuisine, the sauce with the scallops was fantastic. 

This place deserves an encore!
author: Ashley S.

description: This is one of our favorite French restaurant in SF. We love the food and it is very delicious PLUS staffs are very friendly.
author: Mega Team R.

description: The food was not good. Overly prepped and assembled way too fast to be real. Vegetables overly microwaved. Fish dish had no flavor. Tried to add salt to bring it to life.
author: Adam P.

description:
I love this restaurant.

I was in San Francisco on business and travel. This is one of my go to neighborhood place.  Check out their special menu.

I held an event here with 10 people. It's a tiny place and they accommodated my needs with aplomb.  It's small and a gem, make reservations in advance.
 
Service is super!  The Male waiters are cute and flirty.

Food exquisite!  From appetizers to the entree and dessert.  

Noise level is lively.

Decor, Took me back to being in a Parisian french bistro.
author: Maria P.

description: Such a cute little French restaurant, the food is delicious and the service is spectacular !!! Love it!
author: Evelyn M.

description:
This restaurant is hands down one of my absolute favorites in San Francisco. 

The consistency of food, service, and quality never disappoints.  My mom and I go here on occasion, and we're always greeted with smiles, provided with excellent customer service, and always have a great dining experience!  Happy to see that this neighborhood gem has outlasted a few others in the area, and for good reason!
author: Sarah Z.

description:
This place was simply amazing!! Our server was helpful and attentive, and the food was perfectly seasoned. My friend and I came here for her birthday and we tried the Neighborhood menu. She ordered the oyster mushroom soup, snapper, and tiramisu. I ordered a salad with bay shrimps, a braised pork dish, and creme brulee. Everything was awesome! My friend's soup was thick and flavorful, my salad had a hint cumin, her fish was seasoned well, and my pork was delicious! I usually don't like pork because it's a bit dry, but as I went to cut off a piece, the meat separated from the weight of the fork! Sooo tender! 

Would definately come back, i'm already making plans with my other friends :)
author: Elaine S.

description:
Last night was our second trip to Le P'Tit Laurent and rest assured, it shall not be our last. 

We rarely aim ourselves in the Glen Park direction when hungry and seeking food, but I think we should.  Especially when you're talking about an adorable and fairly authentic neighborhood French bistro.

Dinner last night consisted of:

Escargots (obviously)
torchon de foie gras
roasted rack of lamb
vanilla bean Creme brulee

The escargots, curiously, were not served in their shells but instead swimming naked in garlic parsley butter in their little escargots dish.  Not really a complaint, but a bit odd, whenever I have had escargots in France, they seem to be served in-shell.  In any case, these particular snails were tender, toothsome, and delightfully garlicky.

The foie gras was simply divine, there's not much more to say.

The lamb was almost stupidly delicious.  We asked for medium rare (which to a French chef usually means rare) and it was perfect.  The meat was perfectly tender and flavorful, the pain sauce was transcendent.  The only downer was that the potatoes served along with the lamb were rather under-done, and a bit crunchy/crumbly in the middle.  We still ate them, make no mistake.

I found the custard in the creme brulee to be a bit overly sweet, but that may just be personal preference.  I like a mildly sweet custard to accompany the shattering caramelized sugar.  Oddly all the vanilla bean specks (technical term?) had settled into the corners of the dish.  Initially I was disappointed at the lack of specks (I mean, if it says vanilla bean on the menu, I expect SPECKS goddamnit!) but my mood recovered when I discovered all the little troves of specks in the corners of the ramekin.

Various wines and brandies were consumed as well, all simply delightful.

Perhaps we'll return and try the neighborhood meal some time.  You never know.
author: Rachel S.

description:
My partner and I have traveled to Paris with a couple of friends in the past, and when home here in the Bay Area, we like to try out different French restaurants.  And so, this past weekend we celebrated a birthday with dinner at Le P'tit Laurent.  The experience was easily at the same five-star level as some of our best meals in Paris.  The ambiance was very Parisian, the service impeccable, and the food was absolutely stellar.
 
The onion soup and the terrine of foie gras were on par with the dishes we enjoyed in France; the cassoulet was by far much more flavorful than any I've tasted prior; the beef bourguignon was amazing; and the wine list is pitch perfect. 
 
The service was impeccable.  We were seated promptly and the server took great care of us; we never felt rushed. 
 
Overall, an absolutely wonderful experience.  We all left with huge smiles, talking about how we would definitely be back.
author: Wayne A.

description:
Came here for dinner for the first time with a friend. I don't think I had ever had french food til my visit. The food was amazing and I even tried the snails. The escargot was better than I thought it would be. It kind of had the taste and texture of lamb from what I can remember when I used to eat meat. 
This place was well worth the visit and hopefully in the future I'll get to visit again :)
author: Joji V.

description: Very authentic French bistro - excellent food. We started with charcuterie plate- about 8 different things- country pate, cornichon, saucisson, duck sausage and lots more that I can't remember. I had a smoked salmon salad that was generous with the delicious smoked salmon. My main was lamb shank- meaty and tender to the bone. Great service and friendly. Can't wait to come again.
author: Lucy M.

description:
I had their escargot which was delicious, with a frisée salad which was Halloween night called for.  (Last minute dinner plans!)

Service = good. 

Noise = very loud.  You've been warned.

Prices = moderate to expensive. 

I'll need to try their three-course menu. :)
author: Fannie S.

description: Maybe 3.75 stars. Food was pretty good, my friends loved the snails and the lamb shank LOOKED FANTASTICO. I got the braised pork belly from the prix fix meal, a little bit small portioned compared to the beef stew and shank dishes. Pretty good.
