Warm ambiance, great for family get together or friends celebrating a night out with some classy French food!
author: Janie K.

description:
3 stars for food, but an entire star upgrade for: the neighborhood, ample parking, atmosphere that's a perfect mix of elegant & comfortable, and unintrusive service. 

Foods: 
-- onion soup: unbearably salty. I had to avoid sipping too much broth because I didn't want a sodium-inflicted headache later. If cheese was sharply flavored, salt overload masked any of its deliciousness
-- spinach, orange, bay shrimp salada: a sprinkle of croutons, a few sprigs of frisee, perfect proportion of each ingredient, including the bright pinkish-purple raspberry dressing  
-- chocolate fondant cake: i chucked the assigned pear sorbet in favor of plain vanilla ice cream. Moist, though quite average

Sampled sips & bites of her "neighborhood special" (app & entree for $23): unique beet soup, much depth of flavor in the carrots & meat in beef bourguingnon. Would return for this tender, rich french cuisine staple.
author: Fancypants X.

description: this is a really neighborhood gem! it's reasonably priced, great friendly service, and delicious food. It actually may be one of my top 3 favorite French restaurants in the city.
author: Alana C.

description:
Two stars is possibly over generous to be honest. The food was totally devoid of flavor, the restaurant was so noisy you could barely hear yourself think and service left a LOT to be desired. I simply cannot understand the good review here.

Had a calamari salad special that had NO FLAVOR whatsoever. The lamb shank was not cooked right (no clue - under cooked? Over cooked? No clue) and was tough, dark brown and full of nasty sinew. It (together with the almost cold mash potatoes) was covered in a flavorless brown gravy - think a 90 cent packet from Kroger stuck in the microwave. I never did get the green beans I ordered but everything else was so bad I didn't care, a couple of glasses of wine and some bread (that was snatched away before I had finished) and 25 minutes from being seated I am paying $95 plus tip for that crap. That's $4 a minute folks. terrible, terrible. Make it 1 star after all. Back at the hotel, starving hungry and $100 poorer. Yuk
author: Brian G.

description:
Escargot heaven. This tasted just like it did in Europe. The french onion soup is definitely on the salty side; warned by yelpers. The complimentary bread is hot and delicious! I want to say that was my favorite thing eaten here. The butter was salted and soft. Perfect combo. 

The reason I came though, was for the gnocchi. And boy was I disappointed. The tomato based sauce was ok, it resembled more of a tomato basil soup. The gnocchi itself was a bit more dense than I would have liked. Not the chewy dense type, just the, "I need to cut this and pretend to enjoy this" type... 

My boyfriend ordered the Chilean Sea Bass as it is his favorite. Turns out, it wasn't his favorite there. The fish was topped with fresh mangos and covered in sauce. The bass was buttery and flaky, but the toppings were so cold that it made the fish cold; not enjoyable. The portion of the fish was tiny, but the wild pilaf that accompanied it was quite the grand. I tried this dish myself, not a fan either. 

I've been craving a good gnocchi since I got back from Venice. Still I haven't found that dream place yet. So if anyone knows a place... please share!
author: Marlene T.

description:
Absolutely in love with this place. I only wish it could stay open later. The owner is lively and the staff is wonderful. Good is always on point. The crème puffs for desert are amazing. 

Cheers to many more visits.
author: Tiffany H.

description: Wonderful neighborhood restaurant that's non pretentious. My companion said it felt like he could be in a French bistro. Excellent service and food!
author: Becca D.

description: Good food, only if they have bigger space and seating for big family.
author: John B.

description: my boyfriend and I went here for a spontaneous dinner and it was awesome! We both had fish entrées and they were cooked to perfection. We are definitely coming back for more! :D
author: Korra B.

description:
A good place to have a french diner and the ambience is so good.
The food is amazing special the dessert. 
You have to try the pain perdu. let's go
author: Alice D.

description:
Went out on a weekend . Restaurant has old world ambiance. We arrived on time with a reservation but there was no table. Considering that The restaurant is in Glenn park it was very busy. We were made to wait 20 minutes before we got a table.

We ordered some wine and the lamb shank and the fish. The fish was delicious and lamb shanks were ok. The dishes are pricey for the quality I would have expected and they are small. It felt like we were ordering appetizers 

-1 star for a wait time even though we made a reservation. -1 was for the overall quality and price
author: Kishor K.

description:
The manager/owner is very courteous and professional. The service is very good . This place gets packed easily. We had reservation but we needed to wait little longer but it's worthed . 
The menu is easy to sort out and meets all tastes.
They have very good selection of wines. The servers are friendly and helpful. 
I am looking forward to going back .
author: Shawn A.

description:
We had an amazing dinner, encircled by great food and fabulous conversation!  It took about a good hour to decide just where to eat that night.  Once I stepped foot in LPL, I realized that it was the perfect place to be.  It is not a fancy restaurant, more like a small, neighborhood pub; intimate, romantically quiet.  We were greeted at the door with a full-on French accent.  It made me reminisce about being in Paris and 4 years of French in high school.  The most I dared to say though was, "Bonjour."

Their wine by the glass was very limited, so I opted for 2 mixed cocktails:  Le Colonel, a blend of lemon sorbet, vodka & triple sec, served in my favorite glass of choice:  the martini glass.  It was tart with a little tinge of sweetness.  My second drink was, Le Pamplemouse.  An intermingling of gin, Saint-Germain, grapefruit and basil leaves.  This was not as sweet as my first drink, but nonetheless, enjoyable.

For starters, we relished the flavors of Escargot de Burgundy and Salade Frisée w/Bacon and a Poached Egg.  The Escargot was abundantly covered in a garlic parsley butter; absolutely delectable!  The salad had large cubes of bacon, and a perfectly poached egg, all tossed in a sherry vinaigrette.

Our entrees included:  Encrusted Rack of Lamb & Rabbit Normandy.  The lamb was cooked perfectly to a soft, juicy medium rare.  The delicate rosemary sauce enhanced the lamb flavors.  The rabbit was unbelievably delectable!  I would definitely return just to devour this dish again.

For dessert:  Fresh Apple Tart Tatin with Vanilla Ice Cream & Vanilla Bean Crème Brûlée.  The apple tart was so-so; nothing outstanding.  The crème brûlée was good, but not the best I've ever had.

The service was great; waitstaff accommodating.  We enjoyed our many hours of dining there.
author: Jeanie L.

description:
I have been here twice and both times, the service and food was excellent. I had the salmon each time with slightly different side dishes. They put this crazy delicious creme sauce on it which you could basically just pair with anything. 

Also, always inquire about the soup of the day-you won't be disappointed!
author: Erin L.

description:
Made a reservation through opentable, got there on time and got seated right away. 
It was pretty busy at that time. 

Very nice interior and decor. Friendly and fast service. 

Ordered escargot, french onion soup and some creamy potato soup to start. 
Really liked the escargot. 

Burgundy Beef was good. I will pass next.

Overall, i had great date night. Will come back sometime.
author: Maya B.

description:
This is a small, quaint french bistro for decently priced delicious french food. Seating is a bit "cozy" and it's dim light for a nice dinner out. They take reservations but we have been able to walk in on a few occasions as well.

They usually have a 3 course menu (not weekends) you can choose from which is very well priced. If the 2 entree choices don't intrigue us, or we have already tried them, we just usually order from the main menu.

Their soup dijour is usually amazing, we have had the cream of chicken and the cream of brocoli before.

Their Pain Perdu dessert: Caramelized french toast, caramel ice cream is a MUST ORDER! AMAZING.

Parking can be tough in the area so give some extra time to find a spot.
author: Linda L.

description:
It was the night after my wife's birthday and thanks to two god friends we found a way to extend the celebration.

Tucked away in Bernal Heights is a French bistro that seriously is one of the best finds in quite some time. Our friend used to live in the neighborhood and suggested we check it out and we are so very thankful we did. 

The minute you walk in you feel like Scotty beamed you to France. The decor feels Parisian without even trying. We arrived early and found a couple of seats at the bar. My wife started with a glass of French white wine and me a Hine sidecar. My drink was perfectly mixed with just the right amounts of lemon and Cointreau and the brandy warmed my body on a cold San Francisco evening. My wife's wine choice was perfect and thanks to our nice bartender who helped selecting it for her.

Our friends arrived right on time and the owner (who recognized our friend), came right over and sat us at a nice quiet table for four in the corner. It was the perfect place to sit and relax and catch up on life. More cocktails magically appeared at the table and we were now ready to begin our evening.

The menu is classic French and includes all your favorites. I went with the osso-buco de boeuf with polenta. I also asked for a side of French fries of course, which by the way I don't care what you order just get the damn frites! My wife shared a salad to start which I don't remember what it was called, but we both loved it! One of my favorite salads ever! 

Our entrees arrived perfectly paced after our starters along with a French red wine that our celebrity friend picked out. Again, I wish I could remember what it was, because it was excellent and perfectly paired with our dinner. My beef was perfectly prepared and super tender. No knife was needed at all. The polenta was a a little different than most and had a more sticky consistency and was mixed with vegetables (carrots and peas). It was delicious and I like the fact that it was more robust than your typical polenta and stood up to the osso-bucco. The menu also included rabbit which my wife orders 99 out 100 times whenever it's offered. Out of respect to Buddy, I did not sample it but judging by my wife's reaction she must have loved it.

The star of the night was dessert, "Pain Perdu, Glace Caramel" (Pain Perdu, Glace Caramel). It was light and flavorful and tasted like a toasted marshmallow. It was OUTSTANDING to the HELLS YEAH!!

Everything was perfect right down to the service. And thanks to our celeb friend go to meet Laurent who is the owner of this gem of a restaurant. This place will now be on our regular rotation and cannot wait to go back again soon.
author: Rene C.

description: Charming, tiny, a bit noisy but cheap and good wine selection. Pain Perdu is a star for dessert and their casserole is solid. Not expensive, nor cheap.
author: Alex M.

description:
I went there last night with my boyfriend and am very glad we did!

The food and service was absolutely wonderful.  We opted for the Neighborhood Menu, served Sunday - Thursday.  Such a treat, with nice options to choose from. The fish and beef were delicious, as was the creamy vegetable soup.  

I look forward to frequenting this spot more often.  Thank you Le P'tit Laurent!
author: Maryn R.

description:
This was a lovely place for dinner, I think that's the perfect adjective. Tucked away in a comfortable neighbourhood corner, Petit Laurent offers homey French food presented in a non-pretentious manner, coupled with an intimate ambiance. The food is good, not spectacular to write home about, but it also doesn't sell itself as so. It's a solid, cozy, warm neighbourhood spot, and offers a menu that can often delight and surprise. 

Attentive, nice staff. You won't be disappointed.
author: Ben H.

description:
Loving the atmosphere at Le P'tit Laurent, I wanted to take the gf out for her b-day dinner.

Made a reservation through Open Table/Yelp for 7:45pm, however got there a bit before 7:40pm and there were no available seats. Given it is a pretty small restaurant, however we did not end up getting seated WITH a reservation for half an hour. Luckily there was a bar where the gf and I were able to try some of their unique cocktails/beers. But I couldn't understand why they did not save us seats at a table.

When finally seated, the menu looked delicious and it was difficult to choose. Hearing from yelp that their lamb was amazing, I opted for that while Kathleen W. dared to go for the rabbit (a first). Service was a bit sluggish, but overall kind, and I did not mind being seated next to the window as time went by.

Food arrived and everything was very tasty. Lamb was incredibly tender, and a decent portion size. I had no idea that the rabbit came with so much to eat either. Definitely did not expect to really get your bang for your buck with the rabbit. Left us quite full after the meal, which I appreciated for an elegant dinner setting.

Overall, I would love to come back and try more items on the menu, however was not too fond of waiting so long to get seated while having a reservation beforehand.
author: Brandon Y.

description: Loved the neighborhood bistro vibe, especially on a foggy evening. And my cassoulet was really yum. (I love duck confit!) comfort food. A little pricey - but it was busy, so who am I to say?
author: Andrew K.

description: An adorable French restaurant in my backyard. The service is pleasant. The music perfectly fits the ambiance.
author: Paulina F.

description: great neighborhood French bistro. The service and food are awesome.
author: Juan V.

description:
Came here on a simple date night and definitely will not come back for a while.

Ordered their onion soup and it was really disappointing. 
Escargot was tasty but I've had better. 
Steak was tough. 
Dessert was blah.
author: James N.

description: I have eaten here before, but this review is based on a reservation my boyfriend made for Valentine's Day. He made the 9:15 pm reservation at least a few weeks before Valentine's Day, and had received a call from the restaurant the week prior to confirm he still wanted it. We arrived at about 9:05, and we were told by the hostess Ren it would be about 15 minutes until we would be seated. We walked around Glen Park for about ten minutes and returned to wait with the other 2-3 couples hovering around the front door. At about 9:35, another couple who said they had a 9 pm reservation was seated, so I approached the hostess to ask if she knew how much longer it would be. She was super unapologetic, she actually seemed borderline annoyed, and said we would be seated right now. Five minutes later, she led us to a table without any mention of it being so late. My boyfriend and I looked at each other without sitting down, turned back around, told her we were leaving, and left. Probably won't be returning.
author: B J.

description:
LP is one of the most popular little neighborhood restaurants in Glen Park. It's WAY too popular nowadays. Some residents seem to dine there every night. That's a bit too often for me. I don't eat out everyday.

Although there were a couple of times when I couldn't get in, and had to dine elsewhere, I've been fortunate enough to get in before. So I'm somewhat familiar with the food, traditional French cuisine. The "neighborhood menu" (prix fixe) is the best value. But other than that it's not a cheap restaurant.

People read the great reviews, and want to try it. But the place is too small, and cannot handle all that level of attention. My rating is 4 stars because I've had some very pleasant meals here. But that's just for my experience. Any newbies, ignore my rating. Don't come - stay home. All the tables are usually booked. And your only chance is 1 or 2 chairs at the bar, and only right before it opens.

I don't think that the owner is rude, like some mentioned. Because I've seen how hard he works non-stop to keep everyone happy. It makes no sense to try to pack more people inside when they barely can manage serving the packed restaurant they have each night. All u get is bigger delays between courses. Does he treat regulars better than newcomers? It might seem like he's friendlier, but that's only because they keep him in business. He's never been rude to me.

I took this pic one evening right before the dinner rush. It's rare to see open chairs. Actually, ALL the tables were reserved. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/bxs2LmE7CQqkbW7Javm22A/l

The bar area is cozy, http://media4.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/kqGnStI1LJuFAUoNYIAXxQ/l
and has a nice variety of liquors. http://media4.ct.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/SN-R825WAJs-6INzD4SKsw/l On the left side of the bar, there's an intimate corner with 2 tables. http://media1.ct.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/CZoOk-eq_gpJRno-8RncLQ/l

My food pics from one of the rare times I was dining here. The complimentary crusty baguette was warm. http://media2.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ojE5PGkITNa-F_4DJmGwYA/l It reminded me of Le Charm.

I ordered the soup of the day. http://media1.ct.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/zPn-wpfgFx6a5DFVBn6mpA/l I think it was a carrot, parsnip and ginger soup. And my entree was a yellow tail fillet over spinach. http://media2.ct.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/FBmz-7ITg5vqxJNN-Rnwhg/l The week before they had steak and potatoes.

For dessert I got the pain perdu (French toast). http://media1.ct.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/lD1ThdM_vNg9BycAO4a59A/l Even though it was a super busy night. I remember the owner joked with me when he brought the plate, and said here's your breakfast.

Taking the time to joke with customers, refilling drinks, keeping a good attitude, checking with every customer. it's rare to see that level of devotion. I think that's why customers keep coming back.
author: Luis C.

description:
Lovely neighborhood atmosphere and great food!  I've been here several times and never been disappointed.

Make sure you get a reservation, it's a small place!
author: Don N.

description:
This is a French Bistro, so, don't coming expecting it to be a fancy french restaurant. In England this would be a pub. Being that it's a bistro, the menu is limited, and I mean one single sided page. They serve mainly everyday fare, nothing fancy, but good food. I've had the pleasure of eating their cassoulet and the mussels. Both were very good and generously portioned. I have tried their escargot and beef tartar; they were both good but not extraordinary. 

Normally, this would be a 3 - 3.5 star review, but their service has been excellent. I have been here twice and both times they were very busy. Both times, the waiter/waitress were very attentive and had a smile on their faces. Sometimes, its the food and sometimes its the service. This place has both.
author: Tony L.

description: Came one night for a friend's birthday and unfortunately I was disappointed. Service was slow and food was lacking in quality. For starters we had the mussels and french fries. The mussels were actually very tasty but we just wish there wasn't so much sand in them. Very gritty indeed. The table ordered a few bottles of Rose to pair with our meal and that was a very good bottle so I'm glad we were pointed in right direction by our waiter so that was nice. My entree was the rabbit and the meat was dry and the sauce that covered it was far too sweet. All in all for the price we paid for the food, I would expect for these basic cooking skills would not be overlooked. I would probably not dine here again with so many high quality restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Jeromy G.

description:
5 years of high school French, and I have forgotten most of it.

I still know how to say a few things in French, like 

"check please", "good morning/good night", "how are you", "goodbye", "snails", "steak fries", "toilet water" (the perfume name), "do you have any Grey Poupon", "D'you want to sleep with me this evening?" (Oh X-tina and your Moulin Rouge wicked ways, never used this line...), and oh yeah, macarons (not that I give a flying Dutchman about them) to name a few.  

And how could I forget a few bad words that a French college dorm mate taught me... including "it smells like $h!t in here", and cursing someone to do something that involves up the butt (with an honorable "you" at the end = vous). Yeah very useful! 

But ask me for the time or try to carry on a conversation beyond a sentence, I'd be lost.

Truth be told, I'm not that much of a fan of fancy French cooking. Cream sauces + lactose intolerance = fun fun fun. I'd rather splurge on nigiri Lollapalooza at Sushi Ran or Akiko's than at La Folie.

But a bistro offering various styles of comfort food, accessible, and quite delicious? Bring it on!

Glen Park brings back old memories. Had my first ever taste of local Cantonese food right across the street....Hong Sing (cha siu/bbq pork chow fun on steam table!). It's not the best, but did the job in a fix where Chinatown was so much further out of reach

But anyways, LPL is an a-ok bistro.

Roquette salade, betterave et fromage, vinaigrette a la moutarde et citron
Arugula salad with red beet and goat cheese, lemon mustard dressing. This was piled on pretty high and was quite the thick salad to have

Soupe à l'oignon gratinée - the standard French onion soup. It had a wee bit too much of a certain herb... chives? But smelled like rosemary a bit. Decent execution, except it was a tad too salty.

Soupe du Jour - not pictured, but it was cream of lentil and mushroom. Good flavor and texture, but unfortunately on the salty side. Had a spoon to try.

Moules Marinieres et frites - this one is a pretty fail safe order so long as the the Moules are good. Steamed mussels in white wine and garlic, with a side of fries. Mussels might not be at peak season, as the edible flesh were smaller than expected, but still quite tasty. Now the mussel juice that mixed in with the white wine and garlic sauce, was mighty good. Dipped the fries in, and this enhanced the experience greatly. Although the fries were not quite my style...

Slotting it at 3.5 stars, and rounding up to include the quaint décor and pleasant service.
author: Ken K.

description: My absolute favorite French restaurant in San Francisco! Everything, EVERYTHING is scrumptious! And the owner is such a sweetheart. I've been a few times but the most recent time I took my parents (from out of town) for a belated birthday dinner. They made me feel super special with a candle (the norm with dessert) but gave a bottle of wine to celebrate my birthday -- to take home. I've never seen that done before. So sweet! This spot is a gem. Perfect neighborhood-y and so charming. The definites: $20 Charcuterie plate (a steal! So much scrumptious stuff including a homemade rabbit pate!), the onion soup (mmmm that broth!), the mussels with French fries/aioli, and the steak frites in a perfect sauce. So good!
author: Allie S.

description:
no place for a vegetarian. very small portion in our salad order.
Ambience is good but i cant eat that. Staff was sweet.
author: Malvika B.

description:
Got the Tax Relief Prefixe for $20.14 - I had escargot and Salmon, BF had shrimp Salad and gnocchi with ratatouille, ended with (of course) the pain perdu. SO SO Good
Service was amazing as always
Definitely make a reservation
author: Kajal G.

description:
One thing you should know is that both my dining companion and I live really far away from this neighborhood. This is the second time we are here since we love it here so much. The food is fantastic. The waitstaffs are really professional and chill. 

I had the prix fixe weekday special which changes daily. The stuffed mushroom salad was flavorful. Tilapia with spinach and mushroom sauce had some leeks and scallions in it to make it sweet. The fish was cooked perfectly. Tiramisu was very good. 

Dining companion had Dungeness crab and avocado salad, stuffed chicken with mashed potato, and creme brûlée. The salad was nice and creamy. The entree had some of the best mashed potatoes I've had. The dessert had a bit of a spicy kick to it. He loved every single bite. 

The restaurant is very close to Bart which makes it easy to get to. I would recommend it to anyone who like bistro style dining.
author: Sunny C.

description:
Brunch places that take reservations are hard to come by nowadays. Le P'tit Laurent was an exception. The 5 of us were seated at nice little round table in this small, but cozy restaurant that very much had a quaint, French appeal. 

After our coffee service with our friendly server, we were ready to order. It's a small menu, but one with options for everyone. I settled on the Pain Perdu (french toast), and while the description was fairly nondescript, the dish was anything but! 

The dish is described as "French toast served with seasonal fruit and whipped cream." Standard, right? I was in the mood for a bit of sweet that morning, so french toast it was!

Boy oh boy, I was NOT prepared for what came out of that kitchen. Sumptuous, melt-in-your-mouth custard filled (or was it dipped!? or both!?) french toast! I inhaled it like a drug, and it vanished from my plate in near minutes! Wowee! 

My two favs when it comes to french toast come from two well-known Brunch establishments in the Mission - Le P'tit Laurent just gave them a massive run for their money! The french toast is fantastic. Whether your main entree or dessert for the table - be sure to order it.
author: Mansi A.

description:
The food:
Escargot- too much pesto with no other flavoring. It was simply pesto and snail. I would pass on this. ~$10
Oysters- red wine and shallots. We ordered oysters although it was not oyster season but they tasted pretty good for off season! We could see the cream that was evident for off season though but I give it a pass. The red wine with shallots was pretty good but I don't see how you could mess that up. $2.50/oyster 
Rack of lamb- it was too salty but was cooked OK for medium rare..  It needed to be more rare for it to be medium rare. The texture was good but a little tough. $34
Rabbit- I like my rabbit lean. My rabbit was pretty good, very lean, and very filling. Rabbits are filled with protein so it was a very good size for me. I loved the sauce as well it was not too thick. The yams were also very soft and moist while the mushrooms were nice and chewy. $29
Dessert French toast- it was covered in caramel and came with ice cream. It was the best part of the meal. The toast was a little crispy and soft on the inside. Don't pass on the toast. ~$7-8

The service:
Excellent. They were very hospitable and always made sure that we felt comfortable and had every thing that we needed. The sun was in our eyes so they lowered the blinds until we were satisfied, brought our knives before we asked since we had some, always made sure to refill our water container before it emptied. The service was very good. 

Overall:
The service was great it was also very homey and comfy there. The waiters did a great job. The food was decent for the most part except for the escargot. It was really disappointing to have pesto snail for escargot. The rabbit was good but the rack of lamb was also very salty (kind of not worth our $34) so all in all, I give this place 3 stars.
author: Lyra C.

description: This place is run by liars. Who at 7pm told us they could seat us at 8. It's now 830 and they refuse to chase the people who are sitting at our table with there coats on the hell out. God forbid they lift a finger to turn over the table. Liars liars liars.  I have eaten here for years and the food is not what it was. Now the service is joining the food on decline. I'm done.
author: Bobo B.

description: Nice restaurant with great service and food. We tried the beet soup, scallops appetizer, bass, and the kidney. The bread is amazing with the butter, I could just eat that for dinner. We didn't much like the apple tart for dessert. But overall,  the food is great. Will be going back again!
author: Gessa C.

description: Moved from Bay Area to La Jolla  but in Sf last week  chose this nice small neighborhood restaurant again.  Same good food and attention as before.
author: Chuck M.

description: Was looking for a quick bite with my friend after getting our nails done. Saw this place had a good review and decided to give it a try. I ordered the eggs Benedict  and it came out super fast. The portion was smaller than some of the other restaurants but it was a good size for me. I really liked the fries and salad that came with it. Definitely want to go back to try their foie gras burger.
author: Venus Z.

description:
I will give it 3.5 stars. They have friendly staff and cute interior.

 We ordered the escargot, steak and lamb shank. The escargot tasted like the ones you purchase at trader's Joe and I didn't eat half of the lamb. The lamb was tasteless, which is really hard to achieve with this meat. 

The French fries on the side of the steak were the only food I did enjoy. The steak wasn't cooked medium rare but medium. Overall, is probably OK to come for French fries and some wine but not worth for dinner.
author: Rositsa K.

description: We got there right when it opened on a weekday without a reservation.  Luckily, they had a table because the people started streaming in and before we knew it, it was packed!  We had celebratory drinks and two crab cakes.  Drinks were great and the crab cakes were creamy, crispy and tasty all at the same time.  Service was good.
author: Maile N.

description:
Had the pleasure of having dinner here the night before Valentine's Day, was expecting a madhouse with the staff herding people in and out like cattle, but boy was I wrong. This might be one of my all-time best dining experiences ever!

Venue: quaint bistro feel to it, but the lighting made it super romantic.

Staff: super polite and attentive

Food: wow, so pleased with everything! 

Drinks: wonderfully thought out and perfectly balanced

I wish I had more time to write out a longer review, but truly a wonderful night. I will be going back.
author: Arlenne D.

description: Went here for a nice Sunday dinner. They have an awesome special for April that they call their "tax month special". $20.17 for a two course meal, and you get to choose from a few appetizers and a few entrees (except on Fridays and Saturdays). We sat at the bar because we didn't make a reservation ahead of time, but the bar is full service. I got the vegetable cream soup and the osso bucco with mashed potatoes. Both were wonderful. I ate my soup with the complementary bread and butter, and it was fantastic. The meat was falling off the bone and the mashed potatoes were the most flavorful mashed potatoes I've ever had. Service was extremely fast. We got drinks first and had dessert and were out of there in one hour (of course we could have eaten more slowly but it was so good). For dessert, I got the pear tart with vanilla ice cream. It was too sweet for me because there was caramel sauce drizzled all over it. I imagined it being much more refreshing than it actually was. The caramel just made it heavy. I'm sure that's to some peoples taste though!
author: Brittney N.

description:
Lovely cozy setting, rather tight but comfortable. Owner very nice, service above standard.

The first batch of bread we got was delicious, but each consecutive basket got darker and darker.

Dad had the Onion Soup, the goat cheese salad and the Rack of Lamb. Onion soup was very salty. Salad was nice, and the lamb was apparently very nice.

Mother had the mussels, which came with fries. Mussels were decent and flavorful.

I had the escargot and the Rabbit Normandy. The snails were swimming in butter garlic herb sauce and tasted very little of snail as it was absurdly salty. The texture was like rubber before pureeing in my mouth, leaving a sort of unpleasant graininess in my mouth. I suspect hat they aren't fresh.

The rabbit was tender, but slightly dry and a bit bland. The carrots were not properly pureed and had small chunks of slightly hard bits in it.

We decided to go for some dessert to finish the dinner off. I opted for the cheese plate and a creme brulee for myself.

The cheese plate was tiny. Brie, gruier, and what looked like hard bleu with dried cranberries and apricots scattered about. The creme brulee was far less substantial than expected, but delicious.

All in all a decent enough experience, but it certainly did not blow any of us away. I'm certain there are better French restaurants out there with far better dishes and perhaps cheaper to boot.
author: Ivan J.

description:
I've have been blessed to travel the world and enjoy some of the finest of culinary efforts at home in the USA and abroad ~ I popped into the lovely Le P'tit Laurent located in the charming Glen Park neighborhood of San Francisco last evening . . . Oh my goodness! Tout était magnifique!!! I don't know how they do it ~ I've been in the huge, amazing kitchen at French Laundry and I'm quite certain that this kitchen is (how should I put it?) less epic ~ yet, what is created here is truly exceptional. Yes, going to those places such as former mentioned is fun and has its place but if you are like me and have grown to prefer finding amazing hidden gems, Le P'tit Laurent should be on your list. 

Thank you to everyone at Le P'tit Laurent for what you are doing and for a very lovely evening.
author: Lizanne T.

description:
Opted for the neighborhood menu again this time...but was disappointed to find a much shorter selection. Regardless, what was available was still very tasty. I opted for the heirloom tomato salad, sauteed red snapper with lentils, and poached pear.

The salad was to die for. It was so simple, but so good. The tomatoes were crisp and juicy. The dressing was a simple balsamic. The garnish was basil and feta cheese. Everything just went together so well. But if I tried to make this at home, I'd fail so miserably....sigh...next up was the snapper. The fish was sauteed to perfection. It was flaky and melt in your mouth good. The lentils complemented the fish nicely, but compared to the cauliflower puree that I had last time, it just wasn't as good. The poached pear dessert I opted for was not a great choice. It was swimming in chocolate sauce and covered with whipped cream. Had a bite of my friend's caramel french toast - now that was to die for!

The restaurant was also abnormally warm this time. It didn't take long for it to get really stuffy within.
author: Elaine Y.

description: We had a last minute booking through OpenTable on a busy Friday night. Lovely steak frites and cassoulet, and a great Bordeaux to drink. Overall nice atmosphere and felt like being in a small Parisian bistro. The service was ok - but to be expected given how packed the small restaurant was. Tarte Tatin was a bit disappointing but certainly didn't ruin the dining experience.
author: Denise P.

description:
Last time we went, we were really disappointed.  Bummer, because we really liked this place!

My BF's green beans were cold, but his filet mignon was awesome and made exactly how he asked. The older waitress was really short with us and seemed irritated that we sat down when she showed us to our table because it wasn't set yet.

Uhhh, why did you show us to the table if you didn't want us to sit down before you set it? Oh BTW, when setting the table, don't set the plates on one of the chairs. That's gross. People's bottoms go on those. Thanks.

It was my BF's mom's birthday and we thought we would treat her, but I ended up more embarrassed than anything.  Especially because the waitress was only pleasant when dropping off the bill.

She was definitely having an off day, but either way, it was disappointing to feel embarrassed and let down by one of my favorite neighborhood restaurants. I think we'll be taking a break for a while and go somewhere else. But eventually we might go back just to check on it. Who knows.

Bottom line: Use to be one of the best hole-in-the-wall restaurants, but seems to have lost it's charm.
author: Elena P.

description: We ordered the cheese omelette and the eggs beedict. So good. The yolk on the benedict was so good and runny (just how i like it) and the omelette was just perfection. The restaurant itself is decent sized, located at the corner with a bar. They also have bottlomless mimosas!
author: Christine C.

description: I'm from Santa Cruz and I don't get amazing French food like I had tonight!  The French onion soup was out of this world amazing, dark in color and perfect in taste. The seabass was amazing with the cream and caper sauce plus my dad had the rabbit and i discovered I love rabbit, witch as well was cooked to perfection! Over all I'll definitely be back next time I am up in the city!
author: Jodie H.

description:
Fantastic Sunday lunch! 
Very friendly stuff since the moment we walked in.
You really feel like you are in a little French bistro somewhere in Paris.
Everything we had, tasted incredible.
Escargot where to die for:) 
I am just going to say that before we left we book the table for our next visit!!
If you like french food- you can`t go wrong with this place!
author: Bianca G.

description:
One of the most enjoyable restaurants in San Francisco.  

The restaurant is an adorably decorated (petite) restaurant tucked in the Glen Park shopping district.  Again, there are only about 20 tables, so make sure to make a reservation.  You will find it's well worth it.

This past Thursday, after flying in town, my friend and I settled down for a nice cozy dinner.  They have a special menu for "locals" during the week, with a choice of two appetizers, two entrees and a desert from the desert list for 28 dollars, amazingly cheap!  However, this week they had a "tax month" special which was two courses (no dessert) for 20.15---sincerely, a great deal.

I ended up ordering off the menu, I had the escargot which was redolent with garlic, butter and parsley and the mussels, which are prepared in the French fashion, with more garlic and white wine.  Both were delicious, and I certainly enjoyed the crusty French bread that they served in order to sop up the garlic, butter and wine.  My friend had the tax month special, a salad with fried artichoke   he also had a huge lamb shank which was delicious.  

I have also had brunch here and it was wonderful, a great Croque Monsieur (which they added an egg to, which made it a Madame.)  It is a restaurant that I hope to go to often.

One other thing, visit the Bathroom...I think it's decorated so nicely.
author: Joshua L.

description: This is the neighborhood French restaurant that I wish was in my own neighborhood. It definitely pays to be a regular here (the staff has great memory), but I've still received great service despite only having come here twice. The food service is a little slow, but it really does allow for more of an intimate dining/talking experience, as opposed to just scarfing down your food. Get more bang for your buck by doing the neighborhood menu, or if you want to share a small snack with someone, go for mussels and fries.
author: Ghia G.

description: This is a warm and inviting restaurant that serves an excellent meal.  It is both a neighborhood place where you cat sit at the bar for a glass of wine and some French onion soup, enjoy a romantic date, or bring the family.
author: Kat M.

description: Perfect ambience, warm & gracious service, and delicious food. A gem in a city full of great restaurants.  You'll feel like you've slipped away to some little neighborhood in Paris. Take the trip!
author: Angela G.

description:
We were satisfied with the overall experience despite not having a reservation. We were told only the bar would be available and that there was a bar across the street, to wait for our seats. The bar was a cash only dive, however Moscow mules were 4 bucks, so not bad for a 30 minute wait. They ended up giving us a table!

We started with escargot, very hot but the remaining sauce worked well with the remaining bread. My wife had the beef cheek, very generous portion, and I had the lamb shank, which has an abundance of fresh flavored green beans. Both were very tender and succulent.

My wife is with child, but I enjoyed 2 glasses of an enjoyable Bordeaux.

Capped it off with crème brûlée. We wanted to try the French toast so maybe next time.

Great value for a date night.
author: Jason B.

description:
If you want authentic French food this is the place to go to. The super friendly staff will welcome you with a warm bonjour.
My husband and I shared a cassoulet and a great rabbit stew. The portions were dissent. For dessert we had profiteroles. I'm pretty picky about profiteroles and I have to say they were really good.
Laurent the owner is very attentive to his guests. We had a nice chat in French.
As a native I  love coming back to this place.
author: Carolyn B.

description:
I don't often give restaurants five stars, but when I do, it's for unpretentious, cozy, delicious places like Le P'tit Laurent (which on iTunes would have been censored as "Le P*** Laurent).

My girlfriend is French and told me she felt right at home as soon as we entered. Off to a good start! After getting over our initial shock of how affordable the menu was for a French restaurant, we settled on the prix-fixe, which came with a smoked salmon appetizer, steak and fries main course, and delicious sorbet dessert.

With the ambiance and staff both charming and down to earth, as well as a delicious and affordable menu, I couldn't justify giving this place less than a perfect review.

We will definitely be back.
author: Teiki K.

description:
Adorable and delicious little French restaurant in an equally adorable neighborhood.

We loved Le P'tit so much that we ate here twice during our vacation in SF. It's a small place, so be sure to make a reservation. Our first visit, it was completely packed on a week night but we were able to eat at the bar. The second visit, we made a reservation and scored a nice table in the corner with a window view. The atmosphere is great and very European. Food was prepared beautifully.
author: Michele F.

description:
I have been here twice now. 

The food is always good. The onion soup is tasty and te soup of the day last time was a creamy fish soup that was amazing. Ive had the steak once, the braised lamb shank. Also we have tried the neighborhood menu which is a rock solid 25 $steal with soup and desert. The waiters are great, and force you to eat if you dont finish your plates sometimes. 


Cheers!
author: Benjamin B.

description:
My friends and i popped in here for a quick breakfast before getting on bart and it was very delicious! It is definitely a small place and gets filled up but the owners make it work. The service was impeccable plus there french accents are adorable. 

They give you warm bread as an appetizer. I got the vegetarian omelette which was sooo delicious, and they give the meals with fries and some greens. My friend got some grilled egg cheese sandwich thing, we were all pleased. 

It looks like they have a full bar for you hangover aficionados.

Merci!
author: Kathleen D.

description: Perfect date night! Charming, dark, and delicious. Bouillabaisse was great (not former Chez Papa perfection, but really nothing's ever gonna stack up), the wine was tasty and reasonable, and the service was just lovely. My husband's cream of mushroom soup was to die for. The Neighborhood Menu is a great deal if you like what's on it.
author: Brynn D.

description:
ah, voila, c'est la France, non?

Stepping inside from the busy corner of Chenery and Diamond, warmly greeted by a charming tres jolie woman and shown to a table, the evening begins.

Lovely menu, although the type face chosen is a bit hard to read in the dim light. So many wonderful choices, and so French. And the wines, wonderful choices, by the glass or bottle.

Desserts delightful, pain perdu not lost on us.

Great meal, lovely welcome, great service, and well priced. Comment si bon!

What's not to like? Enjoy!
author: William M.

description:
It was date night so the honey and I ended up here, not really hungry but wanting drinks.

We ordered the lobster bisque, which was fantastic if not incredibly rich and used our slightly burnt bread given with butter, to dip.

The service when we were seated was friendly and warm, but a soon as our waitress discovered we only wanted drinks we received a low level of judgment for the rest of the meal.

Prices were right for the food, and the company was fabulous, but the service tinted an otherwise wonderful evening.
author: Meg T.

description:
Looks like a promising French venue, but my expectations were not met. My boyfriend made a reservation via OpenTable and we got seated immediately. After we ordered, we received our wine and bread promptly. Our escargot came dressed with something that is similar to a pesto sauce, it definitely wasn't the best escargot I've had. 45 minutes later and seeing how three parties who were seated after us got their entrees, we received our food after asking where it was. 

I think the worst part is the fact that I could not hear myself think, it's such a small restaurant that the noise travel everywhere. I had to practically shout when talking and it didn't help that we were hungry and irritated. While my sea bass was delicious, I just wish the risotto wasn't made with what appears to be canned peas and carrots? The cassoulet my boyfriend ordered was so salty that it was not enjoyable. The side of fries was nice. For $100, our experience here should've been better.

If you're looking for a nice romantic night out, this place wouldn't be my first choice.
author: Kawai N.

description:
FRENCH TOAST WILL NEVER BE THE SAME. Trust me on this one, you will take one bite and stop chewing, look to the person you came with and say "OH MY GOD" 

You won't even know what hit you.
author: Gabbi R.

description: Cute spot, lovely decor. It definitely looks like a Parisienne bistro. Varied wine list. The salade tomate is really good--organic, nice vinaigrette.. The food gras comes with apple sauce which was too sweet for me. Tried the French onion soup. They brought it out. It looked like Lipton soup with some bits of cheese on top, so I asked for the cheese to be melted . The waiter asked if I wanted more cheese, & I said not really just please broil it. Like--this soup costs over $9. They brought it back again but still no melted. 3rd time was the charm, although some cheese was hard, some burned & way too much cheese. Sigh--although the broth was really flavorful, there was really not enough broth. Chez Maman in Potrero Hill serves a perfect FOS, for $6--$3 bucks cheaper--so I think I'll go over there from now on.
author: Scott F.

description:
Ah, my favorite neighborhood restaurant! 

Le P'tit Laurent serves up some truly delicious, quality french food at a fairly affordable price. 

Their service is sweet and atmosphere cozy. I recommend coming Sunday-Thursday for their neighborhood menu which includes three courses for around $25.
author: Casey M.

description: We've been here before and I remember the food and service being good, but tonight was just a little better. It is small so even with a reservation you may have to wait. I might recommend a 7ish time slot as it seems to slow down a bit by then. I had the steak frites with red wine sauce. It came out the perfect medium and the sauce was incredible. For desert I had the caramelized French toast and it was spectacular. I'm kind of a crackhead for caramel and this thing covered all the bases. It is somewhat pricey but well worth it in my opinion. Service was excellent. Very friendly and very understanding of our 3 mo son kicking it with us at the table. This place is worth the effort.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I had one of my best dining experience!

Good recommendation by my favorite couple and also one of my closest friends. We had a double late birthday dinner date. I made a reservation for 4. We came maybe 15 mins early but it wasn't such a big deal because we ended up ordering some wine in their bar area. Just when we got our drinks, our table was ready and our friends arrived too, perfect timing. It was the longest enjoyable dinner I've ever had, 7:30 - Past 10. The conversation made it so the timing of our food from appetizer to dessert give our tummy a little room for each course.

 I ordered the Escargot for my appetizer. I may be the wrong person to talk about it because it's my favorite. I don't want to be biased but all I could say is, I almost forgot to let my man have a piece so he could try my appetizer and didn't really realize this until there was just one piece left. My main course was the Lapin (french for rabbit) and yes, I just ate a bunny for dinner. It was so tender and the sweetness of the onions on it gave it a really good flavor. I had profiteroles for dessert before but here seemed better? 

Wish this place isn't too far from us!
author: Lora M.

description: The restaurant is cute. The food is the opposite of cute! Been here three times and each time the food is horrible. Cold fish one night, bad mussels another  and the last dish I'll ever have here is steak frites...which was a porter house steak drenched in some mushroom wine gnarly sauce...just awful and medium well was served bleeding. I want to like this place so bad but my stomach is yelling at me to never go back.
author: Gigi G.

description:
First time having French food, absolutely delicious.

I had the portobello homemade ravioli and the beef tenderloin steak. When I first entered the place, service was great, very friendly. It was a bit small, but the ambiance was really nice. It wasn't too loud and every employee was very welcoming.

The ravioli was very delicious and was perfectly cooked. Usually ravioli's is very cheesy inside, but this one was soft enough to taste more of the flavors. The creamy mushroom sauce they toppled over was very good and they also included some more mushrooms within the sauce. It sounds like a dish that would taste very "mushroomy" but it actually wasn't, it taste more creamy and light. 

The beef tenderloin steak was heaven! They did not ask how you wanted it to be cooked, but maybe its because they cook it a certain way already? However, it was fine, very soft, not chewy. It was medium rare, and everything that went with the dish balanced out the taste. Definitely recommend this place!
author: Tina N.

description:
(Review #400!) I haven't really explored Glen Park & am thrilled Le P'tit Laurent took my virginity.  What a cute, cozy French restaurant.  I'm glad we had a reservation because there were folks queued up for a chance to dine while a table for 2 awaited us.  :)  We shared everything so not to deprive the other from tastes.

Fresh mozzarella and red beet Napoleon, balsamic vinaigrette - we're both beet lovers.  This was a delicious salad.  The sweet beets were balanced by the balsamic vinaigrette.

Escargots from Burgundy in a garlic parsley butter - garlic...butter...need I say more?  Of course I OD'd on the bread sopping up every drop of butta!
 
Sautéed bass served with vegetables risotto, capers sauce - fresh & 1 of the lighter (comparatively) dishes.

Lamb shank braised for six hours, French green beans, rosemary sauce - come to mama!  Hearty, flavorful with a rich sauce.

Room for dessert? Of course!

Vanilla Ice Cream Profiteroles, Warm Chocolate Sauce - mmmm a standard.  The 
chocolate sauce was also dark/semi-sweet.

Caramelized French Toast, Caramel Ice Cream - wow, sounds innocent but quite a vixen.  The bread was brioche so rich & pillowy.  Yuummmm!  Didn't want to share but I was a good girl & shared.
author: Kim S.

description:
friendly staff and chill atmosphere but uninspired food.

I had the prix fixe, which was considerably cheaper than the rest of the menu. beef was dry with a boring flavor. same with the potatoes. I like wine when it's served out of nice big wine glasses with a delicate lip.  not here.  you get heavy cafeteria style wine glasses. maybe the non prix fixe would have been a better choice, but then I would feel like I was over paying, unless it was really considerably better than what I ordered.

not bad if you just want a lively place to gather with friends, but skip it if you're looking for an impressive meal.
author: Jimming C.

description:
This review is a long time coming for a spot the wife and I have returned to time and again when hungry for a hearty meal in a cozy spot close to home. A recent visit to the more heralded Central Parc followed soon after by our umpteenth dinner at Le P'Tit underscored the importance of getting out the word that the Glenn Park Frenchie is the City's top French bistro. I honestly can't recall a more satisfying meal out. From value ($27 3-course prefix Sunday to Thursday) to food quality to service, this neighborhood stalwart blew away the unfortunately overrated Central Parc. 

This evening, my wife and I both went with the vegetable cream soup (with a hot baguette on the side to sop it up with) and the short ribs, all off the prefix menu, followed by the otherworldly Pan Perdu for dessert (also included in the prefix deal). We returned our plates sparkling clean, having devoured every last bit of each dish. Le PTit's soups in particular are consistently outstanding, with a taste and texture that the wife and I have yet to be able to repeat at home despite being soup aficionados.

In addition, with it's mishmash of French curiosities all about and huge, old-school mirrors, there's really not a more charming and cozy French spot around. Add onto that a full bar and Voila!, this place stands out as the crème de la crème brûlée (which they also do very well, by the way). We've now been through the entire French bistro circuit in S.F. and it turns out our neighborhood go-to is simply put the best there is at what they do.
author: Matthew Z.

description: Neighborhood Menu is definitely a steal!  And from the looks of the dishes, the portions aren't smaller than ordering the dishes off of the regular menu.  Overall the food was good, but a lot of dishes weren't very memorable.  For the price though I can't complain.  The one stand out dish I had was the mussels.  Cooked to perfection!  I hate it when mussels are overcooked and chewy so I really enjoyed this dish.  The broth with nice and flavorful and the mussels were a great size.  Not too small.  And there were a lot of them!  For the value, I would definitely recommend trying this place.  But since I don't live in the area I probably won't go out of my way to come back.
author: Elena N.

description: This is my neighborhood spot when I'm craving for home-style french food.  It's not your La Folie, Gary Danko, or French Laundry, so don't expect that.  It's casual and cozy with great tasting dishes, generous portions at reasonable prices.  The last couple of times I was there, I had the three course special - delicious from start to finish.  Kind'a cool that the staff speak fluent French too...and English (w/French accent).
author: Leland H.

description:
First meal was at this delightful French bistro on a bustling and sunny Friday Eve after moving (!) to the neighborhood. I was in the midst of an awful post-move cold and was in a total state...

Until my moules frites arrived.

And then I'm pretty sure my happiness went off the charts. The flavors were perfection, and I enjoyed families, friends, and the like coming together to this very special -- yet altogether approachable -- restaurant. My partner and I also shared a baked goat cheese salad with Dijon dressing that was so lovely we contemplated a second order. 

This is going to become a staple of my next years in the community. I know it, and can't wait to try the rest of the menu when I am far more lucid.
author: Courtney J.

description: There is nothing p'tit about Le P'tit Laurent! Big flavors and big love go into the preparation of their amazing selections! Close your eyes and you could believe you are in a quaint Paris restaurant. It's simply charming, as is Laurent and his wait staff. Try the charcuterie - delicious, but everything was!
author: Pam G.

description:
Made a reservation here for brunch on a Sunday afternoon. This place is super quaint! The decor is nice, the staff is superb, and the food was delicious! Had no issues whatsoever with the reservation, though it seemed like it would have been okay without one. It wasn't too busy at noon.

The brunch menu is pretty limited, but there were some fantastic choices (everything looked delicious). Your typical eggs benedict/french toast options, as well as some fancier/expensive options. They have a bottomless mimosa for $14! (Their cocktails looked rather good as well, would try them too if not for the mimosa...) Highly recommended. They definitely did not hesitate to give us refills, and were definitely generous with the alcohol side (though they might have started light). They give you some bread/butter to start too.

The staff was incredibly attentive. Always had water, always had drinks, and food came out incredibly quickly for what we ordered. We were feeling a little bit fancier, so we ended up getting the steamed mussels with white wine and garlic (highly recommended) and the New York steak with the shallot and cabernet sauvignon sauce. Both came with french fries and mayo/ketchup on the side.

The mussels were really quite delicious. That sauce! Probably terrible for you, but it was the right amount of salty and savory. The steak came with a small salad on the side and it was cooked to a perfect medium rare. Paired with the sauce was definitely perfect. Portions seemed just right (tons of mussels, two small medallions worth of steak, which was more than enough for me) and between the two of us we were able to finish all of our food and still have room for dessert (pleasantly full for sure).

After such a pleasant Sunday afternoon experience, we couldn't resist ordering the vanilla bean crème brûlée as well, which was very tasty; the perfect amount of sweetness with a nice crunchy top shell.

Twas not a cheap brunch. I'll give it that (we also ordered... a lot). All in all came out to be about $40 a person (before tip) for the whole thing... but it was sooooooo worth it. Would definitely go back to try their dinner and prix fixe menu, since my friend recommended it and it seemed to be very reasonable for a French restaurant. If anything, the service really made this place shine! Definitely small, could see it getting crowded, and the seats are pretty tightly packed next to each other. Still somehow managed to feel very cosy with very little space.

Places like this are what makes San Francisco great to eat and experience! Only reason why I would brave all that traffic/lack of parking :D
author: Denise C.

description: Had a really great experience at Le P'tit Laurent. Phenomenal service and food for the money. Staff was attentive and made sure that we had a great dinner for our mother's birthday.
author: Jonathan J.

description:
Now that Chenary Park is gone Glen Park is essentially down to Le P'tit Laurent and a Japanese restaurant.  Within 5 mile radius you have a dearth of choice for French food.  You do have Chou Chou (which you should eschew at all cost) up at Dewey, and this restaurant.

Best alternative for Twin Peaks, Diamond Heights, West Portal and of course Glen Park.

The first time we went:
We went on a Friday night, slipped into the last 2 bar seats by the door without reservations.  Of course we didn't complain.  Get seats away from the door.  The bar manager was excellent in serving a row of 8 diners, making drinks and managing the cash register.  She even had time to correct some of our French.

She made and poured our cocktails (nicely done),  and then regularly poured our bottle of wine for us.

The food was lovely.  Oysters fresh, the sauces for lamb, the rabbit, the duck.  All rich and flavorful.  Salad frisee had a nice mix of frisee, lardon (bacon bits) generous with the poached egg warm.

Wine prices average and selection average.  Menu limited but enough of a selection to have fun.

Our bill, 3 appetizers, 2 entrees, and a bottle of wine (lowest end) $185 before tip.

We felt we found home.

The second time we went:
This was a Saturday night, we made reservations late so got a 9pm seating.  Kitchen closes at 10:30pm - be forewarned.

Diners were leaving and the restaurant was at best half full.  The bar had 2 remaining diners.  We were seated at a table by the door even though the restaurant was half empty.  Wear a down jacket.

No waiter showed up until we got up and found a sulky blond one chatting away to a table of 6 dining (could be other waiters relaxing).  His service throughout the evening was tired, cross and petulant like a child in need of his nap or sent to his room without supper.

There was another waiter that showed up periodically to see if we needed anything but you got the sense he was just checking how far we were to leaving.

They got part of our order wrong.  The food was tepid and part of one of our entree was cold, as if whatever was in there hadn't dethawed properly.  

Our bill with the bottle of wine roughly the same.  After we paid, the blond grumpy one asked if we wanted dessert.  

Lesson learned:  If you go, get a seating before 9pm.  Get a seat on the bar or a table away from the door.  Food is good, not worth the suffering and not worth the cold, so just adhere to the lessons learned and you'll have fun.
author: S P.

description: Came here with three others. We were all very happy with the service, the food, the ambiance. All I can say is try it...you'll like it!
author: George S.

description:
This city was built on great food.   Jeremiah Towers, Alice Waters, the French Mafia that started at the South Park Cafe, crossed Market to beachhead on Claude Lane, then colonize Belden Place.  Gerald Hirigoyen at Fringale, crossing Market again to create Bocadillo, Piperade. Chapeau! One word, endless pleasure.
Great.  French. Food.

I had been meaning to get to LP Laurent for a long while, a little neighborhood place, cozy, unpretentious, like wandering out of a cool Parisian Fall night into a warmly lit bistro with food simple, but excellent and excellently adhering to a long tradition.   

Laurent manages to flout and foil all the traditions and aspirations of the restaurateurs who've preceded them.

What a dreadful place!

I ordered escargot, moules, and ratatouille with gnocchi (is this even french? or italian?).  They all arrived within 5 minutes.  Together.  The escargot were hot.  Only the escargot.   

As has been said in other reviews, the snails were drowned in pesto, which wasn't great but was tasty.   The mussels had been good whenever they were made, but that hadn't been for a few hours.  Is that necessary, or even possible, to pre-cook mussels? 

The ratatouille was oxidized, greyish vegetables in an overly acidic brownish tomato sauce that may have been homemade or not, but tasted like canned sauce stored in an open can for good while.  The gnocchi were claimed as homemade, which is likely because no commercial concern could survive selling these dense, sweaty, turdlets.   

I eschewed anything else on the menu after these dishes out of fear of what they might've served me, then resented leaving the waiter a decent percentage on the price of the "meal" even though it was probably least his fault.  Though, in fairness, he can't be ignorant of what he is serving.  Or, better said, perpetrating.  

What a waste of a meal.
author: Marc M.

description:
This is an OK place for a neighborhood joint, but it's not really worth going out of your way for. 

I had the mussels which were ok, but they were very small. The fries were good. My BF had the Osso Bucco, which was good and a big portion. The appetizer, chicken croquettes. was terrible. I've had better food from the demo station at TJs (seriously, I'm not being snarky).

Service was good and the place is cute but for the price and the quality of the food it's just not really worth it.
author: Mike M.

description:
This review is for BRUNCH ONLY.

We went the other week for brunch and it was pretty empty. The actual restaurant is really cute and in a great Glen Park location. The staff was really nice and we liked our waiter a lot.

So, why the 3 stars?

The two dishes we ordered for breakfast were lousy. The croque monsieur was greasy and inedible. The omelet was tasteless. We ended up not eating very much (other then the bread) and leaving hungry. I will never go back for brunch but I hear dinner is much better.
author: M K.

description:
Mais non, cheri.  You can do oh-so-much better than here.  C'est dommage, too, because it's a great location, and a great concept, the neighborhood bistrot.

The lamb was salty to borderline inedible, accompanying potatoes roasted to mush.  The by-the-glass Bordeaux was passable with the lamb, but astringent on its own, and the tarte tatin, doused in caramel over bitter apples, with no pastry to speak of.

Generous portions, but when it's not good food, what's the point?  Ambiance also busy and boisterous.  I found myself pining for some noise-canceling headphones.

Sorry.  Doubt I'll be back.
author: Theresa B.

description: I am no expert, but my steak was absolutely delish. I would come back here again for the cozy atmosphere. Perfect date spot. Great French food with an authentic vibe. The service was top notch and you feel pampered getting new silverware after each dish! Also, the creme brûlée was absolutely fantastic.
author: Brendan C.

description:
Do you like French food?
You should come here even when you're not in the mood. 
This place is really a cute hole-in-the-wall 
If you didn't know you would see it at all. 
I had the special scallops with risotto,
But we aren't fat so we skipped the gelato. 
We also had the clams which were so good we wanted another.
It's definitely a place you want to take your lover. 
The atmosphere was nice and cozy 
And even have a nice bar if you're beer-crazy.
Making a poem is really tough. 
But trust me you really wanna go try this stuff!!
author: Henry N.

description:
(rounded up from 4.5)
The cassoulet was magnifique! The service was also quite good. A little expensive for a restaurant that's kind of cramped and not very unique inside.
author: Tyler B.

description:
I love this little gem bistro...Every time I have been there, I feel like we were in France! This is the only place where the waiter is taking care of you and your children while enjoying a beautiful dinner! Laurent and his team are so friendly and professional that it is always a blast to go and have dinner over there. laurent is so funny that he should be also an actor or a clown if one day he wants to change his career. 
I seems to always take the same courses right, but hey, I cook meat at home and don't have the opportunity to buy and cook mussels, foie gras or fish at home. So Honestly...go for the tuna or crab salad with avocado...a must, then the mussels and frites, unless you are scared of garlic...;) then "La cerise sur le gateau " as French says...The Pain Perdu...so delightful and unique, nothing to compare with our heavy breakfast French toast. The Rabbit is a must too...slurp slurp slurp... My friends, last time, had the rack of lamb and the early special dinner with some prawns and a beet salad and seemed to love it too. They even have Frog legs sometimes on the menu! loved it!
The wine selection is amazing and at what cost? gosh so much cheaper than all these chichi fusion Californian French restaurants where you can't have a decent bottle of wine under $60! we always start with a Lillet or their very nice cocktail with St Germain liquor! And Laurent even offered a bottle of wine for my friend Birthday...she was so impressed! Such a nice touch!
I tell you what? Le P'tit Laurent will stay my favorite restaurant for a long time...I bet you you won't find a better affordable restaurant with this service and this great food! Thumps up!!!
author: Sophie L.

description:
We arrived on a Friday evening for date night while our seven-year-old was at a school function. We thought we had a confirmed reservation through Open Table for 6:15pm, but it apparently got lost in the ether. Laurent was apologetic, even though it wasn't his fault, said they were fully booked but offered us a quaint table at the end of the bar. It turned out to be the perfect spot.

It was our first time here, so we tried the Onion Soup and oysters (Fanny Bay this evening). Both were very good starters and well-prepared. I decided on the cassoulet but my fiancée was torn between three dishes. Laurent stopped by our table, asked if there was anything she didn't like and asked if he could surprise her, to which we agreed. My fiancée got a perfectly roasted rabbit with a lovely carrot puree. My cassoulet was full and rich in flavour, albeit just a wee bit too salty. We also had a nice merlot from Languedoc. For dessert, the chocolate souffle with pear sorbet was divine.

We had a lovely evening, were treated like regulars and the check did not make us gasp. We will definitely return on our next date night.
author: Michael j g.

description:
Food: 2/5
Service: 5/5 
Setting: 5/5
Value: 2/5

Nice little French restaurant. We were a group of 6, and had a very good time overall at Le P'tit Laurent. Unfortunately the food wasn't great... Several of my friends and I took escargots in appetizer, and mussels & fries as a main dish. The escargots weren't very good, and the sauce was very disappointing (I wonder if they even put garlic in it). As for the main dish, the french fries were perfect, but the mussels were suspicious... some of them we even wondered if we should eat them -- they had a distinct fishy smell, were too soft and even somewhat milky. Overall they weren't terrible (we ate them all!), but definitely not "good".

A friend of mine got the cassoulet as a main dish, and he loved it. Desserts were good, too.

For that quality of food, it felt overpriced. 

The rest was great -- service was very friendly, efficient, and the setting of the room was cute and comfortable. And the bathrooms were clean. 

Overall, maybe we got unlucky with our selection... If you go there, I'd recommend avoiding the escargots and mussels!
author: Olivier C.

description:
I liked the area that this restaurant was located in, nestled in the Glen View area it was away from your usual bustling SF. It was easy to find street parking and a short walk to the restaurant while passing by little shops and a quiet neighborhood. 

The restaurant it self was "cozy". My definition of cozy: small but made you feel warm and comfortable right away. The lighting was just right to make you feel like you have your own privacy even though the tables were pretty snug. My boyfriend and I had reservations at 6:15 and they were able to seat us at 6, there were still a few open tables left but quickly filled up by the time we started on our appetizers.

French bread and butter was served on the house. Great french bread, naturally buttery, crunchy outside and soft on the inside. And they kept refilling our basket when we were down to three pieces.

We ordered:

Escargot: It was de-shelled and smothered in garlic sauce. I was kind of disappointed that they were de-shelled, because half of the experience of eating escagot was to de-shell it yourself. But I didn't get to do that. =( The sauce it self was pretty good, my bf really liked the sauce, but I thought it was too garlicky and overpowered the natural taste of the escargot.
 
Soup of the Day: Some sort of Chicken corn thing (I think). This one hit the spot, probably my favorite dish of the night. I didn't have too high of an expectation for the soup of the day, but this one was excellent. It had the right amount of your chicken soup flavor and it was creamy...and there was another flavor to it but I can't recall what. 

Foie Gras: I am a fan of Foie Gras, (but not a connoisseur) so whenever and where ever they serve it I'd always want to try it. This one I'll have to say was not my favorite. Probably mostly due to the fact that it was served cold. I find that I prefer it pan roasted just because it really brings out the aroma, plus it kind of melts the fat. However, this one was not bad, I liked that there were pieces of apple (or pear?) that was stuck into the foie gras and it gives it a bit more texture. It came with caramelized onions which was very good. 

Rabbit: My boyfriend had the rabbit entree that came with potatoes. The meat was almost like dark meat chicken. I was expecting a gamey taste just from what I've heard. But I didn't taste it in the dish at all. It was seasoned pretty well and the potatoes were great. Nice and buttery red skin potatoes. My boyfriend liked it.
 
Veal Paupiettes: I'd have to say by the time I got to my entree, I was getting pretty full. So my judgement may be a bit off. I thought this was just an okay dish, especially since it was one of the more expensive ones on the entree menu. I wasn't necessarily disappointed because I have never had veal (I don't think) so I didn't know what to expect. It looked like it was veal stuffed with small pieces of sausage and probably mashed potatoes and there were strips of bacon around the meat. When I eat meat, I like it prepared as simple as possible so that I can still taste the flavor of the meat. I thought the bacon and the addition of sausages took that away from the veal. All the additional items also made my dish feel more like meat loaf which I am not a big fan of. The dish came with some mushrooms and spinach as sides, they were season well but a bit too salty for my taste. 

All in all the food was three stars, the ambiance was cute, I would recommend for a date night with your boyfriend if you are looking for a romantic setting (the lighting and candle lit table was nice). The waiter was friendly and funny. I noticed he came by a our table quite often to just look over our shoulders to make sure our water jug and bread basket was filled without disturbing us.
author: Amy L.

description: This place is lovely! The food is really great. We ordered the fish and it was one of the best meals we had in a long time. The Apple tart is amazing as well.
author: Julia B.

description:
Cute little neighborhood restaurant.  Very friendly service, could use a little better ventilation on warm nights though.  It's gets a bit toasty in there. Our party had a variety of dishes and they were all very good.

- The mussels had a nice garlicky broth that I wanted to drink as a soup. 
- they had a sea bass special the night I went and the fish was cooked just right with a salsa of some sort, can't remember if it was mango or papaya.  You could tell they used buttering he sauce!
-  filet of beef was nice and tender, just pink in the middle. 
-  the crab and avocado salad just melted in your mouth. The perfect ratio of  crab to avocado with micro greens of some sort. 
- my friend declared the French onion soup as the best ever but I didn't try it. 

For a French restaurant the only disappointment was the profiteroles.  The pate choux was harder than what I usually prefer in a puff pastry. I prefer it to be light and airy rather than hard and crisp like theirs. Overall a good experience but a bit in the pricey side.
author: Heather G.

description: My husband and I flew into San Francisco for a long weekend trip and were looking for a cozy, unpretentious restaurant with good food and Le P'tit Laurent fit the bill. We were there on a Thursday night and their special was a 2-course meal (appetizer and entrée) for $24.  My husband had the squid salad and I had the salmon appetizers. We both had the seafood ragout as our entrée. The appetizers and entrees were cooked perfectly. Good food and reasonable priced. We very much enjoyed ourselves.
author: Tiffany G.

description:
Authentic bistro fare and ambience as well as great service. We ran late because of an Uber fiasco, and the host could not have been more gracious when I called, then held the table for 30 minutes on a busy Friday. 

Our meal was well prepared and delicious, and our server was perfectly attentive. We shall return.
author: Jill S.

description:
I went for diner by myself to Le P'tit Laurent.  I was greeted by Laurent who seated me at the bar with a glass of Bordeaux while they waited for a place to free up for diner. 

As an appetizer, I had the tuna carpacio with spouts and ginger and capers.  It was really good.   the ginger mixed very nicely with the various sprouts and herbs (parsley, coriander and water cress).  I was really surprised by the mix of flavors, it worked really well. 

I then had the rabbit..... WOW. Very very tasty, Also with herbs and a nice sauce.  Served with some mashed potatoes. 

The desert was their french toast with caramel ice cream and caramel sauce.   A very nice desert to end with. 

I enjoyed the place. It is nice to see a bustling atmosphere with Laurence greeting a lot of customers who are obviously regulars.  

I will come back with my wife  --- who happens to be French  ;-)
author: JJ B.

description:
After walking by the packed restaurant several times, I was excited to finally give it a go.

In short - A bit of a disappointment. Good friendly service though.

The escargot was good but I think the snails were cut in half or they were the world's smallest snails. One of holders was missing a snail and was filled with the butter sauce.
Foie gras appetizer was 'ok'.
Steak & Fries were 'ok'. Steak had no flavor on its own and the bernaise sauce wasn't good.
Lamb shank was dry and lacked any sort of flavor.

I'd only go back during pre fixe days if ever. 

On top of it all, the restaurant was so loud I couldn't even hear myself think.
author: Con L.

description:
Some may argue there are better French restaurants in the city and they may have a legitimate point.  All I know is... Le P'tit Laurent is my favorite French restaurant in SF and should be included in that argument.

The cassoulet was made to perfection...the duck melted into the beans and was seasoned just right.  Other restaurants simply add random meats/sausages to beans and call it a cassoulet... not here...this one is done right!  The moule frites is as good as any we had along the Cote d'Azur.  The broth was...well...we would have been happy with just the broth.  Simply wonderful.  The Pain Perdu is worth every bit of praise it receives.  Will admit, I was a bit skeptical about having "French Toast" for dessert...but wow.  May have to start with this dish next time.

The service is great...the restaurant is small, so they will get crowded and busy, but the staff manage to take care of their guests.

Excellent neighborhood bistro!
author: Zoran L.

description:
MMMMMMMMMMM.  Went here last night with friends.  We got the beet salad, foie gras (yum)  escargot, tuna tartare.  SO GOOD.
