I was craving cassoulet, which was why we tried this place, initially, and that was super good.  Huge duck confit leg in there.  Drool.  My one friend had the lamb, and the sauce was amazing.  My other two friends had the steak, and they loved it as well.  Desserts were great.  Had the french toast, the crepe with fennel and the apple tart.  
The service was excellent, and I will be going back here for sure!!
author: Lisa M.

description: Tremendous French cuisine with excellent service at reasonable San Francisco prices. Tucked away in leafy Glen Park this little gem of a restaurant makes you feel like you've been there a hundred times before.  The menu changes so you may want to stop by a few days in advance to see what's cooking.  But count on well prepared and delicious options.  Highly recommended.
author: Kurt L.

description:
Once my favorite restaurant. 

Last night's meal was inedible: 

Frisee aux lardons: made with american bacon, and not real 'lardons'. Basically, a bowl of vinegar and oscar myer. yuck.  
Steak Tartare: mixed hamburger with mustard and KETCHUP. Waitress said they put Ketchup in the steak tartare...degeullasse...sent back. gross. 
Bouillabaisse sauce rouille: basically chunks of fish in a pink mashed potato sauce. not actually a sauce rouille. 
Moules Frites: flavorless sauce, but eaten due to starvation. Sysco French Fries were good. 
Profiteroles: unsweetened chocolate sauce, tasted like unsweetened Hershey powder and cream with crushed chalk. the ice cream and profiteroles were very good, but the sauce was very bad.

Also, a woman had the birthday song and at the end I said 'Brava', because that is feminin for Bravo. The waiter corrected me and said 'Bravo' in a nasty tone. I don't think he realized 'he' is actually wrong. Judging by the way she held her girlfriend's hand, I'd say she was a lesbian, so kind of a double insult to the both of us. 

This was once my favorite restaurant. So many meals and so dear to my heart. But after last night's meal...completement échoué .
author: Steve B.

description:
What a cute little French Bistro! We arrived here for brunch today with 11:00am reservations for party of 6. All the besties were able to agree on a date to celebrate my best friend's birthday (which was last Sunday when I took her to Epic Roadhouse).
We were seated quickly at a nice little round table in the corner. La P'tit Laurent definitely has a French appeal. Quaint. Very charming & intimate.
We were given complimentary bread, a warm and crusty baguette. We all started with mimosas.  Our service was a bit slow but heck, its Sunday brunch time. Besides, our waitress was a real sweetheart. For appetizer, we ordered Escargot. Actually they were so exceptionally good, we ordered 2 orders
 They came out steaming hot in their own ramekins, full of garlicky goodness, parsley & oozing with butter.  TO DIE FOR!!!!!  We used our bread to soak up that yummy butter. A MUST TRY!
For my main, I ordered the Croque Madame, served with a salad & french fries. That's the french's version of classic ham & cheese. It was just PERFECT. The bread was lightly crusted. Oh....It WAS THE STAR OF BRUNCH. 2 other gals ordered the same as me, and 3 others ordered some kind of omelettes that looked delicious with potatoes.
For dessert, a couple of gals were full so we ordered again, 2 orders to share of the Pain Perdue with a glazed caramel sauce to share. It was light & flavorful, and tasted like a toasted marshmallow.  FABULOUS!
Yep, this place is definitely a 5 star for me. And....on my list of Top 5 Brunch establishments!
author: Janet T.

description:
Walked by this little restaurant on the corner many times before I went in to try.  Was drawn in by the Sunday brunch menu offerings: smoked salmon salad, mussels, escargot to name a few...MMMMMM!  

My friend and I went around 1pm on a Sunday afternoon and were seated right away.  The staff was extremely friendly and more than happy to help us with anything we needed.  We ordered the items mentioned above and enjoyed them immensely.  The only downside was that the smoked salmon was a bit on the salty side, but other than that, everything tasted wonderful!  They also provide complimentary bread and butter (the bread being soft in the middle with a crust on the outside that is hard, but not too hard).  Also ordered a mimosa which was wonderful...$10 for one or $14 for bottomless.  Should definitely have gotten the bottomless mimosa, but I guess that will have to be for another time. :)  

Overall, a good place that I want to go back to for Sunday brunch, but also for their other meal times to see what else they offer.
author: Jennifer C.

description: In the mood for something hearty...get the cassoulet.  A little high for price for the portion but it's definitely good.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
Monday Night, Neighborhood menu $25 3 course meal (Zuchinni Bisque, flank steak, profiteroles and French Toast Dessert) , Mussels with fries, 6 escargots, BYOW ($15 Corkage), Not crowded, and a whole loaf of bread...

Set in an intimate and lovely setting like you were transported into France. Even the fork and spoon details are beautiful. It was a beautiful Date Night.

All this for 2 people cost $120 with tax and tip inlcuded....

An absolute Gem.
author: Q A.

description:
this adorable gem is such a charming neighborhood restaurant! and the staff.. AMAZING! the service was impeccable I tell ya!! 

I decided not to go with the $25 prix fixe, even though it's such a steal. instead, i went for osso buco as my entree... the meat was so freaking flavorful, tender and the spinach was cooked to perfection! the polenta was also quite tasty and it was just perfect in this dish!! btw, the portions are HUGE! 

make sure you save room in your belly for some dessert! you HAVE to order the pain perdu! it's their specialty! it's like caramelized French toast! this is just one of those dishes that get better with each bite! makes you wanting more after you finish. 

I most definitely cannot wait to come back to le p'tit laurent and try some of their other menu items!
author: Ann T.

description:
I was eating my way through San Francisco, so sadly I was too full for a starter by the time I got to Le P'tit Laurent. The neighborhood is adorable, quaint and charming, as is the restaurant. 

I had the steak frites, and it was delish! Tender, cooked perfectly to medium rare, full of flavor, and the sauce...well, let's just say that if you put that sauce on my sneaker, I would eat it.

Dessert was very traditional, but no lack of deliciousness here either. Shared the creme brulee and profiteroles. Both quite tasty and satisfying to my sweet tooth. 

In all, a lovely evening.
author: Todd K.

description:
Charming little place in Glen Park Village with a true French feel. 
Although I was there for a brief meal of an appetizer and a glass
of champagne, I was pleasantly surprised at how busy it was and
how fast the tables were filled at 5:30 on a Thursday night. 
I loved the scallop dish and the bread was warm. Service was 
great and I really enjoyed my time there and the meal. I will definitely be back.
In fact, I made a reservation for Sunday night with a friend.
author: Joanne F.

description:
Our favorite restaurant in SF -- yep, that's right.  

We like the food a lot, the ambiance, and most importantly the people.  Funny, how as you get older people matter the most...  Laurent is an actual, true restaurateur, which is very rare. His staff is really super too.  This place is simply a gem.

 As with yelp reviews of your most favorite places, you just have to hope that they don't get so crowded that you can't enjoy them ;]
author: Devin C.

description: My mouth is still doing a happy dance after eating at this amazing restaurant! The Prix Fixe menu is an incredible value - soup or salad, entree and desert for $27! The house made bread is to die for! The salad was amazing - greens, mini tomatoes, fresh mozzarella, I practically licked the plate after soaking up every bit of dressing with the bread I could. I had the sea bass entree with crimini mushroom ravioli and another amazing sauce. Again, wiped up every smidgen of sauce with the bread. For dessert, French toast with caramel sauce and caramel ice cream... crispy edges, deliciously perfect and could barely finish it with this incredible meal. And only $27!!! I will be back, again and again. And the service - impeccable. I highly recommend it. And they are going to open a second one soon - I can't wait! Mwah!!!
author: JoAnne L.

description:
We had dinner here a few weekends ago, and were pretty happy with the experience. 

Since we knew this place was fairly small, we made reservations via opentable.
Although,we  still ended up waiting a bit to be seated. 
It seems there aren't very many people working here, and they are all doing multiple jobs, (seating, clearing tables, bringing out food.) 
That being said, be patient, service is friendly, but not the most efficient. 

The mussels and frites were great, the bread was AMAZING, but my guy's onion soup was pretty lackluster. Unfortunately, his entree was one of the less enjoyable parts of the meal as well. He had the beef bourguignon (sp?) It was a bit bland, and just not very memorable. 

I was torn between ordering the salmon and the sea bass, (which was not Chilean, points for that!) On the server's recommendation, ( i think he may have been the owner or the manager as well) i ordered the sea bass. It was fantastic, cooked perfectly, LOVED the flavors, and my husband and i thought the accompanying risotto was phenomenal. 

We also had some well-made cocktails, and shared the pain perdu for dessert. My husband is not usually a fan of french toast, but even he liked this. 

It was a bit more of an indulgent meal than i normally eat, but it was mostly wonderful. 

I also like this neighborhood, it's easy to get to from where we live, and parking isn't too difficult to find. 

Since the peninsula is greatly lacking in French bistro food, i would definitely come back here next time I'm craving it, (but would eat less bread!)
author: Amanda G.

description: If you are looking for the most elegant French Restaurant in san francisco, you might consider going elsewhere. But the food and wine here are most excellent. Mussels. Ah, the mussels. The filet. The fish. The Macon, the California Chardonnay. The hardest working bartender and face of the restaurant is Chris. When they close for a week or so, don't despair. Chris and the other servers deserve it as they truly pour their hearts out night after night, and always come up smiling and friendly.  The food, as I said, is more than tasty. It's well done with great care. Escargot? Absolutely. Reservations for larger parties highly encouraged. This is one wonderful restaurant experience.
author: Daniel K.

description: Tried the restaurant for the third time on Halloween night. The restaurant was decorated, we were welcomed by a friendly clown, served a great martini by Amy Winehouse! and the food was served by a sexy cat and deer. This is one of my favorite neighborhood restaurants. Started with very fresh oysters with a tasty and tart vinaigrette. My wife had the New York steak and I had the rack of lamb. Both meats were cooked perfectly and served promptly. My suggestion would be to have your sauces on the the side. I felt the sauces overpowered the meat dishes. Desert pain per du was delicious!
author: Dan S.

description:
Hands down..AWESOME. This has to be one of my top favorite SF restaurants. The food is delicious and to top it off the price is affordable. I ordered the neighborhood menu which was three courses (appetizer, entree, and dessert). We ordered other appetizers too but I really think if you ordered the neighborhood menu it's more than enough. We were so stuff that I couldn't wait to get home to unbutton my pants and lay on the couch with my food coma. I had a potato soup, oxtail, and chocolate souffle. Other people in my party also ordered the neighborhood menu with the salad, fish, and some type of dessert. I had a little taste of everyone's dish and everyone's dish was delicious, even our waiter looked delicious. The house bread was so good that we took the leftover home. The bread isn't homemade, it's from a french bakery in the East Bay, said our waiter. 

I can't think of any complaints. Butter and cream just makes everything delicious. :)
author: Victoria C.

description:
Cozy French place with classic food that's good for a weeknight dinner with friends. We dropped by on a Tuesday night for their awesome 2012 tax season special - an amazing three course deal of $20.12 for appetizer, entree, and dessert. 

- Escargot - standard escargot in a garlicky sauce
- Warm Crottin de chavignol and mixed salad - tasty salad with cheese 
- Beef Bourguinon served on a bed of mashed potatoes - Beef wasn't as tender as I'd like
- Sea Bass Meuniere with Vegetable Risotto - pretty tasty although sea bass filet was thinner than I expected and the mushrooms in the risotto chunky.
- Creme Caramel Dessert - ok. very rich and I could only have half of it before I felt sick. Definitely share this.
- Caramelized French Toast - yum!

We also got a 50cL (aka 2/3 of a bottle of wine) of the house wine for $17 - came out to be about $5/glass. Not bad!

Service was a bit abrupt. Took a while to flag down the waiter for ordering, but food came out quickly and the people serving the food were fun and nice.
author: Judy C.

description:
It's a small neighborhood gem...the food was really great. It's small and cozy just like in Europe, so it can get a little loud. 
My only disappointment is the service....We were sitting within a tables reach of another 2 diners who were apparently regulars. That said, if you're a "regular" you get 99% of the attention...if not you end up like us (the poor 1%)  with comments like
"What about dessert?" 
Jeez garcon...(waiter)...trying to get rid of us? No question about the dinner experience to begin with??? 
Very disappointing especially since we had to see how great service looks like 4 feet next to us!!! 

At the end you have 2 questions.

1) How was the food                                    4-5 stars
2) How was the atmosphere/service?     2    stars

Would I come back?....

For the food I would give another try....but....
author: Jeff S.

description: Excellent quality and great decor. The place is a bit on the small side but makes up for it in quality of food. Their bread is awesome. I love dipping it in their onion soup.
author: Eugene H.

description: It's just ok, it's quaint, seems promising but the food is generally average in my opinion.
author: Tom E.

description:
I don't know when it's going to actually happen, but one of my goals before I hit that monumental age of 30 years old is to spend just a little bit of my time in France. Though I've never been, something about their culture has a stranglehold on my curiosity, so in those times of enhanced intrigue, I do what I can to immerse myself as much as possible in their way of life. In this instance, I found myself in good ol' Glen Park in the friendly neighborhood confines of Le P'tit.

First off, this has to be be one of the most comfortable French restaurants I've ever been in. It's got the laid back vibe of a warm, rustic dive bar, but with a voluptuous style that'd appease any gastronome at the same time. Perhaps that's the real essence of European style old country, but in my case, it's still yet to be seen.

I had an opportunity to meet Laurent Legendre (the owner) when I dined, and he has a certain ease about him that makes you feel right at home from the second he welcomes you through the front door. The friendly salutations must rub off onto the rest of the wait staff as well, as I didn't encounter a single salty personality throughout the duration of my stay.

Of course, the warm nature of the staff can only be sustainable if the quality of food and wine strikes a balance, and they certainly don't miss the mark there either. While I was less wowed by my actual entree (the poached salmon and shrimp roulade with corn cake and leek sauce), the hors d'oeuvres of warm steamed Mussels with white wine/garlic, mixed salad with fried artichoke/balsamic vinaigrette, and table side salted butter with french baguette were all quite enjoyable. Similarly, they knocked it out of the park with their vanilla profiteroles and chocolate souffle. Muah!

It's certainly a restaurant worthy of a trek, so if you're looking break out of the usual routine, I highly recommend hopping the Bart to Glen Park. Chances are, you'll find yourself making room for immediate return visits. Bon appetit!
author: Ruggy J.

description:
We ordered just a half bottle wine, because we didn't want to drink too much on a Monday night.  Waitress wanted to help pour more wine into my half-finished glass, but she mistakenly poured water into my wine.  She immediately took my wine away but came back with an empty glass.  No apologies or freebie wine to replace what she threw away!  Oh well...

At the end of the dinner, I asked to have my left over entre To-Go, and she never came back with it.  What messy service =(  Food is decent though.
author: Yen F.

description:
I went there for dinner on a Sunday night with some friends. Cute little place. It reminded me of an old time Paris neighborhood bistro.
Now, for the food... I think they ran out of seasonings before we got there. Everything was really bland from the tuna tartar to the veggie mushroom ravioli. My friend who had the fish said the same thing so it wasn't my imagination. Her husband's cassoulet was beans with little else. The wine was very good, however, as was the caramel ice cream I had for dessert.
I will add one star for service as our waitress was very present and nice.
Too bad the food wasn't up to par!
author: serge k.

description:
I have been coming here since they opened and usually take my mom (who the entire staff seems to know by name...which makes me think she comes here more often and without me).

But just for introducing me to this incredible place, she's forgiven.

The white wine/garlic mussels are my favorite. and their French fries, though I try to resist, always seem to arrive at my table. (I usual claim some kind of momentary amnesia must have occurred during ordering).

the prix fixe menu is always a great deal, but i often find myself ordering the soup, the fried artichoke salad*, or the tuna tartare and the mussels along with a stiff gin martini (they make simple but excellent drinks here).

Honestly, you can't go wrong here, unless you try to show up on any night without calling ahead. this place is consistently close to capacity BUT, while they could squeeze in more tables, they don't, which is very nice and allows you to carry on a great conversation.
author: Mike V.

description:
We made a last minute reservation at this place because we have never tried French food amongst the three of us. One of us was running late. We did give the front desk kind of a hard time, kept changing between party of 2 and 3. When we got there, we still need to wait for 30 minutes. It was a pretty small place. Of course, duck liver was banned. So we chose escargot as appetizer.

We sat down at 9pm in a big table, courtesy of the waitress. She was very nice to us, saved the big table for 3 big guys. We ordered the neighborhood menu. It was a great value for the price. When we got our first dish, my friend just arrived 2 minutes before closing. They gave us the benefit of the doubt and let him ordered. That's excellent service.

House bread: It's okay to begin with and got better as the night went along. The bread could be a little more soft. 

Soup of the day: Cream of Cabbage with something in there. It was creamy, smooth, and warm. The taste was excellent

Escargot: Good and hot. It was made with some green herbs and came in 6 pieces. We liked it.

Bass: The bass taste excellent. It came with rice and some veggies that included sun dried tomatoes. It looked good and tasted good

Beef Strongnoff: I tried it. I thought it was good. My friend said it was alright. It was beef served with pasta, kind of like beef pasta. 

Dessert: That was the one we were waiting for. All 3 taste good

Crème Caramel Maison: caramel on top, creamy in middle. It was very good 

Soufflé in chocolate: The chocolate was hot

Caramel French Toast: My friend really liked it. 

Service was very very good. We would go back there again.
author: Allan W.

description: Our favorite date place! This French bistro is WAY better than any of the trendy restaurants in Hayes Valley, Opera Plaza, or Russian Hill IMO...and much cheaper. Oysters, escargot, foie gras, crab salad, any sort of steak or shortribs...go for it. Their $28 prix frie weekend menu is SUPERB-we had stuffed tomato spinach salad with dungeness crab, shortribs with mushroom polenta and our choice of dessert. Their cheese plate is heavenly with an all imported French assortment.And a full bar- so MARTINIS!
author: Antoinette S.

description:
Food was great, service was great and atmosphere was awesome.

I had the lamb shank my wife had the Salmon with saffron. We shared a bottle of merlot and had creme brulee to top it off.

The wait staff was polite and helpful and extremely friendly.

Definitely a repeat!
author: Jase O.

description:
Picking this place for dinner on Mother's Day was a mistake on my end. Didn't realize they only had the $57 prie fixe menu for the dinner. it was 3-course with a glass of champaign. (3.5 stars)

Overall, the food was nicely prepared and tasty. I guess $57 isn't really that much money for the food. It tasted good but don't expect something really inventive (I didn't).

We arrived there about 15 mins earlier than our reservation time, but we were sitted promptly. The service was nice... but the food came out a bit too fast. I was hoping to enjoy the food and talk with my friend, then enjoy the next course, but the entrees came out as soon as we finished the appetizers. I didn't necessarily mind it all that much, but did find it a little odd.

Service : questionable. it was efficient.. but was a bit rushed and aloof.. it's hard for me to complain about it, but can't say i was impressed.

Starters-
arugula salad with beets and goat cheese :: the dressing was on the heavy side but, we thought it was a good salad to start the meal with. It's hard to go wrong with arugula, roasted beets and goat cheese, right?

salmon with creme fraiche and dill :: salmon was very nicely prepared, and went very well with the rest of the dish.

Entrees-
lamb chops :: what a great dish! the meat was very tender and flavorful. I didn't really care for the greens that came with it (can't even remember what they were), but the meat itself was delightful

sea bass menuiere :: and we hit another homerun with this dish! it was delicious!! I may or may not have licked the dish.

Desserts-
the dessert consisted of a sample of every dessert dish they had. some were very good, some weren't.. not that memorable, overall.

I really wish I hadn't come here for the Mother's Day. I am not sure if I will be back here anytime soon, but overall, I had a good time.
author: Sung C.

description: Love this place. First of all, it is authentic French. When you enter, they great you in French and will continue talking to you in French, if that's what you prefer. The maitre d' was hugging babies and saying hello to passersby and checking on each table and making miracles happen as we dined and loved each and every bite. The decor is also an eclectic collection of all things French. You will not be disappointed.
author: Frank G.

description: Awesome neighborhood restaurant.  Great decor, great food, great vibe.  Its French cuisine, so its going to be heavy, but its delicious.
author: Dan L.

description:
We stumbled upon this Le P'tit Laurent last night and had SUCH a lovely evening.  The atmosphere is dim and charming.  The place was pretty packed, especially for a Monday night, so we were seated at the bar. Our server/bartender Julien was WONDERFUL. He provided excellent recommendations and service! We had an incredible experience here and would recommend this restaurant to ANYONE. The price fix menu is also the way to go. $25 per person = is the best deal in town!

Julien was top notch and made the evening an "experience" for us. Thank you Julien!
author: Laura Z.

description:
La Lecon Francaise Aujourd'hui:

French Phrase:  LE P'TIT LAURENT

English Translation:  Cozy neighborhood bistro that makes you feel like you're back in France.  Warm and gracious host Laurent.  Complimentary glasses of champagne as apology for delayed reservation.  Excellent wine recommendation from bartender Gena.  Great server Bene.  Delicious Beet Ravioli, Salmon with Spinach & Mashed Potatoes, Homemade Cassoulet, and Cheese Plate.  Complimentary bottle of wine and serenade for the birthday girl.  A lovely evening.
author: Amy C.

description:
Main course dinner was amazing: rabbit, lamb shank, bass. 

Unfortunately, the service was pretty frustrating. Apart from the extremely heavy accent of the server, to which I had to ask him to repeat himself 3 or 4 times each time he spoke, he was pretty half witted. He didn't know what Bastille Day was; and when my boyfriend asked him to pair our food with a nice bottle of wine (we didn't have a price range), he chose poorly, a basic california cab that I can get anywhere. We were in a French restaurant for pete's sake! We also ordered an appetizer that we never got. 

I guess I just expected more. There were people smoking outside and the smoke drifted into the restaurant. I had to ask our server to close the door. Things like that I expect the management to notice and take care of for the comfort of their guests.

I guess our server got tired of us, b/c towards the end of our meal (we had to ask for a dessert menu) the manager was serving us. lemon sorbet was great. Creme brulee was the worst I've had.

I'd go back if I had to; but I wouldn't expect much.
author: lelia p.

description: I really like this place. It has great food and service.  The location itself is very charming and very French.
author: Kevin R.

description:
I was really looking forward to trying this local French bistro. It smells amazing inside, and the ambiance is very cozy. Unfortunately, it was so cozy that our table was so close to the neighboring ones that we could hear the people seated to the right and left of us better than we could hear our own conversation.

Cassoulet was good, but VERY SALTY. I had to sip water with each bite to get it down.

Pros: Walking distance from home, cozy, good cocktail menu

Cons: Salty, loud and crowded on Friday night
author: S C.

description: Love the place! We have been eating there since the day it opened... I do miss the days when they had brunch, it was a great treat on the week-end. Love the food. the owner is very friendly, the staff is attentive, and the food is very good. The lamb, escargots, and creme brulee are classic! This is an awesome unpretentious french bistrot. Very much recommended!
author: Jean-Max V.

description:
No reason that thus could not be a five-star rating but the service was so slow, even in the context of a traditional French restaurant...in France. Our table of four received our entrees 90 minutes after being seated prompty for our 7:30 reservation (on a Friday, but still). 

The length of time quelled our enthusiasm for dessert but not the main dishes. How could we not enjoy good French food? The rabbit was very tasty, as were the mussels and fries.

The braided lamb shank tasted delicious, as did its sauce. Unfortunately for me in particular, the accompanying swiss chard was cooked with onions, which was not stated on the menu. Onions and I haven't been able to get along for a while now.

We did order the sides of fries and mushrooms out of order, as appetizers, and fortunately they kept us from getting too cranky. Well, the alcohol helped also.
author: Mike H.

description:
Soooooo...  I really wanted to like this place.  And it was pretty good, but there were a couple of things that I just couldn't overlook.  And will make my husband and I not go back.

I ordered the Onion Soup, which was good but not amazing.  Then I ordered the interpretation of vegetarian lasagna, which was very good.  Then we had the poached pears with whipped cream and ice cream, which was entirely forgettable.

The big problems...  They did not seem overly busy yet everything took a BIZARRELY long time.  It was a two hour dinner for appetizers, an entree and dessert.  On a random Thursday evening.  Our entirely forgettable, perhaps even disappointing dessert took half an hour after we ordered it.  And it was a pre-made dessert that might have taken 20 seconds to put together.  Very frustrating.

What was the most ridiculous thing, other than the bizarre length of the dinner (which did not include any alcohol or indication to our server that we wanted any kind of drawn out experience) was that every time a table would leave, they would SPRAY the table with some kind of disinfectant cleaner, like clorox.  It would fill the air and make everything smell and TASTE like clorox for 5-10 minutes.  This happened many times during our meal.  I'm all for keeping a clean establishment, but this majorly negatively impacted our experience.  Perhaps just pour a little on the rag in the kitchen before coming out to clean the table instead of filling the air in your restaurant with a cleaning solution.  Seriously.
author: Liz B.

description: Had oysters, escargots, the moules with frites, and Belgian blond beer; all great. Service friendly and efficient...felt like being in France
author: Amar R.

description:
Went here with some friends for a nice dinner on Friday night.  The food was great and we certainly felt transported to France.  In fact,  we were enjoying wining and dining ourselves all night in the coziness of this cute little restaurant....until one of the waitresses awkwardly told us that people were waiting for the table.  Although she tried to be kind about it, she might as well have said "You guys need to hurry up and get your asses out of here"... because she certainly killed our good mood for the night.  And although we tried to wrap up our dinner and conversation with dignity, we certainly couldn't ignore her constant running around frantically around our table ..which really told us to "GET THE HELL OUT OF HERE".  

Since when are you not able to linger at your table on a Friday night with some wine and good friends after a great meal?  And since when is it ever proper etiquette to actually tell your customers that they need to leave???  

Sorry cute French restaurant.  Food was great but telling customers to hurry and leave will always leave a bitter aftertaste.
author: Melisa H.

description: Great food. But very bad wine. It's unclear how truly French this restaurant can be when they don't appreciate the difference between glasses for red wine, white wine and water. They poured red wine into water glasses and water into glasses more appropriate for wine.  We asked for red wine glasses, but they understand the reason why we'd care.  All they had were the water glasses they were using. Sad waste of great food when it can't be properly paired with appropriate wine and the correct glassware.
author: Anthony S.

description: Love this local restaurant. The sauce on the mussels is better than any I had in France. The atmosphere is chic/cozy and the service is top-notch. You can practice your bad French and they indulge you.
author: Doreen D.

description:
Truly a neighborhood gem.  This is my 2nd visit this yr. Came here for lunch earlier this year and the salad was huge but the onion soup was too salty (loaded with cheese 'tho). 
We decided to come for dinner after attending a Giants game (they won!). 
They gave us bread 3 times during dinner. The 1st basket was toasty and came hot out of the oven. By the 3rd round, it wasn't heated anymore.  Wonderful crispy bread from Bakers of Paris which was delightful with the soft butter.
I tried the tuna carpaccio, thick slices of tender tuna, even more tender than some of the tuna served at low end sushi restaurants.  Served with a couple of slices of toasted bread - needed more bread with this appetizer, $12.
My bowl of mussels (entree) was good but the broth served with it was better. The wonderful thin French fries should not be missed, just like the way they serve it to you in Paris. 
Hubby had the salad then one of the entree of the day, iron steak.  The meat was cooked perfectly and very tender.

BFF tried the cod (very tender) with vegts and a side of French fries.  BFF's hubby tried the angel hair pasta with prawns. It came with 3 very large prawns and he liked the dish.

I skipped dessert because I was too full. Hubby had the choc tart - wonderfully soft with a dollop of pear sorbet. BFF had a dish of 3 small scoops of pear sorbet which had a wonderful fruity flavor.  Her husband tried the creme brulee' which he really enjoyed .  Good food.
author: Ry T.

description: Service was extremely attentive, staff was accommodating. I had the cream of vegetable soup and a steak. Honestly it was really good, the steak wasn't anything special, but wasn't bad. The cream of vegetable soup however was delicious! I would go back for sure!
author: Jason O.

description: This place is a neighborhood gem. Everything we've tried has been delicious, but the standouts have been the crab salad, escargot, salmon and rabbit. The service, food and ambience are excellent. And, getting a chance to speak with Laurent himself is always a treat.
author: Allison D.

description: Wonderful dining experience.  Delicious food, cozy setting, great service.  I'll be back... :)
author: David O.

description: What an amazing dinner we had at this cute French restaurant! I had the fixed menu - great potato soup, beef bourguignon and an amazing profiteroles asa dessert.. We also had escargot as an appetizer. Everything was just perfect. Real French restaurant that is never easy to find!
author: Merve A.

description:
Step inside on a cold foggy San Francisco night and you feel transported immediately to a cozy cafe in Paris.

My husband and I went here on a Sunday evening to check out their neighborhood prix fix menu and we can't wait to go back.

$25 for a three-course meal.  An soup or appetizer, main and a desert.  Quite a value.

I had the lobster bisque, the sea bass in a basil sauce and the profiteroles for desert.  My husband had the bisque also, the lamb and the pain perdu, which I had to try and it was truly divine.  EVERYTHING was delicious and tasted fresh.

The service was really good as well, we had a sweet girl who was french.

I would come back again for a nice romantic, cozy dinner.
author: Bethany D.

description: Probably 4 to 4.5 stars.  This is a really cute little restaurant that would be great for a fun date or for a group of friends.  I had the duck breast and thought it was really nicely done, and for dessert I had the pain perdu (caramelized french toast with caramel ice cream) which was delicious.  Overall the service was attentive without being pushy, and all my friends enjoyed the food.   As usual for the neighborhood, parking can be challenging.
author: Vivian W.

description:
I'm kicking myself for not visiting this place before as it is practically on my doorstep.  Being from the UK originally I've spent a lot of time in France and stepping into Le P'tit Laurent felt like I'd just walked into a lovely little Parisien neighbourhood bistro.  There was a short wait for our table, ok, actually a little longer than that and we were eventually seated at the bar to avoid an even longer wait but now we've got the only negative out of the way let's get to the good stuff.

First off, this place is so gloriously French.  Owned and operated by the real deal there was a very high percentage of French people working there, to the point where I wondered if they were going to expect us to order in their mother tongue.  Lovely I thought, proper French people generally means proper French food.  Tres bien!  

Whilst seated at the bar we started off with a glass of delicious Champagne.  No domestic sparkling wine would dare to make an appearance on this menu and I was particularly grateful for this as often the bubbly glass pour is a mediocre Napa Valley deal.  

The bartender/waitress was glorious.  She had a real Gallic streak to her, immaculately turned out, polite yet not obsequious and with a whiff of aloofness.  She was extremely efficient in the way she tended to the bar as well as serving the ten diners sat there.   You could never call the service warm and friendly but it was attentive and precise.  I was being indecisive about the food and after consulting with our host I chose the escargot and the rabbit, my partner went for onion soup and the boeuf bourguignon.  A bottle of Vacqueryas from the superbly curated wine list to drink and we were good to go.

The food was outstanding.  The snails were tender, well seasoned and swimming in plenty of garlic, parsley and butter.  The same goes for the onion soup, there was no questioning the quality, this was a top of the line soup packed with caramelised flavour and topped with tangy gruyere.  A basket of warm baguette helped soak up all the left over juices.

After a short wait our mains turned up.  The rabbit was generously portioned with three beautifully cooked pieces laying in a pool of intensely flavoured sauce of perfect consistency and a carrot and root vegetable puree.  Perfect didn't begin to describe how awesome this dish was.  I wouldn't have changed a thing and Chef would have been delighted by how clean the plate was when it returned to the kitchen.  The bourguignon was similarly well flavoured but my dining companion found the sauce a little soupy, it would have benefitted from a little more thickening.

We topped off the meal with a crème caramel, a dish I was never particularly fond of.  It tends to be grainy rather than smooth and this was no exception.  I'm not saying it was bad, or not as intended, I just don't enjoy this dish.  There was no crème brûlée on the menu or I would have gladly ordered this as it is my favourite dessert.  

I finished off with an espresso and some pastis, allowing our server to choose the pastis.  I was delighted to see she skipped past the Pernod and Ricard and went for a more obscure and more delicate example from Marseille.  A glass of port was also ordered then consumed and we paid the modest bill and bid our adieus to the staff who were now starting to close down the restaurant.

As we left the maitre D came over and thanked us for our patience and said they appreciated us not being upset for the 30 minute wait and were generally impressed at how nice we were to them.  I thought this was a lovely touch, totally unexpected and sealed the deal on Le P'tit Laurent becoming one of our regular haunts.  I feel a little mean knocking off the 5th star but with the delay and the slight soupiness of the beef dish I think it is an appropriate score.

As we stepped out I was half expecting to see a street lined with Citroens and Peugeots parked haphazardly but we were still in Glen Park.  Next time we'll go midweek and try the $25 set menu.
author: Tony S.

description: It is May, yet the sauteed vegetables tasted like they were collected from the bottom of the fridge with a tired and dehydrated taste that couldn't be disguised by fresh lemon juice and parsley.  The potato soup was made with chicken stock and mushrooms so it was brown.  The cassoulet was drab like the color painted on the walls, too, and equally tasting.    Not a good sign when the only redeemable components of.the meal are the bread and butter.   Did the chef have an off night?  I finished the meal because I am a plate-cleaner, but I don't think I will revisit because there's not much value in their cooking.  Additionally, the proprietor/host clearly caters to his regulars, leaving myself, who has dined twice there, in the "1%."  Eat  at Le charm, Chapeau!, L'Ardoise for tastier food and warmer service.
author: Lark A.

description:
I went here for dinner on Bastille day with my boyfriend. The entire experience was absolutely wonderful. We sat at the bar while we waited for our table and were more than happy to have a place to survey the cozy and authentic French decor. The whole restaurant probably only has about 15 tables and the atmosphere is intimate and lovely.

Seated promptly, ordered wine and appetizers. The whole night our food came in no time and the wine glasses were constantly refilled. Great service. I had the lamb shank for an entree and could not believe how tender and delicious it was. My boyfriend had the veal and says it was delicious, buttery smooth. 

We ordered dessert as well, profiteroles and creme caramel, both amazing. At one point the entire restaurant sang happy birthday for a guy. The owner made the rounds all night, checking in it at tables and saying hello. Great evening!
author: India K.

description:
The foie gras terrine for starters, drizzled with balsamic vinegar with toast on the side.. wasn't as delicate as other foie gras I've experienced in the past, but was definitely worth the value.

This Toulouse-style cassoulet is a very rustic and filling dish, with its creamy white beans, lush fall-apart duck confit, and pork sausage... This moment of perfection definitely warmed me up quickly and whet every sq inch of my taste buds..  Yum
author: Ty T.

description:
Definitely great price considering a three course prix-fix menu for only $22.  The night we had dinner, I first called to make reservation to arrive at 7p.m.  The person who answered the phone told me he couldn't take my reservation at 7p.m., only 6:30p.m. or 7:30p.m. slots were available.  I said I've read lotsof good things on Yelp about this restaurant but surprised that they couldn't be more accomodating on my request.  In the end, he agreed sticking to our reservation at 7p.m., but this "initial" experience is a half star deduction.

Food is delicious (we had esgarcot as appetizer) and I ordered a glass of Cab, which was quite tasty.  That night, we upgraded to French Onion Soup for $2.50 more and had the flank steak for entree.  Their dessert was the best part of all (imagine chocolate souffle!!).  The other 1/2 star deduction comes from the luke warm coffee and the over salty French Onion soup.  I'd wished our soup had more cheese after all.....  Nevertheless, we still had a great time and will definitely go back when they serve lobster bisque in the prix-fix menu next time.  :)
author: Vicky H.

description: I was rather disappointed with this French restaurant. I was expecting more out it for the prices and how the wait staff sold you on what would be good dishes. My steak was bland. It lacked flavor to it. Even the fries were eh. I may say the escargot was rather delicious. It did remind me of my time in that horrible city they call Paris.
author: Dwight N.

description: Excellent place to have a diner! The food is very good, but its pretty pricey! The guy Laurent is french and will welcome you with a great "bonsoir" and "bienvenue"!
author: Patrick D.

description: The food was ok - but way overpriced.  The service was awful... I can't remember ever having service worse than that.  It was a "special" Valentine's Day dinner.  We ended up spending $250 for two, and they still tried to rush us out of there in less than an hour.  It was as if we hit the maximum time and they just wanted us to leave.  Unbelievable - I don't think we'll ever go back.
author: Paul G.

description:
The restaurant, and owner rocks!!

Went there for dinner with my sisters from out of town, and my parents.  Some of us had the special tax season menu (2 courses for $21), and the rest, lamb chops, NY Steak and mussels.

The apps were delicious - lots of sweet beets, fresh lettuce, and tasty escargots.  

When the lamb chop and steak came, my parents were cutting into it, and it wasn't quite to their liking (medium rare)..but they didn't make a fuss (first time ever).

The owner walked by and noticed that they were not beaming from ear to ear.  He stated that the meats were overcooked, and insisted they be cooked properly.  He whisked them away, and within minutes their entrees reappeared.

The lamb chops were perfect, however, the NY steak was way too rare.  Again, the owner noticed that something was amiss, and asked if the steak needed more time on the grill.  He picked up the steak without batting an eyelash, and came back with a plate of veggies for my dad to nibble on (while the steak was recooked).

With all this switching out, and the owner's incredible attention to detail, my parents were duly impressed (and believe me, that's not an easy task).

We scanned the dessert menu, and decided on the tiramisu.  The owner came by once again, and dropped off 3 desserts!!  

He went above and beyond to ensure that our dining experience was superlative.  He excelled at accomplishing that.

Merci beaucoup Le P'tit Laurent!!  C'est magnifique!!
author: Edward A.

description:
Fabulous. An amazing find in a part of the city we have never been to.

Very cute small and homely restaurant. The service is superior, attentive and friendly. Constantly checking in and making sure you're taken care of.

Honestly, the food was fabulous. You won't go wrong with anything.

Pretty much, don't question if you should go here - just go!

Very excited to go back!
author: Matthew H.

description:
Thanks to Julien this restaurant works and has quality, otherwise it would suck. He's the only one that makes the place great, fun, tasteful, and authentic. The rest of the waiters/bartenders are quite dumb and forgetful. There is also the exception of the Brazilian waiter who is also very attentive and happy. 

I've tried real French food and this is not the best in SF. L'Ardoise would be my recommendation, otherwise if going to LP then make sure you get Julien as the bartender/waiter! He'll make you laugh :)

Otherwise, you'll get a mean waiter, a drama-queen or a dumb one that forgets everything. I would not bring my co workers or friends here. Not even a date. Cheers!
author: Brooke G.

description:
I enjoyed this little neighborhood gem.  i traveled here from Ingleside so it wasn't too far from my home.

The food was decent.  I had ordered the fish entree (sea bass fillet) but the waiter couldn't tell me what kind of bass it was. I try to avoid certain species of fish and it would have been nice to know what I was eating. It was prepared very well though. Cooked perfectly and still moist.

The noise level is very boisterous.  Not very surprising for a french-bistro style setting. 

I had ordered the soup du jour which was a kind of cream of pork soup.  It sound very weird but was extremely tasty.

We finished dessert with the profiteroles w/ vanilla ice-cream and chocolate sauce. The profiteroles tasted stale and not fresh at all. So I would skip that dessert. I may have had a bad batch but I wouldn't order that again.
author: Eric T.

description:
This was the perfect place for a girls' dinner on a Wednesday night. The neighborhood menu was awesome and such a great deal! The bread to start was so delicious and they just kept bringing us more.  I had the escargots to start- yummy, garlicky, buttery, heavily parsleyed snails are always a great way to start the meal. For my entree, I had the beef bourgignon which was pretty good- you get a nice serving of beef that's quite tasty with some veggies and whipped potatoes. It was definitely tasty but I didn't think it was amazing. For dessert, I had the creme caramel which was way too rich for me- I couldn't eat half of it, but that also comes from the fact that I just had so much food beforehand.  It was definitely good, but really rich.

My friends got the lamb shank which was delicious and for dessert some cheesecake which I thought was only ok and the french toast which I thought was really good.

The food is definitely very good and the neighborhood deal during the week is a great deal and totally worth it,
author: Lisa C.

description: My first time trying rabbit..AMAZING!!! Wonderful service, super friendly and helpful staff. Nice atmosphere.
author: Kay G.

description:
Our go-to place for great food in our neighborhood.

Great service. Great food. It's like the place was lifted from Paris and dropped into Glen Park.

Yes, it can get crowded. And hot. And your meal may take a few hours to get through. Like I said, just like Paris.

Go during the week for the $25 "Neighborhood Menu" for the best deal in the city, hands down.

Oh, and get the Pain Perdu for dessert, you won't regret it.
author: Chris O.

description: The service was phenomenal, warm and welcoming from the moment my family and I walked in. We sat any an adorable table and the server could not have been more sweet and accommodating to our one year old. We started with The crab avocado salad and it was absolutely delicious. They did not skip on any part of it and the favors blanched each other perfectly. I ordered the filet and it melted in my mouth. My husband enjoyed the prawn pasta and the sauce was a perfect blend of cream and wine - I finished his plate with breAd!!! U highly recommend this special place. Whenever we have our children at a restaurant we go early and we were lucky enough to sit next to a couple that were both born, raised and now have grandchildren in San Francisco- they come to the restaurant all the time!
author: shareen h.

description:
3.09.12
8:30 PM

Good value, good food, great service.

Too bad there was a piece of steel wool in my sauce.

I would come here again if I lived in Glen Park...but I don't...so I'll trade-up for Chez Papa any day at this price point.

Crab salad:  (C: Outdated presentation.  Tower of wilted greens on the bottom, crab, topped with capers.  Bland.  Tasted like tuna salad)

Sauteed Bass (B:  Bass was nice.  Steel wool in sauce.  Veggie risotto was clumsy.  Some of the carrots were uncut and didn't cook through while some of the other veggies were over cooked.  Cute if my grandma made it.  Lazy if a chef made it.)

Waitress (A:  Attentive, knowledgeable, friendly)
author: William R.

description:
Nice little neighborhood gem that's good for dinner. there's lots of parking and close to glen park BART station also.

-French onion soup - great. very traditional, extremely hot (hate when other places bring you lukewarm soup), cheese is melty.
-Lamb shank - ok. wasn't as pleased as other reviewers made it seem. they ran out of the normal side that usually comes with it, so they let me sub mushrooms instead.
-French toast dessert, never had for dessert and it was pretty good with a small scoop of ice cream
-Apple tart I didn't care for. The apples were too hard for my liking

Pretty good spot for this area and really good fixed price menu, they call it the Neighborhood Menu - 3 courses for $25. It changes weekly and considering Dine About Town is $35 for a three course, it's cheap!

I thought it was pretty cool the waitress spoke entirely in French when speaking with us. I'm not sure if she couldn't speak English or wanted to make us feel like we were in France. Either way, it reminded me of being in foreign language class during school and having teachers not allow any sort of conversation except that one.
author: Dennis L.

description:
My wife and I came here for our anniversary dinner last week and had a blast. we got a sitter and hey squeezed us in last minute on a Saturday night. 
 
We shared a bottle of Tatinger and started off with the fried calamari salad. The greens were a frisee/chop combo with the right amount of homemade blue cheese. For our mains we had the braised beef Osso-buco and the New York steak with frites. My wife is picky about her steak and she loved it. The creamy polenta and mushroom sauce with the osso-buco was delicious. Add a couple of martini's and we were DONE. Next time I'll  actually leave room for dessert.
 
The service was great. You can tell the staff takes their job seriously but does not make you feel like they are doing you a favor. The decor feels like a real France brassiere rather than your typical modern decor in most places in the city. Honestly, that's our speed these days. We need a place that is warm and comfortable rather than hip and standoffish. Like most businesses in Glen Park, it's sort of a locals place. You go in once and folks will get to know you. You go in again and they will probably remember your name and treat you like an old friend. 

Go.
author: Bill M.

description: What a great gem!!! The pork with cabbage was amazing and the rabbit with carrot perfect. The feeling of a small local neighborhood place is great. Wine list is good and reasonable.
author: Vincent T.

description: Excellent little French bistro in the Glen Park area.  We both had the Prix Fixe which was a good deal.  The soups were terrific and the flank steak was flavorful.  James had the profiteroles for dessert which were great in dark chocolate sauce. I had the creme brulee which was tasty but could use some berries to round it off.  Other than that, a really enjoyable meal.
author: Randy S.

description:
I have returned to this restaurant after 5 years after my first and only visit.  I've constantly raved about this place with friends who wanted to try French food and I'm so disappointed at myself that I haven't made more frequent trips to this restaurant since 2008.  What was I thinking?

Went here with a friend last night for a 'catch up on life' dinner.  We had reservations at 7:45 and the restaurant was packed.  We were seated a few minutes after our reserved time which was not a big deal since we made our way to the bar to grab some drinks.  My drink choice was La vie en rose, my friends drink was a lychee drink.  Ohhh my, I love my gin, yes I do but this drink made me love gin even more haha.  

My friend and I agreed that for an appetizer we wanted to share the mussels which also came with fries.  Yumm!  What is in that sauce?  It was divine--probably white whine, garlic and parsley.  We sat there in awe of the flavors dipping our left over bread.  Soooo good!!!  And the fries were just as I remembered it, sooo sooo good!

For our entrees, my friend had Le Cassoulet toulousain Maison which consisted of duck, pork and sausage.  She loved it!!! I had a bite of the duck and it was melt in my mouth goodness.  For my entree I had the Medaillon de porc, puree de pommes de terre, sauce a la moutarde et ananas which was pork medallions served with mashed potatoes.  I had forgotten why they were so good from the last time I had the mashed potatoes here.  Well....the menu doesn't indicate they are truffle mashed potatoes!  SCORE!!!!  Ohhhh Lord!  They were delishhhhh!!! 

The waiter, whom I think may have been the owner, recommended some great red wine pairings to our meal.  They were perfect!!!

And as if that whole meal was the end to a great dinner--it wasn't!  At first my friend and I agreed that we weren't going to have dessert because we were sooo full.  But our waiter came with dessert menus!!! Whhhhy!!!! LOL! We opened the menu and the first on there was creme brulee which was we both were craving for. I stepped away for a minute to use the bathroom and so had my friend order. She asked for recommendations and he said creme brulee french toast.  We were thinking the creme brulee was flavored french toast but it wasn't.  It came to the table and we looked at each other puzzled and said, uh oh that's not what we wanted.  But I mean what could go wrong at this point? First bite............best mistake ever, Second bite......what do we do with ourselves, next bite....nom nom nom nom nom, next bite.....nom nom nom, nom nom nom nom nom, last bite....holy shhhh**t, I'd come back just for this.  LOL!

I live so close to this place, it's deadly for me! I'm going to be back really soon!
author: Mary-Anne C.

description:
Summary: Good food, friendly staff, great bargain.

Came for the neighborhood menu ($25 for three courses Sun-Thurs) on Sun. night. The food was good and a great deal for the price. The bread was warm too, which I really enjoyed.

Would definitely come again.
author: Gary Y.

description:
This place is so cute! My favorite part? The employees actually speak French. Score.

I went here with my dad when he was in town for my Birthday. It's a very short walk from the Glen Park BART station. We went on Thursday which is the last weekday of their special locals Prix Fixe menu. Everything we ordered was spectacular -- soup, salad, short ribs and dessert. Will definitely be back -- so reasonably priced for delicious French food!
author: Lauren F.

description:
Good wines, good ambience, good service.
Food was mediocre and made us sick. They took a couple of French recipes and were able to make them into a bland, overpriced meal.
The onion soup tasted like oregano. This is a French soup, not a pizza.
The sardines in the "special" salad were dry and miserable.
The steak was chewy and salty.
The escargot had nothing special about them.

The only highlights were the wine and soufflet.

This place has a good potential; Great location etc. If they just improved their cooking I'd be happy to come back.
author: Noam R.

description:
This is one of my new favorite spots.
Both times I went, I got the 3 course prix fixe option, which was amazing, very reasonably priced, and left me very full.
The wines were also reasonably priced - I think my glasses were each $7 - $9.
Both times I went, we did not have reservations and were seated almost immediately.
The french toast was so delicous, but so were the soups, the salads, and the mussels. The escargot looked really good - I want to try that next time.
We couldn't figure out if our waiter had a fake french accent or not. But it doesn't matter - he was adorable and helpful, and the meal was delicious. I can't wait to go back!
author: Dana O.

description:
This tiny, corner french restaurant was so cute!

Real french people work here! 

Had the pleasure of coming here last Friday night with the mom in law and the bf.

They have a pre fixe menu during I believe Sun thru Thur, $21 for 3 courses, which my mom in law who's been here before said was great.

We started off with the escargot.  One order comes with 6 escargot, me and mom split one order and my bf had one to himself!  We polished ours off, but when the bf tried his, it was still cold! He had to send it back, the 2nd one he got back was STILL cold! That had to be sent back AGAIN!  The waitress was sincerely apologetic about the situation but luckily we didn't bitch about it :)

For the main course I ordered the NY Steak & Fries, Mom got the mussels & fries, and the bf got the lamb shank.  My steak was HUGE and tender and delicious.  The bf's lamb shank was fall-off-the-bone tender and flavorful.  

While we polished off our food ( I had to take 3/4 of my steak home) we were surprised when the waitress came by with dessert. Not 1 , not 2 but 3 desserts to share among the 3 of us! She said she was sorry for the cold escargot and that this was the least they can do.  So we had creme brulee, chocolate profiteroles and an apple custard thing...all were delicious! That was a nice surprise at the end of the meal.

We were thoroughly stuffed after dessert!  This is a great neighborhood restaurant, albeit tiny.  But the food and service more than make up for it!
author: Jade B.

description: What an incredibly cute nook in the middle of a chill neighborhood, Glen Park. The inner decor is very homey and comfortable, and you can't beat the $25 neighborhood deal. I ordered the french onion soup ($2.50 extra) which was okay -- I would have preferred a little more soup (v. totally onions), the pork tenderloin which was very good, and the creme caramel which was excellent. A great three course meal that was reasonably priced, and the service was great.
author: Mel G.

description:
This place is the best. I came here for my birthday, and I think this has been the best restaurant experience I have had. My family and I reserved a table beforehand and arrived on the dot! We were quickly seated and one person (I think the manager) was attentive and funny (even though it was a friday night and packed). The food was delicious-my family and I had the steak, the lamb shank, the duck, and the seabass. They were all great, but our favorite by far was the sea bass. It was the lightest meal in that you wouldn't feel heavy afterwards. The cream of vegetable soup was great and so was the escargot, while the onion soup was slightly saltier than I imagined (not sure if that was the norm). As we were eating, people stopped by a lot to make sure we were doing well. 

We were stuffed by the end of the meal but decided to get desserts. I got the creme brulee and my brother got the carmel french toast thing. He loved his and mine was okay. It wasn't the worst, but I was looking for something more velvety. (not bad though). I wasn't sure if anything would have been done for my birthday as I mentioned it at the reservation, but as I was about to leave the manager looked at me and said jokingly-what are you doing? I then realized that something was going to happen. Lo and behold, (more) desserts from the table were coming to my table - two scoops of lemon sorbet (so refreshing!) with candles!. The manager stood in the corner of the small restaurant and called for everyone's attention. He brought to everyone's attention that we had not one, not two, but THREE birthdays! He introduced everyone to those celebrating their birthdays and IT WAS THE SWEETEST THING EVER because everyone sang their hearts out, waving their hands, and just being merry. It was so great and lively and just full of spirit!!!!!!!! So if this place has ever treated anyone wrong, I encourage you all to go back and give it another chance because they are the sweetest. I give them so many stars for just the great service, ambience, and experience!!!
author: Sophie D.

description: Sweet little neighborhood boîte where a drunkard bar used to stand. The owner is charming and just-the right-amount-of-effusive, the decor is pleasant, the service is discreet and excellent, and the food delicious. Not a very extensive menu, but that is to its credit. Highlights: filet (rare, please!), pommes frites, Pinot Noir, mood lighting, and badinage. Will be back, although I still wonder where the drunks went after the neighborhood went upscale.
author: Nerd G.

description:
Intimate, a little decadent, and friendly.  

An establishment in Glen Park that I hope is here for years to come.
author: Colleen C.

description:
I wanted to rate this restaurant higher, since the space is charming and the service is very good (esp. considering that there are only three people working the whole room, including tending the bar). My problem was the food.

It was OK. Just OK. I wanted it to be amazing but it wasn't. The problem seems to me to have been a light hand with salt. Oddly, one of the other reviewers I saw here noted that everything was too salty, but our meals were definitely under seasoned. My husband's calamari salad was a nice idea and it was well cooked, but the coating of the squid was bland. My fois gras terrine definitely needed more salt and so did my lamb. The only dishes that came out that we really loved were the steak frites and hubby's desert which was pain perdu. 

All in all there are better French places in town serving very similar food. If I could I'd give it 2.5 stars for the charming space and nice service. But the kitchen needs to step up its game.
author: Mike F.

description: Me and my husband love this place so much! The mussels are to die for and they have some great soups and salads too! Highly recommend it!
author: Flor L.

description:
This restaurant is very charming and the staff was very friendly. 

I tried the mussels and escargot, which were delicious. I liked that the wait staff kept replenishing our bread basket so we could enjoy the sauce from the mussel dish. The wine (a Boudreaux) was also excellent!

I ordered the boeuf bourguignon, and as hard as I tried, I could not get over how extremely salty it was. I managed to eat about half of it with a lot of bread and water.

Ended the meal with a couple spoonfuls of the French toast and caramel ice cream dessert. That was delicious. :)
author: Candice C.

description: Very busy little place I recommend making a reservation to be safe. Also they do a great 3course meal deal that is the perfect dinner. Wonderful French food and wine.
author: Malinda M.

description:
Since we live in Glenn Park we walked to the restaurant.

We had a Friday reservation for our group of 4...so did not have to wait for a table.

I had a "green" salad which...oddly enough was the best tasting red beet salad ever.

Then I enjoyed the Bouillabaisse which was soooo good...I used the bread to clean up all the sauce.  I left that plate clean!

For dessert I shared the chocolate souffle.  When the waiter told us it would only take 10 minutes we knew it was not the traditional souffle.  It was more like warm chocolate mousse in a small bowl.  Nonetheless it was delicious...slightly bittersweet chocolate.

I savored the food...but be warned it is richer than it seems.  I was so full.  I am sure it was due to butter & cream in the sauces.

The service was excellent.  They all seemed to speak English with a French accent.  Since I was visiting with friends I had not seen for some time I gave them almost all my attention.  I did not spend time trying to converse in French with the staff.

Our bill with tips...$200 for 4.  A little high for a neighborhood restaurant.  After all their overhead is much cheaper than downtown.  Hence the 3 stars.  They do have a reasonable prix fixe menu Sun-Thurs which I plan to try.  If it is as good I would gladly raise it to 4 stars.

We will return.
author: Saul M.

description: Dropped in early without a reservation and got a seat at the bar where I was very well cared for!  The food was divine. A slab of beef cooked PERFECTLY and tender! Sauce etc. just great. appetizer just okay. And only four stars because the dessert, a fruit tart, was pretty sad. Tasted as if it was made with condensed milk! The waitress saw that I didn't love it (she also saw that I ate it all!) & didn't charge me for my excellent coffee.  Good place. Rather have okay food served with charm and politesse as this was than great food served with attitude any day. And the neighborhood is heaven.
author: Laurie P.

description:
This is *the* quintessential neighborhood French restaurant. I love their food, drinks, personality. This is our go-to place when we have a special event or just want to be a couple on a date. Their cassoulet is to...die...for! 

My only complaint is how crowded it can be; it's not the crowd but the heat. All those bodies breathing take a toll on the AC. The perfect dinner is during the summer, windows open and a cool, foggy breeze coming through and the taste of some VERY good cider. 

Their specials are really well priced and always tasty.
author: Kris S.

description: The food, service and wine list are always fantastic. If the cassoulet is on the menu, order it! Be sure to have a digestif of Absinthe in the traditional method at the end of the night. Absolutely a favorite spot in SF, but you better not take the reservation I want and fill my place when I want to be there!!
author: Dr F.

description:
La P'tit feels like the neigborhood french restaurant. The owner is on the floor serving people, the staff is just a 3 man team of a bartender a waitress and the owner. The entire feel of the place feels local vs some fine dining french restaurant. 

The food was excellent, the foie gros appetizer was served cold instead of hot and I like the patte feel of it to the more greasy feel of other places. Though I wish it could be heated up a bit.

The beet salad though was kinda bland. I think I might be used to beets having a stronger flavor from having them in a can in my childhood and perhaps this is how beets really taste like but either way, not a strong flavor of anything regardless.

The initial service of getting our order was slow, but after that food came out regularly and on time.
author: Rohan D.

description: My 2 daughters and I came in to this restaurant for a drink after eating at an Italian restaurant across the street. Laurent served us and the drinks were great. We looked at the menu and right away I saw the cassoulet which is one of my favorite French dishes. I asked Laurent about it and he said that it was all house made from the beans to the duck confit. We made a reservation for the following evening. My daughters ordered the steak frites. The steak was good but the frites seemed to be just frozen fries. They were definitely not home made. As soon as the cassoulet was brought to the table I knew it was going to be a disappointment. I lived 20 years in a French country and have enjoyed beautiful French food. I have friends from the south of France and have eaten cassoulet in their homes. The William Saurin cassoulet in a can from France is 1000 times better. I have to say that the cassoulet at Le P'tit Laurent was not just "not good", it was horrible. In a good cassoulet, the beans are tender and white and melt in your mouth, the sausage is fresh and not overly salty, the duck is tender and falls of the bone, and the sauce is velvety smooth with the duck fat. There was absolutely none of this in the cassoulet at this restaurant. The whole plate looked old and reheated 10 times. The beans looked like they were from a can, the sauce was dark brown and salty, the sausage was inedible because of the salt, the duck was ok. Overall this was a horrible meal. During our meal, no one came to ask if everything was going well. If they had, I would have asked to return the cassoulet. We had onion soup which was just ok. The scallop appetizer was good. To top it all off, while we were still eating, the staff and Laurent moved all the tables and chairs in the restaurant in preparation for the next day. It was so noisy we couldn't have a conversation. I spent $260 on this dinner and it was the worst waste of money. Would he have served this cassoulet to a "real" French person? Shameful.
author: Linnie B.

description:
Service is excellent, small cozy tables, quaint decor in the long bar counter.  

Escargot was not bad, not so much a fan of the apple foie gras.  Entree picks were the steak with mushroom/onions and lamb shank.  The steak was cooked medium as it should, the mushroom/onion sauce paired well.  Lamb is a bit gammy (smell) but tasted fine as it was fall off the bone tender.

Reservations recommended as it was a full house.
author: Ju D.

description: Superbement-which is delicious in french!!! Amazing place for date or dinner with friends. Authentic french basics!!! Friendly staff and nice atmosphere!!! bon appeti't
author: Ilya K.

description: The thing about this place, other than the excellent cuisine, is that the owner is a true local restaurateur, in the sense that he is amazingly welcoming, and one feels that he cares about every detail on that place, and every customer. And that spirit permeates every aspect of the business. Feel good French!
author: Sophie O.

description: hands down one of my favorite restaurants in SF.  quaint and cozy with great french food.  Laurent, the owner, is super nice and attentive.  this place rocks!
author: alan b.

description:
Charming neighborhood restaurant with about 15 tables.  Great food and a $30 3 courses meal.
Had a Lapin a la creme which was like a trip back home
Reservation would be a good idea.  Friendly service
author: Philippe D.

description:
Take a step into a French Bistro at Le P'tit Laurent.  Complete with tin ceilings, menu in french and english, french posters on the wall, Eiffel tower motif, and french-speaking wait staff (or at least they speak with French accents), this restaurant drips is a great replica of a French Bistro.

The food is great, but a bit pricey ($100 for two).  Love the escargot appetizer.  The sea bass entre was good (not great), while the monkfish special the night we ate there was fabulous.  The poached pear with ice cream, chocolate sauce, and whipped cream is a delectable dessert.
author: Brad B.

description:
INCREDIBLE! 

Everything I love about French food and flavor but with large portions, nice waiters and a cozy atmosphere. 

My ABSOLUTE favorite dish is the sea bass... it's to DIE for! I'm almost hesitant writing it here because they do sell out of things!

I would definitely recommend the mussels to share with a date - they're delicious and plentiful! 

I wasn't a huge fan of the desserts... but I was so full, I didn't mind! 

I would recommend hopping over to Bi-rite for dessert if you're in the mood!

MAKE A RESERVATION!
author: Michelle K.

description: We had the most remarkable dinner here tonight  the rabbit was superb it melted in your mouth. And the special red snapper was so very good. Our waiter Ivanir suggested the French Chardonnay to accompany the fish. It was ok but not really to our liking. He then poured my husband another glass of California Chardonnay which we both liked better. We r glad to have tried the French wine but much preferred the California chard. Thank you Ivanir for your suggestions. We love this place!!  PC &NA
author: Nikki C.

description: This is the real French deal - all the waiters are really Frenchies :) I had some kind of fish, my friend had the lamb, my other friend had escargot, I had some wine, it's really cozy in there, the decor is nice, it's buzzy but not too loud..this is a great GP gem.
author: Sonya Z.

description: We dined there on Saturday night with our friends.   I had the boullibase, which was just OK.    It smelt fishy when it first came out, but it had a nice variety of fish, three rather small mussels, and a nice pleasant soup base.  My wife had the rack of Lamb, which was much better.   It was well trimmed of fat, a generous 5 ribs, very tender, and a delicious sauce.  Next time I would skip on the boullibase and go for the rack of lamb.    Rather pricey, but good service.
author: W. K.

description: The restaurant is small but quaint with interest and strange french-inspired street sign art.  We sat in the front of the restaurant looking out on to the street; enjoyable view (save for the homeless man that kept waving at us - harmless).  Prix Fixe menu had a suitable array of choices.  Service was fine, seemed short staffed, but attentive enough.  Food overall was very good - seafood cassoulet was delicious but a bit creamy.  Can't remember everything we ordered but we had very little complaints.  We will be back to this place in the future.
author: Jay S.

description: The fact that the owners/managers speak French when you walk-in, brings a sense of "not a typical Americanized-French place". The food and the bottomless sunday mimosas are definitely wonderful addition to a nicely packed menu. One suggestion, make a reservation as this place gets booked!
author: Maria G.

description: I have been wanting to go ever since they opened, but it has taken until now until I finally found time (and a table!) to do so. What a cute neighborhood bistro! It brings me back to visits to Paris, in the older arrondissements where one might unexpectedly find a tiny place to duck into for a fantastic meal! I tried the escargot and bass. Both were delicious and well prepared. Nothing fancy or fancy, just basic French fare prepared with the best ingredients and cooked to perfection. What else can I say? Other nice touches were the bread that they served (warm! so unlike most SF restaurants, but what I miss most about dining in my own hometown of New Orleans, bread basket bread served warm--funny the little things that make me so happy), mismatched antique flatware (took me back to Parisian flea markets). The staff were polite and efficient. The owner greeted us at the door--a very kind gentleman, made us feel welcome. Nice wine selection. Passed on dessert (had our fill from dinner). The only problem was that the restaurant was quite noisy, but perhaps because it was so packed with excited diners.
author: 和子

description:
Nice neighborhood restaurant but.....
Pros: 
- nice location
- nice decoration and ambience
- daily neighborhood menu is affordable
- interesting dishes

Cons:
- service is sloooooow
- cuisine can be uneven and consitency is the hallmark of all great 
  restaurants....

For the record:
- I live in the neighborhood
- have been there about 8-10 times now.
author: Philippe F.

description:
Oh la la.  What an exquisite taste to the senses, along with a nice dark, intimate atmosphere for dining in this neighborhood restaurant.  It's a bright star of a restaurant.  I'm glad they offer a pre fixe or neighborhood menu, three course meal for USD 25 Sunday-Thursday 5:30-9:30 pm.  It allows those who are cost conscience to afford coming here for a taste of the senses experience.  Such a delight to be able to dine at this wonderful restaurant.  Free wi-fi is available.  Their French bread is tasty.

The first course was a soup of the day or a salad, second course offered was pork ribs or trout, last course is a dessert off their menu.  I went with a friend and ordered different things and tasted each other's selections.  Neighborhood menu changes weekly.  The soup of the day had bits of bacon, very tasty but a bit too salty.  The trout was moist, delicious, not overcooked but the sauce on it too salty.

On another visit, I now conclude that generally their food quality overall is very good, but unfortunately too salty would be my biggest complaint.

Must not miss.  BART Glen Park station is just two blocks away.
author: George L.

description:
Escargot 3/5
Lamb shank: 2/5
Cassolet: 2/5
Basa fish: 3/5

The food was okay. The onion soup taste like Chinese medicine. The lamb shank not very flavorful, the Cassolet, where is the duck? Can't taste the duck but the sausage was there.
author: Matthew Y.

description: Really 4.5 stars.   Great atmosphere & service, and truly excellent food that stands out from the already competitive crop of SF restaurants in terms of flavor and presentation, with a constantly changing menu and prix fixe menu that keep me coming back.    You can sometimes wait a considerable time AFTER your reserved table time, but it's worth waiting for.  If it were not for that I'd probably give it 5 stars.
author: Matthew S.

description:
I've been dining at Laurent for years, and it has always been on my short list for reasonably priced bistro food.  So, despite inflating prices and uneven quality of late, it seemed the ideal place for a Valentine's Day dinner.  M. Laurent took my reservation without a word regarding the menu, so I assumed it would be the usual.  When we were seated I was amazed to see that a $69 prix fixe 3-course menu was the only option.  If that weren't enough, the menu clearly stated that 18% gratuity would be added, irrespective of the size of the party (almost of the guests were couples)!  While I always tip at least 20%, I found this insulting -- was M. Laurent afraid his guests (probably 90% neighborhood regulars) would stiff the servers?  Finally, the food was . . . eh.
