The lobster bisque tasted OK with zero lobster, the snails were just OK, lamb chops (ordered rare) were overdone and served with burned green beans, and a skimply portion of duck breast was ho-hum .  The only item on the menu that was better than usual was the desert plate, which featured several treats.  Without any alcohol at all, dinner for two added up to nearly $180 . . . just because it was Valentine's Day.

For a long-established and well-liked neighborhood restaurteur to screw his clientele like this is shameful and unconscionable.  Regretfully, I've stricken P'tit Laurent from my list of acceptable dining venues.
author: Jake K.

description: Came back and had some items from neighborhood deal, love this place! beautiful little setting that feels very much like France!
author: Tiff W.

description: After a recent visit, I'm feeling that this is the best French bistro in town.  If you can, satisfy yourself with the offerings on the $25 neighborhood menu.  The a la carte menu is a bit pricey, but the quality is uniformly good.
author: Victor O.

description: In a nice little neighborhood of San Francisco, a real gem.  The food is simple, French and very, very good. The owner is a great person to know.  You really feel you just walked into a small café in Paris once you sit down. The escargots are great, blanquette de veau reminds me of the one my grand mother use to make us. Make a reservation but get there a bit early as parking is a bit challenging. Or park somewhere further and take UberX :-)
author: Olivier G.

description:
I came here for a birthday dinner last night. Both my sister and I ordered the New York Steak, medium-rare. When the steaks came out, they were both well-done. We figured since it's the most expensive menu on the item, we should be able to ask them to do it right... so we sent both our steaks back and asked them to re-cook it at medium-rare. Ten minutes later, my sister gets her steak back and it's cook correctly (though kind of dry and chewy).  I get my steak back and it's cooked even more than the last time I got it. Soooo I have to send it back AGAIN. The third time they brought it back, the steak was cooked correctly... but it was a really tough and chewy piece of meat, and after all the waiting... I really was tempted to just scratch my order (or hoping they'd comp it or something - but they didn't).

Also, the fries that came with the New York Steak were nothing to write home about. My friend commented that they reminded her of frozen french fries that were just re-heated. Aside from the disaster with the steaks, I had the foie gras as an appetizer. It was pretty good, but a bit on the sweet side. I tried my friend's osso-buco and that was tasty. The interior decorations are cute, and give of a very French-vibe. Though the service was kind of on the slow side. 



I doubt I'll try this place again.
author: Lucinda W.

description: Good food and great service. It's a bit on the pricey side. Their menu changes throughout the year, so sometimes I don't see anything on there that I like. I'm pretty picky when it comes to European food, so that's probably why. I'm also not a fan of their Sunday brunch, I don't love any of the dishes on the brunch menu.
author: amber h.

description: Excellent place. Loved the food and the waitress. The escargot is a must as well as tuna tartar to start. I chose the pork chops during one visit and braised lamb. The food is too good so I never have room for desserts! !
author: Durjay M.

description:
I was introduced to this bistro by a friend of my from France.  My impression of French food is that it comes in itsy-bitsy sizes and will cost you a fortune.  However, when I came here the first time, I was amazed by how small and laid back the place is.  It was very packed so reservation is highly recommended, especially for dinner.  They have many different plates on the menu but the two times I have eaten here I got the 3 course meal (appetizer, main plate, and desert), and it did not break my wallet.  The menu changes for the 3 course meal, so don't expect to come back and get the same delicious item you ordered last time.
I am not an expert in French cuisine, but the food here is very tasty.  The owner is very friendly and also very accommodating to his customers.   I would highly recommend this place for anybody who wants a decently priced good French food.
author: Al C.

description: I had a 6:30 reservation for 5 to celebrate my husband's birthday September 27th and thanks to our waiter Ivanir, we had an amazing time! Dinner was great, but the service was out of this world!! Thank you, from the Carrillo Family
author: Natalie C.

description:
The slow service provided by a confused waiter was torture.  A meal that should've been an hour stretched nearly to three hours.  

It's a good deal and the appetizers are good, but the entrees and dessert were disappointing.
author: Erika C.

description: C'est si Bon! I've been to France a number of times. When my heart is longing, I'll just come here. Love the food, atmosphere, service. The only reason I hesitate to give it rave reviews is that I don't want it to be impossible to get a reservation.
author: She H.

description: My wife and I love this restaurant. A little piece of Paris right in San Francisco. A classic French bistro with great food and moderately priced wine. A great neighborhood gem but also worth traveling for as its only one block from Glen Park BART and parking is easy. Check out their Sunday brunch as well. Reservations are advised on any night of the week.
author: Michael M.

description:
we've been here three times hoping we would have a better experience each time. Everyone raves about this place and we live in the neighborhood so we wanted to give it a few tries since all restaurants have off days. 

The food is really just eh and inconsistent. We've had just bland food, bad food (as in pretty sure these have gone bad muscles),  steak au poivre that didn't have a single peppercorn. Nothing we have had there was worth going back for.

We really did try, but can't get ourselves to go back for a mediocre meal
author: Rose L.

description:
I absolutely love this wonderful French Restaurant.  The service is always impeccable and I have never been served anything here I absolutely didn't love.  

Set in the lovely small town setting of the Glen Park District, this restaurant is located in a prime location.  It still maintains a very French cultured atmosphere.  When you are finished with your meal you are offered coffee.  There never seems to be the pushing you out the door rush so we can get the next party seated feeling.  Though found in most European restaurants, this is very rare in a San Francisco restaurant.

The prix fixe or "Neighborhood menu" is available Sunday through Thursday and offers something great for your tastebuds as well as for your dollar.  You absolutely cannot beat a 3 course meal for $22.00, especially for French food.

Some of my favorite dishes at the place are the Osso Buco (melts right of the bone),  the Biscuit Fondant au Chocolat Amer with Coconut Sorbet (this desert is so rich and decadent, the chocolate combined with the coconut sorbet is to die for), Bouillabaisse de poissons (I have never had a better bouillabaisse, and no matter how many times I have tried to remake it at home from scratch myself, I have never been able to master it.  This is the most amazing bouillabaisse I have ever had).

I love this place for its homey environment and the French comfort food it offers.  You will find me here at least once a week.  Even my few trips to France have not offered me what Le P'tit Laurent can dish out in a meal.
author: Krista L.

description:
My friend and I wandered in after a somewhat eventful evening, just looking for a good place to have dinner and catch up (we hadn't seen each other for about 1.5 years).  The place was packed around 7pm and we didn't have reservations, so we thought we'd have to look elswhere.  However, we got lucky and a table opened up.  

This is a small restaurant, but has a wonderful neighborhood feel to it, and not at all pretentious.  Actually, I think it's cozy and warm and would make for a nice date spot.  The hostess/waitress was very kind and helpful (very French, which added to the appeal--you know, just roll with it--smile).  All the servers were delightful.  The only reason I'm giving 4 stars instead of 5 is that service was slow (long time between courses).  I'm not complaining about it because I was there to catch up with an old friend, and I just figured that we were in the French mode of a long drawn-out meal.  However, you need to plan to spend a couple of hours there or perhaps inform the servers if you are in a hurry.

The food was far above our expectations.  We took advantage of the 3-course meal for $21, which was quite a bargain.  We both had the crab salad, which was good/average. I had the trout (they kindly made it with a different sauce since oyster beurre blanc is not my thing); my friend had the pork chop.  We shared, and were both impressed with both entrees.  Unlike some other reviewers, I found the seasoning to be perfect.  I really have no complaints or constructive critcism for this place (except the time committment already mentioned), which is such a rarity!

I went home and told my husband that I had found a great little French place where he and I need to go on our next "date night".  It's not near home, but we will certainly be back.
author: Areena M.

description: A friend lives in this neighborhood, and I often find myself at this restaurant.  The food is excellent, and the service is very friendly.
author: Robert B.

description:
I picked this to be the restaurant for celebrating my date's coming birthday last night. I got 7:30 reservation last night but had to wait a little bit past that for our table. That was fine. Unfortunately the table we had was a bit tight. The restaurant space is small and seems they packed tables wherever they can, especially the small ones. No big deal, this is SF with many small storefront spaces converted into restaurants.

The menu choices seemed small compared to what I recall of other French restaurants I've visited, which admittedly is less than a handful. We both ordered starters, the main plate, and dessert. I ordered the French onion soup because that's usually a must for me at this type of restaurant. Maybe I'm wrong but I thought it was saltier than it should be. Maybe I was influenced by my companion saying her tuna tartare appetizer seemed salty to her.

In the end we both finished and enjoyed our orders, but admittedly I felt the duck confit and casserole and sausage with white beans casserole had too much beans. I favor orange duck confit in French restaurants but the taste here was masked by the beans. That's just my personal opinion because I understand some other French restaurants serves this too.

The menu says it has a three-course "neighborhood special" for $22 on Sundays to Thursday. Since we came here in a Saturday night it wasn't available, but it looks like something to keep checking back for later in.
author: H K.

description:
Very nice setting, although the dining area is sufficiently small that you may wait tens of minutes after your reservation time. The service is professional, courteous, and efficient. The prices are reasonable in relation to the expense of the ingredients. The food is worth the wait, for the most part, but some dishes are disappointing. The portions are healthy. Here are some standout selections:

Sweetbreads: perfectly demembraned and swimming in a rich, beefy, brothy sauce. Delicious and among the best I've ever had.

Pain Pardu: A custard-y bread pudding (French toast) served with a caramel ice cream. I'm not big on sweets, but this was incredible.

Artichoke salad: A healthy portion of slightly over-dressed greens. The abundance of dressing was acceptable, though, and complimented the artichoke hearts nicely. This dish is bargain-priced for the effort and ingredients that go into it. .

Unfortunately, there were some disappointing selections as well. The following weren't bad, but they weren't remarkable:

Mussels with fries: The mussels were only okay in terms of freshness. They were quite straightforward; not much seasoning besides salt. Some fresh herbs would have given it a bit of brightness. The fries had a taste and texture typical of previously frozen potatoes, which is fine with me. What was not fine with me was that the fries were not oil blanched before the final fry. This ends up making the fries soggy, with no crispiness to speak of. This style is not to my liking, but that's just personal preference. I don't think it's horrible.

Rabbit with green beans: The rabbit seemed like it had been braised in a similar broth to the one used for the sweetbreads, which was a nice flavor. But it's a bit boring to taste it twice in a meal. Most disappointingly, the rabbit had become somewhat dry. Not tough, but dry and a little stringy. The leanness of rabbit makes it a challenging meat to prepare, so it's not a huge surprise. The green beans were sauteed and weren't unique in any way, good or bad. 

Bouillabaisse: Salty as the ocean, and not exactly bursting with freshness. This was the worst of the dishes I tried. 

Cassoulet: Salty, dry and stringy. The sausage had tasty anise overtones, but was also quite salty, leaving you with a double dose of salt.

I'm tempted to return and try the sea bass or the steak. But with all the other good French restaurants in the city, I doubt my return will be in the very near future.
author: Jeff K.

description:
I made an 8 PM reservation last night at Le P'tit Laurent for my boyfriend's 22nd birthday. We're new to the neighborhood, so we thought we'd try out some local fare.

The atmosphere was lively, but not too loud. My only complaint was that we were awkwardly placed at the table in the middle of the restaurant. 

Having just had our anniversary dinner fairly recently at Chapeau!, I was underwhelmed by the food and service here. The neighborhood menu was an absolute steal at $23 a person, but the food was just too salty and the dessert was kind of average...

I really wanted to like this place more, but I don't think I'll come back.
author: Patricia Q.

description:
Love the place.  Very intimate, quicker service than I expected from a French restaurant.  

Thought the escargot and tuna tartar salad was great, and the cream of spinach soup was divine.  My cassoulet was excellent, and I was also impressed they had Tattingers in the cooler.

Great place!
author: Steve F.

description: Simply amazing. Staff is so welcoming, food is done to perfection and in pretty large portions. Atmosphere is true to its name. We absolutely love this place from first sight!
author: Marina M.

description: Love this gem of a restaurant.  You can't go wrong with their prix fixe menu.
author: Misty A.

description: First time having French food and it was great. If they have the Chilean sea bass in the tomato cream sauce (it's a special), then go for that. Oysters were well presented but they weren't really my thing. This place really should have three dollar signs.
author: Siva M.

description:
To start making a reservation is a smart idea if you can! When you get seated and they bring you water ask for ice because they give you warm water in a bottle!!! WARM WATER!!! I don't understand how hard it is to give people cold water, is warm water a French thing? 

My salad was just okay, I had  mixed greens with fried artichoke and parmesan cheese over it, sounded better then it tasted. For my main I had the Salmon with lentils, it was good but I would have liked the cream sauce to have been more light or little of it. Last I had the apple tart, it was a little yuck then yum.

This restaurant sees to get a good turn out, and I think it is worth trying but I am not eager for go back any time soon.
author: T C.

description: I had the New York steak and the flavoring was blend, plus no green and just fries.  I had it medium rare but the cut of steak was still tough. My dad did love their mussels though.
author: Sandy C.

description: Great find! The menu was great with a fantastic quality/price ratio.  We had the soup, the artichoke salad, the smoked salmon as appetizers, and the lamb and salmon main courses, all very good (the salmon was a bit overcooked).  The place is very Frenchie, bistro style, and the only reason why I did not give it five starts is the noise, though that comes with the setting.  I will come back here and recommend this place for sure!
author: Sushi C.

description:
Great host. 
Great service. 
Great food. 
Great prices. 
You can't go wrong with the Neighborhood  Menu. Go for Le Pain Perdu for dessert... trust. 
For starters, sweetbread with walnut sauce. In case you did not know, not bread, rather the thymus gland if the animal. It's delicious.

Bonus for it's proximity to the Glen Park BART and home.
author: Geordie E.

description: We've loved Le P'tit Laurent for years, it's our favorite neighborhood choice for special occasions. And it's been reviewed so often, and so positively, that I've not felt compelled to chime in.  I still love it, but our dinner on a recent Friday night had definite shortcomings.  It's always busy and noisy and crowded, but the staff seemed to be coping less well.  Our waitress misunderstood part of our drink order, took our food order without writing it down but then returned because she had forgotten part of it; our main courses came out of the kitchen before our first course dishes were cleared; an unordered glass of wine appeared at the table.  My onion soup was more than a little oversalted to my taste, and I see several other Yelpers have made the same observation.  Moules/frites were wonderful as always; didn't have cassoulet this time, but it has been wonderful in the past.  Price seemed a bit steeper than before, $65/per with 1.5 drinks.  I'm still a believer, so I'm hoping this dinner was an exception rather than a sign of decline.
author: Joseph S.

description:
I went here with my wife a few months ago for dinner. The restaurant itself was low lit and not too loud (Tuesday night) so it made a nice setting for a cosy and intimate meal. I had the prefix menu with the pork chops. It was very savory and tender!

Solid service and very friendly staff. We'll definitely be back.
author: Alex Y.

description:
I feel like I'm on a whimsical movie set at Le P'Tit Laurent.  The frenzy of activity in this small, authentically Parisian bistro is closely supervised by the colorful Laurent, and his personal touch rubs off on patrons (such as myself) who practice rusty French phrases while imagining a view of the Eiffel Tower outside the window.

The food is very solid, well-executed, and satisfying, but stops short of exquisite except in the case of the mussels, which are large and meaty with a white wine-garlic broth that should be bottled or at least served from the tap alongside the Stella.

I also would give high marks to the tarte tatin.  I've found it hard to track down faithful renditions of this French classic in the U.S., and Laurent's version makes me nostalgic for the Left Bank.

Laurent's three-course, prix fixe "neighborhood menu" (Sun-Thurs) is an absurd steal at $24.  The menu changes every week, and I've been glad I've had reservations on each of my visits as there have been no empty tables in evidence.
author: Derek W.

description:
Made reservations for 8:30pm on a Thursday and was not seated until 9pm.  What is the point of making reservations? After being seated, it took another 10 minutes to be greeted by the waitress. I agree with Kim M in that although service is friendly, it was spotty during the dinner service.

Food was so heavy it made me a little sick...I had the sea bass which is suppose to be one of the lighter dishes.  Perhaps it was just what I ordered...
would return to try some other entrees.
author: Ren C.

description:
We were visiting SF and hadn't been in this neighborhood before. When we were walking around I noticed this bistro  and it looked like a nice place to book dinner. What perfect luck! I haven't had such an honest French meal like this outside of France. 

I had the rabbit with the salad frisee, both were impeccable. My husband had the trout which was also A-1. Service was great, and washing the meal down with a delicious glass of Calvados made for a perfect ending.
author: C I.

description: We just walked out after finding hairs in both our onion soup appetizer AND our lamp shank entree. They were very apologetic. I can deal with finding a hair, chalk it up to a fluke, but finding two in one sitting is absolutely inexcusable. Gross.
author: David M.

description:
I finally ate here, after constantly walking by and creeping out the diners when I stare in the window.

It's super french inside, decor and people included. It is, by far, the most not-in-France french place I've ever been in. Fellow francophiles will love that part. It's also very friendly and neighborhood-like. You can tell they love Glen Park, and vice-versa. 

The food is appropriately, also super french: rich, filling, and delicious. I started out with a creamy onion soup. Entree was a gut-blaster if ever there was one: steak (I forget what type) covered in foie gras sauce (a lot of it), with a side of greens. Discomfort aside, I had to get a vanilla creme brulee for dessert. Agreed with Beth W. that the sugar crust was a little thin, but it was still very well done, I thought. Wine list was great (we got a bottle of cote du rhone), and so was the service.

We walked out of there spending a little less than $100, total, which sweetened an already sweet deal. One of the best places in town, and I will definitely be back.
author: Tara R.

description:
staff is friendly and efficient 
the food was good, not too heavy nor light
the set menu is a really sweet price point 
ambiance is heartwarming
author: Whitne Y.

description: The food was excellent, with the rare full bar at an SF neighborhood restaurant.  I had the rabbit Normandy and it was amazing with a very generous portion.  I will be coming back.
author: Theodore G.

description: All French staff, friendly and helpful. Great food. Prix fix Thanksgiving dinner was not just delicious, but cheap at half the price. Will definitely come again.
author: Yannick L.

description: After living near Diamond Heights since 2005, I've been wanting to try this cute little bistro. Well last Friday my friends finally made that wish a reality and took me for dinner. All in all, it was a very good meal- solid French bistro food, enormous portions! And their baguettes with butter- tasted like they were flown straight from Paris. The three of us went through two baskets. Everyone was friendly and efficient.
author: Terry N.

description: Neighborhood special is really a special deal!  yummy yummy all in my tummy! =)
author: Akiliano T.

description:
Cozy, charming, and pretty authentic French, steps from Glen Park BART.

This place does Basic French extremely well.  
 - Onion soup served in the traditional manner, very hearty 
 - Escargots in parsley garlic butter ... yummy if you like 'em 
 - Vegetarian soup du jour, cream base but still managed to be light
 - NY Steak & frites with a rich reduction sauce 
 - I didn't try the rabbit but my colleague loved it
 - Braised lamb shank came with potato, was flavorful and fork tender
 - Grilled salmon was cooked thru and still moist, on a bed of lentils
 - Desserts were simple and yet fabulous:  creme caramel, tarte tatin

Portions are generous.  A 3-course meal will suffice.  Plus there's plenty of warm crusty baguette.  

Prices are reasonable.  Appetizers about $9, Mains about $24, Desserts about $7

We didn't get adventurous with wines.  The carafe of house red ($23) was great.

Space is tight, and some of the seating configurations are a bit awkward.  But the staff kind of makes up for that, with their warmth and French hospitality.

Recommended!
author: Robert B.

description:
I was taken here for my 21st birthday recently. 

It was a delight. The food was truly amazing (I highly suggest the Rabbit). The staff was very professional and had a very pleasant sense of humor to boot.  

When our table was not ready on time with our reservations we were given complimentary drink from the bar, which was a nice gesture. 

This place is wonderful.
author: Meghan L.

description: The steak was great.  Tried the cassoulet which was also great.  I would kill someone for the french toast dessert.
author: Kelvin S.

description:
SUMMARY: Pricing is good, as were the appetizers, but the seafood and dessert didn't keep up.

SETTING: Seating is not tight, the windows are big, and the silverware's has a solid heaviness.

PRICE: Most of the dishes are in the mid-hi teens (Monkfish = $17.95). PRIX FIXE = $19.95 (M-Th 5:30-7pm). Includes 1 of 2 appetizers (soup or salad), 1 of 2 entrees (fish or meat), and any dessert.

FOOD (see pics): 
TOMATO SALAD  = 5/5. Red and golden baby tomatoes with bleu cheese. Not tart at all, best part of meal.
TROUT = 3/5. Trout on a bed of spinach. Creamy, but bland.
MONKFISH = 3/5. Fish was a little rubbery and could've used more seasoning.
TART TARTIN w/ Caramel Ice Cream = 2/5. Bad choice of ice cream, tart not sweet enough and not warm enough.
author: David G.

description: We went here for dinner last night and it was as good as it gets!  The french onion soup was perfect, the beef stew and salmon were both amazing as well.  Dessert was as delicious as the whole experience.  The place is pretty small and you'll be in there tight, but it's not an issue.  Enjoy!
author: Shellynnie W.

description: The restaurant is very cute. Great food. The quality in food is spectacular and the food is a very authentic and French which is hard to come by.
author: V L.

description:
Came here the first time for a "girl's night out" upon a friend's suggestion and thought the food was amazing (I had the rack of lamb - so tender and juicy it slid off the bone with ease) while the ambiance was cozy and warm.

I have since introduced my boyfriend to the place and it has quickly become our favorite French restaurant in the city.  

All the dishes we have tried (including the escargot, the beef bourguignon, and the aforementioned rack of lamb) have been delicious. Perhaps our favorite, however, has been the Rabbit Normandy.  The rabbit is tender while it's accompanying sauce is so delicious we used our bread to make sure we soaked up every last drop.

Definitely going to come back and try the prix fixe menu.
author: Anne B.

description: LOVE the "neighborhood prix fixe" deal - $25 for three awesome, home-style cooking dishes! Lots of cream, which makes this European happy. Topped off the experience with the chocolate souffle. Fast, friendly service on a Friday. Can't wait to go back!
author: Eirik O.

description: Darling lil place in Glen Park. They do a great job with the meats; the star of all French Bistros. The staff is very friendly. It's a bit on the noisy and squooshy side but a fun place for casual dates or a nice dinner after work.
author: Shum S.

description:
Glen Park is a pretty small area but it's got a bit of charm to it.  And to add to that charm is this place right here, Le P'tit Laurent.  A small casual french spot that serves up an affordable yet delicious french meal.  It makes for a definite cool spot to meet/catch up with friends and such.  

They've also got a $@5 Prie Fix menu with an appetizer, main, and dessert.  Therefore, we cleverly ordered 2 of those and 1 other dish to share and try.  Great minds do think alike.  Between the three of us, we went to town on the menu and definitely had to go boxes:
-French Onion Soup - pretty much what you expect
-Creamy Vegetable Soup - the name probably doesn't sound as good as how it was because it tasted really good
-Mussels and French Fries - how could you go wrong with this?  Fries too?  The broth was perfect for soaking up with bread too
-Rabbit - My choice for the rabbit was influenced by the difficulty in finding it prepared the way it was and although the texture was close to chicken, it didn't taste gamey and with the flavor in the sauce, it was magnificent.
-Beef Osso Buco - this was flavorful indeed and had some bone marrow in it to add to the indulgence. 
-French Toast - probably not that great as it was just a bit drenched in its own sauce
-the other dessert was a crispy layered thing with ice cream - perfect

All that, 3/4 caraffe of wine, and a scotch on the rocks for $170.  Pretty good I'd say.
author: Vincent K.

description:
I wish I could speak French because I feel compelled to write this review in French.   Alas, I cannot.   From the moment I walked in, I felt as though I was transported to a bistro in Paris.  OK, maybe more like restaurants I had visited in a small town outside Beaune or in Nice because of the friendly service and relaxed atmosphere.  The food was great and the service was friendly and accommodating.  

Open for dinner only, I recommend making a reservation (by phone) because the place was pretty busy when my party of four came during the week.  They offer a three-course prix fixe "Neighborhood Menu" at $21-22, which is a great deal.  

One of us is a vegetarian and she ordered the Chef Vegetarian (see their menu), which looked beautiful and smelled incredible.  The rest of us had the Neighborhood Menu and each course we had was really great.  There was much praise for the potato leek soup which was offered as Soup du Jour.  The fish we had was cooked tenderly, served atop creamy polenta and flavorful sauce.  

Because we were in a hurry (such a crime, but the circumstance was such) we had communicated with our server about our time constraint.  She was really great about bringing our food out timely and offered to wrap our desserts to go, which I thought was very nice of her.

I see "not kid friendly" listed under the general info above, but while we were there a party showed up with a girl maybe four or five years old.  One of the restaurant staff immediately brought out a high chair and there was no fuss, no raising of the eye brow.  So if your kid is well behaved enough I don't see why you couldn't bring her/him.

I am definitely going back, and so is everyone  else in our party.  We all talked about how we are going to bring our SOs back here, so I think that means this is a great place for casual romantic dinner.
author: Alice A.

description:
Read as 3.5 stars.

This teeny place is always crowded.  As a fan of French bistro food, I was really excited to go here.  Despite an 8:00 reservation on a random Wednesday, we had to wait until 8:25 to be seated.  

The owner was very apologetic and brought us each a glass of sparkling wine to compensate.  It was really sweet, in my opinion, but my friend seemed happy with it.  The bread was warm and delightfully & deliciously crisped.  I did find the list of wine by the glass small and uninspired.

We both ordered the frisee salad.  Again, my friend enjoyed it more than I did. My poached egg was a bit overcooked and did not open and spread over the salad as it should and the salad seemed a little light on the bacon to me.  

I got the Beef Bourguignon.  It was good but lacking a little something and the potatoes were overly firm. 

We got an apple crisp for desert which despite taking more than 20 minutes to arrive was quite yummy.
author: Jeff P.

description:
What a mixed bag experience we had last night.  Walked in.  Waited at least 5 minutes to be great by one of the staff (not good).  She seated us immediately and the restaurant was full (good).  We ordered an appetizer that was suggested by the server.  It never came.  We order drinks (big mistake).  Mine was some undrinkable Kool Aid-like concoction.  Art's was poor but at least drinkable.  I told the server my drink was not satisfactory and order a vodka martinin, thinking you couldn't screw that up.  When the bartender finally brought the replacement drink (well over 5 minutes later), he slammed it down so hard the olives plopped out onto the table and he walked away.  I almost walked away at that moment, but friends were sitting in the next table and I didn't want to make a scene.  The server never noticed the olives on the table.  She also brought our entrees before the appetizer and when we asked about the appetizer, she said she forgot and she can bring it now!

This would be a zero star rating but for the fact that my sea bass was AMAZING.  Truly delicious.  I probably won't go back because there are too many good options where they actually have good service (this was worse than any service I've had in Paris).  Though, I'm tempted to go back for the sea bass.  It was terrific.
author: Kevin M.

description: Amazing food, friendly wait staff and great ambiance! Definiately some of the best French food I have had in SF!
author: Kristy M.

description: We had just gotten back from Paris the week before and were craving French food, and since we were going to be in the neighborhood, we made a last minute reservation and had no problems getting in on a Sunday night. What I love about this place is this is authentic French food. We ordered off of the Prix Fixe menu, which of course is so very French, and had the Beef Bourguignon. It was heavenly, flavorful, complex, tender and oh so delicious. This meal took us right back to Paris. And the place was packed. We'll be back!
author: Richard S.

description:
I make it a point to visit this restaurant every time I come to San Francisco.  The food and the service and the atmosphere are amazing.  Best food I've ever had.  Truly stupendous. 

The Neighborhood Menu is a great value. A three course meal for a fixed price and the selections are always very good.

If you want to order from the regular menu, I highly recommend the cassoulet.  Also the escargot appetizer is outstanding.

The chocolate souffle with coconut sorbet is excellent.  Sweet and refreshing. And the vanilla profiteroles with chocolate sauce is perfection.
author: Marlene M.

description:
Oy. This is a place I've given far more chances to redeem themselves than any restaurant should get. Every meal I've had here over the years has had decent high points but also low points and outright failures (cold food, flavorless preparations, etc.) mixed in. But friends and acquaintances continue to mention this place like it is something special, so I keep checking back to see if I have completely missed something.

This last time was no different. After a good carrot soup, I had the signature cassoulet. If you've had cassoulet in France, it tends to have structure and a bit of delicacy on top of its hearty, fatty peasant ingredients. Instead, here it is a watery bowl of giant meat chunks and beans that are not blended together at all. There is no evidence of any slow cooking: the meat, duck fat, beans, and broth should congeal somewhat. And it gives you the impression that this is French food interpreted by way of Nashville. This inconsistency is consistent with all my previous dinners here.

Perhaps this is what makes this an authentically French restaurant, besides the French-speaking staff. Many of the restaurants in France are hit-or-miss if not outright underwhelming, despite the dreamy images of French restaurants over in the States. Le P'tit Laurent is just as underwhelming as the many sub-par French bistros.

After giving this place a fifth try, I won't be coming back to test any more. I know precisely what I can expect from now on.
author: Teddy B.

description: This place is amazing! My wife and I after an hour of decision making on Yelp decided to come here, we were more than satisfied. Our drinks were top notch, French onion soup was off the charts delicious, and my lamb shank was fall of the bone perfect. The ambiance was great too, my wife and I felt like we were in France being greeted and seated by the owner. The place was so packed we had to sit at the bar, but the second there was a table available the owner quickly came to offer us the better seat!! He was so thoughtful, it was the best service I've had in a long time....
author: Tony L.

description: We took out friend for dinner. It was a busy Monday night good thing we made reservation for 5 people. 4 of us ordered neighborhood menu deal and one order of New York steak.  In my tongue the food tasted too salty but the service was great. One of the waiters speaks French during service and she was happy when I replied her in French. The food can be more enjoyable if they reduce the salt.
author: Skinny S.

description:
Pretty impressed, very good authentic French food in the heart of Glen Park. We had the fried artichoke salad and bacon/lentil soup to start. Both very tasty. 

Mains were chosen: an excellent poached salmon with leek sauce for my wife. Top notch. I had the rack of lamb, quality meat cooked to perfection with nice roast potatoes and sauce. Could have used more veg and potatoes but I always say that.

Excellent service, attentive but not intrusive. Place was busy but not noisy, good atmosphere. No problem tasting a couple of wines before choosing either. Very good meal all in all, and pretty reasonable price too.
author: Brian F.

description: We used to live in Paris, and Le P'tit Laurent is the closest thing that I have found in SF to a typical Parisian neighborhood bistrot.  The proprietor(the short, red-haired Laurent of the name) runs the place; and the food is excellent and moderately priced enough that you can enjoy it regularly. It is small, so reservations are advised, but we have had a good time eating at the (small) bar and chatting with the (usually French speaking) staff.
author: E A.

description: we went over for a Sunday brunch. the menu was trimmed, but everything tasted great, hosts (owners?) were friendly and chatty, and we had a great experience. a hidden gem!
author: Ehud K.

description:
After attempting to "walk in" to Le P'tit twice, I realized reservations were required.  My friend and I went last night and we had an exceptional dinner.  The prices were reasonable given the high quality of the ingredients, the service was polite and the atmosphere was charming.  What was quite unique was the noise level, not too loud, which allowed us to carry on a conversation across the table from each other.  

So, we started with a frisee salad with poached egg that was so unbelievably good I almost wanted to stop at that.  My friend asked for the recipe for the dressing, while she repeatedly dunked slices of French bread into the broth.  For a main course we shared the beet ravioli and the cassoulet.  The ravioli was brightly colored, attractive and tasty.  The cassoulet was meaty, rich and mouth-wateringly delicious.  Since we were full at this point, we normally would have stopped, but I had to try the tarte tatin and was not disappointed.  My only complaint about the restaurant was that it was rather warm and humid.  Still that would not stop me from coming back here and I highly recommend it to anyone wanting wonderful French food in the charming Glen Park neighborhood.
author: Virginia T.

description: This place is a MUST GO. Located in Glen Park neighborhood in SF. For those who don't really know, glen park is a great neighborhood away from the busy downtown but without leaving the city. Just a BART away. With that being said, I have had the pleasure to dine in this fine establishment. Nothing brings joy to me but good food paired with good wine enjoyed with amazing company. This restaurant definitely brings all that. And they do not break your bank. For $50-$60, you and a date have a complete French meal served to your satisfaction. I look forward to my next visit.
author: J C.

description:
I visited for dinner in February and we happened upon the great neighborhood deal of a three-course dinner for $20. 

It was 5:30p and we got squeezed into the last available tall chair seating. 

By 6p the place was packed with families and old people from the 'hood. 

While it was really cool to have the restaurant speak to you in French and it feels sooo authentic, it's also a tad awkward when I'm asked a question and I have no idea how to reply.  When I finally replied, "Ice water please." She muttered, "OK, chateau de eau."  

House water! You making fun of me lady?

But then there is the free flow of warm, crunchy baguette and the amuse bouche of salami and cornichons.

PS I was waiting outside of Canyon Market and took a picture of a dog sitting in the driver's seat of a car. I thought that it was funny. If you look closely at the background you'll see Mr. Laurent surrendering to my photography skillz.
author: Jacquee P.

description: We were here on a Friday night and made sure to come starving. Make reservations before hand. Five stars because I have no complaints at all. Dinner was outstanding and service was too. We sat at the bar and had Julien as our server/bartender for the night. We had the calamari and a goat cheese appetizer. Both were perfect. Calamari must be marinated before its coated and fried because it was so tender! The goat cheese on a price of sliced past with mixed greens and honey was so good, I was sad to share. Then we shared the cassoulet with duck confit. Yeah. Scraped the plate clean. Although I did share my duck. We finished the meal with caramel French toast with caramel ice cream and a couple lattes to wake us up from the food coma we were about to fall into. Everything outstanding. Julien was charming and attentive with suggestions ready. We could not have asked for a better evening.
author: Jena D.

description:
Yesterday was my first time trying French cuisine. I am so glad it happened at Le P'tit Laurent! My girlfriend and I along with two friends of ours decided to make it a double date, and we all really enjoyed ourselves and, of course, the food! I started my meal with the Escargots from Burgundy in garlic parsley butter which was incredible! I know people get grossed out by the thought, but really, this is one awesome dish! 
While I am drawing a blank on the name, the four of us decided to share a bottle of Chardonnay, which went so well with the 
Escargots that I thought I had died and gone to food and wine heaven! For my entrée, I had the rack of lamb with French green beans. I loved it! My girlfriend, and our friend Evelyn had the roasted lamb with potatoes, and they raved about them. Our friend Burt had the salmon and said it was excellent. For dessert, I had the Caramelized French Toast, Caramel Ice Cream dish, as did Burt. We both agreed that while a bit unusual, we really liked it. My apologies to Evelyn that I don't recall the dessert you had, but I know you loved it. My girlfriend, Donna, had the Vanilla Ice Cream Profiteroles, Warm Chocolate Sauce and was as happy as could be with it!

The service was wonderful! The owner, Roger, came to our table, despite the restaurant being at capacity, to check on us, and the server was very prompt and courteous at all times.

Speaking of the capacity crowd, if you're looking for intimate and quiet, this may not totally be the place, unless you're lucky enough to show up on a quiet night, but even on a Monday, the place was, as I said, packed. The overall experience was so wonderful, however, I can't even deduct a star from my review! The food, the service, and the fun our group had getting to know each other made for one wonderful, unforgettable experience! Le P'tit Laurent? Nous vous sommes extrêmement reconnaissants (   We are very grateful to you).
author: Alan W.

description: Appetizers were good. Everything else was very mediocre including the service...
author: David B.

description:
Some good friends took me here for a birthday dinner, and I was very pleased for the most part.  The ambiance and setting inside the restaurant was very casual Parisian neighborhood eatery, and nothing like the stuck-up European bistros you might find in the south of France.  And prices were incredibly reasonable priced compared to other well-known French restaurant in San Francisco. 
Too bad they didn't have any type of fois gois on their menu, considering that's what I was looking forward to. Apparently, it's only in the menu at a certain weeks, so call ahead if fois gois is what you're craving for.  Everything was delicious and tasty, but not spectacular.  Their french toast dessert is to die-for, and probably the best French Toast I ever had.
In short, this is a great a great neighborhood French restaurant w/ good food and service that won't put a dent in your wallet.  Merci!!
author: Emmett B.

description:
Being Pricey was expected but when I wanted the prix fixe  deal of meal I had to pay for the regular price at the end.  Certainly, it wasn't expected.
I go to the restaurants that fixed three course meal but pick and  choose from menu whatever I wanted.   I was thinking about the same deal and it was too dark to see the prix fixe's menu.  Even I was told the owner that I am here for the prix fixe meal he said nothing and let me do it without any prior to ordering.  In the end, I was surprised by the amount of bill.  And he didn't admit his mistake and still demand the paying for the whole thing.
The price was too high than it deserve to be so I won't go back there againl.
author: bluemoon p.

description:
Small, comfortable, casual, friendly place with good food at an incredible value.

I had the Neighborhood Special, 3-course fixed price for $22 which changes weekly and has a choice of two appetizers, two entrees and any dessert. I had lobster soup, veal with vegetables in wine sauce and chocolate souffle with coconut sorbet. I sampled the steamed mussels and cassoulet. 

Everything was wonderful, the portions generous and the service attentive, yet not overbearing. The restaurant also has a little bar with about 10 seats that was warm and welcoming.  

Parking isn't too difficult- there is a lot on Bosworth, it's walking distance from BART and 52/44 bus lines.

Le P'tit is a great addition to the neighborhood and a great place to bring someone when you want to get out of the city center.
author: Jessi H.

description: Le P'tit Laurent is one of our favorite restaurants in San Francisco. We love the atmosphere -- it's cozy and romantic! The food is tres magnifique, and the service is stellar. Laurent is always warm and welcoming. If you have never tried their melon soup, you must! My husband loves it.
author: Jessica L.

description: Just back from a wonderful dinner at Le P'tit Laurent in charming Glen Park, San Francisco. Foggy, Drizzly. Perfect. My oysters were followed by Chilean sea bass over braised watermelon radish with some terribly French sauce highlighted by lemon and star anise. Just great. Sorbets and espresso rounded off an un-oaked chardonnay Macon-Villages. Excellent all around and so now, 62.
author: David A.

description: I loved that place everytime I went. It feels like a real French place. Not too fancy, just authentic and real good food !
author: cyril l.

description: The food here is amazing, and the service impeccable. I have been here 3 times so far and every time have been very pleased with the food, as has everyone at the table. The beef is especially delicious- if I could eat it every day, I would!
author: Laura G.

description: The soup was vry good and i forgot what i ordered but overall was delicious. i will come back in the future.
author: Linda A.

description: A fabulous restaurant in Glenn Park.  The sauces are marvelous.  This is our go to place for fantastic French cuisine.
author: Tom J.

description: Had sea bass, and I have to say it was very good. But it was a bit too pricey, too. Waitpersons were very nice and attentive. Overall, it was a nice dining experience.
author: Mike M.

description: Delicious and intimate. Great local restaurant in a darling neighborhood. Great for date night or to take your family when they're in town. Beeg bourgignon, steak frites, French onion soup...everything we had was good.
author: Katie O.

description: The devil's in the details and Le P'tit Laurent gets those details pretty darn close to French perfection.  The highlight for me was really the escargot: Tender, buttery, and scalding hot.  While my Beef Bourgogne hit the right kind of pub crawl chic, it's the crispy French baguette and their blacked snails that'll have me coming back for more.
author: Michael D.

description: What an amazing surprise! The maître d fit us in. The creamed vegetable soup was "wow!" The beef Bourgogne melted in our mouth. Nice selection of wines. Prixe fix menu option made it reasonable with several dessert selections. Lovely neighborhood cafe with charm and pleasant service. Will come again!
author: Stephanie X.

description: Bad food, bad service, rude and loud people next to me. The service sucks.  The stupid waiter did not bring the first 2 courses and offered us desert as a comp and charged us for corkage fee.never go back.
author: E P.

description:
Very nice neighborhood eatery. I started with the sweatbread cassoulet which was very flavorful. Continued with the seafood bouillabaisse. The shrimps were huge, perfectly cooked. The fish was tender. The base was soup for the soul. 

I also stole a taste of the duck leg cassoulet, and was happy I didn't get it because although it was amazing, I would have been up all night from the heaviness of the dish. But I was more than happy to mooch a few bites from my friend.

I ended the evening with the creme brulee. But it was so cloying, I could only have a few bites.
author: tessie n.

description:
Go for the Prix Fixe!  So delicious and only $21!  

I got the salad to start off with - perfect combination of a light dressing with a super tasty cheese.  Then on to the chicken - well cooked with delicious brown sauce and even better.. the mashed potatoes.... finally, they let us pick ANY dessert from the menu!  The choices were not limited!  I got creme brule, of course, and it could not be better.  The host also recommended a bottle of wine that was tasty and only $31.  

The ambiance is cute, great for a date or anything really (I went with my cousin).  I told my dad about it and he's ready to go now too!

BTW luckily my cousin make a reservation as I was told the wait for 2 would be 1.5 hours.
author: Brittney B.

description:
We recently went her for a birthday party. We had wonderful service. The wine list had something for everyone. The steak was fantastic as well as the salmon. The appetitzers we had were tasty. It gets noisy, so I would not recommend for a first date or an meal with people you dont know very well. 
For my sisters birthday the whole restaurant sang. It was very sweet. I would suggest that they learn to make a proper dirty martini. The staff was great and taught us some fun french words!
Definately make reservations early for larger parties.
author: Angela G.

description: I went here for dinner on my birthday because I walk by it everyday needed an excuse to go in. I got the lamb and didn't love it but the drinks were good, great ambiance and our waitress was super sweet. I don't see myself as a repeat customer, but I had a good experience.
author: Aaron H.

description:
This place is awesome.  My husband and I went here for our fanniversary tonight and couldn't have been more pleased.

The food was absolutely delicious - from the crab salad and steamed musseles for appetizers, to the cassoulet and filet mignon - everything was so flavorful and delicous.  We topped it off with the perfiteroles with chocolate sauce which was amazing. 

Very reasonable priced food - I felt we hit a gold mine - with the quality of food to what you pay.  It's such a great deal.

The service was excellent as well - delightful wait staff and wonderful atmosphere - very cozy and comfortable, warm and inviting, I just can't say enought - we loved it.

We will definitely be back.
author: Gina C.

description: The food is wonderful country French home cooking. The menu hasn't changed over the years, but hey, why fix what ain't broken. The wait staff was very friendly and efficient. The decor could use a freshening up. The location is wonderful with the large windows overlooking a busy pedestrian street. It is a good French restaurant in charming Glen Park.
author: WhatDoIKnow S.

description: Le P'tit Laurent is good if your looking for homestyle french cuisine. The establishment itself is very small and the tables are very close to each other. Parking is easy. Its a convenient locals place. I would recommend this place if all the above is okay with you. I stop in from time to time so I can say with all certainty its  "A-OK" in my book.
author: Toni T.

description: Had a great dinner time here. The neighborhood menu is an excellent value. Great food, excellent, attentive service. $15 corkage. Nice atmosphere. A true neighborhood gem. Good idea to make a reservaton-this place gets packed!
author: Maria T.

description: The neighborhood menu is offered Sun-Thurs for $25pp. Great deal for good food. The staff and owner was very friendly. Would love to come back to try their neighborhood menu again as they it changes weekly.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Neighborhood menu rocks ill be here next week! Benny the waitress is very nice. The food was great! I will be back!
author: Elizabete Maria T.

description: A french bistro it is. Standard menu made well. Wasn't a fan of the french onion soup. The atmosphere was comfortable and homey in a good way. The owner was friendly. And I would definitely go back as a local french restaurant.
author: Raymond H.

description:
Have wondered about this place for a while, and finally made the trip. Well worth it. The wine is great, the onion soup was very good (though not the best I have ever had), the oysters were unreal, and the lamb shank was better than Kokkari. 

I will definitely be going back here, but word of advice, it is small, so unless you want to sit at the bar, make reservations.
author: BigArm K.

description:
Very nice little (very little) French restaurant in the heart of Glen Park, but you do not hear the outside noises and you are really transported into France so that, when you do step outside after your meal, you are shocked to be on US soil.

The waitressing staff seems to be all French and very polite and helpful.  The menu is a bit limited but very good.  The beets salade appetizer was delicious and the lapin (rabbit) was excellent as well.  There was a heavy sauce on the rabbit, which was not mentioned on the menu, but, other than that, it was very good.

We will be back!
author: Sailing A.

description: The 'neighborhood menu' option Monday through Thursday is a great deal.  Francophones will enjoy conversing in French with the fluent bi-lingual staff.
author: Chet M.

description:
I was treated to a fantastic birthday dinner here by some friends.  It's a tight squeeze, but on the night with all that rain, thunder, and lightning, it turned out to be a really cool experience.  Our waitress was really great at handling our table, comped me a birthday drink, and even though she got the entire restaurant to sing to me...I certainly appreciated the effort...and I was already wearing a friend-provided crown...

Would definitely return for some tasty French fare and earnest waitstaff.
author: P D.

description: The owner (I assume) is a complete racist jerk!  It seems if you are not French or at the very least caucasian he would prefer not to serve you.  Multiple times we went in and clearly saw different treatment.  Just walking in he grudgingly stated "bon jour" as if upset we came in.  Couple after couple (Caucasian) came in after us to an EMPHATIC "BON JOUR!!!!."  Following that the service was clearly not intended to make us comfortable.  Last time we went at that point, we got the hint.  I wish the Red Rock was still there instead.
author: Jose T.

description: DON'T order the steak with the wine recudtion sauce. The sauce tasted very strange. I tok it home in case my husbanc would like it. He isn't as particular as I am, but he didn't like it either. The escargot needed more seasonings. The service was great; the atmosphere fun; the prices are reasonable. It is too bad that what I ordered wasn't good.
author: Lynne T.

description:
Went there one night to celebrate my recent promotion.  We were actually aiming for Chenery Park a little up the street, but they were closed, so we ended up here.  The other reviewers were not kidding when they said that this place was tiny!  It really was, and the tables were so close together that you just generally had a feeling of being squished.  

The staff here were genuinely French, and our server was quick to suggest true French dishes on the menu to try, like the escargots for appetizers, the cassoulet for the entree, and the profiteroles for dessert.  The escargots at this place are probably the tastiest I've had so far.  The cassoulet was also very tasty and rich, so rich that I had to take more than half of it home as leftovers because I could not finish it.  I did not try the profiteroles, but my fiance and stepson cleaned their plates, so it must have been good.  

One other thing about this place is that the bread they serve once you sit down at a table just keep on coming.  As long as you finish one bread basket, out comes another one with another helping of butter.  So if you're a bread fan, this is your place.

As other reviewers have noted, the service here tends to be slow, but I think it's intentionally that way.  They definitely don't rush you as you're deciding to order, and they don't rush you to finish up your entrees and order dessert.  So if you've got 2 or 2.5 hours to spare for a meal, this place is worth a try.
author: Meg P.

description:
How could I have forgotten to write our review since April 2011? Urgh...

Hosted a party for my husband's 40th.  Laurent was so easy to work with to ensure variety within budget.  His wine suggestions are perfect.  He doesn't always recommend his high priced items either! He really listens to what you want or are looking for.  Party size was about 24 people and not a disappointed soul.   Their service did not lack either.  The kitchen & wait staff were perfectly synchronized.
author: Ange M.

description:
My husband took me here for my birthday last week - it was literally like stepping through the door and entering Paris. This neighborhood gem is super crowded, and has a prix fixe menu which changes weekly for 20 bucks from 5-7pm Sun to Thursdeee! Call for a ressy though, because this place is packed most nights of the week!

They were running super late on the day of my birthday, so we went up the street and browsed at Bird & Beckett Books, and when we returned, the hostess gave us each a glass of champagne and apologized for the wait. She was super friendly, and has a thick french accent, which I find ultra-charming. She also offered to put my flowers in the fridge while we were at dinner. Very thoughtful!

We shared oysters which were tasty and very fresh. I ordered the slow braised lamb leg, it was so tender the meat literally fell off of the bone! deeeelish! My hubby ordered their steak & pomme frites which were super yummy as well. The night ended with a very young french waiter singing me happy birthday with his french accent and I was charmed. 

Thanks for a great birthday dinner!

I also hear the same chef is opening a second restaurant in the lower haight...can't wait to try that one too!
author: Ingrid K.

description: This is easily one of the best "neighborhood" restaurants in SF. The owner/host is charming and remembers your name, even if you haven't been there for months. The food is excellent French comfort food. The rabbit in particular is my personal fav. And the drinks are super reasonable. Give it a try.
author: Jay N.

description: Fall of the bone, frenchy french good time. The waitstaff is full of life and very sweet. I love that its a nice neighborhood restaurant. Since they rotate the menu so frequently, you could probably eat here every night if you wanted to. My only complaints were that you can see right into the kitchen and it breaks the reality and nice atmosphere and the dessert plates are too big for the dessert and they usually give you the wrong utensils for dessert (dessert just slides around the plate while you attempt to  eat it with your spoon, when you should have been given a fork). This is place I would recommend to anyone living in the area or who wants a nice quaint dinner out. Non-pretentious and you can really taste the love and effort the cooks put into the food.
author: Heather T.

description:
I took a bit of a hiatus from writing reviews, but this restaurant brought me out of retirement because I want others to know what a gem this is!  It's tucked away in Glen Park, a lesser known area of San Francisco.  I wouldn't have even known about it but my French roommates French friends were raving about how extraordinary it was, so I felt compelled to try it out.  My bf threw me a surprise birthday party here a couple weeks ago...and I was definitely thrilled!

The service was generally attentive...the pace at which the food was brought out was a little on the slow side, but I think that was intentional too.  It allowed us time to hang out and chat over some lovely bottles of wine.  Incidentally, my bf had brought in a bottle of red and we weren't charged a corkage fee!  I don't know if that's typical, but it was a nice surprise.

The food was absolutely divine.  I sampled a little bit of the rack of lamb and it was outstanding!  I ordered the mussels appetizer, which was a very generous size and oh-so-yum-yum-yummy.  There was plenty of share around the table.  Silly me!  I also ordered the bouillabaisse...which bore a striking resemblance to the mussels, but of course had a lovely assortment of other seafood -- fish, shrimp, and miscellaneous goodies in a richer tomato-based  sauce.  Delectable!  

The desserts were a beautiful end to the meal. I shared chocolate cake paired with coconut ice cream. But I was really won over by the profiteroles! 

I will definitely make another trip out to LPL again soon!
author: Evelyn K.

description:
My family went because my husband found this place while scouting around the glen park bart station. 

My daughter and I had the prix fixe, while my husband had the salmon with red bean sauce. The red bean sauce was interesting...my husband loved the salmon though and my daughter and i loved our meals especially the dessert which you could choose from the regular dessert list. My daughter had some king of chocolate cake which turned out to be more jelloey but we were all fighting to eat it. I shared some sort of fruit crumble with my husband which was good but not as good as my daughter's...
author: jen j.

description:
I love this place for several reasons:

1. close to home. i can drink as much wine as i want and can take the bus home without a problem
2. food is wonderfully comforting and delicious. (braised short ribs were out of this world)  
3. this place is a definite reminder of a bistro is paris
author: liza c.

description:
Ate here last night- love the bistro atmosphere!  Everyone who waited on us was French, so I was definitely transported back to Paris, which was a nice feeling.  My honey had the lamb shank which was mammoth, while I had the Beef Bourgenion (sp?).  My dinner was a little on the salty side, but the meat was very, very tender.  We started with mussels and fries- can't beat that!  Could've had more garlic to my taste, but that's okay.  

The ambience was the best part of the experience for me.  I would definitely go back as it was a cool neighborhood place.  While we were there, people were on the elder, rather than the younger side, very casually dressed in jeans, etc.  Everyone was enjoying themselves and there were two birthdays going on, so I liked the fact that it was a good place to celebrate.
author: Kimberly C.

description:
I think I'm a bit of a french dork. 

I enjoy the usual Francofile shtick: I listen to that pseudo-Air music with lots of breathless women saying things that sound provocative, even if I don't understand what they are talking about. I convince myself I can speak French fluently after I've had one too many (much to the chagrin of those that actually speak French). And I have a photo of the Eiffel Tower on my desktop at work. Needless to say, this obsession with all things francais definitely spills over to dining. Voila--j'adore Le P'tit Laurent... 

I dream about their cassoulet. There is nothing more comforting to savor on a cold winter's evening (or...let's face it...a July evening in San Francisco--same difference). Beans that wrap you in a warm blanket of broth, chicken that trips over itself as it falls off the bone, and heavenly bits of duck. 

Our server was the sassiest French person I have ever met--petite, with her hair in a mischevious bob. When I ordered their signature desert--something with the P'tit Laurent name in the title, although I can't seem to find it on the menu now--she arched her eyebrow in what I would like to say was admiration, and said "D'accord". 

What I received was a refreshing combination of lemon sorbet and vodka--a grown up slushie that is the perfect end to a hearty meal, not only because it is light, but also because it kills any guilt that you may have picked up after performing a restaurant faux-pas like licking your plate clean.
author: Molly W.

description:
Great local authentic french food - rustic and cute! I love it because it reminds me of a french restaurant I ate at in Montreal. 
Definitely make a reservation though, so popular that sometimes there's a wait even with one. (minus one star) 
AMAZINGGG frisee salad, one of the best I've had. 
I also really enjoy their mussels, bouillabaisse, and beef bourguignon - definitely french comfort food! If you're ever having a bad day, come here and you'll immediately feel better.
author: Rachael G.

description: Again, everything top notch for everyone at the table. Rabbit, Lamb, Mahi-Mahi, Slugs in Garlic, Soup, wine selections, everything rocked. Great service from Beni and the staff. Another great neighborhood gem in SF!
author: Joe Bob J.

description:
Service: impeccable and amazing, the owner is funny as all get out!

Food: Some dishes were decent and others were amazing! We ordered the french fries and mussels for an appetizer which were both great!

My boyfriend had the cassole which was so-so to me but he really liked it.
I had the chicken which was the best dish of all we had!
His mom had the beef bourgeois which was really good too!

Atmosphere: quirky, cute French style.

Downfall: prices were a bit expensive for the portion sizes and took a bit long and the restaurant is small so it is very HOT in there! Not really any fresh air and no fans.
author: Deseray T.

description:
This has been my go to restaurant for visting family members, after work dinners, and impromptu "no, I really don't feel like cooking" nights out for years. The staff is friendly, laid back, and have adorable French accents that make you smile the second you walk in the door.  The neighborhood menu is a ridiculous bargain, and I occasionally dream about their profiteroles. They do get booked up quick, it's a tiny place, and you often have to wait past your reservation a decent amount of the time.  But now that the owner has taken over the cool oyster and wine bar across the street (Sel et Vin), who cares!  ALSO, and this is why I truly love them, they have high chairs.  Seriously. This is not the kind of place you would expect to be kid friendly, but there you have it. Generally just plain awesome.

So why the 4 stars?  As much as I want to give 5, this is a restaurant review, so the most important attribute is the food.  And I have had some dud meals (wow do they love the salt shaker).  It is not the best French in the city, for sure, but for $22 and with all the perks, you couldn't keep me away.
author: Jess L.

description: cute little place!  i love the setting.  it is very cozy and comfortable.  the best part is the awesome service.  The food? hmmn maybe brunch food is just not my thing.  we ordered smoked salmon salad, duck sausage special and escargo.  my mom loves my salmon and her special so i give it a four.  we both love the cofffee!! they have such awesome service ill be back here to try their dinner next time.
author: Elc C.

description:
We always mean to come here more often -- after all, how many "neighborhood French restaurants" are there in San Francisco? But it's usually so busy we either have to wait a long long time, or get a reservation, which is just what we did last night. 

Both my sweetie and I went for our usuals -- the frisee and bacon salad with poached egg for me, the mussels and frites for him. Both were delicious as usual. For the main course I had the lamb shank, which comes with an extremely generous portion of falling-off-the-bone tender lamb as well as plenty of chard. I agree with the other reviewer that the jus was a little overly salty, but this is a winning dish. My date had the fish special, monkfish over sauteed spinach and dressed with truffle sauce, which he says was tasty. 

Again, I went for my standby with dessert -- creme brulee. The sugar crust was too thin to shatter, but it sated my recent craving for burnt sugar nonetheless, so I'm not going to fault it for that. 

On top of all else, Laurent took our order and made sure that what I ordered would allow me to steer clear of any flour/wheat/gluten in my dinner. And they didn't rush us out of the restaurant at the end of the meal.
author: Beth W.

description:
This is a cozy french restaurant that is the perfect place for meeting with close friends or a romantic evening. It is the perfect place for good wine,  a great meal and good conversation.

My favorite dish is the duck cassoulet. The service is friendly, well informed regarding the menu and their bar tender or sommelier is great. This is one restaurant that provides good value. The sommelier was very helpful in selecting various glasses of wine to par with the meal. The price for the glasses of wine was very reasonable. Overall, food was very good and it was a delightful experience. Well worth it.
author: Evaristo V.

description: Whenever I need to be whisked away from our cloudy city to under the stars of Paris I go Laurents. His food is solid, (I can close my eyes, point to any dish on the menu and always be satisfied). Staff couldn't be friendlier, (and most of them are 'French') and overall ambiance is very warm. Le P'tit Laurent is off the beaten path of city chaos and absolutely wonderful. Very high marks!
author: Lena K.

description:
Cozy with a nice buzz of conversations milling around the room, this place is a stone's throw from my house. We went to it for our anniversary on the suggestion of a friend and we were overall pleased.

The food: The soup of the day -- potato leek -- was disappointing: watery and "meh," but the onion soup was incredible. The salads were tasty and original. The husband's salmon was wonderful and my steak was great. The lamb shank looked fantastic at the next table -- it fell off the bone (I should've ordered that), and the dessert was light and wonderful.

I'm giving the place 3 stars for a couple of reasons: 1) after clearing our table of our meal it took 20 minutes for someone / ANYONE to approach us to ask if we'd like coffee and dessert (we had 3 different people dealing with us through the course of the night and by this time of the evening the place had calmed down considerably. There was no reason for such a wait. 2) the chairs were THE most uncomfortable things I have ever sat in. And when we stood up to leave I knew I was going to be in trouble. My back is still out of whack 2 days later. For the menu price it would be a good idea to invest in some decent chairs. 

In all, good food, and friendly staff (maybe a bit off that night) would have me back in a snap, but the chairs will keep me away.
author: Jeff C.

description: 3.5....The bread was not good the night we were there, but I've heard this is not always the case.  We went prix fixe...neighborhood menu...$22.00.  First course,spinach salad with a citrisy dressing, sweet firm pear, nuts, blue cheese, and orange was fabulous.  The lamb was like a ragout and served with a homemade mushroom ravioli.  Tasted fine..very rich, but the color was just....bad...gray/beige.  The lamb was fatty...The pasta dough for the ravioli was al dente which is good.  3 sorbet scoops for dessert...pear,mango and lemon....refreshing after the rich entree and perfect. Fun waiter.
author: Bleep S.

description:
We went for my birthday. Cute and cozy neighbourhood restaurant. Good selections of wine and there was a very nice English bartender. Most of the other staff are quite friendly and french. The escargot in butter as an appetizer really yummy! The duck was good. The lamb was great. The trout was best! 
They also have a prix fixed  menu from M-Th from $22. If we lived closer, would check that out too.
author: Shaheen L.

description: Awesome ambiance, great food and a wonderful staff !! Cant say much :)
author: Amit S.

description:
Lovely litttle french restaurant.  A true French restaurant with true French food.  There were four of us, we all had something different from the menu, all was excellent.  The service was grand, attentive, but not overbearing.  The waitstaff was very busy, and managed to keep everything flowing in a space that requires hip pads elbow pads and a deft sense of manuvering in such a tiny space.
Reservations suggested, and do not go before your time, there is no place to wait, and the bar is packed.
author: Gary R.

description: If you want to try REAL French food?  Then this is the place to go to.  They have the staples of French food and everything is made with love.  Service is great,  I think we were waited on by the owner him self the whole night.  It's a cozy, old French decor.  When I tried the food I forgot that I was still in San Francisco.  Amazing experience!
author: Alison L.

description:
Neighborhood menu is an incredible deal, and the options are always delicious. We've taken friends here several times (with a reservation - restaurant is tiny so a reservation is key) and they always come away raving about the food. The lamb shank is particularly popular with all our Indian friends.

Oh, and the house red in the carafe is a great value as well!
author: Jaclyn C.

description:
Most French restaurants are too  "swift, hip, cool, attitudey" for my taste.

I  am more of a "laid back" type.

We had a gift certificate to LePetit Laurent, and went, for that reason.

We WILL be going back, monthly, at least....  The combination of price, atmosphere, service, and great quality is the best.   I had the steak, and my wife had the lamb....  Both were tops.

jack barry
author: John B.

description:
Every now and then, I find myself reminiscing about the good old days of my childhood:
-smoking a Gitane at recess while watching the girls play hopscotch; 
-debating with my buddy Benoit about the best way to undo a woman's bra when blindfolded and handcuffed;
-sharing a pichet de rouge and a philosphical discussion about the meaninglessness of it all...

Aaaaaaah, good times!

Then, I turned seven, and I had to get serious about life.

But one thing remained a constant: my fondness for a good entrecote (cuisson a point) with a side of frites.
So entering Le P'tit Laurent felt like taking a step into the past, what with the waitstaff all sporting the proper attire (white shirt, black pants) and accent (my waitress was from Caen).

The space is intimate: You'll bump into fellow patrons while making your way to the bar or squeezing through to reach your table. 
The space is noisy, although not due to some cooler-than-school soundtrack that makes conversation all but impossible. No, it's the sound of a happy clientele, most certainly well-lubricated by a rouge or blanc, and enjoying a tasty, well-cooked meal.

I started off with a frisee salad featuring a poached egg... Delicious, but somewhat overshadowed by my anticipation of the main dish. When it came, I found myself au paradis.
A beautifully-cooked entrecote with a sauce bordelaise and crunchy, golden fries. The aroma wafted up to my nostrils and a tear formed in my eye.
Dessert was a creme bruleed to perfection, sweet and smooth enough to make a grown man blush. 
The waitress gave me both a spoon AND a fork. I asked her if, where she comes from, people use forks to eat creme brulee (some sort of Norman custom, perhaps?). She replied, "Merde!" No, she didn't. She laughed and filled my wineglass.

Now, granted, my enjoyment of this meal has everything to do with growing up in the land of cheese-eating surrender monkeys. However, I do not hesitate for a nano-second in recommending this great eatery. It fills me with Gallic pride to do so.

Bon appetit!
author: Green L.

description:
Transformational experience!  Small, cozy, adorable setting and savory, rustic cuisine makes this place closer to dining in Paris than dining in Paris itself!  

Our silky, moist and fresh Blue Point oysters embodied a harmonious blend of the rich, sweet, and salty, which were beautifully balanced off by a glass of champagne.  Our succulent Frog Legs were tender and mild in flavor, pared with refreshing and citrusy beet salad.  The Cassoulet, which is said to date back to the 14th century, was the highest note of every French dinner I've had in this city thus far.  Imagine intense flavors of hearty stew of beans, pork sausages and tender "butter like" duck confit - all melting in your mouth at the same time...  

I know what you're thinking - "how can I possibly go on after undergoing such a miracle-like experience?"  But not to worry, enlightenment is quickly to follow, possibly even faster after the divine Crème Brûlée.
author: Tati K.

description:
If nothing else, the experience is authentic because to be frank, I haven't been treated this poorly by the French since I was in Paris.

I have tried twice to eat at this establishment. When they first opened I walked in on a Wednesday around 5 and asked if there was any way to get a table. The hostess nearly laughed at my request. She acted as if I had asked for a same day table at the French Laundry. Ok, fair enough. 

Round two. Last night my boyfriend and I walked in to try to get another last minute table. Upon entering I was immediately overwhelmed by the smell of varnish (they had just painted). I then noted that under the fresh paint smell there was a slight hint of something else-- the smell of dirty diaper. I couldn't believe my eyes, this place had allowed a diner to prop their dirty diapered infant up on the bar as they ate. 

I was still attempting to get the attention of the hostess while deciding which was more offensive-- the baby or the paint-- when a group of 3 French women physically pushed my boyfriend and I out of their way, waltzed into the restaurant doing "air kisses" and chanting "bon soir" and took the last available table. The host then approached and told us that we would have to eat at the bar (next to said smelly baby) because there wouldn't be another open table for several hours. We declined, thus, I can't comment on the food but I can say if you want an authentic French experience, go to Le P'tit Laurent.
author: christi m.

description:
This is the bomb!!!!
