Little Larry's rocks. It is my very humble, untrained opinion that this is one of the best restaurants in the city. You actually get what you pay for here. I've been in Little Larry's three times now and haven't had a bad experience yet. The soup of the day has always been great. So far I've had the Sea Bass and Mussels. My wife and I are going tomorrow night for supper. She hasn't been here yet and I can't wait to hear her impression on this place.

I strongly recommend this for anyone. It's located a block away from the GP BART station and it's also located right on a bus line. 

If Little Larry's is indicative of how the French eat everyday, then I want to go.
author: Wayne B.

description:
I've been meaning to get over here for quite a while now, and finally made my way here tonight.

This is a very small restaurant, and was very busy even at 7:30.  All of the servers speak French, oddly.  (!!)  That was a nice touch.  Makes me wish I paid more attention to junior high French that I was forced to take.  Three years, and all I can order is:  Un Coka, le Frie.  At any rate, it's best to have a reservation.  

The menu has a prix fixe option if you like.  But I went a' la carte and chose the Onion Soup, Steak Frites, and Profiteroles for dessert.

I'll start with the soup.  It was VERY good, but the onions should have been caramelized a bit longer.  The broth was seasoned very well, and the cheese and bread brought it all together, but I was looking for the sweetness of long cooked onions.  The Steak Frites was cooked to Medium Rare, but needed a bit more seasoning.  The steak comes topped with a port wine soft cheese, but I think I would have preferred Blue cheese, or just plain herb butter.  The Profiteroles were good, but I've had a bit better.  The cream puffs were almost crunchy, but the warm chocolate sauce was good.

So why four stars?  The service is very good, and made me overlook some of the food issues.  Don't get me wrong ... Le P'tit has good food, but some of it could have been executed better.  I suppose I should try more things, but I wanted to put in my thoughts before I go back, because I WILL forget what I had!

Food:  3 stars
Service:  Merits one additional star.

Since it's in Glen Park, that means no parking!
author: Michael M.

description:
I'm no french food connoisseur, but the service/ambiance/decor is pretty much what i expect. pure honesty and a bit of french rudeness give it that extra special something.

the food is perfectly priced in the middle range territory that makes it a nice affordable meal every once awhile but not an everyday thing.

the oysters were always fresh, the escargot perfectly seasoned in the most succulent sauce ever (bread dip worthy!). i've yet to be disappointed by the steak frites, the salmon, the rabbit, the scallops and dessert items (lemon vodka sorbert!!!!!)

the pre fixe menu is an excellent bargain giving you a classy sampling of what they have to offer. 

while some may complain about the service, i don't think it's anything really worth complaining about. americans just want to be pampered and serviced much too easily. 

this is fast becoming a family favorite.
author: Sean L.

description:
I remember when the existence of one semi-upscale restaurant in Glen Park was a big deal (that would be Chenery Park).  And now there's a full-on French place?  Note to self: must buy house here quickly, before we hit Noe-esque prices.

Of course, plenty of folks still haven't heard of Glen Park, so prices are still a relative bargain.  Especially the $20 3-course prix fixe, served before 7 PM Monday-Thursday.  Just the thing to temporarily melt away your food-crisis blues.

So, as a semi-local, I felt I had to check this place out in spite of the decidedly ambivalent food reviews.  And I'm glad I did; firstly, I absolutely love the space in here, with windows on 3 sides, a bar that perfectly anchors the room, and plenty of French kitsch.  Many reviewers refer to it as "cramped", but to me the density just emphasized the neighborhood feel, which I much prefer to typical French stuffiness.  Waiters are authentically French, and thus...quirky, but don't be intimidated--this is Glen Park, your neighborhood (or a neighborhood that's lucky to be getting your business - either way, you can botch your French pleasantries with your head held high).

And I really couldn't complain about any of the dishes (except for my usual rant: if I don't have to blow on the soup, it's cold).  My first experience with escargot went very nicely (perhaps because it was pre-shelled?  The texture is like calamari, by the way).  The braised lamb was as tender as duck, and the sea bass over creamy risotto...truly the way fish is meant to be.  Dessert menu is a bit run-of-the-mill, but the pot du creme is a deep dark abyss of chocolate, though again, I would have preferred it hotter.

Larry, I think this is the beginning of a beautiful gentrification.
author: Wes M.

description:
Just tried this place with some friends tonight.  We went for the fix price menu, or as they call it, the neighborhood menu, which costs $21.  It includes appetizer, main course, and dessert.  

The appetizer was calamari salad - basically a salad with pieces of calamari in it, and slivers of crunchy onions, and it was very tasty.  

The main course I had was sea bass, with lentils in a creme sauce.  I really liked it, though it was quite rich.  

For desert I tried some peach custardy thing, it was OK, it was my least favorite item of the night.  My friend had this warm chocolate cake with coconut sorbet on top, and that was delicious.

The restaurant is very comfortable and not stuffy, which kinda goes counter to what you think of as French.  Has a very neighborhood vibe.  It's medium-ish sized, and is quite loud with all the chatter.  But everyone seemed to be enjoying themselves.  It was crowded because most were there for the fix price deal.

The service was attentive and prompt.  The owner is quite theatrical when he serves food.

I'd go again to try more things on the fix price menu, as well as try other things on the regular menu.  For French, I say it's a really good deal.
author: Ramon C.

description:
Hands down the French place I keep recommending. What I like is that everything on their menu is just French (no pizza/italian/californian/fusion dish), their weekly menu (now 3 courses for $25) is a great deal. The quality of the food is consistent and great, plus they change their menu all the time. The owner Laurent is always nice, they have regular French-speaking people on their staff. 
It's a busy little place that makes me feel like I'm back home.
author: Agata H.

description: I love this place! (based on a single visit)  It is better than most of the comfort food and bistro fare that you can get in most of France.  The atmosphere is warm and friendly, as if you are stepping into a special neighborhood restaurant where the staff already know you.  The food is traditional, but exceptionally well executed.  The moules frites (mussels with fries) were tender and the broth so good that I drank all of it!  And the cassoulet was the best I have ever had, with smokey lardons and savory white beans, sausage and lean chicken on the bone.  My companion had exquisite lamb shank and is still raving about it! I will be going back....
author: James T.

description:
Mon Dieu, I love this place.  

I 've been wanting to try LPL for a while, having read the great reviews here, and having heard all about it from two of my foodie friends (and these girls have a high bar), and sadly, having just waved a wistful au revoir to my dear friends from France who just flew home to Paris after a wonderful visit here,  so it was THE choice for my birthday meal, and my French FIX.  5 stars for l'perfect night.

The Food:  Flawlessly excecuted,  I had the mussels with pommes frites, mushroom soup (sublime), beef bourguignon, pot du creme chocolate and lots (and lots) of wine.  Bread continually dipped into the broth of the mussels long after the critters were gone, forks and plates passed around the table sampling the salmon and poulet and profiteroles until the plates were clean.I weighed six more pounds the next day and still had the glow of a good meal so, darn it, I didn't even care.  God.  I love France.

And this place really feels like a slice of the real thing.  The atmosphere is cozy and happy, the staff are FRIENDLY, WELCOMING and GOOD (both the chef and Laurent came by the table to say hi at different points of the meal) and the food doesn't dissappoint, in fact it really will make you happy.
author: Mark N.

description: Great, intimate ambiance perfect for first dates. I had the onion soup, which is phenomenal and great on a cold winter's day, and the mussels, which is a dish large enough for two people to share. I ate them all because it's one of my most favorite dishes to eat in this lifetime. You also get a whole baguette to yourself. It is a bit pricey, but honestly, it is worth it if you want attentive service and wonderful French food. The desserts look fabulous, and are perfect to share as well. Profiteroles I will have to try next time I'm there. They have nice specials, with lots of fish options. Totally going back there again with family or maybe a date.
author: Gina R.

description:
I wish I could give this place 6 stars.  Since my first visit, I have been back many times.  It is reliably wonderful, an experience to look forward to.  The  food has never been bad--be it fish, beef, rabbit or lamb, it is all amazing.  The soups and the desserts are not to be missed either.

This place's real claim on my heart is the staff though.  They are attentive and endlessly friendly.  The last time we were there, my party stayed for over 2 hours on a meal that started with foie gras, proceeded through an amazing soup and salad, amazed us with steak and fish, and finished with a breath-taking round of deserts.  Through the whole thing, our waitress made suggestions, kept our water full and our dishes clear, and went out of our way to make sure we had a good time.  I spilled my wine at one point, not surprising given my clumsiness and how small the tables are.  She only smiled and dismissed my apologies, promptly bringing me a fresh glass (full of a French wine that she assured me was better than our Napa selection).  

All and all, this is definitely one of my top 5 in the Bay Area, maybe even my favorite.
author: Casey H.

description:
MIAM, MIAM!  We did not make a reservation and went there on a whim.  In fact, I think that we were under-dressed for the occasion (we had just come back from a hike).   Yet, the host GRACIOUSLY found us a table in the CROWD.  Apparently, this little bistro is quite a popular venue.

I was pleased to hear French spoken.  It was music to my ears.  The service was remarkable and the food, equally so.  Of course, any night that starts with flourish ends with flourish.  

We began with a glass of champagne and some appetizers.  My bf ordered the onion soup (DELICIOUS) and I started off with a salad (lovely dressing).  Then, we moved into the main course:  cassoulet for me and a salmon for the bf.  My meal was absolutely breathtaking.  The taste was truly on point.  It was most likely the best cassoulet that I've had.  My bf was lukewarm to his dish.  Yet...dessert...oh...spectacular.  My bf ordered the pot du dreme, which was rich and decadent.  I ordered the profiteroles, which were crispy and light.  

I was extremely pleased by the food and the service.  I would love to go back.  My bf may not be so eager, since we dropped over $100 for the entire meal (including tip), but it was WELL worth it!
author: Hiromi N.

description: The owner or the chef should visit the local farmers markets to see what fresh food is about. I had the neighborhood special on Thursday and the bay shrimp appetizer tasted as if it came from the bottom of the freezer. It was dressed with an uninspired cream dressing and served on a tough bitter piece of radicchio that could not be cut with a knife. I sent it back. The Mahi-mahi was also tired and dry and served with a lentil and carrot mixture that reminded my of canned peas and carrots adding nothing to the fish dish.  I met a friend who had been there with three people on Wed night and had the same experience. We have been to this restaurant in the past and found the food and price reasonable but will not be returning soon. If you do go stick to drinks and desserts and skip the  tired uninspired food. Too bad to waste a great location and nice bistro atmosphere on bad food.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
What a year its been... Watching the slow progression of this restaurant from bar, to half finished exterior to lines awaiting outside felt comparable to the year I had, except mine still feels like a half finished exterior with some of the framing still exposed. Even still, every time I've seen the world YELP I've cringed and thought "god I never go anywhere, no time, no desire... what a year." 

But that thought process took a vacation last night as my boyfriend, his parents and his sister took me to Le P'tit Laurent. They live just a block away and though the restaurant opened some time ago his mother vowed (every opportunity she got) to not go in until they finished painting the exterior. Last night she decided was the night and invited me to join the family. 

Two things to consider: 
1) For those who have not read my reviews I was born and raised on hybrid versions of Asian and Mexican cuisine. If it didn't have soy or some kind of ancho and cumin it was not in my diet. 
2) With out going too gravely into detail, living at home with the rents, and an impending surgery (minor but still surgery none the less) of one of said rents has drastically modified our diets at home and we eat virtually no salt and have switched from white rice to brown... Brown rice in a Filipino household? I know the sacrilege. 

My boyfriends father however, is half french and his Hapa mother spoke french for years and thus both have a fond appreciation for the finer points of french food. With that we 3 youngins were told we'd be eating escargot. As much as I cringed at the thought mostly all the pomp and circumstance and special tools to get such a small creature out of its shell. I was also gravely concerned about the texture, fearing it would be like eating a piece of tire. But I then said to myself... "Buck up you whimp. You're Filipina you can eat anything!" Attempting not to express this to the boyfriends family, I went for it and found it tasted like any other shelled creature (clam or mussel came to mind minus the fishy bit) and mostly like the butter garlic pesto they put on top. The act of taking out of the shell and consuming it went unnoticed by all, crisis averted. 

The bread was wonderful, the roasted tomato-asparagus soup I had was wonderful. I ordered the beef bourguignon and here's where I depart from rave reviews but I must return to my two things to consider. The meat was tender, veg were perfectly cooked but I did not entirely enjoy this dish. The issue is that I am unsure if it was me, or the dish that was to blame. Having eaten virtually no salt, my plate seemed extremely salty. I mean with every bite I took I wanted more then changed my mind as I could feel the salt bloat coming on. So tasty, but so salty. Perhaps this is how I got to know that the bread was so good. This morning I feel salt swollen and have to think of a way to get it all out of my system. Don't get me wrong I wouldn't take back the meal, I just wish it hadn't gone down like that, was it me? Or the dish?

I'll go back again when the opportunity presents itself, perhaps try the chicken, which I must point out the boyfriend's sister banned me from ordering the same thing as her, why I don't entirely understand.  The service was decent, as was everything else we ate, so when I'm feeling fancy and the boyfriend doesn't want to drive perhaps we'll head there again.
author: Niki M.

description:
The martini was too watery--they definitely bruised it..  

We have to go back and try again.  To be fair i should mention that we have had the good luck to eat in France...so this was a  disappointing meal because we had high expectations.  The lamb was fairly good,  but not  delicious.  In fact, the whole meal was very erratic in quality .   I kind of got the impression that the chef thinks he can cook because he is French and not because he can cook.

The soup had grainy bits of cheese, so clearly the chef does not know how to make a soup base (how can that be??  Don't all French people know how to make soup?  Isn't it in the genes?).  The osso bucco was  delicious but served barely warm. 

DO NOT GET THE CREME BRULEE--it was obviously made ahead --the top was COLD!!!  This also puzzles me because I expect creme brulee to be perfect in a French restaurant.  In fact, in my experience, I have found French to be exacting restaurateurs, so why this one was not... well any way the service was perfect.  Really very good attentive waitstaff, and helpful, too.  And the prices are extremely reasonable.
author: Jorah N.

description:
I ate at Le P'tit Laurent last night and I think it was one of the best dinners I have ever had in San Francisco!  (Makes me want to reduce all of my previous reviews by one star so that I can show just how fabulous I think this restaurant is.)

Usually I like clean "California" cooking and this was far from that but SOOO good!  I had a frisee salad with bacon and poached egg, beet ravioli which came in a sauce with so many wonderful things that you could hardly see the ravioli, and cassoulet.  The room is charming and even better, you can actually HEAR the person(s) you are dining with, even though the tables are close together . . .The crowd is mellow and the whole place has a wonderful vibe.  Don't miss it!
author: Ilse C.

description:
C'est magnifique! 

zis place, how do you say, ees very french, no? 

ah, bah, oui! It is! Once inside, it looks, feels, smells like you're in a bistro in Paris complete with loud Americans and French Speaking staff.

I went last night with a couple of friends, one of which is from Bordeaux, and we all thought this place very charming and the food very, very good. I guess we were hungry because we went through 3 baguette's (definitely not stingy with the bread) before our main dishes arrived. 

The prices - c'est pas chere -- pour 3 personnes -- $140 including glass of wine, desert, 3 entrees and cappeccino (sp?) (that's with tip!)

I will visit again!!!
author: Vanessa J.

description: we waited 15mins even we had a reservation, the place is small and crowded. The food was ok, just ok. I mean, nothing bad, I am just not impressived.
author: Spencer S.

description:
The atmosphere, food, and wine make this a teriffic restaurant experience.  We live in Bernal Heights, and we find ourselves frequently heading over for dinner.  And finally I'm writing a review because my partner and I both said, as we walked out, "Wow, that was an outstanding meal."  And on top of that, we felt that way after a very bad beginning at the restaurant (read on).  So it must have been good.

It was a chilly, blustery San Francisco evening, so I opted for the cassoulet.  It was outstanding.  Not the best I've ever had, but darn close.  And I didn't have to go to Paris or Brasserie Beck in Washington, DC.  Also, my partner had the bass, and he raved about it the entire time.  It was truly delicious.  We both also had onion soup, and again that was exceptional.  Fair warning -- you can't be afraid of salt here!  We are not, and we found everything was wonderfully seasoned.  But if you are tentative about salt, the cassoulet and onion soup in particular might be overwhelming.

The owner was friendly and recommended an excellent Burgundy wine with our meal.  He was great.  While he was serving us, we started talking about our favorite wines from Souther Rhone...and he went to his cellar to bring out a bottle to show us.  He explained why he favored this particular producer from the Southern Rhone.  Although we stuck with his original recommendation, it was an interesting discusison, and we appreciated it.

Our one complaint -- and the reason I cant give this restaurant 5 stars -- is the service.  Our server took over 10 minutes to approach us once we were seated.  No water, no bread...nothing...and we were literally about to walk out when finally she appeared to ask us if we'd like water.  We've been several times, and that isn't a "normal" occurrence by any means.  So we cut them some slack and stayed.  And we're glad we did.  That was the only blemish -- and it was a significant one -- on an otherwise truly excellent experience.  We'll go back for sure.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
We went to Le P'tit Laurent last Saturday and we were very happy to find this restaurant. We are a french group and we have looked for a french restaurant in SF. When we found Le P'tit Laurent we hoped to remember France. We were charmed by the greeting, food and environment. 
See you later for another dinner.
author: Jonathan R.

description:
Everything one of their entrees has been worth every penny.  They use really fresh ingredients and they cook their food perfectly. I've always been more impressed with their entrees than appetizers and far more by their appetizers than desserts. Its desserts are nothing special, even verging on mediocre, but their wonderful entrees and delicious bread make up for it.

If you go between Sunday-Thursday 5-7, they have a neighborhood special: 3 course Prix Fixe menu for $20. Choice between 2 appetizers, 2 entrees and a dessert from their dessert menu.

The service has never been short of wonderful! Make sure you make a reservation, particularly on weekends. You can probably get away with a walk-in on a weekday, but most likely not on a weekend.
author: Irene D.

description:
This place must be Glen Park's neighborhood gem because it's always packed. We were lucky to get a table within 10 minutes without a reservation on a weeknight. The service is prompt and very friendly. The decor is very cute: typical cozy french bistro with wood furniture and earthy colors. The food was unfortunately a bit of a disapointment. Everything sounded great on the menu (including the 3 course special prix fixe menu for $19.95 from 5:30-7pm) but the taste was just so so. The escargots and french onion soup were just ok as appetizers. As for the entrees,  the beef in the boeuf bourguignon was dry and the white wine broth for the mussels and frites lacked flavor. The best part of the meal was definitely the apple tarte tatin (upside down caramalized apple tart), one of my all time favorite desserts.


Ambiance: 4 stars
Food: 2.75 stars
Service: 4 stars
Overall: 3.5
author: Trinh T.

description:
Fabulous.  And I'm no Francophile.  Au contraire mes amis.   But here's the thing...I like French food.  I love Bistro fare.  I love places like Cafe Claude, and Bistro Roti (R.i.P.)  I love any cafe with "de la Presse" in its name.  And now, any restaurant with "P'tit Laurent," as well.

We went because they have a prix fixe menu which is soup or salad, entree and dessert for about $20.00.  Add a glass of wine and a nice tip, and three people, and I mean regular sized people, not Lilliputians, can have a good, filling meal for about $100.00.  This is very, VERY reasonable, for what was offered.

"What was offered,." you ask?

Well, for starters, I had the vegetable soup.  This was a creamy vegetable soup in a chicken stock soup base.  It was fantastic.  With a nice piece of French bread and a little butter....or a lot of butter, if you're in the mood, it makes for a great appetizer.

My entree?  It was sauteed shrimp and gnocci.  Great sauce, and in a twist on the usual approach, many more shrimp, than gnocci.  What made it superb, was the inclusion of asparagus tips.  

The other entree was a pork chop which was actually pretty well prepared...but enormous.  It came with creamy mashed potatoes and some veggetables...but the centerpiece was this massive piece of pork.  It was....a sight to behold.  

"Why," you wonder, "does that make it superb?"  Well...only because asparagus and brussel sprouts are two of my favorite vegetables  

And for dessert?  Creme Brulee...naturellemente.  I added a macchiato to top the meal, also, because I wanted to stay up until about four in the morning...both objectives, of course, were attained.  We also had profiteroles (yum) and a apple tarte which was very good.  

Though we went without a reservation, we were seated almost immediately.   And though it didn't appear to be on the menu, our bar hostess made me a lemonade the old fashioned, and truly French way....she squeezed lemon, added a little syrup, and gave me the glass with a big bottle of water.  Definitely a treat.  And finally....they have the most amazing ceiling.  A tin ceiling!  I don't know what constitutes a true French Bistro...but I do know this...a tin ceiling gets the extra star.   Yep....parking (which they don't have) and a tin ceiling (which they do) account for that little extra something that I look for when dining out.

If you are in the Glen Park area....this is a place you have to visit.  I felt like I'd been transported to France, and I only drove out from the Mission.

C'est fantastique!
author: Daniel O.

description:
Le P'tit Laurent is completely, dead-on like a bistrot that I would eat at in France.  The eclectic decor,  the slightly bossy but totally endearing service, the "we love butter and so will you" sauces on their plats.  Wine list was reasonably priced at around $6-8/glass.  The lapin rocked, but the escargot was too heavy on the herb, mild on garlic.  Saddy.

The prix-fixe menu is an awesome bargain, something that you would easily pay $20 bucks more for at Fringale or any other French restaurant that isn't in Glen Park.  

I also enjoyed being easily 30 years younger than anyone around me.  Wow, the crowd in there was geriatric on a Sunday.  But since the bulk of my bistro experience is eating with J's grandparents in Provence, I felt right at home.
author: Lorin Y.

description: Excellent service, food, and amazing atmosphere in this tiny Lil restaurant. Salmon was superb. Be sure u make reservations at least 2 hours before going. Its easy to do through yelp app!! Try the French toast dessert. Even their coffee was
author: o h.

description:
Though I don't think I'll soon forget my meal here, I'll write this review while the memory is still fresh. 

Like the vast majority of the people here, I'm an unabashed and unapologetic foodie. Visiting Paris while abroad was a pilgrimage. Since coming home, I've really missed homey French fare. Le P'tit surpassed all of my expectations!

I ate the Normandy-style rabbit, which was incredibly tender.  Easily one of the best rabbit dishes I've ever had.  The potatoes were a perfect complement, and the portion size was enormous.

For dessert, I ordered the Creme Brulee, which itself is a pretty reasonable standard by which to judge a restaurant.  The caramelized layer was the thinnest I've had in the states (for comparison, its about one fourth the thickness of what Chenery Park serves.) with tons of vanilla. The perfect end to a standout meal.

If you're looking for authentic bistrot fare, Le P'tit is the place to go.  Don't forget to make reservations, though...walk-ins tend to wait a while.
author: Zachary S.

description: If you want to feel like you are in Paris without taking a flight and without jet lag... just GO FOR IT! Le P'tit Laurent is the perfect place to eat French classic food from a Boeuf Bourgignon (Beef) to a Blanquette de Veau (Veal) I've been amazed by the quality and the service! The Chef is there and talk to you 'a la Francaise' which means he's taking time to check if everything is fine and even to know you better than just a 'Bonjour'! Great place, great food! Bon appetit!
author: Helene G.

description:
One of those neighborhood gems that you wish was located in your own neighborhood.    Came by on a Friday and although it was packed the staff worked hard to get us a table without a reservation.  However I would definitely recommend reservations.

Food is wonderful and bistro like -- colder the night better the food!

Bordeaux and cassoulet -- That's they way to go!
author: Douglas G.

description:
Great homey French food in a charming bisto setting. Owner and staff were very friendly (at there on Thanksgiving).

Loved the (highly recommended) Cassoulet, plus everything else we ordered. The wine is quite reasonable as well. Will return for sure.
author: Joey D.

description:
My husband and I stopped in on the off chance for brunch, as there seemed to be a few tables free. The host was welcoming and the service good. I had the vegetarian omelet and my husband had the ham and Swiss cheese omelet. Both were extremely tasty and loaded with wonderfully fresh herbs. They had a nice array of teas to choose from and husbands coffee was refilled three times. 

It would have been five stars but for the small piece of ham found lurking in my omelet and the slightly too squishy bench seat!!
author: Rachel P.

description:
We stopped by a few days after opening night, after failing miserably to find a simple tub of sour cream at the Canyon Market.  Had plenty of time to decide on a snack of escargots and house white.  Seems like they're still working out some kinks in the service... but eventually we got our bread and from that point everything just kept getting better.  After a few minutes spent peering around at the the decor (verdict: hard to miss the French theme, but not at all cheesy) we got our snails.

12 perfect, garlicky, buttery, basil-y escargots.  So good, and a great match with the bread and inexpensive wine.  With snails that good we couldn't resist dessert - three delicious profiteroles.

The drip coffee was mediocre... but 4 stars nonetheless.  We left happy, and surprisingly full.  We'll be back soon to try the entrees and the "neighborhood" prix fixe.
author: Brett W.

description:
6 of us went out to Le P'tit Laurent tonight.  Unfortunately, we had a very unsatisfying experience. 
Here is why:: 

1. We had to wait 1 hour past our scheduled reservation time to be seated. There were no comps, nor were there any apologies given for the large delay in time. We found this to represent a complete lack of planning on the part of the restaurant as well as lack of respect for their patrons.  And as there were 6 of us, and the interior of the restaurant is quite small, we could not wait inside and were instead left to fend for ourselves on the sidewalk. Did I mention that it was absolutely freezing outside? 

2. One person ordered the sea bass, which came to the table completely cold. And the reorder for this came out only lukewarm

3. Two people in our party ordered the Monkfish. Both orders were overcooked, although in the case of one, half of the fish was overcooked to the point of chewiness while the other half was perfectly fine. I informed our waiter of this.  The waiter went and spoke with the chef, and was told, "its supposed to be well done".  I was completely incensed that he didnt believe me.. 
How can he say that the order was properly prepared if half the order is good and the other half is bad. It seems as thought it would be obvious that the fish was not prepared well. I tried again to explain my issue but alas they were very dismissive.  I felt completely insulted.
Regardless of whether or not they believe what I say, they should show a certain degree of respect to the client, which was completely missing from this portion of our evening.

4. The second wine order we placed was dismissed by the waitress as not a good choice (They serve wine they don't feel is acceptable?) She said another wine was much better so we went with her recommendation instead.  The wine tasted like grape juice which is hard for a French wine to taste like.  I wish we hadn't listened to her.  Do not order the Languedoc 2003. 
5. We did not tip them well as we didn't feel teh experience warranted a good tip. And we were questioned about it repeatedly.  Eventually it caused a scene. And I chose to just add a bit more money so we could leave without anymore harrassment.

I am completely embarrased that I hyped this place up to my friends.  

The dinner was not worth the money.   I will not be going back to Le P'Tit Laurent because of the service and the inconsistency of the food.  If the owner had come by and taken care of the problems I may have had a different review. 

Sorry Mr. Laurent you have lost at least 6 customers tonight.
author: culinary q.

description:
Fourth time dining there,

Last time taking 3 friends out and one b-day girl.  My friends were an hour late, P'tit Laurent didn't mind.  The table was ours for the night (first class service in my opinion)

The food was excellent! We all tried different things and shared, everything was cooked to perfection, and the service impecible! It's nice they have a variety of wine, and we bought a carafe of house wine, it was delicious and in the budget.

I LOVE this place, I hope they stay in business, their prices are sooooo reasonable, and we must have had the table for 4-5 hours.(can't imagine how they make money).
author: Karen H.

description:
Went to this place for brunch when the line at Tyger's across the street was too long.  It was surprisingly tasty!  I got the Croque Monsieur, which is basically a ham and cheese sandwich with an egg on top of it.  It was delicious!  A pleasant surprise.

I haven't been here for dinner, so I can't comment on that.  But Brunch was good!
author: Chad H.

description: Had a very nice anniversary dinner with the husband last night-booked through Open Table.  We were seated promptly-had a lovely table and a complimentary glass of champagne for our anniversary (thank you Open Table and restaurant owner...) and that was really nice and much appreciated.  We had the tuna tartare app-deelish- and we both had the steak frites-YUMMY.  We both loved our dinner.  The service was just right- the place is tiny but whatever, we minded our own conversation and had a very nice dinner.  We will def return for the steak.  I would say the price is moderate for restaurants like this nowadays-almost $70, with no alcohol and no dessert.  We thought that was fine.
author: Shannon J.

description: If France is anything like the experience I had at Le p'tit Laurent, I'm getting on a jet plane now and moving to France. I'll live out my own Eat,pray,love dream. I'll put on my eating pants and Eat baguettes morning,noon and night. I'll Pray when the button flies off my pants, I don't hit anybody in the eye. I'll find a nice Frenchman to Love and have fabulous French babies. Wonderfully funny and warm staff. Food was c'est magnifique. Merci beaucoup Le p'tit laurent for a wonderful night.
author: Sophia C.

description: Food, value, atmosphere are a 5.  Its a little tight / small inside so its tough to give a full 5 stars.  Love this place, love the staff.  Great location, awesome food -- Absolutely love the Cassoulet and the French Toast dessert...
author: John B.

description: The service was excellent...the staff appeared to be having a good time...even when they made a mistake...a sign that they don't take themselves too seriously. The food was very good...the cassoulet was better than any I've had in France...there was much more meat than would normally be served in France - but the audience is American... This is a bistro-style restaurant so the intent is to serve good quality, flavorful food...not the latests and greatest foodie chow...and they succeed...The mid-priced wine was delicious and worked well with the dinner...Thanks.
author: Dan L.

description:
Hooray for Glen Park! Hooray for Le Pet't Laurent! I may not want to eat French food as often as I want, say, a good burrito (La Corneta) or tasty pizza (Gialana), but I love that it's available mere steps away from my front door.

On our inaugural visit, we both enjoyed a small yet flavorful tureen of onion soup. One of my favorite parts of this traditional dish is the gruyere gratinee, and I was not disappointed. (So strange that J. doesn't like cheese, but hey, more for me.) My rack of lamb was cooked perfectly, with different herbs than I'm used to. Alas, it was a bit saltier than I would've liked, but that's a relatively minor complaint. J.'s beef bourguignon was tasty, too.

Service was attentive but not obtrusive. I felt crammed in to the small dining room, though. It's not their fault that the space is small, but there should be perhaps one or two fewer tables.

Will I be back? Je pense que oui.
author: Tara M.

description:
Woot, I beat Ro V. to the review!

Took a special trip out to cute little Glen Park just to taste  the escargot here. (based on previous reviews)  Our little group is an adventurous one so we're down for a journey outside of the normal zones.  Although most of us had already tried escargot for some of us it was the first time! (ie.moi)

First impression, wao...tiny.  But hello, the name says it all!  It's size however does not make you feel cramped, I'd say it's more of a "cozy" feel.  The staff is excellent at maneuvering themselves around chairs and patrons at the bar without making you feel in the way.

The bartender was extremely helpful with wines I must mention, not in an intimidating snobbish way, like she was our friend really trying to help us out with our decision.  We felt totally at ease and very comfortable discussing wines with her.

Okay, so on with the food!!  I was surprised with the escargot, honestly I expected them to be rubbery and have a bad texture (like clams) what I got was a very soft supple meat inside, with buttery goodness.  I recommend for sure.  The dishes all 4 of us chose were amazing.  We each sampled each others and were so impressed.  Salmon *drool* with mashed potatoes underneath was my choice, I honestly didn't want to share!  Rabbit I sampled was perfectly cooked, my friend across from me had Boeuf Bourgignon (french-style pot roast) which was so yummy, the beef melted in your mouth.  My bf got the Cassoulet which he was very happy with, being that he IS French, this was like soul food for him.

Prices were great, food was excellent, staff super friendly and accommodating.  So why 4 stars?  The truth...desserts were lacking. 

We ordered 3 desserts (I'm a total dessert crazed maniac) Creme brule, chocolate creme pot, and the apple tart.  All in all, were we so bummed that the dessert changed our opinions from 5 to 4 stars.  We were truly sad about it.  Because first let me say, this place is awesome, I HIGHLY HIGHLY recommend it.  But the desserts were "meh".  The apple tart was cold and served on top of a wet pastry with apple slices in a weird molded mixture of applesauce. (literally tasted like Motts apple sauce to me) The creme brule was good according to my companions but it wasn't warm and the creme seemed too light to me, I like it a tad richer.  The chocolate creme was light and airy whiched suited it, and to me was the best of the 3 desserts.

I highly recommend this place, as far as *true* French cuisine goes, I think they hit the mark 100% and at an excellent price to boot!
author: Mary R.

description:
I'm no expert on French dining, but luckily during my experience at Le P'tit Laurent my date was!

We went in on a Sunday night with reservations, and the place was packed... with old people. The staff was warm and friendly, not standoffish as some people have said. Our table was a little awkward though, we were seated against a bench and they literally had to pull the table out completely to seat me, and pushed it back in -- essentially trapping me. "Um... I guess going to the bathroom is out of the question?"

Anyway, the French bread they brought out was delicious and the little pot of butter made indulging quite easy. I started with the green salad with feta and dijon, my date had the French onion soup. My salad was good, if unoriginal, but my date's soup was incredible. He said it was the best he'd ever had, and coming from a sassy French boy this is a good thing.

As a vegetarian they offered me one viable entree, a radish ravioli of sorts, while he ordered the rabbit. He polished his off, while I well... didn't. My dish was an awkward combination of stewed vegetables and gummy ravioli; the flavor was good and made a great dipping sauce for the bread, but the execution was poor. Tsk tsk. 

Then came the grand finale: DESSERT. This was the saving grace that made the meal all worthwhile. We ordered a chocolate pot de creme and an apple tart with caramel ice cream. So good. SO GOOD. Ahhh I will come back for either of those, time and again.

The ambiance of this place was really made by the Glen Park atmosphere. I adore Glen Park, and this restaurant fits in well with the small-town vibe. The interior is borderline tacky, but the staff was friendly and the food was good (and authentic, as I was told).

I would come back here for dessert and coffee, but I'd avoid a repeat of the soggy veggie entree fiasco. A good, romantic nook -- IF you're a carnivore.
author: Megan B.

description: Pretty good overall. Very good escargot and I enjoyed my salmon special in curry sauce throughly. Its really crowded and noisy and small. We had an 8 o clock reservation and were told to wait outside in the cold for 15 minutes after 8 till our table was ready. Pretty steep prices but good food.
author: William K.

description:
It's okay.  It's all right.  I can definitely say I KNOW my French food.  

I love me a Cassoulet.  This one was not great.  I ordered a Tarte Tartin (a dessert that I personally make exceptionally well) was not great.  Cote Sud in the Castro does a better job.

I think the only reason we got good service was that my father brought some frou frou French wine with him to have with dinner and the server was impressed.
author: Lynn L.

description: Small but beautiful decor. 6 people + alcohol = under $300. Great service. More locals than tourist
author: Lana L.

description:
I ended up eating here by accident.  Was really only planning on having a drink at the bar.  Ended up eating some really good food at the bar too. 

This carrot and artichoke soup was tart and tasty and the bouillabaisse was spot on.

I also like the decor and how small this restaurant is.  Guess you'd call it cozy if you were speaking in slumlord studio apartment terms.  

An awesome addition to Glen Park, and I'm not saying that because I live in the neighborhood and want my property value to go up.  

I'd definitely eat here again in a heartbeat.
author: Antichris E.

description:
Always on the lookout for french food, I dropped by this corner bistro with a friend, both of us self-professed devout francophiles, without rezzies.  We were told dinner was an hour wait & the full bar a half an hour.  Our sweet host Laurent, who I recognized quietly but immediately from Clementine in the Sunset, was impeccable in his service.  We were seated at the bar within 15 minutes & had dinner in front of us not too long after we ordered. 

Everything on the menu looked good, but we kept it simple ordering Mussels (fresh) & frites and Beef Bourginone for me.  The beef was tender & we sopped up the rest of the yummy sauce with the bread (we ate too much bread).

After a glass of french champagne & chardonnay each, our gracious bartender split a cocktail of St. Germain, an elderflower liqueur, plus champagne into two flutes for us to share...the perfect digestif, in my opinion......Onto to the next place for Trivia Night...

(4 stars)
author: Patty H.

description: Really great food, and truly excellent service. I will for sure be coming back often!
author: Carla D.

description:
LAY
OFF
THE SALT

That alone would improve the food experience here quite a bit.  This place deserves 4 stars solidly, but the Onion soup and the main course were overpowered with salt.  The creme brulee was pretty decent, but not that great.  For $180 dinner and a bottle of wine for two should be damned good, and I just wasn't that impressed.
author: Scott S.

description:
Disclaimer: I am not a French restaurant foodie, but I immediately felt I was getting the "real thing" at Le P'tit Laurent. 
   This place reminds me of the very early years at Le Central on Bush. Our group of 8 was really too large for this tiny place, but the staff did a great job making it all work out. We all were very pleased with the great service, authentic feeling French decor (all that was missing was the cigarette smoke), and the excellent food. A real treat was that all the tasty and generous dishes arrived hot at the same time!! The noise level is moderate, and the waitperson was excellent. A very nice addition to the Glen Park scene, and definiitely worth traveling to. I loved it!
author: laurence c.

description:
Stopped in for the first time last night. Nice ambiance, sharp service, solid food at slightly lower price points than I'm used to. Had the duck cassoulet, salad special, creme brulee. All worked out well.

Only downside was, ironically, the wine-by-the-glass/carafe selection. I only wanted one glass of red, but there were only two or three available, and the one I got was nothing to write home about. Was going to order a half carafe, but found out that the house red wine was a Pinot from the Central Valley. Wine list overall had a decent price range and selection, but I didn't feel like ordering a whole bottle last night.

But like Le P'tit Laurent and would go back.
author: Eileen B.

description:
There were many things I loved about living in Glen Park last summer, but this place was at the top of the list.  It's a tiny neighborhood restaurant in a tiny neighborhood, and it's every bit as cozy and comfortable as that would imply.

The service is noticeably on the slow side, but only because both staff and customers are so relaxed--I've definitely never felt neglected here.  On the contrary, I relish the feeling that I'm encouraged to linger over my meal for as long as I'd like.  It's the kind of attitude I love about being in Europe (or my native Midwest!) and rarely find in the Bay area.

Most importantly, the food is awesome and an amazing value if you take advantage of their weekday prix fixe menus.  I'm hard pressed to think of anywhere else in SF where you can get a generous multi-course meal in the twenty dollar range.  The dishes are rich, but like slow eating that's also my cup of tea--I've never been disappointed with anything I've ordered in my several visits here.  

Even though I'm temporarily away from SF, I make it a point to stop here whenever I'm passing through the city since it's easy to hop off 280 (or BART) and to find a place to park.  Nonetheless, I can't wait until I'm just around the corner again!
author: Elisabeth D.

description:
Oh Le P'tit Laurent, how I love you so! The boy and I took my mom here to impress her with our excellent taste in food, and Le P'tit didn't disappoint. 

The atmosphere kept my mom entertained. From the way the matre'd sassed with us to the eclectic decor to the rich dishes they serve, Le P'tit feels like walking into a small, family-run French restaurant. And for the most part, that's exactly what it is.

The meat dishes reflect this homey feel the best: the rabbit and lamb dishes are slow cooked until they practically melt off the bones. The rich taste is comforting, even if it may be too rich for some people. All the other entrees and appetizers are equally delicious.

My personal favorites when coming here are the soup du jours and the bread. Never doubt the power of the complimentary bread. In this case, it completely makes the meal. 

The desserts are not particularly special, but after the appetizers and entrees, it won't matter very much. The rest of the food (and atmosphere) is just too good.
author: Linh L.

description:
this restaurant is perfection.

every dish is thoughtfully created, and flawlessly executed. the timing is not rushed, nor is it painfully slow. the service is impeccable: the staff is helpful without being obtrusive. the ambiance is cozy, warm, and intimate. 

the neighborhood menu is a wonderful deal at $22 for three courses, and is updated weekly. 

somehow Laurent balances casual neighborhood and fine dining, without seeming pretentious or overwrought. 

enchanté. indeed.
author: Brooke B.

description:
My sole experience here was excellent. Took my wife there on the evening of her birthday - we live in Bernal/GP area, so just kind of wandered in and took our seats at the bar. 

French onion soup was crazy...and I went pretty simple on dinner - steak w/pomme frittes. Cooked to order (medium rare) w/the frittes - nice comfort meal . My wife got the salmon...both of our dishes were very good. 

Dessert was on the house thanks to it being my wife's b-day, and they sent her home w/a nice bottle of Pinot Noir as a gift. Nice touch.

Nice having this little, cozy spot in the 'hood. Got a little attitude on the front end, but just give it back and all's well! The owner (that would be Little Larry) behind the bar was really kind and helpful. Had a nice Bordeaux w/the meal to boot. The tab was reasonable for the quality and ambiance. We'll be back for sure.
author: Carmine D.

description: French All the Way!!!  It's not a gimmick or a theme restaurant, it really is a little French bistro with real, down to earth dinner fares (not fusion french food), EXCELLENT service, reasonable price and a full bar.  The awesome bartender even made me a great mojito with fresh mint and all.  They have Chimay on tap, great wine and champagne.  For those of us in the area, this is a real GEM, a gift from culinary heavens, right at our doorstep.
author: Barndi K.

description:
They serve the house wine in a little ceramic jug that holds A LOT more than you would expect (love that). Good bread, good wine, good snails (pretty shells), lively atmosphere, plus, lots of Frenchies in this joint.  It's usually packed to the gills so make a reservation.
3 weeks later... So I made a reservation this time and came back for a real dinner (and more wine and snails and bread).  I had the rich, bean and lamb cassoulet, which is clearly the ideal entree for a cold and foggy Glen Park night (they usually don't make it with lamb but I think they ran out of pork or duck or something).  My dining cohorts each had a perfectly prepared salmon on a bed of spinach and creamy mashed potatoes. Also, most of  the servers at P'tit Laurent have accents so after a couple of those little ceramic wine jugs, you feel like you might actually be in France. HA!
author: Kerrinski S.

description:
This place is wonderful! Friend of mine suggested we eat there one night and had no idea that the restaurant was even there. Last time I was in the Glen Park area that particular spot was a bar. Anyway, this is a must visit. 

French cuisine but not french portions. The staff speak french but they aren't obnoxious. Everyone was very friendly and courteous. The wine list is diverse and has something for everyone. We sat at the bar and were served by the delightful Gena. What a sweetie. Great suggestions on food and wine. We had the lamb and the beef and then finished with the cheese plate and a shot of fernet each. LOL. Make a reservation. This is a popular place. I can't wait to go back.
author: Heather L.

description:
I have eaten at Le P'tit Laurent twice now. Once for brunch - Croque Madame - and once for dinner - Cassoulet.  Both times were very enjoyable. My wife and I took our 10 month old baby to brunch and she was made extremely welcome. For dinner I sat at the bar with a Parisian friend (who was in his element) and we had a great meal and even better wine. The woman working behind the bar was good fun and not over intrusive. She persuaded me to try white port - a first for me - though I think I prefer the red variety.

Great job at turning a shitty old cocktail bar into a great neighborhood gem.

**Interesting xenophobic comment from one reviewer - being French is not synonymous with being rude.**
author: Tony H.

description:
Le P'tit Laurent seems like a solid place overall, and I applaud it for helping to raise the profile of Glen Park, but it just didn't cut it for a vegetarian.

The service was great - owner, waiters and bartenders are very friendly - but there wasn't a lot of choice for vegetarians. I suppose that I should expect that from a French place, but I just didn't feel like I got my money's worth.

The chef and owner were nice enough to make a special-order vegetarian entree, and it was good, but not great enough to justify the price that we paid. After a 3-course meal, my dinner companion and I left feeling less satisfied than our $110 bill would have justified.

I hope I'm not being unfair - I'm sure it's a great place if you eat meat - but if you're a vegetarian, I'd recommend one of the other restaurants within a block of this place.
author: Sekhar S.

description: My husband and I went here for our 13 year anniversary this weekend.  We used to live in Glen Park years ago when they first started.  We moved 4 years ago, and wanted to go to Laurent for our visit back to the city.  This place has the best food, service and ambiance. Truly the best burgundy beef I have ever had.  I can't say enough good things about this place. You will not be disappointed.
author: Marla Z.

description:
Met up with some friends after far too long. We've been meaning to get together forever, but they have kids. Don't get me wrong. I love kids, especially the little guys. But friends with kids always want to get out for a grown-up time and have to arrange for sitters and before you know it, months have past. And they might even have a new little person. Which leads to more babysitting issues.

So finally we get together. We meet at Le P'tit Laurent where both Hubs and his old school pal have been, but the wives have not. 

To start, we had a delicious salad with goat cheese and tiny tomatoes and a big ol' plate of delectable escargot. I am usually not a huge fan of the snails but these were fabulous!

All but me had the neighborhood menu (the prix fixe) with a scrumptious soup and fish or pork chop. I sampled the fish - delish! I had the cassoulet - so yummy and homey with just the right hint of pretension (so I wouldn't feel like I could have done it myself with enough time and the right recipe).

A perfectly wonderful meal. Right in our own backyard!
author: Vanessa L.

description:
I like to write reviews where I get to rave, either positive or negative.  I can't quite muster the enthusiasm for either, where Le P'tit Laurent is concerned. 

The food is good: not bad, not great.
The service is brusque: neither friendly nor rude

Despite this, they are always packed, which might be why I get the feeling that they don't think they have to try very hard. 

I do love the buttery wonderful escargot...  and the entrees are fine...   and I keep coming back...  I just wish I could enjoy myself more while eating here.
author: Miss Information X.

description: I just had one of the worst brunches ever. First, I've never had a weaker, more tasteless Bloody Mary in my life. The vegetable omelette was covered with horrible hollaindaise sauce (which was not included in the description on the menu), and it was filled with over-cooked, soggy veggies. (And oh yeah, this was after being brought the wrong omelette--and there are only two kinds on the menu.) I got a decent side salad instead of the fries that were on the menu. But for a place that's trying to develop a brunch following, this was hardly promising.
author: Fred S.

description: Amazing food! Sea bass w/ risotto was delish, and the salmon entree as well! I shall definitely make another appearance at this place soon. The maitre d' /waiter was very entertaining w/ his dry humor. The ambiance was very cozy perfect for romantic dinner or simply enjoying a meal with wonderful foodie friends. Oops I almost forgot  the profiterole dessert---A+ for sure.
author: LaDig Q.

description: There is a neighborhood menu (prix-fix) Sunday-Thursday for $22 that is quite the deal, but I ordered from the main menu.  First of all, the service is fantastic, never did my bread basket empty nor my water glass.  I started with the onion soup, which was perfect.  It reminded me exactly of the soup I had in Paris, not too salty, just perfect.  The waiter even suggested next time I could order it with extra cheese, but I wouldn't change a thing.  Next I had the tuna-tartar, and I was tempted to order a second because it was so good.  I decided to get the Cassoulet, which is a strong dish, with beans, duck, pork and sausage.  It is a rich filling dish and I was getting stuffed.  For dessert I opted for the sorbet sampler to cool and cleanse my palate, my favorite was the pear.  I wouldn't hesitate a trip back to try everything else on the menu!
author: Shawn H.

description: Really enjoyed the cocktails, and friendly staff. However, the entrees were a little too salty and dehydrating. It took away from the other flavors in the dish (he had the chicken, I had the lamb shank). Escargot was delicious. Creme Brulee is my favorite dessert. I was disappointed that the service was relatively slow overall, and (while we weren't in a rush) I was disheartened that it took them nearly 20 minutes after I placed the dessert order for them to merely return and say they were out. I didn't bother ordering anything else. While not-bad, it didn't really wow me enough to return (for the price).
author: Shawne B.

description:
I love this place. The maitre di is warm and nice, the waitress is fun and interesting, the dinner food in particular is just lovely, and the winelist is good. And they don't try to sell you priciest wine either merely one in your pricerange that goes with the food. 

Since writing this I changed my review from 4 to 5 stars. Laurent is overall magnifique. Two comments though, the beet ravioli was better when it first opened. The sauce was cremier and more delicious, and maple syrup does not come automatically with the french toast. Maple syrup probably isn't served in france but I crave it for breakfast.

What a wonderful addition to Glen Park! I will go there for years to come.
author: Denise D.

description:
neighborhood menu!!!!!!!!

if you did not love me before, you will love me for suggesting this place.

super friendly wait staff. great prices & comfy classic french food.

i did the neighborhood special prix-fix menu for only $22!!! what the whaaaaaaaaaaaaaat???? really great french food & service for applebee prices....this is nuts. like upside down world.

for the fixed menu last night, you get the soup du jour, a choice of red snapper or sliced duck breast for the entree and dessert..

i got the escargot, carafe or red wine, french onion soup ($2.50 extra to sub this), the sliced duck, and the french toast for dessert. 

All so tasty & really great service. 
such an unexpected gem.
Will be coming back!!!
author: Tiger Lily ..

description: I've been here twice and love it. The first time was actually a better experience - it was my birthday and my brother & I arrived without a reservation to a packed restaurant. The owner took pity and found us a table after only a short wait. The staff treated us like royalty the whole night and even brought me a complimentary bd dessert (embarrassing but sweet). The 2nd time the wait staff was different and not as charming - not their fault - they tried, but it seemed a little disingenuous. Food both times was spectacular, wine both times could use a little improvement. Ambience - they pack it in, but it's o.k. I never felt too crushed. I love that it's a neighborhood place where the owner clearly puts his heart and soul into every detail. Meilleurs voeux!
author: Vida Equilibrada L.

description:
Just like L'Ardoise, Le P'tit Laurent is a great (perfect) neighborhood French restaurant. The only reason I didn't give them 5 stars is because I keep the 5th star in my pocket for restaurants like La Folie. 
Dinner was flawless, delicious, great service! And the price reasonable. Go!
author: Frances G.

description: Le P'tit Laurent has been in Glen park since we moved to the neighborhood. It is NOT one of those restaurants that after they are established, food and quality go down hill, NO! this restaurant never disappointed us. Food is always excellent, ambiance is great, and the service is also very nice. I had the menu for the night, starting with a salad, it was refreshing, and my friends had the special soup, which was very delicious, and for the main course, I had salmon, my friends had mussels and cassoulet- they all were excellent. It was a Sunday evening, the restaurant was energetic, service was fast and everyone was friendly. The wine selection was also decent. The overall experience is very authentic French bistro with amazingly good quality service. It's definitely one of the best French restaurants in SF in its category, perfect for a relaxed, positive  dining experience. I think it is a perfect fit for Glen Park. Hope it will be there for many many years to come!
author: Ann W.

description: This was a definitely a dining experience! As soon as you walk in you feel like you are taken out of SF and into France. The wait staff is incredible and this is coming from a waiter and culinary school graduate. I felt like they treated me as a regular even though I am not, but I might become one now. The food is simply divine so many different flavors perfectly crafted into each dish. I won't even suggest any particular dish because I know everything they do they do it to perfection. Treat yourself to this amazing place and you will not regret it. Thank you Le P'tit Laurent for the amazing dinner it was like I told our waitress "life changing" Bon Appétit!
author: James E.

description: I'm not a fan of French food, but this place never disappoints. Great service--the owner is magnificant and the fish is always amazing.
author: Dawn D.

description: Oh so sad that this wasn't a better experience. I've been wanting to go for a while now and finally last Saturday... Salad was overdressed and heavy, meat was salty... French food is supposed to be understated - this is like the McDonald's of French cuisine. Worst of all it was boiling hot in the restaurant. I mean like sauna hot. We ran out of there after dinner just to get some air. It is an adorable place though and I have to hope it was just a bad night. Won't go again though - so many great places to choose from why take a risk?
author: Keko K.

description:
Small place. Best to make reservations... but worth the wait.
Yummy food! We've tried most the menu and each dish was very good.
The Escargot (YUM), Onion Soup,Frisée salad with bacon and poached egg, sherry vinaigrette,Sauteed sweetbread with spinach,Red beet raviolis with Parmesan cheese and seasonal vegetables,Sauteed bass......  I could go on... all YUUUUUUUMM!!
Definitely a place to "Dine"... not a place for you if you are in a rush!
Check it out yo!
author: Kara Y.

description:
good services, good food, good price, fall in love with this place after the first time.     

must try their coffee and dessert........  so tasty.........  

remember must make reservation......  this place always pack.....
author: Cora L.

description: Love, love, love this place. Their neighborhood 3-course menu is a bargain. Their soups are delicious, recently had the potato leek which was great. We have yet to have something on the menu that disappoints us. I particularly like the lamb shank. The pan perdu for dessert is WOW!
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description: Tonight was our first time at Le P'tit Laurent and it will be our last. What a rip-off!  Granted, it was Valentine's Day, and maybe everyone (but us) assumes that those special Valentine's Day menus are rip-offs, but we paid $69 each for an appetizer, main course, and dessert sampler that were nothing special, and did not include wine or coffee.  However, what turned us off most about Le  P'tit Laurent was the service. The atmosphere is French bistro, and the staff speaks French, but the service was anything but. We were rushed through the meal, fast-food American style, from the moment we sat down. They didn't wait until we finished our wine before plopping down the "coupe de champagne" at the end of the meal, and brought us our bill before we finished our dessert, without bothering to ask if we wanted coffee, or anything else. There were no other customers waiting for tables, so I don't know what the rush was, but if you're looking for a leisurely meal prepared and served with the care only a chef and staff can give who truly love food in the French tradition, this is not the place.
author: Ellen B.

description:
I was there last nite to celebrate my 1 yr annv with my bf.  i have to say, for 20 bucks, the food is pretty good. great portions and the pre-fix was pretty good food. we had the seafood paella (a little on the salty side for me, but bf said it was good) and pork tenderloin with mashed potatoes, damn, the mash was goood and creamy...yum.

ordered the escargo, it was delicous. but u have to love butter, cuz that was what it was drenched in. we just soaked it up with our bread, cuz u can't waste like that.  it was very garlicky, just the way i like my butter.

i had to take one star off cuz for dessert, i ordered the warm apple tart, but it wasn't warm.  i'm picky like that.

for $60 tax and tip, it was a fine 3 course meal.

***updated 5/28/2008

went back for their neighborhood menu last nite with a friend.  we got there early so getting a table with no reservation was easy peasy.  we got seated in the high chair table by the big window.  it would have been a great experience for both if it wasn't for the sun baking us all thru dinner.  All the other windows had coverings, except for the one we were sitting next to.  I asked both the waitress and our busboy if there was anything they can do, both said no and simply walked away.  

the food was good, but getting sunburned was not.

so minus one star.
author: Ames K.

description:
No complaints from me!

Everything we had was perfectly executed:
Escargot
Sea Bass - I am impressed with this, is was done perfectly
Creme brulee - very crispy on top

Nothing super amazing, just French food done right.

One funny moment was when the waitress was trying really hard to pronounce "monkfish" (it was the special) and said it over and over, sometimes saying "monkeyfish." Yeah, I'd like the monkeyfish please!
author: Thlel Yan D.

description:
ate here on 10/22/14, their website says wear a beret and get a free drink with purchase of one also, well we all went here just for that and the manager said we dont do that any more! well take it off your site and call your web guy and pay him! they dont take american express too, and their menu says 20% grat for up to 6 and then 18% for over
we had 7 but was charged 20% and they added it to the grand total which service was bad, the food runner just placed everones order where ever he wanted and the servicer
was too busy to come back to see if we needed anything else. Very furgalness on their
part wont be back and dont reccommend! french onion soup too salty we shoudl have
returned it at $9.00 a cup! save your money any try Frangile or Chennery Park for less the cost! nice decor though and lease the friends were had was great! dont order the skirt steak its cut up into tiny pieces for you on the three course meal and the attipezer
is mexican dish i had the same thing at a mexican restaurant many times! good luck if you dine here. on the way out everyone had to move in their chairs as there is no room
to walk in or out unless you are child sized! they need to take out a few tables as its a
fire hazzard for sure! forget going if you are in a wheelchair or crutches!
author: cat t.

description:
I'm updating this now since I noticed I wrote it when they first opened. I'd originally given four stars and they definitely deserve 5 based on subsequent developments. Everything really came together and I had many fine meals here over the years--probably in the neighborhood of 100 times overall, before I left San Francisco. It's a wonderful, friendly, tasty, professionally-run, and pleasingly-decorated place and it became an integral part of my neighborhood experience.

Original review follows:

Overall I am quite pleased.  I've eaten there just once and will return.  Service was excellent and very friendly.  My quibbles with the food are relatively minor--they've only been open for a few weeks, and everything was basically tasty.

(ETA: My food quibbles: onion soup too salty, cassoulet too healthy, bread too eh.  No complaints about the tarte tatin, which was absolutely fantastic.)
author: Jonas E.

description: we really enjoyed the restaurant. good food and lots of charm and good cheer. will go while waiting to show up in paris in 2014
author: susan w.

description:
Tried this place for the first time the other night, having recently moved into the neighborhood. My friend and I both ordered from the prix fixe "neighborhood menu" -- he had mahi mahi, I had short ribs, and we both started with a really lovely lobster soup. Everything was fabulous, the service was friendly and charming, and the whole tap, including a glass of wine each and coffee and dessert for both of us, came to about $65. You can't do much better than this for that kind of money. They've just earned a new regular customer.

UPDATE 4/7/09: Just returned for a second visit. I had the onion soup and one of the night's specials which was a terrific salmon dish that I can't properly describe but which was outstanding. My companion had beef bourgognon, of which I snagged a taste. For dessert I had creme brulee -- one of my favorite things in the world, and their version was as good as I've had. Once again, absolutely outstanding and a spectacular value. I am officially hooked.

ANOTHER UPDATE, 2/3/13: Brought a couple friends from out of town here the the other night and everyone loved it. Food was wonderful as always (especially the sweet potato-tomato soup and the pain perdu for dessert -- OMG! I had the cassoulet which was really good but a bit on the salty side, which may be a problem for some, but overall still one of my favorite restaurants.
author: Bruce M.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here for dinner last night since he wanted to try a casual French restaurant. The atmosphere was cozy and we got seated right away. 

The prefix dinner is available from Sunday to Thursday and is a great deal: appetizer (soup or salad), entree and dessert for $21. I tried the soup du jour (tomato and corn soup) and pork osso bucco (after a fellow diner raved to us about it)... very tender and delish! My boyfriend had the duck confit salad (which he raved about) and the lamb shank (was a bit gamey and the au jus was a bit too salty). We shared the assortment of sorbets. It was a glass with lemon, passionfruit and guava sorbets. Very fresh and tasty. We also had a nice bottle of Heron cabernet savignon. 

Overall, we had a good experience and will come back. Our only complaint was the chef walked around and only spoke to select tables. He briefly smiled at us but did not ask us about our dining experience. We thought that was a bit snobby. The owner seated us and was attentive but did not introduce himself, which is a surprise because the current owner/chef (Chef Philippe Gardelle) of restaurant that he formerly owned (Clementine) is so personable and friendly. The rest of the staff was polite.
author: Kaila Y.

description: Awesome restaurant! Love their price fixed neighborhood menu. Everything is good there and you will leave completely full!  I thought the food here was much better than a lot of places in Paris.
author: Francine T.

description:
Food's not bad.  The decor's eclatic.  Bathroom's small (not my favorite part of the restaurant).

Owner's super nice.  I've had really great service there and not very satisfactory service here on separate occasions.  It's all in who you get as a server.

Location's great.  Not far from the freeway, parking not too difficult.

I'll go back just because the owner makes me feel very welcome (as if I'm visiting, or coming home).
author: Winnie C.

description:
They were pretty good. Here are the pluses -

1. I had their "mixed green saladw/feta cheese" and beet ravioli (on a bed of vegetables). Ingredients tasted fresh. Aah, and for appetizers, we ordered raw oysters - they, too, were fresh.

2. It was cozy, and small, which is the key to the success of a restaurant. You serve less people, thus, food quality and (assumably) service don't get compromised. The neighborhood-like feel, yet crowded, ambience gave it a nice hustle and bustle. 

3. Portions are just right, and not too large. That is the key to digestive satisfaction - esp if you are a wine drinker. 


OK - here are the minuses:

1. I was kind of expecting this, but service is indeed compromised here. Staff and wait people look rushed, they try hard to be attentive, yet don't have that little extra time if you have some sort of question or special need. The owner was very nice, as was the wait-person. 

2. It's crowded to the point of having minimal walking space - you kind of have to expect this. 

3. I rarely eat French food, so this might just be a characteristic of it, but I didn't care too much for the sauce on the ravioli. It tasted like salt and cream; mixed with the water that they cooked the vegetables in. 

Don't get me wrong, the food was good and it tasted fresh, yet taking into consideration all of the other variables, it wouldn't be my first choice of places to go.
author: Jimmy L.

description: Great French food without the pretense.  They serve what I'd imagine is French comfort food. If you like pork and beans, you have to try the casserole.
author: Jeffrey L.

description: I had the prix fixed menu the other evening. I has the bell pepper salad and it was NOT good. Smothered in a creamy dressing.  Raw peppers were fresh, but they should have been roasted and the skins removed. The fish main dish was way over cooked.   No sugar was given with the coffee. For $22, the meal was correct. You get what you pay for. What i had was not a "French" dinner.
author: Spencer F.

description: I travel regularly to Paris, and my favorite spots there are the tiny places with comfort food. This is the only place I've found outside France that feels like we could be there. Our bouillabaisse and boeuf bourgignon both were excellent. Profiteroles perfect balance of pastry, ice cream and intense chocolate sauce. Nice selection of affordable wines, including by the glass. Highly professional staff. Wonderful to find the prunelle eau de vie among the digestif options. I'm just sorry it will be a year before I can get back. FYI, they will be closed a couple of weeks in the summer for a kitchen remodel.
author: Christie H.

description:
Last night we met some friends for dinner to celebrate our recent engagement.  We picked Le P'tit Laurent after a friend in the neighborhood suggested it as an alternative to Chenery Park (which I love).

We were greeted by Laurent and met our friends at the bar. It became immediately clear to the wait staff we were celebrating and they did all that they could to make our evening so special.  

The food is fine, typical french bistro, no haute cuisine.  The standouts are the incredibly nice servers who appreciate friendly customers who try to speak French, the intimate but not overly crowded space, and a great neighborhood vibe.  

We were given our cork from the champagne as a keepsake as well as a bottle of wine of congratulations.  What a pleasant and memorable surprise.

We will definitely be back.

Food: 3 stars
Decor: 4 stars
Service: 5 stars
author: Amalia S.

description:
Went here last night with a small group of people.  I thought the food was excellent and the atmosphere was very comfortable.  There were two birthdays in the restaurant and the host had the entire restaurant sing happy birthday.  I thought that was pretty cool.
Oddly enough, I wasn't much of a fan of the onion soup.  I thought it was way too salty.
The main course was excellent.  I would definitely go here again.
author: Lauren B.

description: I was there with 9 other friends last night.  Every one of our meals was OVERLY salty.
author: Marc B.

description:
What a nice surprise! Comfortable and very authentic!

We walked in just to have a glass of wine, but eventually my craving for mussels took over. They had just run out of mussels, so we opted for the bouillabaisse plate and it was as if we were transported to France. 

I am not EVER in this area often, so it was a nice touch to the evening and a pleasant discovery. If I ever get to this hood again, I'd definitely eat here again.
author: Freckles D.

description:
I loved the wine.

The food was good, but I have to go back to try the other stuff. I don't think the rabbit is their best dish.

Desserts are yummy. The oysters were well prepared.

UPDATE:

The initial rush has slowed and now it's mostly locals that come by. I like the food and I think the cassoulet is wonderful. That seems to be the general consensus.

I love their really chill corkage policy. 

The bar is well stocked.
author: Eugene L.

description:
I don't think I'd ever have come to this part of the city uninvited - I don't even really know what this neighborhood is called, but there's some fun looking offerings here on Chenery Street, and one of them is Le P'tit Laurent, a charming little French restaurant.  

Everyone here seems to be a native French speaker, or else they have been practicing their accents a lot.  We met Brad and Christie for dinner here with a reservation and were seating on time.  The restaurant was quite full - lively but not overly loud.  Our waitress poked fun at the fact that we filled up our small glass with water and saved the big one for wine.

"You must be French!" 

That was pretty funny.  (I don't look remotely French, being Chinese). 

She also dusted me with bread crumbs clearing the table.  No big deal, and she asked if I was OK in a very French fashion.

"Did you receive a piece of bread?"

Good humor worth half a star. 

In terms of food - I had the frisee salad with lardons and poached egg.  Not bad - I felt like the dressing and the lardons at other French places is more flavorful.  The egg was perfect.  For my entree I had the beef bourginion, which was satisfyingly rich and tender atop some creamy mashed potatoes.  The baguette was warm, crispy and maybe the best bread I've had in some time.  I also liked the little cornichon with cured meat on the table to start.  I was too full to order a dessert.  I tried a morsel of Elaine's rack of pork with apples and truffle and it was quite nice also.

Total for dinner for four (4 first courses and 4 entrees and a bottle of nice wine) totaled out at $180 including tax and tip, not bad.    

I liked it - I think I enjoy the French food more at Chapeau! and South Park Cafe, but if I'm in the neighborhood again I'd come back for more at Le P'tit Laurent.
author: Don L.

description:
We have always wanted to try this place, passing by it almost daily, especially upon noticing the constant crowds.  And when we finally did enter, we were not disappointed.
