Crowded, we were told that to sit at the bar we would need to order food as well.  Hungry, we tried a few appetizers.  YUM!!!!!!  Need to go back for the meal.  The staff was very efficient and the barkeep (Fern?) was a gem.
author: Scott S.

description: Walked in for the first time last Monday, I had no reservation but there was space at the bar.  I loved the decor of the place.  The service was really good and the food was absolutely amazing.  I had the rabbit, probably best rabbit I've tasted.  My friend had the boeuf bourguignon, which he also loved.  Considering the size of the portions and the quality of the food, it is pretty inexpensive.  Wine by the glass was also good and very well priced.  Can't wait to go back!!
author: Paula F.

description:
We had a really great experience here yesterday.

The food was all excellent (though they are a bit liberal with the salt).  The service was very friendly and the staff really is french. 

Our party had: mussels, NY strip, french onion soup, carrott/celery soup, a stew, and chicken and everyone seemed very very pleased!
author: Michael M.

description:
A cozy, lovely spot in the middle of the Glen Park neighborhood. Excellent service--Laurent (the owner) was charming and attentive. The trout salad (trout and potatoes) and the salmon were both fresh, tender, perfectly seasoned, well-presented, and bursting with flavor.  I snagged a bite of my friend's dessert, an apple tart that came with a thin crust, and it was good, but probably not as stellar as the savory dishes...the thin pastry seemed a little soggy, but the apples were excellent--not too sweet, and fragrantly spiced.  

Although the restaurant was busy, we never felt crowded or rushed, and this cozy (but not cramped) restaurant proved to be the perfect place for a meal and conversation with an old friend I hadn't seen for many years.  I got the sense that a lot of the diners P'tit Laurent are regulars, giving the place a wonderfully friendly, neighborhoody feel, something missing from many San Francisco restaurants.

As a plus, street parking was plentiful in the neighborhood and the restaurant is right down the street from the BART!
author: Bear S.

description: If you haven't come yet, do so. The location in Glen Park is fantastic and unimposing. Once you walk in you realize that the place is all about not being pretentious and serious about its food. My wife and I came for our anniversary and got the neighborhood menu. I had an excellent whitefish on a bed of flavorful rice and my wife the lamb with pasta. The fish was excellent, the lamb great but a tad salty. The vegetable soup opener was amazing and dessert wonderful. The staff was very friendly and attentive. At $25 each for the dinner and another $50 in coffee and wine we left smiling and eager to come back. In fact, we have been looking at house listings in the neighborhood ever since. Call us fans.
author: Jack R.

description:
Our group of 8 came for a dinner at 830 but didn't get seated until 9 and not order until close to 930.

Despite the delicious food,  the crowd on a Tuesday night reflects that Glen Park needs more restaurants.

Lots of large groups also change the atmosphere.  It felt almost chaotic at times, but the food and the staff made up for the crowd.

The appetizers and dessert trump the main dishes, and the serving of everything was generous.

Maybe come for the early bird special before 7?
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Two words:

Killer brunch.

But the service can be slow and I like my tea hot not lukewarm.  Dinner is good here too and I like that they have a full bar.
author: SaraMitra P.

description:
J'adore ce restaurant! 

Lorsque je mange ici, je peux presque parler français.

Just having a glass of wine at the bar with a little something, is a wonderful way to step outside the flow for a little while.

Le P'tit Laurent - Je t'aime!
author: yelper y.

description: Excellent French food.  Just about everything I have had at this restaurant has been incredible.  Check it out Sunday-Thursday because they have an incredible prix fix menu for circa $22.
author: Toby R.

description: I've had great experiences here and think it is a gem of a neighborhood French Restaurant. Been a few times, enjoyed the food and service. Definitely intend to return
author: Sarah F.

description:
I strolled into this little place for brunch sort of by accident a couple of weeks after it opened, and had one of the best breakfasts I have ever had.  I had seen the dinner menu, which was close to being outside of my price range, so I was surprised to see that the brunch menu was reasonable.  I ordered the pain perdu, which was to-die-for delicious--covered in melted butter and strawberry sauce--and my boyfriend ordered the ham and gruyere omelette, without the ham.  Also amazing.  

Then, about a week ago I took a friend there, after raving for days about how delicious it was.  What a disappointment! The waitress this time refused to make the omelette without ham, and my french toast was burnt.  The coffee was still good and strong, but the rest was mediocre at best.  I'm not sure if they are still working out the kinks with the increased business, but I sure hope they pull it together, as I'd like to go back to dreaming about that french toast...
author: Caroline G.

description:
Loved it!!  Atmosphere, food, service, & easy parking.  What more could you ask for in a restaurant.  Oh yeah..the prices were pretty reasonable for French fare.  We had the Escargot for starters.  The Rabbit (very tender and delicious esp. the next morning) and the Lamb for our entree and the Creme Brulee for dessert.  Not to mention 4 glasses of wine, 1 Kir Royale, and 1 St Germaine on ice all for a little over $100 ($105 to be exact).  What a deal!!  Did I mention great service??  Yes, our waitress was French and very enchanting.  The chef even came out to our table to greet us.  

I will be going back during the week to try out the 3 course meal for $20.
author: Lisa E.

description: Somewhat disappointing. Pleasant bistro but a bit too noisy. Service was inconsistent. as was the food. Love traditional French but this falls short. Not a value.
author: Lawrence J.

description:
I had the best time at Le P'tit Laurent on Saturday, 11/6. Great company, exquisite Georgian Wines, great food, excellent service.  What else can I ask for?  Thank you!  We had a great time!!!!!  Enjoy this video http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K-33CXsBXUk 
We shall come back soon....chef Laurent Legendre merci beaucoup!!!!
author: Alex R.

description:
First visit on 11/24/07
The Highs: great mussels with a broth that commands a lot of bread, which never ran out. Skip the fries - they were mediocre; Two great fish entrees, the monkfish and the sea bass, both under $20. The Lows: an amuse bouche with crab that tasted old; a salad that that boasted of goat cheese, which meant a thin wafer the size of a quarter with a smear of cheese and a dab of honey; the desserts were weak. Service was great, and I would definitely go back
author: Chili Bill E.

description:
The fiance and I went to try out their prixe fixed meal. Good portion sizes for the price ($20). The place is pretty small and the tables pretty close together. The food was good, but nothing spectacular, except for the onion soup and escargot, which could have been because we went during the first few months of their opening.
The waitress was polite and attentive, but I got the feeling she was analyzing us and got the up and down glance from her a few times. I was also intimidated by her French accent, ahahha...Neverthless, we still received proper service, but were not treated as warmly as those who spoke French.
author: Kat T.

description: Le P'tit Laurent is an atmospheric and friendly brasserie in the Glen Park neighborhood.  I makes you feel as if you are in Paris, except the service is better.  I have eaten there on dozens of occasions over the past several years.  The food is very good, authentically French, and reasonably priced, especially the midweek prix fixe dinner.  It has a nice wine selection, including a better than average house wine.  The mostly French waiters and waitresses are excellent and knowledgeable.  This all adds up to relaxed and enjoyable dinner, which has remained consistently high quality over the years.
author: Douglas V.

description: We visited for dinner with two friends from another country who are widely traveled and experienced restaurant goers. We all found the ambiance and service to be excellent and the food and wine list to be very good. The food is just like what I have had in small Paris bistros, and very good. We thoroughly enjoyed our experience here.
author: Melinda C.

description:
I love this restaurant.  It is in my neighborhood and the "neighborhood menu" with soup or salad, entree, and dessert for $21 is an incredible deal.  It is very French, but without any snotty attitude.  

So why just two stars?  SALT!  

I have been there four times in the last two months and on three of those visits, at least one item I ordered was too salty.  PLEASE stop with excessive salt.  Last night, I sent back my entree, asking them to remove the sauce, which I thought was the source of the extreme salt.  I should have asked them to rinse my entree, as it was too salty even without the sauce.

I want this place to be my go-to neighborhood restaurant, but the excessive salt is driving me away.
author: mcs s.

description: Had an absolutely amazing meal here on Friday.  Our waiter was fabulous and had the best sense of humor I've ever experienced in a French waiter!  He also let me order in French (without looking pained by my non-native accent) and treated the English speakers at my table with grace.  The cassoulet brought back memories of the cassoulet I had on tour in Toulousse.  Everything on the table was tremendous and all four of us had a great time.  A magical evening!  I can't wait to come back!   A little loud on a busy Friday night, but really a fabulous experience.
author: Wendy T.

description: This is my favorite spot in Glen Park. Extremely cozy, neighborhood with a beautiful bar and friendly staff. On top of all of that, the food is delicious! On top of THAT, they have neighborhood specials during the week, which means you can actually afford to go there more than on special occasions! It's a Christmas miracle, people. Come and check it out.
author: Shannon C.

description:
Great neighborhood bistro!    Easy to get to by BART (1 block from Glen Park station) & you can usually find parking w/in a block (try the short term lot opposite the BART station.  

They offer a great deal of a prix fixe (appetizer, main dish, and dessert) for $21 (Sun-Thurs 5:30-9:30).  Their regular menu is quite affordable.

Steamed mussels and frites was huge and cheap!  Their sauteed sea bass was melt in my mouth delicious.   

Their creme brulee and apple tart were ok, not great.  

They're small, so they fill up quickly.  I usually try to go early (b-4 6:30) or make reservations.  It's size keeps it intimate and not too loud.  Laurent is always there to greet and I'm glad he opened a restaurant on our side of town.
author: J T.

description: Went here at 9 pm after a poetry reading at Bird & Beckett around the corner. Endless baskets of bread, first one was fresh and warm and the others probably recycled from other tables, but we didn't care. Half carafe of house wine, a pinot noir. Fried artichoke salad. Mussels. And Sweetbreads. Too full for dessert. Service was fantastic. I felt like I was in France. Le Sigh.
author: Sam Z.

description: I thought we were in a recession but this place is always bumpin! I love the $22 pre-fixe "neighborhood" menu and apparently I'm not alone. They change it every week and I always look forward to checking it out. After a tough day at work, this is one of my favorite spots, the wine, bread and food have never disappointed. Plus the place is cute and has always felt authentic and unpretentious.
author: Elise B.

description:
We had a large party of, with large expectations, having read the Yelp, Google and TripAdvisor reviews...  Le P'tit Laurent DID NOT DISAPPOINT!!! Fabulous service, with a stellar menu, and great country French delicious food, accented with fantastic French wine... We sampled, across their entire menu, and there was copious sharing... Stunning salad plates and  very authentic country-
style French Onion Soup, Escargot, and oysters started us off in fine fashion, paired 
with excellent bottle selections of fairly priced vin ordinaire... 
Then it was time for the entrees... WOW!!! Exceptional in every respect!!!  My and two other guest's Boeuf Bourguignon was astounding, very tender and flavor-packed... 3 in our party had the Sauteed bass served with cauliflower puree, Grenobloise Sauce; and all were impressed... Two had the Fish bouillabaisse served with rouille sauce and croûtons... They loved this dish... Our guest of honor had the Rabbit Normandy served with carrot puree, and she raved about it...
All in all; we loved this dinner, will come back, and will tell our friends...
author: JAY C. O.

description:
I'm giving this 3 stars b/c it was just "OK".  Nothing special but nothing horrible to report.

I had the same waiting experience as other reviewers.  My 3 friends took me there for my bday, we had a 7:30 reservation on a Tues which I thought was a pretty quiet time.  It wasn't, the restaurant was full when we got there and we were told it would only be "a few minutes" and that we could stand by the bar and have a glass of wine.  Well the bar was full of diners and there wasn't anywhere to stand so we kept shifting around each other getting in each others (and other peoples) way.  The "few minutes" ended up being almost half an hour which was annoying.  I don't know the answer to this, other patrons don't want to be rushed and tossed out, but if you run a restaurant, you need to be a better judge of how long it takes to turn your tables and take reservations accordingly.

The 4 of us ordered different things and shared everything.  The mussels were good, the onion soup was OK, the asparagus soup was a mistake and needs to be taken out back and shot.   The salmon was OK but the signature steak dish was underwhelming, the meat was tough and the sauce wasn't very special.  The vegetarian dish was just a bunch of stir-fry vegetables that didn't really have any taste and my friend who ordered it said she wished she'd gotten something else.

We shared one dessert and it was very good, but they neglected to put a candle in it which was fine by me, but my friends were angry b/c they had pre-arranged it and double-checked when we got there and was pretty much the only reason they pushed to get dessert.  The next day, my friend said she wouldn't go back b/c when she paid said something to the owner/manager or whatever he said "we don't do that here, whomever told you that was wrong"  Um, gee it was your own damn waitress who agreed to it when we sat down.

So don't bring someone here for a bday if you want a freakin $0.05 candle in your $10 dessert.
author: Iris F.

description:
A great place for a low key birthday dinner party!

This was my second meal at P'tit Laurent.  I'd wanted to get back and when friends offered to take me out for my birthday, I chose this place.  I was not disappointed at all and, after the first course, my friends, too, declared this place a real keeper. 

The birthday candle in the center of my Tarte Tatin at meal's end came as a surprise,  and our co-diners at the adjacent table sang a bit and congratulated me. Embarrassing a bit, but all done in good humor. It was actually fun rather than awkward as it might have been at a larger or stuffier restaurant. 

The service was excellent and charming in that special, warm Gallic style which, as many reviews here suggest, is not the overbearing friendliness Americans expect and are used to.  Rather, respectful and professional and wise.  At the end of the meal, the owner, Laurent himself, served us coffee and spoke with us. 

Very good traditional food, a substantial St. Emilion, old friends, an atmosphere made intimate with Gallic charm and warmth, and the flavors of divine classic French dishes such as Boeuf Bourgignon and Soupe a l'Oignon and all at reasonable prices---- dining happiness. 

What's not to love?
author: Tony S.

description:
What a cool little place.  Had dinner at the bar with my girl last week, and the food, atmosphere and service were all good.
I had the duck salad with dijon dressing, great bite in the dressing and the duck was nice and warm, yum.  The foie tourchon was also good, but a bit too much spiced apple with it.  It was cold, thought it would be better warm.
My girl had the bass, and it was delish!  The lamb shank was a little small, and i was expecting a little more savory, but still very good and tender.
The place was packed with an Xmas party, but the staff were friendly and welcoming, squeezed us in on a busy night.
Will return.
author: Nathan D.

description:
a little crowded feeling (authentic, felt like being in France)

service quite pleasant (not as authentic, didn't feel like being in France at all)

soup of the day (some rich velvety pureed vegetables), lamb shank with spinich, apple tart.

lots of people having a great time. (including me!)

The only thing I wasn't down with was the two groups of people celebrating birthdays.  Yes, I'm a crusty, ill tempered curmudgeon and I absolutely do NOT want to sing Happy Birthday to you. (much less twice within the same hour)
author: Poppy C.

description:
Ate here the other nite.. a tuesday... called to see if we needed a reso but the owner Laurent said to pop on down he will seat us... good start..
Was promptly seated by said owner in the cutest little corner table.. yay..... excited to be out on the town with my baby... anyway all the food was pretty tasty the Foie Gras torchon was great... with an apple puree that was almost quince like in its texture... oysters... amazing mignonette... some of the oysters were too small even if they were Kumomoto's and they did not detach them from the muscle.. dunno about you but i like to just slide them in my mouth without too much effort... according to Laurant this is how people like them these days... yeh right ha ha said not me I am lazy like that... we also had escargot with tons of garlic and parsley.... super super tender.... entrees fillet mignon with dauphanese pots I think which my partner liked, I thought it was ok.... I had a cassoulet with duck confit pork and sausage which was really tasty... desert creme brulee , very good... not too sweet and nice texture... we had a couple glasses of bubbly to start and a bottle of Mariah Sanctuary Zin which was pleasantly dryer than I thought it would be... never ending bread basket.... amazing company and good service... funny moment.. I was cleaning the plates to make it easier on the staff and Laurent said hey the kitchen is that way... ha ha... all in all a great and charming experience... will definitely return....
author: andrew k.

description: After a few more visits, I'm updating my review to 5 stars. Le P'tit Laurent is the best French Bistro around. Consistently excellent food, very professional service, a Sunday-Thursday prix fixe @ $21 that is hands-down the best food value in the city. You can spend a ton more money in San Francisco and not get anywhere near the experience.
author: Chris H.

description: OMG, this place is just sooooo good. It's probably a good thing that it's so popular making it very hard to just pop-in for a meal. If I could, I would eat here every other day! A few folks mention they are heavy on the salt--I probably have to agree because I salt everything, but not here. So, for me it's a non-issue. Prices are also super reasonable--you'll spend more on wine than food. Definitely make a reservation--or get there right when they open to grab a seat at the bar. Each time I've been, the bar is full within 15 minutes of opening.
author: Wendy G.

description: So, I feel a little bad giving this place a one star b/c I have not eaten here.  However I did receive a gift cerificate worth $100 from a client of mine.  I am, like many others in the city, a very busy working professional.  I was waiting until the perfect romatic night to use it.  That night finally came.  I obviously didnt notice at the time of receiving the gift that you have up to one year to redeem.  Is that even legal in California, and who does that?  I called, and pleaded to see if they would make an exception.  She politely said not after a couple weeks of the date of expiration.  Give me a break!! It was for $100.  So they just get to pocket my client's money?  Absolutely RIDICULOUS!!  I cant comment on the food, but make sure your recipient of any gift certificates from this place knws about their one year expiration rule!!!
author: K B.

description:
We only had a single day in San Francisco and with so many restaurant choices in this culinary capital, it is quite overwhelming with so much to chose from. We decided we wanted to go to a French Bistro and we did do some research. After reading about Le P'tit Laurent at a number of internet sites like yelp and Zagat, we chose this lovely place. We made a reservation via open table in the afternoon and luckily an 8:15 spot was open on Thursday, October 18. We arrived a bit early and there was not a table available. Laurent happily greeted us and invited us to have a few drinks at the bar which we wanted to do because of our early arrival. The French bartender was wonderful and attentive. One thing that needs to be understood is that everybody that works here contributes to every aspect of the restaurant. Laurent, who owns the place, cleans tables, brings delicious french bread to the guests and also will bring the food and wine. The man does not take a break and you can see how respected he is among the staff. This is a lovely neighborhood Bistro and certainly there were many regulars. Laurent and his staff treated us as though we were regulars.

I started with the onion soup and my wife, the escargot. Both fantastic. Then, I had the rabbit and my wife the Beef Bourguignon. Just incredible. The portions are large so be aware that you do get more than enough. In sum, this was a wonderful experience from beginning to end and as one other reviewer said, you do not want to leave. It is small, but that is part of the charm. Hard not to fall in love with places like this and when you have a French owner with a French staff, you have a winner. 

Thank you Laurent.
author: Giovanni S.

description: We went here for brunch while visiting NYC last October based on yelp reviews. Food was very good and the atmosphere was wonderful.  They have a good selection of draft beers - always a plus after a long sat night of partying in NYC!
author: Scott R.

description:
This place is tucked away down in the tiny little Glen Park neighborhood.  It has a nice authentic, cozy feeling....like you're sitting at a restaurant in France.  I'm not sure how they do it, but their servers also magically have French accents.  

We walked in on a Sunday evening and it didn't take them long to seat us.  They have a great pre fix menu for $22 (appetizer soup or salad), main course, and dessert).  Their menu changes weekly so I'll only review what we had.

First course:  
-  Beet salad with goat cheese and arugula was not what I expected.  It was okay at best and because I substituted the goat cheese for blue cheese, that may have taken away from what the dish was supposed to actually taste like

- Roasted bell pepper soup was decent, but nothing to write home about. 

Second Course:  
- Chicken with mashed potatoes was pretty good.  It was a large serving with vegetables served on a bed of creamy mashed potatoes

- Halibut with some type of creamy white sauce was very good.  The fish was a little on the dry side but with the sauce, it was worth coming back for.

Dessert:  
-  Vanilla profiteroles with warm chocolate sauce was pretty good.  The texture was just right and the serving size, 3 pieces, was enough to share
-  Bitter chocolate cake with coconut ice cream was the best part of the entire meal.  It's not really a cake, more of a mousse consistency.  I usually hate coconut flavor stuff but the ice cream was actually very good.  Both flavors complemented each other really well.    

Overall, both desserts were worth coming back for. 

The meal was $22 each for 3 courses so it's definitely a place I'll be coming back to!  Bon appetit!
author: Kristie G.

description:
These guys/girls rock... Super good food and are on top of it at all times.  I am a fine dining bartender, and these guys do french food/drinks/wine really well.

  It is appreciated and continue to do what you are doing.  Small place and loveley!!!
author: Nick D.

description: This is a great local gem - good food, attentive wait staff.  We loved the onion soup, the steak fritas.  I had the cauliflower soup and loved it.  Initmate place and fun staff.  We have been twice so far
author: Jeff H.

description:
Lovely place, courteous service, good soup, bread, wine, and dessert. Entrees are getting quite salty over the recent period. Tried the fish last night, it had texture like chicken! Hard and dry, with ton of sodium. I brought it to the manager's attention, he was real courteous about it and told me wine's on the house; but then I was charged for dessert that came with the set dinner. Brought it to their attention, they removed the dessert from the bill, but added the wine to it. Huh? Whatever, I'll pay for what I've ordered...
Still one of my fav place to go due to the atmosphere and service, as well as the bread, soup, escargot, and dessert. Maybe I'll order some you-can't-screw-this-one-up type of entree next time.
author: P S.

description: A neighborhood jewel. The food was very good and the service attentive and never rushed. And the fixed price dinner was a very good value.
author: Cynthia G.

description: Love this place! Laurent and his staff are sweethearts. The food is really good and the fixed price menu is great. I love the fact that place is small.
author: Flo A.

description:
Do yourself a favor and treat yourself to the Pre- fixe meal on a weeknight do it as a special treat.  Celebrate the weekend early, reserve a table.  Delicious 3 course meal.  I came with 4 friends on  Tuesday night.  Fantastic personal service, great wine, soup/salad, entree and dessert  We completely cleaned our plates.  The menu changes weekly.

Fantastic French fare.  Rich, filling and just enough.  Including tip, wine, coffee, and tea the total came to $180.  On a saturday night it would be more like $350.
author: Maya C.

description:
Arrivé a 18:35 pour une reservation de 18:30, mon ami avec 10 minutes de retard.  Accueil sympathique et correct, diner impeccable.  Notre amie nous a joint vers 20:15 pour un verre de vin.  A 20:42,  pile,  5 minutes après avoir regle l'addition, la serveuse nous a demandé de faire place au client suivant.  Inacceptable.  Et en plus elle faisait la tronche.
*********
Arrived at 6:35 for a 6:30 reservation, my friend arrived 10 minutes later.  Service was fine, dinner even better.  A friend joined us around 8:15 for a glass of wine.  At exactly 8:42, 5 minutes after we paid our bill, the maitre d' asks us to leave because people with the 8:30 reservation slot were waiting.  And on top of it she gives us attitude when we express our shock.

In 30 years of dining at restaurants all over the world and of every quality, this has happened to me exactly once before.  

There are too many fine restaurants in this city to put up with that sort of behavior.  Go somewhere else.
author: Misha W.

description: Very nice little French place. Great French food in a good atmosphere that does not break the bank.
author: Jan H.

description: I have been to this place more than once because I like it; but my last experience was not pleasant at all. I am having dinner enjoying the atmosphere when a group of people come in and start speaking Spanish; one of the waitress yells "Speak French, we are not in a 'TAQUERIA'". I am sorry but who would do something like that in San Francisco, the most cosmopolitan city in the world? I did have a conversation with her and expressed my disappointment to which she replied 'I am sorry' in her French accent. You cannot stereotype your customers like that. Shame on you Le Petit Laurent.
author: papa c.

description: First time coming here, I ordered the rabbit meat entree and it was soooo delicious.  Their price are not bad with a pretty decent portion.  Saw that they have neighborhood 3course menu which is reasonable for $25.  Overall, a great try.
author: YELP U.

description:
Ah yes, how I love French cuisine!
I love that each bite feels like it has an entire stick of butter in it.
I love that when I eat French food, my entire vascular system slows to the point that I almost lose consciousness if I'm not paying attention to my breathing.
I love that wine plays an important part in the meal.

BUT I HATE  that the portions are as big as a slice of salami!

Well, not here at Le P'tit Laurent. All of the other prerequisites are in full effect, yet the portions are generous and incredible!

My wife and I had the chance to have a rare date night with no kids before or after (you know what after means!!). We live very close to this newer restaurant and have been wanting to try it. We walked up with no reservation right when they opened at 5:30 and were seated right away.
The inside is cozy and warm and they have made good use of a small place. The old bar that exists from when it was a bar serves as a nice center piece for the restaurant. We chose the less formal bar type seating.
The wait staff seams predominately French but do not strike me as pompous or obnoxious as so many French waiters can...sorry. The young lady that helped us was very nice and helped us with our order.

We order Cream of Mushroom soup, that is hands down the BEST Cream of Mushroom soup I have ever had. We also had a mixed green salad that came with small pieces of toast (there is probably some fancy French name for toast...but I'm not French, so let's just call it toast?) with goat cheese and honey...once again, incredible!!

For our main course, my wife had beef bourguignon and I had pork Oso Buco. Both of these portions were very hardy and incredibly good. This is where the butter in every bite comes in. The food was so rich, a small portion would have been fine, but with a larger portion...well it was even better! Our portions were big enough that we almost couldn't finish...but not worry I did!! Our wonderful waitress also was kind enough to recommend wine by the glass that would match up well with what we were eating and actually set us up with some of the less expensive wines. They were both very very good. I'm a sucker for wine and told her that, but she said that the wine that goes best with our dish happens to be less expensive. I love that I had sucker written on my forehead and she didn't go in for the kill.
The desert was the only thing that wasn't incredible, but it was still good. I had Creme Brulee and it was just OK. We did see some of the other deserts that looked very good, so I will pass final judgment on this place after we get out and try again!!

All in all, this was a very very good eating experience for me. The desert is the only knock I have, and like I said, I will try again before I decide that the desert is just OK. The service was great, the food was incredible and the wine also very good.

Oh, and the date night that was to end with no kids...*wink wink, nudge nudge* ended with me in a food coma on my couch. I should deduct another star for that, but it's not there fault I can't handle my butter.
author: JR H.

description: I'm sad.  I love to eat good food and I want to have as many good, walk-to restaurants in my nabe as possible.  But it's not to be.  Two visits:  first visit I had a grey/brown blob of gloop on a plate (the string beans or snow peas - whatev - that were mentioned on the menu weren't there - no green anything).  That was the rabbit.  One pc - thigh I think - was delish.  There was a brick of impenetrable white meat - breast I guess - that I couldn't saw into w/my knife and fork. The second visit I had beet raviolis that had an overwhelmingly 'musty' taste - and I saw nothing beet colored - just grey/brown.  Disturbing.  Actually I made three visits.  Once to have a late night drink at the bar - I had an Armagnac that was tres cher and tres ordinaire.
author: Carolyn S.

description: I was incredibly impressed with this place.  Usually a restaurant in its first week is still improving its dishes and perfecting its service, but not this place.  The service was flawless and the food was delicious.  My dining partner and I started with Mussels in a delicious white wine and garlic sauce with a side of Frites.  Then I had Salmon with zucchini and mushrooms in a garlic sauce while he had Streak Frites.  Both were perfectly cooked.  I couldn't believe how moist the fish was!  Then Profiteroles for dessert....my favorite.  When I come back I definitely want to try the Tart Tartine with caramel ice cream !
author: Stacy R.

description:
My husband and I have eaten here three (3) times between 2008-2009 and I thought that I should finally write a review.

First time - exquisite!  Service was delightful.  Food was savory and well prepared.  We had escargot, salad, beouf bourguinon, NY steak, wine.  Delicious.

Second time - Enjoyable.  Again, service was lovely.  Escargot - it was definitely previously frozen because it was chewy and nearly inedible.  The NY strip - devine!

Third time - Decent.  Service, accommodating, lovely, delightful.  I ask if the escargot was fresh - it was this time.  I should have asked about the NY strip - it was not NY strip that we were served.  It was a Ribeye cut without a doubt.  Displeasing.

Special note about the wine - The wine list for the most part tends to be off by one year.  If the list quotes 2005, you may receive a 2006 instead.  Carefully review your label prior to drinking.  If you want to drink 2006, but pay 2005, that is up to you.
author: Kristina M.

description: Le P'tit Laurent makes fabulous homey french food in a quaint small restaurant. The service is always impeccable and the food stands out as some of the best french food in the city. Make sure to make reservations or otherwise you will have to wait. But it is worth it.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
Firing on all cylinders...

Nice neighborhood bistro.  All the classic fair is well represented; the mussels had a wonderful flavor, rich with butter and leeks, the smoked salmon was well presented and had a nice light oil, with dilled creme fraiche, good salads, good entrees (our party enjoyed the chicken with couscous (very good), the cassoulet (Delicious) and the rib eyes (good) and excellent desserts (a perfect tart tatin is a wonderful thing to behold!).

The service was friendly, the chef was charming and the management was concerned about our welfare.

If you add in the fact that the prices are reasonable, the wine list is acceptable (had a nice Oregon Pinot Noir) and the room is inviting, this restaurant is sure to be a winner.   We'll even have to return repeatedly to help make certain it does well.
author: T T.

description: I'm very fond of this restaurant, its staff, its food and atmosphere -- therefore kind of outraged by the recent comments of two cranks. I don't know what happened to them the night they purportedly dined at Le P'tit Laurent. It's very hard to believe they ate at the same place I've enjoyed so much in the past.
author: Marvin G.

description: I had an awesome dinner there last night! I was transported back to Paris! The host and staff are fantastic! The prices are a great value!
author: Douglas H.

description:
I've been here three times, all of them excellent, but tonight's visit was beyond exceptional. The food was phenomenal, everything we ate. Bang-for-buck, one of the best meals I've had in recent memory.

The prix-fixe Neighborhood Special is the way to go, unless you're in the mood for some incredible bass or French Onion Soup. Tonight's menu included a ravioli dish with shredded lamb shank and mushrooms--incredible flavor, cooked to perfection. We also had a red cod with risotto, equally as tasty and texturally satisfying, with a great sauce that was sopped up cleanly with our ample supply of bread. Generous portions of everything; you're not gonna leave hungry.

Courteous service and warm, comfortable atmosphere, as always.
author: Ivan B.

description:
I drive by there every day and was very curious about this new "French Bistro" so a couple of friends and I decided to try it out for Brunch on Sunday Dec 2nd 2007. 
First impression, was OK but we were greeted by a snooty French waitress/owner/angry wife whatever, not a good start. Even thought the place was half empty it took them 25 minutes to be able to order. When I tried to get the waitress attention she gave me a "Une  minute" with an attitude only the French can give you (mind you part of my family is French).

My friends ordered a Kir Royale and a Bloody Mary. Kir Royale as expected, Bloody Mary a disaster, Tomato Juice with a little Vodka, no condiments... we sent it back.
We ordered the soup (carrot) it was completely watered down and not hot.
Main course:   boeuf bourginon - excellent
Steak with a bordelaise sauce (ordered on the side) came with sauce all over it. They took it back and return it a minute later (one can only imagine how they removed it) needless to say my friend did not eat it. The french fries were horrible, brown and triple fired old and nasty.
2 of us ordered Croque Madame, both of them arrived cold, with the cheese barely melted. Sent them back to re-heat... taste - nasty, we had each a couple of bites and then left it.
Total cost $84, no apologies or anything else for that matter. You want French food stick with Chez Papa or Chez Maman over in Portrero Hill or if you want rude service but still good food Absinte.
author: Marco B.

description:
Getting out here was a non-adventure- having planned a week or two ahead (unwisely, without calling ahead!)- the rush hour BART to Glen Park Station was a DRAG AND A HALF! This is the BART of the future, ladies and gentlemen! There is NO AIR TO SPARE inside the BART cars! Air has been removed for your discomfiture and displeasure...
Anyway, on a day as hot as yesterday, you'd-a thunk any good restaurant worth the name would be offering folks CHILLED water and COLD wine... but not Le P'tit Laurent! After getting squeezed into a little corner (obviously the reserved customers had priority, although half the restaurant was empty)- they brought me a tepid glass of room temperature water, which just about made my day, not.
I ordered the Lapin facon Normandie, a nice plate of bunny served to you in a savory rich Normandy sauce and with purple mashed potatoes. (nice touch there!). Bugs came well done, the meat slid right off the bone with little coaxing, two haunches and a bit of- that must've been his chest. Poor guy, unnamed and unknown, gave his life to make my dinner. Bless you, Sir Bunny, you sure taste good. They give you a dish of French bread alongside which made a great way of not wasting the tasty sauce and then I had my wine, a Syrah that was quite chesty and full, but which might have gone down even better had it been COLD. 
I do plan to come back here sometime, regardless the WARM WATER & WINE, but I give them not a four, but a three star rating just for that. (touche!) DO make reservations if you are going, otherwise, you will just be another of the hoipolloi, and did I mention they are too good to offer beer at the bar? Well, they are. But at least, it's nice to find a real French restaurant in the City with the cojones to offer coney on the daily menu.
author: Mark L.

description: I love this place! Although they do not really honor reservations which is pretty bad and why I chose 3 stars. After having made the reservation, we had to wait for 40 minutes to get a table. I love the food and the ambiance. Great valued pre fixe menu. The banana mango crepe with fennel dessert was exceptional.
author: Suj a.

description:
We recently moved to Glen Park and have been checking out the local restaurants of course, and man, are we lucky or what to have such great French food so close-by!!?

Love the room; dark, with window along this corner building, looking out onto Diamond and Chenery streets in the heart of Glen park downtown.  I have a soft-spot for French food, so maybe a little biased here, but I loved everything.  My beef bourgogne was perfect.  Wine was great. Salads were great.  Even the host/waitress/owner(?) makes you feel like you're in a Paris bistro... quick and to the point, but helpful and friendly.
author: N G.

description: Excellent choice for marvelous french bistro cuisine. The escargot were fresh, with pesto, garlic and butter. An absinthe to start the meal was prepared at the table. Steamed salmon in a lobster sauce with mussels was fresh and delicious. And the staff couldn't have been more helpful or polite. Had a taste of the cassoulet, a rich blend of blackeyed peas, duck confit, and sausage. A very hearty stew! I'll be back for more! Prices were tolerable as well!
author: David G.

description: For a neighborhood restaurant, this place rocks and is definitely worth checking out. It's bursting at the garters with atmosphere and coziness. The food is hearty and tasty, great selection of wine and all the Frenchy-ness makes it a little bit different. Really disappointed to see it only gets 3.5 stars (same as Tyger's and less than Chenery Park...are you kidding me people?) it's a great place to dine with a group of friends or for a romantic dinner where hopefully the slight wait to be seated or served won't ruin your night. I'm just bummed they stopped serving lunch at the weekends.
author: Jo M.

description: Went here with my brother and my wife. Everything we ordered was great. The staff was great. Just moved to Glen Park last week so I think I'll come back here often!
author: Glenn D.

description:
Saw this place down in Glen Park a week or so ago, was curious and saw good things here on yelp, and tried it tonight with my partner and a friend - and had a wonderful time - good food, reasonable prices for the type of food, and spectacular service - even though we were seated at the bar (otherwise it would have been at least an hour wait as we did not have reservations).  Gina, our bartender/server was a special treat - bubbly and fun and right on top of things.  We had a reasonable bottle of a French fruity semi-dry red wine recommended by Laurent - quite nice. We tried the sweetbreads (perfect - and the sauce was heaven sopped up with extra bread afterwards) and tuna tartare (though a bit spicy and too many bell peppers for my taste - good nonetheless).  Then we had the salmon (again  - wonderful sauce and creamy texture cooked to perfection); lamb (nice portion, again tasty and cooked just right with a olvely sauce - though again had some veggies - zucchini and bell peppers I could do without), and the caseole (great sausage and duck with white beans ...) and dessert - pot de creme was heavenly, apple tartin was good and special with the ginger touch, and though the profiteroles we well portioned - I was not crazy about them - but not bad.
Overall a wonder experience at a fraction of what most French restaurants would charge for the same - and in a fun, cozy neighborhood place - though way tiny and crowded - we went with the flow and the bar seats and service turned out to make it even more fun.
author: Jeff H.

description: What a quaint little Glen park gem.   I have been twice now.  Both times I started off with the salad with fried artichoke, so very good.  I have had the salmon and the lamb shank.  Both were excellent.  The service is very friendly.
author: Christina C.

description: Wow, that was good!!! Just home from a delicious meal and felt it was my duty to spread the word.  Great service, super warm and quaint atmosphere. We ordered the prix fix, appetizer, entree and dessert ($21) and were recommended the perfect wine, it was such bargain for the flavor and overall satisfaction. I always thought it was going to be soooo expensive to eat here, but now that I know... they will be seeing me more often! Super yummy, they had bread on our table right away and lots of it, which good, I was hungry and it was the perfect amount of time between courses (not too long) everything was smooth and fast and the wait' staff very attentive.  I am totally full and happy and excited to have a neighborhood restaurant of such high quality with affordable prices!
author: Tanya J.

description: Fabulous - have dined here with friends twice, and everyone enjoyed the entire experience.  Pricing's not bad, and the food is delicious.  What a gem for Glen Park!
author: Catherine T.

description: The owner Laurent Legendre, was very warm, attentive and welcoming throughout our dinner. Even holding aside the velvet curtain and door upon our exit for my fragile dining companion. We both enjoyed the varied menu and options, but do wish there were just a few more beef oriented options for those of us from the mid-west originally, that just gotta have our beef wherever we dine. Our reservation through open table was in the system and we were seated immediately and never felt rushed throughout our meal even though the restaurant continued to fill up.
author: Shelley F.

description: It's been awhile since I've been here, but damnnnnnnnnnnnnnn...SO DELISH! I was a bit wary of going to a French restaurant since I'm a vegetarian and knew that there would prob be a singular item on the menu for me...and although there was literally one choice, it was bangin! My dinner mate was drooling over his dish as well (sorry, can't remember the names of the dishes).  Amazing meal in an intimate setting that really throws you into a time/location warp.
author: Alicia O.

description: Great food, great prices, but the owner/head waitress is really high anxiety and stresses me out a little bit the way she darts in between close set tables.
author: T D.

description: Really enjoyed the food and the atmosphere. Although you'd better make reservations. European style, they do NOT rush the patrons as they eat their meal. Made for a very relaxing dinner savoring good food.
author: Sile O.

description:
Geez, 28 reviews for a place that just opened not long ago.  Okay, I haven't been here, but I have heard rave reviews from my neighbor who sussed out the place and came here the first week they opened, and who also introduced me to Laurent himself.  I will come here at an off time if there is such a thing.  Every day I pass by, it's packed to the rafters!  Glen Park has gone through major changes in the last year...all good, especially with this addition!
Update: Took a year, but finally got here.  Split the Lamb entree w/my cousin and we each had the crab salad. We were disappointed that it was canned crab, but the presentation had a unique build with the strips of cucumber wrapped around it. We ordered a side of mashed potatoes to go along with the Lamb, which had a lot of succulent meat. I had the Tart Tartin and my cousin had the better dessert, the Profiteroles...mmmmm, nice and crisp.
author: Arlene C.

description: Visited for birthday dinner with my family and everyone's meal was outstanding. The service was amazing, the escargot was fantastic, and we had a nice bottle of wine. Laurent even sent me home with a nice bottle of wine as a birthday gift! To Laurent, Head Chef Eliseo Soto, and the entire waitstaff: keep up the great work!
author: J.J. P.

description: If you were in Paris, this would still be on the extremely elegant list. Laurent, his wonderful chef and gorgeous staff makes me and my sweetie feel as though we are as revered like chocolate mousse. Every restaurateur who wonders why their tables are not filled in this recession needs to stop in and experience the magic.
author: Janet P.

description: i'm not going to lie. the food is good. authentic french. rich and yummy. the inside is warm and cozy, however the service isn't so great and for me, why pay alot of money here for good food but bad service, when i can go to chapeau and have great food and excellent service. on average the price per entree is around $20-$25, unless you choose the neighborhood menu which is under $30 and i believe it's 3 courses. we stayed a la carte, and for that price, i expect good service. unfortunately we had to ask for spoons for our soup, forks for escargot, refills on water, and another bottle of wine which surprised me because as a former waitress i know that the easiest markup on a check are the beverages and the higher the bill the bigger the tip. i guess this waiter didn't care. in saying all of this, the food was delish. we went with the waiters suggestions and he was on point at least with that.
author: SF Native M.

description: Simple flavorful French Bistro food at reasonable prices.  The wine list is fair with some god regional selections. The Negroni the bartenders craft are quite tasty. There is a prix fee menu on Sundays that has not disappointed yet. Try it you just might love it.
author: Brian G.

description: Nestled in a quaint corner along Diamond and Chenery street Le P'tit Laurent brought us back to France.  This isn't the Bistro type of french food either.  For dinner we started off with an escargo appeitizer and opted to try the lamb shank and beef bourguignon.  The meats were perfectly braised and melt in your mouth tender.  We were also in love with the french bread and probably had ourselves 3 baskets in which we dipped in the escargo sauce and the beef bourgignon.  There was quite a selection of wines from France and Europe although we opted not to try anything that evening.  Service was wonderful, and although we made reservations and arrived early, we were seated promptly.  We did notice a $22 three course prix fixe menu in which we might try on our next visit.  Street parking wasn't an issue since we just merely parked at the Glen Park Bart Station parking lot for free and walked around the corner.
author: Cathy L.

description: Exceptional cassoulet and lapin. Authentic local French bistro. Delightful and friendly staff. The pot au creme  and creme brulee are terrific desserts. A good value.
author: Rich W.

description: Well done French comfort food with the additional benefit of innovative preparations on the specials.  The service is warm and friendly, but take your time and enjoy the fact that you will not be rushed through a lovely meal.  Excellent house wines are available by the glass and the bartender, Julien, makes dining at the bar a must!  We have been twice and cannot wait to return with friends and family.  This is an oasis if you are looking for a genuine dining experience which distinguishes itself from the corporate, overwrought eateries all over town.
author: Neira F.

description: Fantastique! The service was charming attentive and playful, The food was incredible! I highly, highly recommend it. We had the escargot which was delicious. The mussels were perfect and it was all I could do not dip the whole basket of bread in the sauce. The carpacchio was a little mushy for my tastes but the balsamic dressing was divine and overcame the slight flaw. The beet raviolis were so incredible that my daughter and I were fighting over it! My huband loved his rabbit as well...run don't walk as soon it will be impossible to get in!
author: Roxanne M.

description:
Fantastic!  And I'm so thrilled, as a Glen Park resident.  I went here with my husband and 4 friends the other day and every one of us loved our food.  The service was a bit slow, but as one of my friends noted, that's the beauty of a French meal--linger over the wine!  Highlights:

-Sole:  Delicious, light, and lots of fish
-Vegetarian ravioli:  my veg pal has eaten this three times and loves it, beets and mushrooms galore
-Cheese service:  they come to your table, show you 5 varieties, and cut it to order--you can have all five!  Amazing cheeses as well, and the woman who served them knew her cheese.
-Wine:  exceptionally reasonably priced.  We had a Pinotage and a Pinot Blanc and each was under $35 and delicious

Also-we were not hurried out, and were there over 3 hours, and the last party to leave.  Wonderful place, a good value, and a welcome addition to the neighborhood.
author: Rebecca B.

description: My Wife and I had dinner there, they recommended a pasta dish, I tried it and it was so salty I explained to the waitress and she brought it back to the kitchen and to show the chef.  The waitress brought it back and didn't say a word.  I didn't eat it and the waitress tried to avoid me the rest of the evening.  I think they should had the courtsey of offering me something else or a sorry.  I did not recieve neither.  When I left, I saw the chef outside and told the chef, and he said he knew.  I think the host of the restaurant should apologize because I do not plan to ever go back. I paid for a meal that I never ate.
author: Ron L.

description:
BOTTOM LINE: My new fave French bistro in the City.

I LUV me some P'tit Laurent! Ate here for the second time ever last night & everything was parfait! Amazingly scrumptious perfectly seasoned appetizers, salads and entrees. My man had the lamb - I don't eat lamb but he said it was out of this world, falling of  the bone, melt in your mouth good. I had the bass - ok my mouth is watering just thinking about it.  The cassoulet is also really good. 

The chef, owner and hostess are all super nice. and the food is served on the fast side. It's a really small space but it feels quaint and romantic not claustrophobic. 

Make reservations - they get busy. Sometime I gotta try the prix fixe menu. i just never can get there before 7.
author: Lisa M.

description:
Good food, reasonable price, nice service.  It was cheerful, too.
What a nice little place.  It was busy even though it was week night.  Reservation recommended. 
I would like to visit it again between 5:30 - 7 Mon-Thurs, which they have specials for less than $20.
author: Miinno N.

description:
We live in Glen Park, but are pretty much regulars at Zuni Cafe.  We had had many enjoyable meals at La Ciccia and were pleased to see this French Bistro arrive.  Chenery Park Restuarant is nice, but kind of boring so we haven't been back for quite awhile.
We decided to take a chance on Le P'tit Laurent a couple of weeks ago.  We had a terrific meal and a very nice dining experience.  We liked it so much that we decided to take another group the following week.  These people had a home in France for years and they were also delighted with the place.  I think the real clue to having a good experience is to make reservations ahead of time.  Don't walk in without reservations and then write a nasty blog about not getting a table.
author: john w.

description: I went there for the first time on Saturday.  I was not sure how I felt when I looked inside the restaurant but the experience turned out to be very positive.  The service was some of the best I have received in a while.  It felt like France with the long slow meal.
author: Sara W.

description:
Being a resident of Glen Park, I am thrilled to report that Le P'tit Laurent is an outstanding French Bistro in my neighborhood. We dine 
here at least once a week and I can safely recommend all items on the menu, especially the soups which are absolutely delicious. Regardless what you order, it will be prepared in the traditional french style. The manager, Sonia, is ultra accommodating (and quite a terrific artist as well). Keep in mind that the restaurant is extremely popular. Reservations are required!!! 

Although I may be biased, Glen Park is a charming village and well worth a visit. Sitting at the corner table (by the divided window) is a perfect vantage point to take in the atmosphere of our quaint village. Be certain to check out the Canyon Market for specialty foods and head across the street to the Cheese Boutique for great prices on imported cheeses and international foods. 

Tell Sonia that Jeffry and Kelly sent you! You won't be disappointed.
author: Jeffry O.

description: This is a seriously good French restaurant! It is small and intimate with a nice "buzz" and nice waitstaff (except for the sometimes snooty hostess). I have been here several times and it has always been tops. If you go, try the Lamb shank. It melts in your mouth. Wine list is reasonably price. If you take BART, it is only a block away from the station.
author: Tom B.

description: Really delightful place.  We did not have reservations so we sat at the bar and ate.  The food was delicious and the service was excellent.  You really feel like you are at a brasserie in Paris (w/o the smoke).  Definitely worth going to.
author: Karen B.

description:
Been meaning to try this local bistro and my wife and I finally got away from the kids to check it out. No reservation but got a pair of seats at the bar right away. Tight fit but very comfortable, excellent bar stools.

The menu is very traditional french bistro style food. This is not a bold gourmet cuisine experience -- the dishes you'd expect to find are mostly here. We ordered basics and were enthusiastic about the choices nonetheless.

Appetizers: A decent start.
 - smoked salmon salad (special). overall attractively done and my wife found it very good.
 - frisee salad. fairly tasty but over-dressed, which makes the frisee wilt. still this was perfectly fine.

Main Courses: Again, very inconsistent.
 - lamb flank: my wife was very disappointed. the meat was oddly tasteless, and the sauce didn't do much for it at all. 
 - bouillabaisse: best dish of the evening. very nice assortment of prawns, scallops, white fish, salmon, and mussels. the base was herby and fresh tasting, and the fish was nicely balanced by chunks of potato. a classic dish and well done.

Dessert: A very poor ending.
 - apple tart: This french specialty should be a softball they hit hard. Instead it was terrible. The pastry was burnt and the apples were soggy. Overall it was disgusting and bitter.
 - profiteroles. Mediocre. The pastry was oddly crunchy and flavorless, and the balls were filled with bland ice cream. 

Given how competitive a dining market San Francisco is, and how consistently poor-to-average this food was, I am surprised how this place is crowded every night. The fixed price menu ($21 for 3 courses) is attractive, but we didn't have that choice on a Friday night (our meal was about $120 with no alcohol). Perhaps, some might say, we were just unlucky, and should give it another try. I'm sorry to say I won't. Why eat at a proven loser when there are fantastic restaurants available at the same price point?

Overall the service was friendly, professional and efficient, but the good service doesn't rescue the sub-par dining experience.
author: Richard F.

description:
So sorry but we recently had a really poor experience here. We'd been coming here for awhile and really liked it - both food and service. All of those times the owner had been on the premises as maitre'd - he is a great guy, very charming, and takes good care of his customers.
     However this time he was not there. In his place was an incredibly snotty French woman. First, she opened late while people with reservations were standing around outside waiting. No apology from her, nothing. When she opened, the first thing she did was welcome a friend of hers with kissy face, take flowers from her, and not even acknowledge the guests. She finally got around to sitting people. Then we sat there for FIFTEEN minutes in an empty restaurant, waiting for someone to come over to our table. She and the bartender were 5 feet away, completely ignoring us and chatting to each other. I finally got up and went to the bar and asked if we could order a drink, at which point the Frenchwoman gave me a truly dirty look. Pardon me for interupting your little tete-a-tete! She came over to our table twice during the meal and was truly toxic each time.  
     When friends of hers came in to the restaurant, she was all kissy with them, but with any diners she didn't know she made faces and was unpleasant.
     If Laurent does not get rid of this woman they are going to lose customers. We were not the only ones that night who were unhappy with her, and we now hesitate to go back, in spite of how much we've liked the place in the past, for fear she will be there and ruin the experience.
     We have been to Paris many times and have never encountered this kind of rudeness there.
author: Dexter N.

description: Very good early bird special.  Only once ordered a fish that was a bit tough, otherwise all of the food was very good.  The French waiter was even nice!!
author: Susan A.

description: I had dinner there this week and had one of those unfortunate experiences where EVERYBODY's dinner was better than mine.  I ordered the veal from the prix fixe menu and it was dried out, overcooked and tasted like overdone roast beef, more than a tender veal.  The soup (potato, fennel and chicken) was delicious, and the escargot that we all shared were phenom., but the veal  . . . not so much.  I'd probably try it again (but not any time soon) just to see if my experience was an aberration.
author: Cristina S.

description: We came here for brunch today.  This is a small little bistro.  Service was not bad, but the food was most excellent.  The egg benedict was great.  The ham and cheese omelette was most excellent.  The best was the chicken sandwich.  We will be back for more for sure.  The only problem was that the restaurant was ran by only 2 people, so don't expect super fast service, but I thought it was adequate.
author: AhLin C.

description: WOW!  What a find!  Thanks to YELP, we ate here Saturday night with friends from Berkeley (they took BART, which stops a block away) who are part owners of a certain VERY special Berkeley restaurant.  They said: "This is just the kind of restaurant Berkeley needs!" and we know Santa Cruz County DEFINITELY needs a wonderful French restaurant that is affordable and not at all pretentious.  We all felt as if we were in Paris!  The food was outstanding, as was the service, and the charming hostess.  Yes, the tables are VERY close together, but it was worth it!  Every dish was a succulent gem (sweetbreads, 2 salads, filet de bar, bouillabaisse).  I want to go back tonight!
author: jill c.

description: We were seated about 20 minutes after our reservation time and it was not worth the wait. The escargots had a bland watered-down sauce. The french onion soup was a huge disappointment. I have already blocked out the main course. I think our guests pretended to like their dinner. To be clear, it's not that the food is horrible, it's just that the dishes are worse than they should be - considering how simple and flavorful the ingredients are. The host and waitress were VERY friendly.
author: Marina N.

description: I was weirded out by all the French accents by the workers--yes, all of them. But we got very good, attentive, friendly service. The roast chicken and the smoked salmon were very good, as was the winter vegetable soup. A Chimay and a Kronenberg were both ice cold, just the way I like it, and each came in its own branded glass. For dessert, the caramel creme was fantastic, just melted in your mouth, not too rich. I honestly had no complaints other than just missing out on the prix-fixe menu that ends at 7pm.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I'm always on the lookout for the new French restaurants and looked forward to eating at Le P'Tit Laurent since I moved to Glen Park a few months ago. My family had a belated birthday dinner for my mother one Sunday, and she got lucky and was the only one who LOVED all her food.

I ordered the frisse salad with over easy eggs and pancheta and was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed it. The French onion soup was also nice, but my mother's crab salad was killer - all crab and hardly any salad. Delicious.

My mom's chicken was also fantastic, while my steak was good, but too huge a portion. Our other guests ordered the swordfish, but had to send it back since it was undercooked.

Desserts were lovely. My profiteroles weren't as good as Chapeau! or Cafe de la Presse (the shell was a little thicker) but still very nice. The wine list is decent and they serve Pastis, a must for any Francophile!

I was happy with the service and would definitely go back. That is, if I can't get into Chapeau!
author: Adrienne D.

description:
Four stars, why not five? Well, its just not that fabulous.  It's certainly is as good a choice as any, but its small, and noisy.  However, the atmosphere seems very French, having just been to Paris, its not unlike some of the over-rated French restaurants.  What do I mean by that, for starters, actual Parisian Restaurants are crowded noisy affairs and not as great as we've been lead to believe.  You can get decent food, but you pay too much and are often encouraged to hurry up already so others can get in.  If you are willing to spend say, a whole month's paycheck, you can get some incredible stuff in Paris, but other wise, its a lot like Le P'tit Laurent.  If you live in Glen Park, be grateful that you've got a cute place that serves decent food.  However, I live in the Richmond District and the only reason we went over to Glen Park was to see Laurent himself.  He's a very charming and hardworking man.  I hope his business does great things for him.  As far as his servers go, my husband liked the women there, and he speaks a little French, so he had a good time with them.  As for me, I couldn't have cared less, but they were adequate as servers.  The big Norman waitress (big up front) almost drove my husband into fits of lust, but I just rolled my eyes.
She's very funny otherwise.  We will probably wander back there occasionally, but it can't be a main stay for us, its just too much to travel and if you are going to drink any wine, not a good idea to drive.  But I think you should try it.  Make reservations PLEASE, all it takes is a call, why is that so hard for people?  if you even call 10 minutes before you think you want to go, why don't you?  I can't help but wonder about the people who whine that they got a cold shoulder when they didn't have a reservation.  If I don't have a reservation, I will sit at the bar, I'll wait until there's room, and I won't whine.  Oh, its helpful always to learn a tiny tiny bit of French.  Just so you can greet the staff.  It will be more like dining in Paris that way, don't be an ugly American.
author: Sarah H.

description: The Glen Park district is a hot bed of great eateries--ranging through Japanese, Chinese, Italian, Mexican, French--and this little French restaurant is the best of them all. Lucky me, I live just up the block and have been frequenting them frequently!  Le P'tit Laurent (The Little Waiter) has a genuinely first generation French staff, a top knotch chef, and always an incredibly deliscious menu. If you want to sample true French cuisine--I mean soups and stews, fish and steaks, breads and cheeses, and desserts--you should definitely reserve a table in advance. This place is great!  One additonal word of advise, if the waitress suggests a particular dish, always take it! They know what they are talking about. Enjoy!
author: Chris C.

description: went here last Friday night, when my girlfriend & I sat down the first thing I noticed (other than it being TOTALLY packed, and the great use of space) was how much the look & feel reminded me of Clementine.  Surprise! Laurent was a former owner @ Clementine - Service is extremely friendly and honest (our French waitress gave us her professional  opinion on wines & desserts with accompanying beverages.   She was spot on with choices as she let us taste the options)  Escargot was sublime, as was the carpaccio & our respective fish dishes.   I'm sad that I no longer live in Glen Park at an exciting time when restaurants and the Canyon Market have opened up
author: Sfgpgirl G.

description: We loved this spot and are psyched that it adds another restaurant to the growing Glen Park scene.  Service was very good (surprising for a new restaurant) and the food was spot on bistro fare.  Nice work Laurent!
author: Ann F.

description: I take bart to Glen Park daily and decided to try this little place to satisfy a late night craving for Creme Brulee. The staff was very nice considering the fact that I'm a broke college student who walked in wearing a sweatshirt and jeans.  Coffee was good. Creme Brulee was great.  I came alone this time but definitely will try this place again w/a friend.
author: Nicole C.

description: I had a very French moment at Le P'tit Laurent. After the waitress brought our wine, and poured me a taste, she disappeared (it was crushingly busy), so I grabbed the bottle and reached for one of my friends' glasses. Within moments, she rematerialized, and with a quick "tsk, tsk!" and a shake of her finger, relieved me of the bottle, and did the honors. It was one of those moments where you feel served and subservient at the same time. I loved it.
author: Gregory M.

description: I would definitely go back.  Attractive restaurant, tasty food and good service.  They know how to capitalize off of their French accents--peppering their speech with French phrases seemed more concocted than natural, but it charmed me nevertheless!  Food tasted good, BUT the soup and creme brulee were both cold (slightly warmer than room temperature).  I do not like snobby/perfect restaurants run by companies formed by superstar/millionaire restauranteurs...I prefer the authentic, personable, neighborhood feel of Le P'tit Laurent!
author: Gran A.

description: their mussles are to die for! I can eat 3 baskets of bread just to dip up all the broth! delicious! great wine and great service! I always make a point to come here every few months and treat myself.
author: Erin Elizabeth K.

description:
My husband and I moved to San Francisco about 4 months ago. One of our first orders of business? Finding a great French restaurant.

Our first try was Le P'tit Laurent and just like that, our search is over. Great food, reasonable prices, and great ambience. If you like French food, go here.
author: Rose L.

description: One of our favorite "neighborhood" type restaurants! Excellent date place... IF i ever went on any. :-)
author: All About Town ..

description:
I've only eaten here once, but I had the chilled avocado soup, and the rabbit.  These were truly amazing dishes, especially when you consider the price, which is reasonable considering the quality of the food.  

The waitress was most definitely French.  She was condescending and literally scoffed at my choice of wine to go with my rabbit.  I had chosen a California chardonnay, she insisted on a French wine.  Sorry, honey, but don't you know California wines have kicked the French's butts in two tasting competitions recently?  

But I don't care about this as much when the food is so good.  My rabbit was literally almost as good as the rabbit I had at La Folie.  That is saying something because La Folie is 5X as expensive.  If you get to Le P'tit Laurent before a certain time (I believe 6:30) you can get a very reasonable prix fixe meal.  It is hard to get a table, so make a reservation, though I got lucky and was seated right away when I just showed up.
author: Brendan R.

description: This is a wonderful French, neighborhood restaurant. I love the ambience and food. Reminds me of bistros I ate in when I was in Paris. Little Larry's (as I like to call it) always delivers a great experience. The staff, including the owner, are very friendly, not hoighty-toighty as they could easily be given the number of people who want to eat there every night.
author: John B.

description: Like South Park Cafe, this is simple French bistro fare at a reasonable price. I ate here once on the night of the Oscars and it was very quiet (though I know it is busy most of the time) and the meal was excellent. Definitely will be going back.
author: Thomas K.

description:
Overall the atmosphere was cozy, but seemed at times too crowded and a little loud. Our waitress warmed up eventually, but initially appeared to not have time to give us any recommendations about the menu. Eventually she suggested the cassoulet, the beef, and the bass.

I had the mixed salad with fried artichoke. It was fantastic. This was the peak of my meal. I had the cassoulet for my main meal. The meat was very tender and tasty, but it was incredibly salty. I almost couldn't finish it. My wife had the soup of the day which was a tomato and lobster soup. She said it was good but also salty. For her entree she had the Beef Bourguignon.  She said that was tasty and tender but also too salty.
author: Pennan B.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. It's close to home (Glen Park), but after several visits, I just won't go again.

I came home via BART (about a block away) and walked over to LPL and had the prix fix dinner with my partner. We came early and we were immediately seated by a native French speaker who was delightful. We practiced our French, she told us about her province. We had a great dinner.

Sadly we never saw her again, and found ourselves more and more disappointed with each visit. The food quality (overly salted beef bourguignon, dry lamb, etc) as well as the service (bordered on nasty our last visit) declined. That last visit was with a elderly Quebecoise friend of ours who was so badly treated because she dared ask for greater explanation of the menu that I'm ashamed we didn't just leave. No only does it warrant an "I don't like it" but given that we live in an area with such excellent food choices, I strongly encourage readers to skip LPL and look elsewhere.
author: Lewis B.

description:
After 10 visits this is becoming my favorite french restaurant with reasonable prices.. Waitresses are very friendly and efficient. It usually pretty packed so make reservations or see if you can sit at the bar. 

The food really is at a high level. The chef creates intense flavors, the soups are always big and bold, just fantastic and surprising. The artichoke salad is one of the best I've ever had. Highly recommended. 

Le P'tit Laurent is doing a great job, we take out of town guests there now because we know it is consistently enjoyable.
author: John W.

description: I moved to Glen Park in January and after eating at Gialina many times, Chenery Park once and La Corneta pretty much once a week, I felt that my options were exhausted. I was so excited when Le P'tit Laurent opened as it would give me another option. My boyfriend and I went on a Friday, but sat down at 5:30 figuring  we would beat the dinner crowd. The server was extremely nice and friendly, however the restaurant was so jam packed that she brought our food and barely noticed us again. We ordered wine that we never received, waited what seemed like an eternity to get our check, and the food was not as great as I would have liked. I will say that the mussels are a ridiculously great deal - they pile them HIGH. It's a cute place but the experience was overall, pretty blah. I would go back for brunch though to see if the food/experience is better. You get one more chance Laurent!
author: Heather M.

description:
I ordered the Salmon with mash potato and spinach; my partner ordered the beef bourguignon. Both dishes were excellent, the beef - outstanding. The vanilla ice cream profiteroles floating in chocolate sauce were perfect for dessert. In addition to attentive and authentically French waitresses, the chef and owner visited our table to check on the quality. 
We went back for Sunday brunch. This time I had the beef bourguignon which was again great with an ample portion. However, the brunch fayre that my friends had was nothing special.
author: Chris W.

description: Charming little French Bistro that transports you instantly to Paris (if it weren't for the "Egglettes.com" storefront right across the street).  VERY cozy (read occupancy limit of about 40-50), but the servers are charming and attentive, and the food is spot-on.  We had a lovely mushroom soup to start (almost licked the bowl!) - I proceeded to devour a sensational dish with sea bass covered in a delectable sauce.  My companion had the steamed salmon served on a bed of mussels, spinach, and mashed potatoes - tres bonne!!  We shared a perfectly lovely half-carafe of the house white wine.   Prices are VERY reasonable for a French restaurant in the city - our bill was less than $65 for two!   I will visit encore, encore, et encore!
author: Debbie B.

description: Loved this cozy neighborhood bistro - very Parisian.  Cute 'hood I had never been to before with no problem finding street parking on a Saturday night.  My husband and I started with salads - mixed green for him, frisee aux lardons and poached egg for me - delish - a bit vinegary but very good.  I ordered the rabbit, subbing frites for the mashed potatoes - excellent!  The rabbit was meltingly tender in a wonderful reduced sauce.  The frites made me very happy, indeed.  Hubby had lamb shank, which was equally tasty.  Service was friendly and the whole place felt warm and filled with happy people.  Dessert was warm caramelized apple tart - perfect.
author: Laura W.

description:
I had the salmon and the food was DRENCHED with butter and cream.  It was so rich I couldn't force myself to swallow it.  The service was nice and I enjoyed my wine, but man that was the worst salmon dish I've had to date.  Not hard to cook salmon, make it simple and not RICH.  All I could taste was butter.  Imagine eatting a stick of butter that's just melted.  

I wouldn't recommend this here.
author: K T.

description:
went there last night for the first time and I highly recommend it!!

great food, the neighborhood menu for $22 is a perfect treat (Su-Th)!
staff is very friendly and all desserts are delicious!!

Go and try out yourself! 5 stars!
bon appetit!
author: Christina P.

description: Several years ago we were so pleased to hear that a so-called bistro style French restaurant was opening up in Glen Park.  This has been a disappointment from the first visit.  The space and atmosphere are great, but the food overall just not up to the price tag, or to any price tag.  We've had lackluster bistro food, a brunch visit where the english muffin in the the eggs benedict was not even toasted (some kind of french/english rivalry?).  My husband and I went last night  for a one more chance visit;  the bordeaux and cassoulet were pretty good, but onion soup was overwhelmed with oregano and the bouef boeuf bourguignon was tough - needed much more simmering.  Service was lackluster, you knew when you gave any kind of feedback, it was not going any further than the server anyway, so why bother?  Want excellent bistro food - check out L'Ardoise in Noe Valley - no comparison.  Good eggs benedict - check out Liberty Cafe.  From now on, we'll spring for a cab rather than dining in the neighborhood.  Consistently and sadly disappointing.
author: Lucy M.

description:
