Disappointing.  It looked like a great spot .I wanted to give it a try.  I was pretty disappointed with the food though.
Like the atmosphere and service was ok. 
Better french bistro in the city.
author: Bob c.

description:
I have been there three times and the food had never disappointed me or my husband.  My only negative coment is the food comes out too fast.  We tried to slow them down by just giving our appetizer order, then ordering the entree later, but, it still came out too fast.  This place is a gem but needs to slow down.  I feel very rushed.
P.S. Try the vodka sorbet.....it is incredible.
author: Cathy V.

description:
I gotta say, I was not massively impressed. We are lovers of French food and were excited to try this place. From the get-go the whole experience was mediocre and disappointing
.
 We made a reservation several days in advance and we still had to wait for 45 minutes plus.  Because its so small and it was packed there was only one seat available and so one of us had to stand. We wouldn't have minded the wait had they given us a complimentary glass of wine or appetizer, or something. But, nothing, and cause it gets hot in there (b/c so small) the door was open and so we were standing in a draught too.

Anyway, we eventually sit, the waitress is friendly enough but by this time we were starving so a bit quicker would have been preferable.
Food: I ordered snails - they were alright, nothing special, the sauce was a bit overpowering. My companion had the cured meats. I swear, they were like something shrink wrapped you could get at the deli; rubbery and bland.

Entree, I had the beef Bourginoin (sp?) and i was SO disappointed. There was far too much sauce and too little anything else. The beef was alright, there was no  medley of flavors hitting my tongue though. The mash potato was a JOKE! I think it was the instant stuff. It was thin and they were not generous with the portion. I make it better at home and i am no chef. 

My companion had the lentil stew dish, and  enjoyed it.

Chocolate mousse for dessert, again, nothing special, it was too solid, not light and frothy and it was very cold, as if delivered straight from the freezer.
So, all in all, not a place i will frequent, but it could have been a one off bad experience, and since my companion enjoyed the entree, I will probably give it another try. First run was not a success.
author: pirate p.

description:
One new addition to our favorite "affordable" French restaurant list, along with Le Charm, Cote Sud, Baker Street cafe and la Provence.
The menu here is composed of traditional French cuisine. You can't go wrong. "Home away from home" as my wife and I are from France and the French part of Switzerland.

We took the escargots, a frisee salade, a sole, a cassoulet and a tarte tatin. Everything was good, special mention for the frisee and the tarte tatin. Service was friendly and efficient. Wine was good. I recommend the good value champagne too. We'll definitely go back to try the rest of the menu.
author: Jordan L.

description: I get there at about 12:45 on weekends when it's quiet....DARN I shouldn't have told you then!!  I run in for a fast soup and baguette and a salad, he knows I'm on my lunch break and only have half an hour so makes sure everything comes out pronto!  I miss my jaunts to France and coming in here makes me feel better.  So its small and theres a line at peak times, so go off peak times bozo!!  A charming place, makes you feel like you're overseas on vacation again!!
author: Monique G.

description: I came in kinda drunk last year and he suggested a pinot and i said ive already been drinking a bit so perhaps something else. he looked at me with aghast expression and politely asked if i was going to allow him to select a wine and I said yes, I would.  another time last year on a date her and I were waiting for a table and she was tired of waiting and told the guy -"Im tired of waiting, can we have a table now?" - He looked at her with aghast expression and said that she would have to wait.
author: Joe D.

description: We were going to go to Fleur de lys and instead ended up at this incredible hidden gem. Tucked in a mixed and interesting San Francisco neighborhood on a central corner. Great local French decor without being gimmicky. The owner greeted us and periodically came to help us make choices without being overbearing. He suggested a fantastic Pinot Noir, rather than a white, to go with our Bass and chicken entrees. The fish was about the best I've had with a coriander infused sauce. Chicken also had a lovely sauce with cumin, innovative but still French. The owner pushed us to try the French Toast desert even after I told him that sounded terrible; was I glad I let him push me. Crispy and soft, burnt drizzle of caramel, slight salty butter undertone, hard to describe but with a coffee and a glass of muscat, incredible.
author: Jedidiah B.

description: Now this restaurant is really quite the find! A little over a year ago I had the good fortune of being introduced to this little neighborhood gem where I got Frenchified; and I don't mean cut-n-fried potatoes. They usually feature one fish-dish and one meat-dish that you can order from the 3-course prix fixe menu. Lamb shank and pork osso bucco that falls off the bone, salmon, red snapper, lobster ravioli, seafood, frog legs, sweet breads, and oysters. No, not all in one sitting. The flavors are strikingly distinct and it's obvious that the chef takes a great deal of time to achieve well-balanced flavors that satisfy your palate. Order a glass or half carafe of wine with your meal, enjoy your company, and you're set for one pleasurable meal. Yes, this is a small quaint place crowded every time I go with lines out the door. The restaurant staff are genuinely French, speak with heavy accents, and are tentative to their guests. What?! The French are friendly to their patrons?... you bet they are. For a great little dinning experience come hungry cause they're gonna feed you some really good stuff.
author: Gina A.

description:
Our first time diining here.  We had heard conflicting reports from two friends, but on eating there last night, I can say that  the favorable report wins.  Very much a french neighborhood bistro experience.

Having been in France many times, the experience was just like being there.  Both the atmosphere (including close proximity of tables) to the food to the service.  Very authentic.
author: Davi D.

description: I've walked by this place so many times: seeing the warm cozy atmoshpere and the faces of all the happy diners - I just had to make it here and for no less of a reason then for my birthday dinner.  We were seated quickly to our table and immediately I felt like I was in France.  Our hostess and servers were charming and attentive.  The food was classic, cooked to perfection, and the sauces were seasoned so well.  I often have to add salt or pepper to my dishes but this time everything was superb.  I'm adding this place to my list to take friends and out of town guests.
author: Angela C.

description: I'm giving them 4 stars, but that is being generous. It's actually under four but there aren't fractions available. This place is good for large groups, they accommodated our group of 6 with ease and the environment was good for our loud and indulgent group. The waiter was totally on with his service and never had us wait for fresh glasses or to uncork a new bottle of wine. So, for atmosphere and service I give high marks. The food was not as good as I have been hearing. The snails were the same tired old garlic and butter that's been done a million times before. The rabbit was good but not great and my boyfriends lamb shank had a strange consistency although the flavor was good. One thing I will say is the amount of garnish this chef puts on his dishes is laughable. Giant piles of chives on EVERYTHING. It was rather absurd and became a bit of a joke with the table. I'd probably return for the prix fixe though.
author: jen w.

description:
I am a long time reader of Yelp and had to put this, my first review in for Le P'tit Laurent. The food is decent bistro fare and I have been twice. The owner was friendly and very accommodating. But I believe it helped to have fluent French speakers at your table. Our first time the service was great and the bill was big (for 8 people, three courses, and several bottles of wine). The waitress (the same one both times) was very helpful but not pushy. 

This second time (n= 6) we had one French speaker at the table and when she asked in French "Does anyone else speak?" and our friend said "no" the waitress proceeded to say to him in French " Let's make a game of making the others try to pronounce their dishes in Francais!" What I find a little demeaning is when she corrected the pronunciation of all the guests and then wouldn't leave us alone till two of us had perfected saying  "Beef Bourguignon" several times. We didn't order a first course nor much wine and that pretty much left us unattended for longer periods of time than other customers. When one person ordered a steak well-done she insisted he have it medium-well several times and brought it to him that way.  I'm all for helpful suggestions and meat med-rare is my preference too but to just plain ignore a request from the customer is rude in my book. Overall I think it is a nice addition to have a bistro in the neighborhood but expect to be treated differently depending on how much French you speak and how much you choose to order. Perhaps that is the nature of all eateries but for this mid range neighborhood, there was too much attitude and not enough excellent food to back it up.
author: Jamie C.

description: Ate the rabbitt in bacon ragout and it may just be the best rabbit I ever ate. I was nervous about the random add of bacon, but it added a delicious smokiness that was to die for. The service is slow but lovely. The place is so cozy. It's the perfect neighborhood bistro.
author: Namita K.

description: This has to be the worst French Restaurant in San Francisco.  We went on a Saturday night and the service was awful from the start.  It took 30 minutes before the waitress took our order.  The table next to us also had to wait a long time.  The New York steak was cold and the butter couldn't even melt it was so cold.  The french fries looked and tasted as if they had been reheated several times.  The waitress was no where to be found.  We finally flagged down the bus boy and told him in Spanish our food was terrible and he replaced it.  The second time the food was cooked properly and was Okay, but nothing to write home about.  Le Zinc on 24th Street and Chou Chou on Laguna are MUCH better French restaurants.  The table next to us waited 45 minutes for their food to come out.  When they complained to the waitress she said "that is the french way"  They were Indian and had specifically asked if the Scallions had bacon.  They were told no and the Scallions did have bacon.  They were celebrating a birthday dinner and the person paying couldn't eat his dinner.  AGAIN, no waitress to tell about the problem.  Another table had the waitress spill carmel on her shirt.  Finally the waitress came by our table and I was able to tell her about the first steak being terrible and that the busboy had helped us.  The table next to us just wanted the bill.  They waited another half an hour for the bill.  When the waitress came with the bill she said "I hope you enjoyed  your dinner" and they were finally able to tell her they didn't because the Scallions had bacon.  She just smiled and said thanks for telling me.  Then she came back and told them they would take the meal off the bill.  They had to wait again for another bill.  This is the worst place I've ever been to.  There are so many French restaurants in the city that I would advice anyone to skip this place and go to either Le Zinc or Chou Chou.  If you are in Glen Park and are hungry, go across the Street and grab a burrito at La Corneta.  The food is better and you'll save a lot of money.
author: P S.

description: I've gone to le p'tit laurent since the beginning and just realized that I haven't posted any reviews yet ! Shame on me, especially because I go there very often and LOVE that place ! I feel at home there (I am French). The food is simply excellent : you can have entrees from any part of France such as a boeuf bourguignon or a bouillabaisse. It's NOT the kind of place where you only have the choice between a croque-monsieur, a crepe and a tart... The staff is energetic and so charming ! They also know how to marry wine and food to let you enjoy your dinner as a real "gourmet". I also appreciate the way they painted the walls to make you feel like dinning... in the Eiffel Tower ! All that + French music for a very reasonnable price ! Vive le p'tit laurent !!! I'm so glad to have that restaurant so close to my place !!!
author: sophie g.

description: Came here for the brunch on a Saturday.  Once again, I left with disappointment searching for the best french toast in SF.  Not the right bread, overpowering sauce, and the most importantly the custard was not done right.
author: Bella L.

description: Mediocre at best. Wines by the glass are horrible and I can make better creme brulee. Although the manager did comp us our apertifs since we had reservations and had to wait about 15 minutes for our table.
author: Vyl C.

description: A-MAZE-ING.  Yes, I know that's spelled wrong but I needed to make sure you get the point.  Now, I'm no French foodie but I know what I like and, DAYAM, did I like this bistro!  I've never had sweetbreads (I don't want to know what's in it so you don't need to tell me) before but the sauce that it was in was really "spot on."  I've never had cassoulet, either, but, if it's made like this in France, put my "derriere" on the next flight to the Froggies!  My profiteroles with warm chocolate sauce were, 'ow u say, ooh-la-la!  In accordance with Yelp's review guidelines and  Yelp being all about honest reviews, I ain't gonna lie and say I didn't know the chef (he and his girlfriend DID buy me drinks @ The Mint once or twice!) but if I didn't like,-scratch that- LOVE the food and the service in this place, I wouldn't have written anything at all.  The place is busy and p'tit (like it's owner) so I suggest you go early (we made reservations for 6 PM on a Thursday and saw a line out the door when we left).  The wait staff is extremely courteous, patient and attentive.  A bien tot!
author: Antonio H.

description: We love this place; great food, great cosy atmosphere, pleasant service, reasonable prices and not noisy. Hard to get all of that in one location. Neighborhood menu is a great bargain!
author: Sailor C.

description: This tiny little French restaurant has a lot of charm crammed into very minimal square footage.  I believe I counted a total of 12 tables when I ate there with my family on Sunday.  Needless to say, reservations are highly recommended.  As mentioned in a number of other reviews, Le P'tit Laurent offers a $21 Fixed-Price Neighborhood Menu (Sunday through Thursday) which includes your choice of soup or salad, one of the 2 listed entrees, and dessert.  The soup of the day was a tasty puree of spinach, leeks, onions, and carrots.  According to the menu, the salad featured rock shrimp --- something you rarely see on menus here in California.  However, when the salad was delivered to our table, it appears that they had perhaps run out of the rock shrimp, and were just using regular shrimp instead.  (Oh well, we're not in Titusville, Florida).  For the entrees, we had the pork chops, a lamb shank and the bouillabaisse.  Overall, I rate the food a solid 3.5 stars.  The highlight of our meal was our delightful waitress named Fleur (who also doubled as the bartender and hostess).  Fleur is such a lovely French name, don't you think?  Truth be told, Fleur only speaks a few words of French, and actually comes from the Derbyshire area in England.  Nevertheless, her charming personality very much enhanced our dining experience.
author: Don N.

description: Nice people, superb food, very good service and reasonable prices. It's a gem in Glen Park.
author: Oscar C.

description: 8 of us came here for Dinner on a Monday for my husband's birthday and the place was packed. Luckily I had made reservations! The decor is pleasant and quaint--ranging from cottage on one side of the restaurant to "under the Eiffel tower" on the other side. The food was incredible! I had sweetbreads for my appetizer and the huge lamb shank for my entree. Others had appetizers of potato chip covered scallops, mussels, and salads. Everyone raved! I heard the cassoulet and the rabbit are superb too. The prices are very reasonable as is the $14 corkage fee. I had sorbet for desert. I'm not sure if its homemade, but the strawberry had too much orange zest in it for my taste. The peach was good though. I believe this is the same person who used to own Clementine before it was sold to Chapeau. Definitely worth another visit!
author: Gabriella M.

description:
As my friend and I sat in this small, cozy restaurant we both said at the same time if we were traveling in Paris  and were in this restaurant  we would think we had struck gold.  First of all the three course dinner offered daily is delicious and very reasonable at $20 or $21 a person.  Good choices for each course and each excellent.
It is very crowded so you really need a reservation and parking around there is challenging.  But anything worthwhile is worth the effort.  
One reason this restaurant hums along nicely is that the owner is there all the time, at least every time I have been there, and that is frequently.  He goes around to each table and carries on a nice and brief conversation. ( I hate it when the owner or waiter decides to make you their new best friend.)
Save yourself the aggravation of a snooty French restaurant when this one is friendly and good.  Going to Paris is great but Le P'tit Laurent is a nice consolation prize.
author: Sally F.

description: Excellent  neighborhood gem, i've been here numerous times and and I'm just finding time to write a review. Service is outstanding and the food is very good. can't go wrong with the prix fixe menu. Everything on the menu is good.
author: Kevin T.

description: Love this place. The staff is amazingly charming and really add a nice flair to the dining experience. Everything I have tried has been amazing. Watch out to not get filled up on the baguette. Just saying.
author: Suzanne H.

description: I really enjoyed this restaurant.  I am seven months pregnant and when I told my friend I needed meat, she brought me here.  The braised lamb was DELICIOUS.  Service was nice, and reminded me of some of the small bistros I've dined in, in France.  The only complaint is that the restaurant  is quite cramped, in more ways than one.  Admittedly, most seats don't feel very comfortable at the moment, but I really was having difficulty settling down with my big belly, they were pretty small.  Also, the restaurant was so packed with people that it was hard for me to squeeze between tables to get to the bathroom.  Because there were so many people in there, it felt like the temperature rose 10 degrees.  By the time I got outside I was really welcoming the foggy, breezy air, again, to somebody that didn't have loads of progesterone running through their bodies, they may not even notice.  Over all, great restaurant, I think I will try and make a trip back after my hormonal chaos settles down, I don't have to lean over to make sure food gets in my mouth (and not on my belly), and I don't overheat from chewing to much.
author: Jessica D.

description: Went here with 3 girlfriends this week and was very impressed with the food (veal short ribs, mashed potatoes.) The prix fixe was a good deal at $21, and the service was perfect except for the fact that they forgot that it was one of my girlfriends' birthday. (I'll cut them some slack for that, since there were apparently at least 3 other birthdays being celebrated there that night.)
author: J M.

description: We went to this restaurant on opening night and we had an incredible meal. The service was excellent, despite the fact that they were jam packed, the food was delicious and the atmosphere was lively and fun - perfect for a neighborhood bistro. We ordered the mussels, the steak frites and the beef bourguignon.  The beef bourguignon unbelievably good. Truly one of the best entrees we've ever had.  The owner of the restaurant, Laurent, used to own Clementine which is where my husband and I got engaged.  We told them that and they gave us free cocktails and wine all night (who knows, they might have done that for others since it was their opening night, but it made us happy!).   We also participated in the first Happy Birthday sing-along at the restaurant -- all the patrons chimed in, it was very festive and you could tell everyone was really happy to be there. We cannot wait to go back!
author: Mary Beth B.

description: I went here because of the reviews and it seemed popular when I passed by.  My parents were in town visiting and we decided to take them there for a nice dinner on a Saturday.  That was a mistake.  The food was good. Eating is my hobby, and I know good food.  However, the service was just enough to ruin a nice night.  The waitress didn't take our order for 25 minutes, didn't ask us what we wanted to drink, and then got our dessert order wrong (even after repeating it twice and pointing to it on the menu). She then had the nerve to say it was our fault the wrong dessert was brought out.  I spend a lot of time eating out with friends and clients, and I will not be coming back despite the great food.
author: Nick V.

description: I would have agreed with another reviewer who wrote "The food is good: not bad, not great. The service is brusque: neither friendly nor rude." Except that we were told that we had to leave because they needed our table within 10 seconds of signing the credit card slip. We had a three course meal and a bottle of wine in an hour and 15 minutes. I'm sorry but I thought I was going somewhere for a nice dining experience, not somewhere where their mission was to turn tables.
author: Martha M.

description: delicious. from the cocktails to the french toast. we went for our wedding anniversary and at the end we realized we hadn't even tasted each other's food - we didn't offer each other any because we were too busy eating it!  great value for money and delicious food and wonderful service. loved it and will return again and again.
author: patricia d.

description:
We went there because Chapeau was booked! Oh how I do regret of not having been more thoughtful and plan ahead making the Chapeau reservation earlier. 
If you only look at the menu the food looks like a good value. However, after you actually ate it, this first impression fades because the quality of the food is just  not there. I had escargot as an appetizers which was OK. The bread was good though. My main course was a rabbit on a bed of mashed potatoes. Tasted OK but very poorly presented. Desert was also OK. 
If I were to rate the food alone I would give it two, maybe three stars at best. However, the reason this restaurant does not deserve more than one star is because of the horrible, rude service and the noise level that requires constant yelling so that the person on the other side of the table has a chance to hear what you say. I expect the latter issue to go away over time because the number of "patrons" will certainly go down.
author: Oliver G.

description: I am so disappointed.  I had higher expectations for this adorable looking bistro.  It was so exciting to see a place like this open in Glen Park, but looks can be deceiving.  The restaurant looks cute and cozy with lots of nice detail and is often packed.  My husband and I went for dinner and loved the atmosphere and the service.  The place was already full by 6:30 p.m. so we ate at the bar.  The bartender was very friendly and helpful.  However, the food was not impressive in the least.  I ordered the crab asparagus salad and the beet ravioli.  The salad came with no asparagus and mushy, fishy tasting crab that was more like canned tuna than anything else.  I only had two bites and hungrily looked forward to my main course.  When the beet ravioli came, it was missing the parmesan listed on the menu and looked soupy and full of gray vegetables.  But I dug in anyway.  My first bite of ravioli was, well, odd.  It was very doughy and chewy.  Another bite, and I thought maybe it was undercooked.  By the fourth bite, the raw flour taste came through clearly and I realized they were indeed raw.  Maybe they thought the hot broth would cook the ravioli, but it didn't.  I gave it back and they offered me a free dessert.  The cheese platter I received was fantastic, thank goodness.  So I filled up on bread and cheese.  My husband ordered the neighborhood menu and his food was fine.  He got the mozzarella and tomato salad, the pork chop and the creme caramel.  They were all fine, but nothing to get excited about.  In the end, although I really wanted to see this place do well and was excited about the Clementine connection - my meal sucked so bad I won't be back.
author: Catherine H.

description: My wife and I went there on our 24th wedding anniversary for no other reason than we had a $50 coupon that a friend had given us for our birthdays last October , 10 months earlier.  The atmosphere was phenomenal.  It really feels like a Parisian restaurant and I am not one to go  gah gah over everything and anything French.  While I mostly eat vegetarian I do on rare occasions break down and eat seafood.  I ordered the mussels and fries and they were superb.  The salad was also delicious and the bread perfect.  They only had one vegetarian entre on the menu and it was also delicious but perhaps a bit on the salty side.  Our waitress was absolutely charming and on finding out that it was our anniversary gave us a parting gift after which we all hugged.  It was a delightful evening and I would recommend the restaurant highly to anyone!
author: Joseph S.

description: Nice ambiance, good food, quiet romantic spot.  We sat at the bar and were able to order off the whole menu.   The bar tender was lovely and fun.  The artichoke salad was awesome.
author: S E.

description: I loved it.  Really cozy atmosphere.  We had seven people and it was still comfortable for us but definately make a reservation.  The host there was very friendly and helpful.  The food was really good and the prix fixe was such a value.  I am gonna go again.
author: A N.

description: This is a second visit.  The first was not a positive experience. We want to like the idea of authentic French bistro food within walking distance of our house, who wouldn't! Lots of people like this place, it's usually full. The meal for two was: oysters, followed by a crab and asparagus salad, then a bass served over potatoes and leeks, and a 'vegetarian' dish of beet ravioli.  The oysters were fine, then it went downhill from there. The crab was not any kind of crab I am used to, and had a mouth feel more like canned tuna fish, the asparagus was one limp stalk. The bass was mostly skin, although nicely browned and with a generous dollop of fresh herbs, it came across like a miserly portion, despite its presentation. The ravioli was just weird, two oversized, flat, grey doughy things stuffed with what we assume were beets.  So that's the deal here, looks like, sounds like, walks like authentic bistro but mon cher, believe me --  we can do better.
author: Mark P.

description: We are house sitting for friends who live nearby in Diamond Heights, and this was on their list of fave neighborhood spots, and are we ever glad we tried it!  We stopped in on a Tuesday night at around 7:30, without a reservation, hoping for the best.  Everyone was so sweet; although there was no table for us, we dined at the bar and were deliriously happy with the food.  And the value was amazing. The $21 prix fixe menu was tasty and satisfying, with a rose vin de provence was just right and complemented our meal.  We started with a perfectly seasoned creamy spinach-butter lettuce soup, in a chicken stock base that hit the spot on a cool evening.  Next we had prawns with a fennel puree in a rich yet light tomato sauce that was refined and oh so good.  Not to mention the bread with such a nice crispy crust.  Dessert was also outstanding; my date/husband had the warm apple tarte, and I had lemon sorbet drowning in vodka (le p'tit Laurent Colonel).  A great deal and a great meal.  It felt as if we were in a little town somewhere in provence. We'll be back again before we leave, and we're only here for 10 days!
author: Hollis B.

description: My friend and I stopped in to have a drink and ended up staying for dinner. The server was great and the mussels were perfectly paired with fries and a incredibly refreshing French Rose. The atmosphere was great. In fact, we ended up staying until way past closing without realizing it! The experience was fabulous!
author: Krishawna F.

description: It was cute; it was fun.  We were able to hear our neighbors' conversations in detail because Americans are LOUD!  In France it's ok to have tables close together because the French speak low.  But the food was excellent, especially the dessert, fondant chocolat.  Yum!  It melted in our mouths.  Lovely wines, merlot and sauvignon blanc.  A great evening.  Afterwards we walked up to Bird & Becket Bookstore and browsed around their unique selection.  Hooray for Glen Park!  Parking was easy at 5:30.  I lived in France for years so the wait staff didn't bother me.  They were nice but not American...
author: Bea Z.

description: after wanting to go here since they first opened their doors, we finally made it and le p'tit laurent did not disappoint!  the food was delicious - very rich and flavorful and excellently paired with the wine.  the atmosphere here reminds me of bistro jeanty in yountville - very cozy and warm and comfortable - not an ounce of pretence.  our waitress was adorable (particularly with her french accent), and very knowledgable and helpful as well.  we will definitely be back!
author: Erin C.

description: Great food, fun atmosphere.  Make a reservation- it's tiny and crowded.  Funny waitstaff- all very French.  Good price- only $120 for five people- appetizers, mains and a bottle of wine.  Will definitely go back.
author: Alex C.

description: Very authentic French bistro...decent although slightly overpriced.  Occasionally cold entrees probably because kitchen can not keep up with the crowd this restaurant brings.  Good bar.
author: Christine N.

description: Always an excellent value and quiet weeknight get away. I haven't worked my way through the entire menu but every experience (about 5) has been memorable and friendly.
author: Dennis M.

description: Our party of 5 were all very disappointed. Two of us had the cassoulet which had little flavor and tasted like it had been cooked that afternoon - which is not what a cassoulet should taste like. I had the Foie Gras for an app which did not taste fresh at all, I asssume it was defrosted. My son had the beef, which was swamped with too much sauce and it tasted like they had poured a whole bottle of liquor in it rather then flavoring with it. One had the lamb which she said was OK. The waitress was very nice and very helpful with the wine we brought in, but it was clear she was working way too many tables at once. All in all, there are much better french restaurants in SF and we won't be back.
author: LH N.

description: Out with old high school buddies last night (Monday) and we discovered that this place was very very reasonable price wise. We chose the prefixed menu which was somewhat relaxing for a dinner....knowing it all came together for you and all you have to do is just pick your food then 'wha-la... wait and enjoy the company of your fellow diners.  I highly recommend trying it out. Loved the coziness of the whole room...small and sweet!
author: CJ L.

description: I'd give it more than five stars if I could.  I discovered Le P'tit about a month after it opened in July 2007 and will tell you that it immediately became my favorite French restaurant in San Francisco.  When I'm in town, I eat there an average of twice a week.  For one thing you can't beat the three course prix fixe dinner for $19.95 (served from 5:30 PM until 7 PM) Monday through Thursday.  The entire menu is good -- but the weekly special is usually extraordinary.  Since they operate seven days per week, it's possible that their premier chef gets a night or two off -- which is the only thing I can imagine that would account for some of the negative reviews I've read.
author: Dianne B.

description: Pretty good food and a real cozy place. Cozy as in tiny but it's not too bad. The service is pretty good and they give you huge portions, especially for a French restaurant. The only criticism about this place is that their menu is pretty boring... i have been there 4 times and it is always the same. It would be nice if they could switch it up a bit. Its a great semi-formal place for a date, nice but, lets just say, you wouldn't propose to your girlfriend there.
author: Mark M.

description: Ca Super! This was a perfect example of "third time is a charm".  I had dropped by twice before and wasn't able to get a table but this time I made reservations a week in advance for "Tuesday Date Night".  We shared a meal of frisee salad (divine), cassoulet (piping and delicious), beet ravioli (very creative presentation) and tarte tatin (j'aime une tarte) and we devoured every bite.  My friend, a wonderful cook in her own right, was drenching her bread in the sauce and I wasn't sure that she wasn't going to pick up the plate and lick it too.  The only thing stopping her was that we were still on our first bottle of wine!  The reason I am not giving it 5 stars (like my friend did) is that it was hot & steamy inside and it was a cool SF evening.  A little too hot, as I had to take off layers of clothing and I am usually NOT to hot, if anything I am always cold.  So, if they get the temperature right, I'd give it 5!
author: V T.

description: Didn't particularly challenge my understanding of French cuisine, but well executed and delicious none the less.  Great, really great, service.  The neighborhood menu, offering a $21 prix fixe 3-course dinner  5:30-7 Su-Th, was outstanding.
author: Andrew G.

description: I haven't eaten here yet, but wanted to report that a new French restaurant has opened in Glen Park. It's great to see additional dining options in Glen Park.
author: Marina D.

description: Tried it on opening night was was mightily impressed, though we had to wait.  That's not unusual for a first night experience.  Lovely food, great wait staff and I look forward to going back for the neighborhood 3-course prix fixe.  Thanks for finally opening!!!
author: Anne M.

description: Super cute bistro, great service, and delicious food. I went here for their weekday prix-fixe special - 3 courses for $20. It's such a great deal and the food was terrific. I had a root vegetable soup, followed by roasted salmon entree, finished off by their chocolate pot de creme which was to die for. My date had the creme brulee, which was outstanding. I love this place!!
author: pas t.

description: I went here on a Sunday for my birthday because people recommended this place, and I was so happy that I went here. I made reservations and the owner called me back and confirmed it with a pleasant attitude. The restaurant had charm and was in a nice area with plenty of parking. They had a fix menu price of $22.00. With this you were able to pick a soup or salad and we both salad and it was great. Then you could pick chicken breast seasoned perfectly with nicely seasoned mash potatoes with a nice white sauce or pest mushroom raviolis with prawns. Then you could pick a dessert. My wife chose the creme brule' and I chose the chocolate cake with ice cream and caramel sauce. Everything was so perfect. The staff was pleasant and on top of it. They were there to pour water or get more bread before you could even think about needing more. The wine was good and I liked the atmosphere of the place. I recommend this place big time. For the quality of the french food and service, I would have to say this is a great bargain. I am recommended this place to everyone.
author: david b.

description: went again the other night and I swear it was the best yet...they have changed the mashed potato course to a carrot puree that was excellent with the rabbit...I can't order anything but the rabbit, since it is the best I've had in the city...salade duck confit was excellent, and the escargot perfect...reasonable wine list and full bar with nice neighborhood people watching too..still the best neighborhood restaurant

author: liv a.

description: food was delicious and we also had the best waitress i have possibly ever had- benedict. we took our 1 year old son out for 5.30 early dinner with his grandparents. it happened to be his 1st bday the next day. she was the most charming person with both my inlaws and son. we were all enchanted. she paid attention to every detail. the food was very good- delicious mussels & scallops. at the end of the meal, ice cream and a candle arrived at the table while Bene encouraged the entire packed restaurant to sing my son happy bday. as we were leaving, they actually GAVE my husband and i a congratulatory bottle of wine. amazing food and service.
author: Gillian P.

description: My husband and I wanted to try this local French restaurant which I walk by many times on my grocery shopping trips.  During the wait for our 8:30 reservation, our table was almost given away to another couple.  Fortunately, the people realized we were waiting and decided they would come back another time.  Then the hostess offered us seats at the bar to have a drink while we waited.  Fifteen minutes later, we were shown our table.  Altogether we had waited 30 minutes for our reservation.  At that point, another couple arrived and were seated at the table next to ours.  They had brought their own wine, and we noticed the waitress taking their order.  I thought that the waitress had realized her mistake, but promptly disappeared again.  When she finally arrived at our table, my husband politely pointed out that we had waited a long time for the table and couldn't help noticing that she had taken someone's orders before ours.  We were rudely told that they were on time for their reservation.  I told the waitress that not only were we on time but had to wait!  She turned to me and said that I was impolite and that if we knew where the door was, we should leave!!  So we did.  And we will never return.
author: Sharon M.
